Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Ardmore, Oklahoma" and may be so cited. 
Charter reference- Ordinances to be codified and published in book form at least every ten years, § 19. 
State Law reference- Revision of ordinances and publication thereof in book form, 11 O.S., 1961, §§ 579, 580, 583. 
Sec. 1-2. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-3. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the mayor and board of commissioners, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the mayor and board of commissioners: 
    Board of commissioners. Whenever the words "board of commissioners," "board," "this board," or "the board" are used, they shall mean the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Ardmore, in Carter County, Oklahoma. 
    Commissioner. The word "commissioner" shall mean a member of the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be excluded in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be included. 
    County. The words "county," "the county" or "this county" shall mean Carter County, Oklahoma. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed". 
    Officers, departments, etc. Whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title alone, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma". 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the word "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Roadway. The word "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The words "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Oklahoma. 
    Street. The term "street" shall include any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place, square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written or in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Sec. 1-4. - Code Enforcement; Penalties for Violations; Designation of Enforcement Officers; Issuance of Summons and Complaint; and Abatement. 
(a)  General penalties for Violations of Code; Continuing Violations. Whenever in this Code or, in any ordinance of the City, an act is prohibited, or is made or declared to be unlawful, or an offense, or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is said to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance for traffic-related offenses relating to speeding or parking shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) and costs. For all other offenses, the maximum fine shall not exceed seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) and costs. Provided, however, the City of Ardmore may not impose a penalty, including fine and cost, which is greater than that established by state statute for the same offense. Further provided that the City of Ardmore may not prosecute offenses declared by Oklahoma statute to be felony offenses. The maximum fine for violations of City of Ardmore Ordinances regulating the pretreatment of wastewater and regulating stormwater discharge shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and costs. Each separate violation of this Code, or of any ordinance, shall constitute a separate offense. The Municipal Judge may levy costs of up to the maximum allowed by state law for any violation of a municipal ordinance. 
(b)  Designation of Enforcement Officers. Police officers, animal control officers, city lake rangers, code enforcement officers and the City Building Official, hereinafter called "enforcement officers," as designated by the City Manager, are hereby authorized to enforce all provisions or ordinances dealing with buildings and building regulations, zoning, dilapidated vehicles, child care and day care centers, fire prevention, drainage and flood control, aviation, parks and recreation, swimming pools, water, sewers and sewage, signs, streets and alleys, sidewalks, subdivisions, peddlers, trees, weeds and grass, oil and gas wells, health and sanitation, housing code, litter, mobile homes, trailers, mobile home parks, junk, garbage and refuse, animals and fowl, and any general nuisances. 
(c)  Issuance of Summons and Complaint and Procedures. In carrying out such duties as designated by the City Manager, enforcement officers, as defined in subsection (b), may cite any person violating or attempting to violate the provisions and ordinances referenced in subsection (b) by issuing a summons and complaint. An enforcement officer may issue a summons and complaint to any violator or responsible person in charge of the premises where the violation takes place requiring them to appear in Municipal Court. In issuing such a summons and complaint, the enforcement officer shall proceed as follows: 
(1)  The enforcement officer shall prepare a written summons and complaint to appear in Municipal Court, containing the name and address of the cited person, the specific nature, location, and date of the alleged offense, the ordinance number that has been allegedly violated, and the time and date of the Municipal Court appearance. Unless the person cited requests an earlier date, the time specified in the summons and complaint to appear shall be at least seven (7) days after issuance. 
(2)  The summons and complaint and any copies thereof, shall be personally delivered to the cited person or mailed to the cited person by certified mail return receipt requested. 
(3)  The enforcement officer shall file one (1) copy of the citation with the Municipal Court Clerk within three (3) days after issuing or mailing the citation. 
(4)  Failure to appear in Municipal Court at the time specified in response to the summons and complaint shall result in a municipal warrant issued against the person cited and may result in an additional charge of Failure to Appear. 
No person shall interfere with, hinder, delay or obstruct in any manner whatsoever, an enforcement officer as defined in subsection (b) above, in the performance of his/her duties. 
(d)  Right of enforcement officers to enter premises. Subject to constitutional limitations, any enforcement officer, as defined in subsection (b), engaged in the discharge of his/her duties is authorized at all reasonable times, to enter and examine any building, structure, vehicle or premises for the purpose of making inspections thereof. Before entering a private vehicle or dwelling, the enforcement officer shall obtain the consent of the occupant thereof, or proceed with a police officer obtaining a court warrant authorizing entry for the purpose of inspection. 
    Enforcement officers authorized to enter and inspect buildings, structures, vehicles, and premises as herein set forth shall be identified by proper credentials issued by this jurisdiction. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use an official badge, uniform, or other credentials so as to impersonate an enforcement officer for the purpose of gaining access to any building, structure, vehicle or premises in this jurisdiction. 
    Any person violating or attempting to violate this section shall be guilty of an offense and punished as set out in subsection (a) of this section or, when appropriate, may be charged with a felony in District Court. 
(e)  Orders for abatement of nuisances associated with enforcement actions. The Municipal Judge of the City of Ardmore shall have the authority to order the abatement of any nuisance, illegal structure or construction, or any health or safety hazard which is a violation of City Code. Such abatement order shall be in addition to any other fines or penalties provided. The Municipal Judge shall also have the ability to direct the Building Official, Chief of Police or the City Manager to carry out an order for abatement of any violation, nuisance, illegal structure or health or safety hazard. 
(Ord. No. 1603, 1-31-69; Ord. No. 1694, § 1, 9-5-72; Ord. No. 2079, § 1, 9-7-82; Ord. No. 2127, § 1, 10-3-83; Ord. No. 2500, §§ 1, 2, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 2508, § I, 11-6-95; Ord. No. 2632, § I, 12-6-99; Ord. No. 2974 , § I, 9-8-15) 
Cross reference- Law enforcement officers training fund reimbursement, § 17-2; "offense" defined, § 19-2. 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the mayor and board of commissioners. 
    Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, is hereby amended to read as follows:..." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: 
"That the Code of Ordinances, City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which said section reads as follows:..." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the mayor and board of commissioners without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1959, § 10-5) 
Sec. 1-7. - Application of ordinances outside corporate limits. 
    All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby extended to all real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city outside the corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein, insofar as they are applicable. All ordinances of the city which shall go into effect in the future, shall also apply to, and be in full effect within the boundaries of all said outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable. The words "City of Ardmore" or other words in any ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance provision is limited to the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to mean and include also the said outlying real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 10-4) 
Sec. 1-8. - Membership in Oklahoma Municipal League. 
    The city is hereby authorized to procure the services of the Oklahoma Municipal League and to have membership therein, and to appropriate funds to pay for such services and membership. 
(Code 1959, § 10-6)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Wards established; boundaries. 
(a)  Established. The city is hereby divided into four (4) wards with boundaries as hereinafter described. 
(b)  Ward One. Ward One shall consist of that part of the incorporated area of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, lying north and west of the following boundary line description: beginning at the point of intersection of sections 21, 22, 27, 28 Township Four (4) South, Range One (1) East, Carter County, Oklahoma; thence extending easterly along said section line to the centerline of Interstate Highway I-35, thence extending southerly to the centerline of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, thence in an easterly direction to the centerline of North Rockford Road, thence in a northerly direction to the intersection of North Rockford Road and 4th Avenue N.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 4th Avenue N.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and Wolverton, thence in a northerly direction along the centerline of Wolverton N.W. to the intersection of 14th Avenue N.W. and Wolverton N.W., thence in an easterly direction to the intersection of Hargrove N.W., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Hargrove N.W. to the intersection of Hargrove N.W. and Monroe Avenue N.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of Monroe Avenue N.W. to the intersection of Monroe Avenue N.W. and North Washington Street, thence in a southerly direction to the intersection of North Washington Street and State Highway 199 (Sam Noble Parkway), thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of State Highway 199 (Sam Noble Parkway) to the intersection of Refinery Road ("D" St. N.E.); thence extending northerly along the North-South Section line of Sections 20, 17, and 8, Township Four (4) South, Range Two (2) East, Carter County, Oklahoma, to the city limits. 
(c)  Ward Two. Ward Two shall consist of that part of the incorporated area of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma; the north and west boundaries are described as follows: beginning at the point of intersection of "E" Street S.W. and 3rd Avenue S.W. and extending northerly along the centerline of "E" Street S.W. and "E" Street N.W. to the Intersection of "E" Street N.W. and 4th Avenue N.W.; thence in a westerly direction to the intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and Wolverton N.W., thence in a northerly direction along the centerline of Wolverton N.W. to the intersection of 14th Avenue N.W. and Wolverton N.W., thence in an easterly direction to the intersection of Hargrove N.W., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Hargrove N.W. to the intersection of Hargrove N.W. and Monroe Avenue N.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of Monroe Avenue N.W. to the intersection of Monroe Avenue N.W. and North Washington Street, thence in a southerly direction to the intersection of North Washington Street and State Highway 199 (Sam Noble Parkway), thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of State Highway 99 (Sam Noble Parkway) to the intersection of Refinery Road ("D" St. N.E.); thence extending northerly along the North-South Section line of Sections 20, 17, and 8, Township Four (4) South, Range Two (2) East, Carter County, Oklahoma, to the city limits. The south boundary line is described as follows: beginning at the point of intersection of "E" Street S.W. and 3rd Avenue S.W., and extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue S.W. to the intersection of 3rd Avenue S.W. and "D" Street S.W., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of "D" Street S.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue S.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 4th Avenue S.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue S.W. and "A" Street S.W., thence in a northerly direction along the centerline of "A" Street S.W. to the intersection of "A" Street S.W. and 3rd Avenue S.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue S.W., over the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad to 2nd Avenue S.E., extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 2nd Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 2nd Avenue S.E. and Park Street S.E., thence extending in a northerly direction along the centerline of Park Street S.E. to the intersection of Park Street S.E. and White Street S.E., thence extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of White Street S.E. to the intersection of White Street S.E. and "P" Street S.E., extending in a northerly direction along the centerline of "P" Street to the intersection of "P" Street N.E. and 3rd Avenue N.E., thence extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue N.E. to the southeast corner of the S.W., S.E., S.W. of Section 26, Township Four (4) South, Range Two (2) East, or to the city limits. 
(d)  Ward Three. Ward Three shall consist of that part of the incorporated area of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, lying south and west of the following boundary line description: beginning at the point of intersection of section 21, 22, 27, and 28 Township Four (4) South, Range One (1) East, Carter County, Oklahoma; thence extending easterly along said section line to the centerline of Interstate Highway I-35, thence extending southerly to the centerline of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of the Burlington North/Santa Fe Railroad to the centerline of North Rockford Road, thence in a northerly direction to the intersection of North Rockford Road and 4th Avenue N.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 4th Avenue N.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and U. S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street), thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of U. S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street) to the intersection of U. S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street) and the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, to the intersection of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad and 10th Avenue S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 10th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 10th Avenue S.E. and Hugo Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Hugo Street S.E. to the intersection of Hugo Street S.E. and 11th Avenue S.E., thence in a westerly direction along the centerline of 11th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 11th Avenue S.E. and Potter Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Potter Street S.E. to the intersection of Potter Street S.E. and 12th Avenue S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 12th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 12th Avenue S.E. and "A" Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of "A" Street S.E. to the intersection of "A" Street S.E. and Anderson Street S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of Anderson Street S.E. to the intersection of Anderson Street S.E. and Carter Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Carter Street S.E. to the city limits. 
(e)  Ward Four. Ward Four shall consist of that part of the incorporated area of the city of Ardmore, Oklahoma, lying south and east of the following boundary line description: beginning at the intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and U. S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street); thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of U.S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street) to the intersection of U.S. Highway 77 (Commerce Street) and the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad, to the intersection of the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad and 10th Avenue S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 10th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 10th Avenue S.E. and Hugo Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Hugo Street S.E. to the intersection of Hugo Street S.E. and 11th Avenue S.E., thence in a westerly direction along the centerline of 11th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 11th Avenue S.E. and Potter Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Potter Street S.E. to the intersection of Potter Street S.E. and 12th Avenue S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 12th Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 12th Avenue S.E. and "A" Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of "A" Street S.E. and Anderson Street S.E., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of Anderson Street S.E. to the intersection of Anderson Street S.E. and Carter Street S.E., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of Carter Street S.E. to the city limits. The north boundary is as follows: beginning at the point of intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and U.S. Highway 77 (Commerce); thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 4th Avenue N.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue N.W. and "E" Street N.W., thence extending in a southerly direction along the centerline of "E" Street to the intersection of "E" Street S.W. and 3rd Avenue S.W., thence extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue S.W. to the intersection of 3rd Avenue S.W. and "D" Street S.W., thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of "D" Street S.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue S.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 4th Avenue S.W. to the intersection of 4th Avenue S.W. and "A" Street S.W., thence in a northerly direction along the centerline of "A" Street S.W. to the intersection of "A" Street S.W. and 3rd Avenue S.W., thence in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue S.W., over the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad to 2nd Avenue S.E., extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 2nd Avenue S.E. to the intersection of 2nd Avenue S.E. and Park Street S.E., thence extending in a northerly direction along the centerline of Park Street S.E. to the intersection of Park Street S.E. and White Street S.E., thence extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of White Street S.E. to the intersection of White Street S.E. and "P" Street S.E., extending in a northerly direction along the centerline of "P" Street to the intersection of "P" Street N.E. and 3rd Avenue N.E., thence extending in an easterly direction along the centerline of 3rd Avenue N.E. to the southeast corner of the S.W., S.E., S.W. of Section 26, Township Four (4) South, Range Two (2) East, or to the city limits. 
(Code 1959, § 20-1; Ord. No. 1566, § 2, 8-15-67; Ord. No. 1650, 10-5-70; Ord. No. 2562, 9-15-97) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to designate ward boundaries, § 4. 
State Law reference- Authority to divide city into not less than four (4) wards and establish the boundaries there, 11 O.S. 1961, § 642. 
Sec. 2-2. - Board of commissioners-Meetings; when held. 
    The board of commissioners shall hold a regular meeting at 7:00 p.m. on Monday, July 1, 1969, and Monday, July 21, 1969, and on the first and third Monday of every month thereafter; provided that, should the first or third Monday be on a legal holiday of the city, the city commission shall set another meeting date which does not fall on a holiday. 
(Code 1959, § 1-1; Ord. No. 1614, §§ 1, 2, 6-16-69; Ord. No. 2099, § 1, 2-22-83) 
Charter reference- Commission created, qualifications and number of members, § 4; compensation of members, § 6; powers enumerated, § 7; meetings, § 10. 
Sec. 2-3. - Same-Place of meetings. 
    Every meeting of the board of commissioners shall be held in the commission chamber in the city hall, unless, in the case of an emergency, the mayor or the commissioners calling a special meeting, designate another place in the city for the holding of the special meeting; provided that an adjourned meeting may be held at any place within the city designated by the commission. 
(Code 1959, § 1-2) 
Sec. 2-3.1. - Attendance at meetings by board, council, commission members; report; failure to attend. 
(a)  All appointed members of city boards, councils and commissions shall attend at least fifty (50) per cent of the regular meetings of any respective boards, councils and commissions to which they are appointed. 
(b)  The chairman of the various boards, councils and commissions of the city shall report to the mayor on a semi-annual basis, the attendance records of the various members of their respective boards, councils and commissions. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meetings of that particular board, council and commission during the past six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2052, § 1(1), (2), 2-1-82) 
Sec. 2-3.2. - Terms of office for appointed members of city boards, councils, commissions, etc. 
    All appointed members of city advisory and recommending boards, councils and commissions and the members of the Ardmore Development Authority, the Library Board and the Hardy Murphy Coliseum Trust Authority shall not serve longer than six (6) continuous years or two (2) consecutive terms, whichever is longer. Time spent completing an unexpired term shall not count toward this limitation on service. 
(Ord. No. 2266, § 2, 7-20-87) 
Sec. 2-4. - City manager; to be chief administrative officer; duties generally. 
(a)  The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the city. He shall have all powers and duties prescribed for him by section 22 of the city charter, by other provisions of the charter, and by ordinance. 
(b)  The city manager shall sign all warrants drawn on the city treasurer for the disbursement of city funds. 
(Code 1959, § 1-3) 
Charter reference- Appointment, term, qualifications, removal of city manager, § 20; powers and duties, § 22. 
Cross reference- Duties relative to city purchases and sales, § 2-60 et seq.; to be ex officio member of Downtown Airport Commission, § 3-26; appointment of building inspector, § 6-4; to supervise the sale of cemetery lots, § 7-9; approval of cemetery monument plans, § 7-16; appointment of civil defense director, § 8-2; to be executive head of civil defense organization, § 8-3; appointment of fire chief, § 10-36; supervision of health department, § 13-2; appointment of housing inspector, § 14-2; duties relative to receiving notice of public nuisance, § 18-4; bond, § 20-3; to be ex officio member of planning commission, § 22-5(e); appointment of chief plumbing inspector, § 23-4; appointment of chief of police, § 24-2; inspection of utility poles, wires and cables, § 30-71. 
Sec. 2-5. - Assistant city manager; appointment, compensation, duties. 
(a)  Appointment. The city manager, with the consent of the board of commissioners, may appoint an assistant to the city manager who shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(b)  Duties. The assistant to the city manager shall assist the city manager in the performance of his duties and shall perform such other duties as the city manager shall prescribe. 
Sec. 2-5.1. - Acting city manager. 
(a)  Assistant city manager as acting city manager. As provided by section 21 of Ardmore Charter 1959, in absence from the city of the city manager, or if the city manager is unable to perform his duties, or if the city manager is suspended by the city commission, or if there is a vacancy in the office of the city manager, the assistant to the city manager shall be the acting city manager until such time as such city manager is available to perform his duties. 
(b)  City clerk as acting city manager. In absence of both the city manager and the assistant to the city manager, or if both are unable to perform their respective duties, then the city clerk of the City of Ardmore is hereby appointed as the acting city manager until such time as the city manager is available to perform his duties. 
(c)  Designation by city commission. Nothing herein contained shall be construed as any limitation on the powers of the city commission to appoint or designate an acting city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1579, §§ 1-3, 5-6-68) 
Editor's note- Section 2-5.1 is derived from Ord. No. 1579, §§ 1-3. This ordinance, nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as said section in the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 2-6. - Department of finance; city clerk to head. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled department of finance, the head of which shall be the city clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Charter reference- Department of finance created, § 23; city clerk to head department of finance, § 25. 
Cross reference- Taxation generally, Ch. 27. 
Sec. 2-7. - City clerk-Appointment; term. 
    The city clerk shall be appointed by the city manager with approval of the board of commissioners for an indefinite term, as provided in section 25 of the Charter. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Charter reference- For provisions as to city clerk, see § 25. 
Cross reference- Duties relative to alcoholic beverage occupational tax, § 4-20; issuance of dog licenses, § 5-26; bond, § 20-3; issuance of hunting and boating permits, § 21-16. 
Sec. 2-8. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The city clerk shall have such powers, duties and functions as may be provided by the Charter, by applicable law or by ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Charter reference- Duties of city clerk enumerated, § 25. 
Sec. 2-9. - Same-Duty to attest warrants drawn for the disbursement of city funds. 
    The city clerk shall attest warrants drawn by the city manager upon the city treasurer for the disbursement of city funds. 
(Code 1959, § 1-5) 
Sec. 2-10. - Same-Duties relative to election ballots. 
    The city clerk shall receive the statements of candidacy properly filed by candidates for the offices of commissioners and members of the board of education, as provided by sections 35 and 49 of the Charter. The city clerk shall arrange the names of the candidates for each office alphabetically on the ballots, and shall have the ballots printed and properly delivered to the election officials. The names of candidates for members of the board of education shall be printed on separate ballots. 
(Code 1959, § 1-6) 
Charter reference- Candidates to file with city clerk, § 35; candidates for board of education to file with city clerk, § 49. 
Sec. 2-10.1. - Same-Execute all release of liens. 
    The board of commissioners of the city, specifically designates and authorizes the city clerk to execute all release of liens required to release of record any and all liens held by the city, without the necessity of the release of lien being authorized by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § 1, 1-4-99) 
Sec. 2-11. - City treasurer-Appointment, term. 
    There shall be a city treasurer, who shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, as provided by section 26 of the Charter. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Charter reference- Office created, duties, § 26. 
Cross reference- Bond of city treasurer, § 20-3; duties relative to Employee Retirement System, § 20-32. 
Sec. 2-12. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The city treasurer shall have such powers, duties and functions as may be provided by the Charter, by applicable law or by ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Charter reference- Duties of treasurer enumerated, § 26. 
Sec. 2-13. - Department of law; city attorney to head. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled department of law, the head of which shall be the city attorney. 
(Code 1959, § 1-24) 
Charter reference- Department of law established, § 23. 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 2-14. - City attorney-Appointment. 
    The city manager shall appoint the city attorney with the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1959, § 1-24) 
Sec. 2-15. - Same-Duties. 
    The city attorney shall be the chief legal adviser of the board of commissioners, all officers, departments and agencies of the city government in matters relating to their official powers and duties. He shall represent the city in all legal proceedings. He shall perform all services incident to his position which may be required by law, the charter or ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 1-25) 
Cross reference- City attorney to be ex officio member of Downtown Airport Commission, § 3-26. 
Sec. 2-15.1. - City prosecutor; office created; appointment; qualifications; duties. 
    There is hereby created the office of city prosecutor, said prosecutor to be appointed by the city manager with the consent of the board of commissioners. The city prosecutor shall be a member in good standing of the Oklahoma Bar Association and shall be admitted to practice before the highest court in the state. The duties of the city prosecutor shall include the prosecution of all cases involving the violation of any section of this code, of the charter, or of any other city ordinance and such other duties as the board may prescribe by ordinance or resolution. 
Sec. 2-16. - Engineering department-Established; city engineer to head. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled engineering department, the head of which shall be the city engineer. The city manager shall appoint the city engineer with the approval of the board of commissioners. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the city engineer shall have supervision and control of the engineering department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-26) 
Cross reference- City engineer to be ex officio member of city planning commission, § 22-5(e); streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25; inspection, enforcement and supervision of all street excavations, § 25-23 et seq.; issuance of permit for digging water wells, § 30-35. 
Sec. 2-17. - Same-Duties. 
    The engineering department shall make all needed plans and specifications for paving, sewers, water facilities and all other engineering construction for the city, and shall supervise all such construction and work, regardless of whether it is being done by contract or by city personnel; provided that an engineer other than the regular city engineer may be appointed for a particular project. The city manager shall have power by executive order to regulate the relationship between the engineering department and other departments, agencies and offices of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 1-27) 
Sec. 2-18. - Department of industrial development-Established; director to head. 
    There is hereby created and established a department of industrial development of the city the head of which said department shall be the director of industrial development. 
(Ord. No. 1507, § 1, 5-17-65) 
Sec. 2-19. - Same-City manager to appoint director. 
    The city manager shall appoint the director of industrial development with the approval of the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1507, § 2, 5-17-65) 
Sec. 2-20. - Same-Authority of city manager to appoint industrial director of development authority as industrial director of city. 
    The city manager may elect to appoint the industrial director of the Ardmore Development Authority as industrial director of the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 1507, § 3, 5-17-65; Ord. No. 1989, § 1, 6-16-80) 
Sec. 2-21. - Same-Duties of director. 
    The duties of said director of industrial development shall include, but not be necessarily limited to, the following: 
(a)  Maintain close liaison with the state and federal agencies to promote and to secure the industrial development of the Ardmore Industrial Airpark of the city. 
(b)  To assist present industries located at the Ardmore Industrial Airpark in growth and development. 
(c)  To make personal contacts with proposed industry in an effort to secure the location of said industries for the city. 
(d)  To maintain close liaison with the Ardmore Industrial Development Corporation, the Ardmore Development Authority, the Chamber of Commerce and other interested organizations and individuals in promoting the industrial growth. 
(Ord. No. 1507, § 4, 5-17-65) 
Cross reference- Airport generally, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 2-21.1. - Development authority-Composition. 
    The Ardmore Development Authority is an express public trust created for the use and benefit of the City of Ardmore with the City of Ardmore named as the sole beneficiary in the trust indenture creating the authority. The Ardmore Development Authority consists of nine (9) members designated trustees, all as set forth in the trust indenture, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.2. - Same-Appointment of trustees. 
    The board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, according to the trust indenture shall appoint the trustees to the Ardmore Development Authority. All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular meeting of the board of commissioners each December. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.3. - Same-Term of trustees. 
    The trustees of the Ardmore Development Authority shall serve a term of three (3) years as provided in said trust indenture, as amended. No trustees shall be appointed to more than two (2) successive full terms. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.4. - Same-General duties. 
    The Ardmore Development Authority shall promote and secure industrial development, including the development of industrial park property, assist the present industries in growth development and make contact with proposed industries in an effort to secure the location of said industries for the City of Ardmore and to maintain close liaison with all interested organizations and individuals in promoting the industrial growth of the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.5. - Same-Compensation of trustees. 
    The trustees of the Ardmore Development Authority shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.6. - Same-Director and staff. 
    There shall be a professional director and staff appointed by the Ardmore Development Authority. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-21.7. - Same-Budget. 
(a)  Immediately prior to the first Monday in April of each year, the Ardmore Development Authority shall submit to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore a budget which shall include the necessary expenses for operation of the Ardmore Development Authority for the ensuing year. The mayor and city commission may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portions of such budget as are not defrayed from the income realized from the authority from other sources. 
(b)  Any organization contributing more than fifteen (15) per cent of the budget for the Ardmore Development Authority may submit to the mayor a list of qualified persons for the mayor's consideration when making the annual appointments to the Ardmore Development Authority Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-22. - Library board; established, gifts, bequests to vest in city. 
(a)  There shall be a library board as provided by section 24 of the Charter. 
(b)  The titles of all property (real and personal) given or bequeathed for the benefit of the public libraries, shall be vested in the city, but all such property shall be under the administrative supervision and control of the library board. 
(Code 1959, § 1-41) 
Charter reference- Library board generally, § 24. 
Cross reference- Issuance of public library bonds, App. B. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to appoint library board, 65 O.S. 1961, § 72. 
Sec. 2-23. - Street division-Street superintendent to supervise. 
    There shall be an administrative division entitled street division, the head of which shall be the street superintendent. Subject to supervision and control by the public works director, the street superintendent shall have supervision and control of the street division. 
(Code 1959, § 1-28; Ord. No. 2733, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 2-24. - Same-Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the street department, among others, to construct, repair, maintain and improve streets, alleys and other public ways; provided that the city manager or the board of commissioners may place particular projects relating hereto under the engineering department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-29) 
Sec. 2-25. - Public utilities department-Department director to supervise; appointment, duties of department director. 
(a)  There is hereby created the department of public utilities of the City of Ardmore. 
(b)  The head of the department of public utilities shall be the public utilities director. The city manager shall appoint the public utilities director, with the approval of the board of commissioners, who shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the department head shall have supervision and control of the department. 
(c)  The director of public utilities shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  He shall have supervision and control of the water utility. 
(2)  He shall have supervision and control of the wastewater utility. 
(3)  He shall have supervision and control of the sanitation utility. 
(4)  The department director shall, in addition to the above outlined duties, perform such other duties as are delegated to him by the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 1-30; Ord. No. 2733, § 2, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 2-26. - Technical services division-Division head to supervise; appointment of division head. 
(a)  There shall be an administrative division entitled technical services. Subject to supervision and control by the public works director, the technical service division head shall have supervision and control of the division. 
(b)  The technical services division head will perform the following duties: 
(1)  Repair and maintenance of all city owned facilities and telephone systems; 
(2)  Repair and maintenance of traffic signals, street signs and painting and upkeep on all city streets and crosswalks; 
(3)  Perform such other duties as delegated to him by the public works director or city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 1-31; Ord. No. 2733, § 3, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 2-27. - Parks and recreation department-Department director to supervise; appointment, duties of department director. 
(a)  There shall be an administrative department entitled park and recreation department, the head of which shall be the park and recreation director. The city manager shall appoint the park and recreation director with the approval of the board of commissioners who shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the park and recreation director shall have supervision and control of the parks and recreation department. 
(b)  The parks and recreation director shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Repair, maintain and improve all parks, playgrounds, swimming pools and other recreation facilities belonging to, or under the control of the city. 
(2)  Repair, maintain and improve all city cemeteries. 
(3)  Mow street medians and assigned rights-of-way and/or supervise private contractors. 
(Code 1959, § 1-32; Ord. No. 2733, § 4, 3-3-03) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation generally, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 2-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2733, § 5, adopted March 3, 2003, repealed § 2-28, which pertained to park and cemetery department-duties and derived from § 1-33 of the 1959 Code. 
Sec. 2-29. - Airport department-Superintendent to supervise; appointment of superintendent. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled airport department, the head of which shall be the airport superintendent. The city manager shall appoint the airport superintendent with the approval of the board of commissioners. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the airport superintendent shall have supervision and control of the airport department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-34) 
Cross reference- Airports generally, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 2-30. - Same-Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the airport department to have charge of, control, operate, repair, maintain and improve the airports and all other aviation facilities under the control of the city; and also to enforce and administer all airport or aviation regulations of the city, and insofar as it may be appropriate, of the federal and state governments. 
(Code 1959, § 1-35) 
Sec. 2-31. - Sanitation department-Superintendent to supervise; appointment of superintendent. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled sanitation department, the head of which shall be the superintendent of the sanitation department. The city manager shall appoint the superintendent with the approval of the board of commissioners. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the superintendent shall have supervision and control of the sanitation department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-36) 
Cross reference- Garbage and refuse, Ch. 11; health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 2-32. - Same-Duties. 
    The sanitation department shall collect and dispose of garbage and other refuse as provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 1-37) 
Sec. 2-33. - Garage division-Division head to supervise; appointment of division head. 
    There shall be an administrative division entitled the garage division, the head of which shall be the garage superintendent. 
Subject to supervision and control by the public works director, the garage division head shall have supervision and control of the garage. 
(Code 1959, § 1-38; Ord. No. 2733, § 6, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 2-34. - Vehicle maintenance department-Duties. 
    The vehicle maintenance department shall repair and maintain all vehicles of the city government except in those cases where the repair and maintenance of such vehicles is performed by others in accordance with the policies of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1959, § 1-39) 
Sec. 2-35. - Department of public construction; established; city manager to supervise; duties. 
    There is hereby created and established a department of public construction, the head of which shall be the city manager, who is authorized to appoint one or more assistants. The department, with the assistance of the city engineering department, shall, under the supervision and direction of the city manager, construct such public works and projects as the city commission may from time to time direct. Such public works and projects may be constructed by the labor force of the city. Such works and projects shall be limited to those for which a general bond issue has been authorized at an election held for that purpose in the city. The purchase of all material or supplies used in connection with such works or projects shall be purchased upon a sealed bid basis by the city manager in the manner prescribed by ordinance for the purchase of supplies, material and equipment. Nothing herein shall prevent the city manager from purchasing such material or supplies on the open market if, in the discretion of the city manager, such purchases shall be for less than the lowest acceptable bid submitted. 
    During such time as the city labor force is engaged in the construction of such works or projects, all salaries and wages, except that of the city manager and the city engineer, shall be paid out of monies received from said bond issue as the work upon said project is completed or as salaries and wages hereunder may become due and payable. Such salaries and wages shall be paid upon a duly verified claim being presented by such employee to the city clerk of said city in the manner now being followed for the payment of regular claims against the city. 
    Upon completion of such works or projects as aforesaid, the wages and salaries of said city labor force shall immediately terminate, and such wages and salaries shall thereafter be paid from the general funds of said city. 
(Code 1959, § 1-40) 
Sec. 2-36. - Department of public works; established; appointment, duties of department head. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Department of Public Works of the City of Ardmore. 
(b)  The head of the department of public works shall be the superintendent of public works who shall be appointed by the city manager with the approval of the board of commissioners and shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(c)  The superintendent of public works shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  He shall have general supervision and control of the garage division. 
(2)  He shall have supervision of and responsibility for the maintenance of the pavement of streets and alleys and supervision of sidewalk inspection and supervision and maintenance of all of the public improvements. 
(3)  He shall have supervision and direction of the streets, pertaining to repairs, maintenance and cleaning of same. 
(4)  He shall have general supervision and control of the technical services division. 
(5)  The superintendent shall, in addition to the above outlined duties, perform such other duties as are delegated to him by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2733, § 7, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 2-37. - City commissioner declaration of candidacy. 
    A declaration of candidacy for the office of city commissioner of the City of Ardmore must be accompanied by a petition supporting the candidate's filing signed by ten (10) per cent of the registered voters who voted in the last City of Ardmore general election in which two (2) or more candidates ran for the office of city commissioner as reflected in the records of the Carter County Election Board office or by a cashier's check or certified check in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) payable to the City of Ardmore. 
    A candidate's filing fee shall be returned to the candidate if the candidate is unopposed in the primary election or receives more than thirty (30) per cent of the votes cast for the office for which the candidate's name appeared on the ballot. 
(Ord. No. 2873, § 1, 7-7-08) 
Secs. 2-38-2-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Warrants to be drawn for the disbursement of city funds, § 2-9. 

Sec. 2-46. - To be verified, in writing; contents. 
    All claims against the city must be presented in writing, with a full account of the items, and verified by the oath of the claimant, or his agent, that the same is correct, reasonable and just, and that there are no credits or off-sets thereto except as may be shown thereon. Such claims shall show in detail the amount due on each item, the date thereof, the purpose for which each item was expended, and such other facts as are necessary to show the legality of such claims and each item thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6-16) 
Sec. 2-47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2511, § I, adopted December 18, 1995, repealed § 2-47, Formerly such section pertained to board of commissioners to consider and derived from § 6-17 of the 1959 Code. 
Sec. 2-48. - Officers to be liable for payment claims before board approval. 
    Any officer or agent of the city who shall knowingly, willfully and intentionally pay, or allow payment of any claim against said city before the same has been duly allowed by the city manager or his designee, shall be liable, together with his bondsmen, for all money of the city so expended, paid, or encumbered, together with interest thereon from the date of such expenditure, payment, or encumbrance at the rate of six (6) per cent per annum. 
(Code 1959, § 6-18; Ord. No. 2511, § II, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 2-49. - Provisions not applicable to personal service. 
    No part of this article shall apply to the payments for personal service, namely salaries and wages. 
(Code 1959, § 6-19) 
Secs. 2-50-2-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY PURCHASES AND SALES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Purchases and sales, § 27; sale of property valued at more than $50,000.00, § 28; contracts for public improvements, § 29. 

Sec. 2-60. - City manager authorized to make purchases up to twenty-five thousand dollars. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to contract for and to purchase or issue purchase authorizations for all supplies, materials and equipment for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government where such supplies, materials and equipment do not exceed the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). 
    (Code 1959, § 6-20; Ord. No. 1950, § 2, 9-4-79; Ord. No. 2602, § 1, 2-16-99; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Sec. 2-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1950, § 1, enacted Sept. 4, 1979, repealed, § 2-61, relative to purchases of $1,000.00 to $2,500.00, derived from Code 1959, § 6-21. 
Sec. 2-62. - Purchases and sales over twenty-five thousand dollars; Bids required. 
    Where any contract for the purchase of, or the issuance of purchase authorizations for supplies, materials and equipment for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government exceeds the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), such shall not become a binding obligation of the city nor shall such be approved until approved by a majority vote of the city commission. Except as provided in section 2-65 of this Code before the purchase of, or the contract for, any supplies, materials or equipment, or the sale of any surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment, the value of which exceeds the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), ample opportunity for competitive bidding shall be given; and the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best responsible bidder in the case of purchases and in the case of sales to the highest and best responsible bidder; provided that the city manager may reject all bids and in the case of purchases may buy in the open market at a price less than the lowest bid received from a responsible bidder; and provided further that, if no bids be received, the city manager may buy in the open market. 
(Code 1959, § 6-22; Ord. No. 2603, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Sec. 2-63. - Contractual services-Defined. 
    "Contractual services" shall mean services to be provided as described within a contract. 
(Code 1959, § 6-23; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Sec. 2-64. - Same-City authorized to purchase. 
    Contractual services may be contracted for and purchased in the same manner as supplies, materials and equipment are authorized to be contracted for and purchased. 
(Code 1959, § 6-23; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Sec. 2-65. - Competitive bidding not required for certain purchases. 
    The following may be purchased without giving an opportunity for competitive bidding: 
a.  Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services whose cost does not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in a single transaction for total price of one type of item, not cost per unit. 
b.  Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services purchased from another unit of government at a price determined to be below the price obtainable from a private seller, including government surplus. 
c.  Materials, supplies, equipment, or services may be purchased without obtaining quotes or bids where purchased through an interstate/interlocal purchasing agreement entered into between the city or its trusts and the interstate purchasing co-operative. This division (B)(8)(c) shall not apply to "Public Construction Contracts" as defined in the Oklahoma Public Competitive Bidding Act of 1974, (61 O.S. §§ 101 et. seq.) 
d.  Contractual services (gas, electricity, telephone service, etc.) purchased from a public utility corporation at a price or rate determined by the state corporation commission or other governmental authority. 
e.  Contractual services of a professional nature, such as engineering, architectural, legal, accounting, medical, laboratory testing or other such professional or skilled services which, in keeping with the standards of their discipline, will not enter into a competitive bidding process. The department head will make a recommendation to the city manager regarding the need to submit requests for proposals (RFP to various vendors. If the city manager determines it necessary, a request for proposal (RFP) will be prepared. The request for proposal (RFP) shall include scope of work, specifications, requirements and minimum standards for the services to be provided. When an RFP for professional services is approved, a limited number of qualified professionals known to the city will be invited to submit a proposal setting forth their interest, qualifications, and an explanation of how they can meet the city's needs. In securing professional services, it is the primary goal of the City to obtain the services of a professional who has a proven record of providing required services in a professional way. A contract will be negotiated with the professional deemed to best meet the city's needs and requirements. 
f.  Used supplies, materials or equipment when price is of prime importance and the difference in cost between new and used is significant, where equipment will be used infrequently, for a limited time, for training or auxiliary operations, or when better delivery is essential. Purchases of used equipment requires careful shopping and the requisitioning department should make every effort to secure a minimum warranty or guarantee that the equipment will perform as needed and that service or replacement parts are readily available. 
g.  It is recognized that certain supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services may only be procured from sole source vendors or may have a uniform price wherever purchased. (i.e. maintenance on city computers or other office equipment). Therefore when it is determined in writing by the department head that the supplies or contractual services cannot be competitively bid due to sole source availability, the supplies or contractual services may be procured with following the normal bidding procedures. Such documentation shall be forwarded with a purchase requisition, which includes a request for encumbering funds and a sole source affidavit (signed by department head) to the finance department. A sole source letter from the manufacturer or distributor should also be obtained. The finance department must approve all sole source requisitions prior to purchase. 
h.  The city manager shall approve all purchases of used supplies, equipment or materials that do not exceed twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in cost. 
(Code 1959, § 6-24; Ord. No. 2603, § 2, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 2695, § 1, 11-5-01; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Sec. 2-66. - Emergencies. 
    The provisions of this article with reference to competitive bidding shall not apply when the board of commissioners declares by a four-fifths ( 4/5 ths) vote of all of the members thereof that an emergency exists. 
    "Emergency" as used in this section shall be limited to conditions resulting from a sudden unexpected happening or unforeseen occurrence or condition and situation wherein the public health or safety is endangered. 
    The reasons for declaring an emergency and not complying with the provisions of this article relating to competitive bidding shall be entered into the official minutes of the Board of Commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 1845, § 1, 2-21-77; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1845, § 1, amended this Code by adding provisions designated as § 2-65, which provisions the editors redesignated § 2-66 inasmuch as the Code already contained a § 2-65. 
Sec. 2-67. - Authorization for payments. 
    The board of commissioners of the city does hereby authorize the city manager or his designee to approve payment of any claims or invoices for supplies, materials or equipment submitted to the city for payment. The city manager shall establish an internal control structure adequate to provide reasonable assurance against the unauthorized or illegal payment of invoices. Such system of internal control should include the following control procedures: 
(1)  Proper authorization of transactions and activities; 
(2)  Adequate segregation of duties; 
(3)  Adequate documents and records; 
(4)  Adequate safeguards over access to and use of assets and records; and 
(5)  Independent checks on performance. 
(6)  Identification and recording of all valid transactions; 
(7)  Description on a timely basis of the type of transaction in sufficient detail to permit proper classification of the transaction for financial reporting; 
(8)  Measurement of the transaction's value in a manner that permits recording of its monetary value in the financial statements; 
(9)  Determination of the time period in which the transaction occurred to permit recording of the transaction in the proper accounting period; 
(10)  Proper presentation of the transaction and related disclosures in financial statements. 
(Ord. No. 2511, § III, 12-18-95; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 7-16-18 ) 
Secs. 2-68-2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CITIZENS' ADVISORY COMMITTEE BOARD 

Sec. 2-71. - Created. 
    There is hereby established within the city a board which shall be known as the community development citizens' advisory committee board. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-72. - Composition. 
    The community development citizens advisory committee board shall consist of eight (8) members who shall be citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-73. - Appointment, term of members. 
    The board shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of the city commission. All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular commission meeting each May. The members of the board shall serve a term of three (3) years; provided, however, that on the first board two (2) members shall serve one (1) year, three (3) members shall serve two (2) years and three (3) members shall serve three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2257, § 1, 6-15-87) 
Sec. 2-74. - Ex officio member. 
    The mayor may, with the approval of a majority of the commission, appoint a member of the city commission to serve as an ex officio member of the community development citizens advisory committee board. Said ex officio member shall serve for a period of one (1) year beginning May 1st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-75. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor by and with the consent of the city commission may remove any member at any time. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-76. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the community development citizens advisory committee board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-77. - Organization. 
    There shall be a president, vice-president and secretary of the community development citizens advisory committee board, selected from the members of the board, elected by the board, and at its pleasure removed. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-78. - Rules. 
    The community development citizens advisory committee board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the government of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-79. - Record of proceedings. 
    The community development citizens advisory committee board shall keep and preserve a true record of all its proceedings and official acts, and said record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-80. - Report to city commission. 
    The community development citizens advisory committee board shall on or before the second Monday of April each year, make report to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-81. - Budget. 
    Immediately prior to the first Monday of April each year, the community development citizens advisory committee board shall prepare and submit to the city commission a budget which shall include the necessary expenses for operation of the community development citizens advisory committee for the ensuing fiscal year. The mayor and city commission may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portion of such budget as is not defrayed from the income from other sources. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-82. - Attendance of meetings. 
    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on a semiannual basis, the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meetings during the six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-83. - Board meetings. 
    All meetings of the board shall be public and on or before the fifteenth day of December of each year the chairman shall submit to the city clerk a written statement designating the date and time of the board's regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-84. - Public notice of meetings and submission of CD application to HUD. 
    At least two (2) weeks prior to any meeting, a public notice will appear in the legal section of the local newspaper, specifying the exact time and location of the meeting. Also, CD staff will utilize the local media to inform the public of any upcoming assembly. 
    All meetings will be held at a time intended to maximize attendance, and will be held in a facility which is easily accessible to the general public. 
    To conform with Federal Handbook 6503.1, Section 570.300 (b), public notice will also be given when the CD application is submitted to HUD. Contained in this notice will be a statement relating to the possible objections which can be raised by persons protesting the application on one of the following grounds: The applicant's description of needs and objectives is plainly inconsistent with significant, available facts and data; the activities to be undertaken are plainly inappropriate to meeting the needs and objectives identified by the applicant; the application does not comply with applicable law; or the application proposes activities which are ineligible. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 2-85. - Duties. 
    The committee shall function to provide continuing citizens input into the Ardmore CD program, shall strengthen the lines of communication between citizens and staff, and shall act to meet the citizens participation requirements of the Community Development Act of 1977. 
(Ord. No. 1922, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Secs. 2-86-2-90. - Reserved.

All meetings of the board shall be public, and on or before the fifteenth day of December of each year the chairman shall submit to the city clerk a written statement designating the date and time of the board's regular meetings. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-13-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85; Ord. No. 2346, § I, 2-18-91)

    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on an annual basis the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meetings during the 12-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85; Ord. No. 2658, § VI, 7-17-00)

(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-121. - Rules. 
    The board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the government of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the city commission. The board will be governed by Roberts Rules of Order when applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-122. - Record of proceedings. 
    The board shall keep and preserve a true record of all its proceedings and official acts, and said record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-123. - Report to city commission. 
    The board shall on or before the second Monday in April of each year, make a report to the city commission on the activity of the board for the past year. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-124. - Budget. 
    Immediately prior to April of each year the board shall prepare and submit to the city commission a budget which shall include the necessary expenses for the ensuing year. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-125. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise shall be filled in like manner as original appointment, except that if the vacancy is for an unexpired term, the appointment shall be made for only the unexpired part of such term. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85) 
Sec. 2-126. - Purpose of board. 
(a)  The purpose of the board is providing activities related to youth programs and recreation, education and community awareness. 
(Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2181, § 1, 1-7-85; Ord. No. 2658, § VII, 7-17-00)
