ARTICLE VII. - SEAL 

Sec. 2-130. - Description. 
    The seal of the city, shall be in the form of a pictorial ellipse displaying in separate quadrants symbols of the City of Ardmore, the State of Oklahoma, Indian Territory, and the United States of America, with dates of organization of each, all of which are to be surrounded by the words, "Seal of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, 1887." Said seal shall not be more than two (2) inches in diameter. A facsimile of the seal is attached to this article and made a part hereof for all purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2122, § 1, 8-15-83) 
Editor's note- The city seal does not appear herein but is on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 2-131. - Custody. 
    The city clerk shall be the official custodian of the seal of the city and shall keep it in his office and be responsible for its safekeeping. 
(Ord. No. 2122, § 1, 8-15-83) 
Sec. 2-132. - Use. 
    The city clerk shall affix the seal of the city to all instruments of writing of whatsoever nature wherever required by ordinance, resolution or order of the board of commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2122, § 1, 8-15-83) 
Secs. 2-133-2-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - COMMISSION ON AGING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2299, § I, adopted Nov. 21, 1988, has been codified herein as a new Art. VIII, §§ 2-140-2-154, at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Fair housing, Ch. 9.5; health department, § 13-2 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 21; planning commission, Ch. 22; provisions for the physically handicapped, App. C, § 15-29A. 

Sec. 2-140. - Created. 
    There is hereby created within the city a board which will be known as the Ardmore Commission on Aging. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I (1.1), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-141. - Composition. 
    The board shall consist of nine (9) persons who shall be citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.2), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-142. - Appointment of members. 
    The board shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city commission. All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular commission meeting each May. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.3), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-143. - Term of members. 
    Members of the board shall serve a term of three (3) years; provided, however, that on the first board, three (3) members shall serve three (3) years; three (3) members shall serve two (2) years; and three (3) members shall serve one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.4), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-144. - Ex officio member. 
    The mayor may, with the approval of a majority of the commission, appoint a member of the city commission to serve as an ex officio member for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.5), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-145. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor, by and with the consent of the city commission, may remove any member at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.6), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-146. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board, occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise, shall be filled in like manner as original appointments; except that if the vacancy is for an unexpired term, the appointment shall be made for only the unexpired part of such term. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.7), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-147. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.8), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-148. - Meetings. 
    The board shall hold at least six (6) meetings per year and adjourn meetings when necessary. All meetings of the board shall be public. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.9), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-149. - Organization. 
    There shall be a president and a vice president, selected from the members of the board, elected annually by the board and, at its pleasure, removed. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.10), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-150. - Rules generally. 
    The board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the government of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.11), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-151. - Record of proceedings. 
    The board shall keep and preserve a true record of all of its proceedings and official acts. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.12), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-152. - Report to city commission. 
    The board shall, on or before the second Monday of April each year, make a report to the city commission on the usage, conditions, operations and other information that may be requested by the commission or the board wishes to provide. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.13), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-153. - Budget. 
    Immediately prior to April of each year, the board shall prepare and submit to the city commission a budget which shall include the necessary expenses for the ensuing fiscal year. 
    The city shall provide administrative support for the commission through the department of planning and development. Other than incidental costs, the city will not provide direct funds for programs supported by the commission unless approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.14), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-154. - Purposes of the board. 
    The commission shall coordinate with both the public and private sectors to help implement programs which benefit and involve senior citizens, including, but not limited to, the following areas: 
(1)  Health care and nutrition. 
(2)  Transportation. 
(3)  Education. 
(4)  Housing. 
(5)  Arts and crafts. 
(6)  Recreation and physical fitness. 
(7)  Employment. 
(8)  Adult day-care. 
(9)  Crime prevention and victim assistance. 
(10)  Emergency services. 
(11)  Legal services. 
(12)  Federal assistance programs. 
    The commission shall coordinate with the following agencies and organizations to encourage more efficient and effective programs which serve Ardmore senior citizens: 
(1)  All health agencies and organizations. 
(2)  AARP. 
(3)  SODA. 
(4)  Chickasaw Housing Authority. 
(5)  Ardmore Higher Education Center. 
(6)  Ardmore Parks and Recreation Department. 
(7)  Ardmore Municipal Golf Course. 
(8)  Ardmore Village. 
(9)  Southern Oklahoma Nutritional Program. 
(10)  Employment agencies. 
(11)  All existing senior citizen organizations. 
(12)  Social Security. 
(13)  And all other appropriate agencies. 
    Representatives from these organizations will be encouraged to attend commission meetings and participate in its activities. 
    The commission shall serve as an advisory board to the city commission regarding all issues which impact senior citizens. It will make reports and recommendations to the city commission regarding the various activities and programs proposed or coordinated by the commission. The commission shall also help analyze public policy proposals at the local, state and federal levels which may impact seniors and provide the city commission with information and recommendations for possible action. The city commission must approve all programs which involve the city or require city resources before such programs are implemented. 
    The commission shall promote senior citizen activities by coordinating the distribution of information on senior citizen programs throughout the entire community and by providing information and assistance to agencies and interested groups which serve senior citizens. 
    The commission shall facilitate the role of senior citizens by encouraging them to maintain continuous involvement in all aspects of the community. 
    The commission shall develop a five-year plan which outlines proposed programs with yearly goals and objectives. Said plan shall be updated annually and submitted to the city commission for approval. 
(Ord. No. 2299, § I(1.15), 11-21-88) 
Sec. 2-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CITY TREE BOARD 

Sec. 2-156. - Street trees defined. 
    Street trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation located on land lying in public rights-of-way, public easements or within any publicly owned lands including public parks. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-157. - Creation and establishment of the city tree board. 
    It is hereby created and established a city tree board which shall consist of up to seven (7) members who are citizens and residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96; Ord. No. 2888, 8-3-09) 
Sec. 2-158. - Term of office. 
    Each member of the tree board, appointed by the mayor, shall serve for a period of three (3) years, except initially the term of two (2) of the members of the tree board shall be for only one (1) year, and initially the term of two (2) of the members of the tree board shall be for two (2) years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. The city manager of the city or his designee will serve as ex officio member of the board, along with a member of the Ardmore Beautification Council who will also serve as ex officio member. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-159. - Compensation. 
    Members of the city tree board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-160. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel, develop and/or update annually a written plan for the care, preservation, trimming, planting, replacing, removal and disposition of trees and shrubs on public lands and in public rights-of-way. Such a plan will be presented annually to the city commission and upon approval shall constitute the official comprehensive tree plan for the city. In addition, a progress report shall be made semiannually to the city commission. It shall be the duty of this board to seek designation as a Tree City, U.S.A. and then actively participate in the development and update of ordinances relating to the removal and disposition of hazardous conditions related to trees, dead or dying trees, and trees containing Dutch Elm disease. These ordinances, when adopted by the city commission, shall serve as the statutory basis for the enforcement authority of advisory recommendations made by the city tree board. These ordinances shall identify planting, development and maintenance procedures to include species, types, spacing, location restriction and care of trees in the public domain, as well as outlining duties and liabilities of both city personnel and the private professional engaged in tree care and removal. In addition, it shall be the duty of the city tree board to assist in planning and implementation of any annual Arbor Day activities. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-161. - Operation. 
    The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules of operation, as may be necessary for governance of such board, not inconsistent with the Code of Ordinances of the city or any rules and policies of the city, and keep a journal and minutes of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-162. - Interference with City of Ardmore personnel carrying out approved policies and plans of the city tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with Ardmore city personnel who are carrying out the approved policies and plans of the city tree board or any of its agents while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removal of any street trees, park trees or any tree on public property as authorized in this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-163. - Review by the city commission. 
    The city commission shall have the right to review the plans, policies, conduct, acts, and decisions of the tree board. Any person may appeal, within fifteen (15) days of said action, any decision or recommendation of the city tree board to the city commission, who shall have final authority for all decisions, actions and recommendations of the city tree board. 
(Ord. No. 2522, 2-18-96) 
Sec. 2-163.5. - Street tree species to be planted. 
    The following list constitutes the official recommended street tree species for the city. No species other than those included in this list are recommended for planting by the city: 
Small Trees Medium Trees Large Trees Amur Maple Ash American Linden Autumn Olive Austrian Pine American Sycamore Crepe Myrtle Bald Cypress Burr Oak Flowering Dogwood Chinese Pistachio Caddo Maple Holly (deciduous) Honey Locust (thornless) London Planetree Panciled Goldenrain Tree Kentucky Coffee Tree Pecan Pear (fruitless) Japanese Black Pine Red Oak Purple Leaf Plum Lacebark Elm Sawtooth Oak Redbud River Birch Shumard Oak Smoke tree Virginia Pine Sweetgum Desert Willow Water Oak  
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2548, adopted Dec. 13, 1996, purported to amend Ch. 2, Art. IX, by the addition of new provisions to be set out as §§ 2-163-2-173. To avoid duplication of section numbers, such new § 2-163 has been redesignated as § 2-163.5, at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-164. - Street tree species not to be planted. 
(a)  The following species of trees shall not be planted in the parkways or where such trees will injure sewer or storm drains of the city: 
(1)  Aspen; 
(2)  Black Locust; 
(3)  Box Elder; 
(4)  Buckeye; 
(5)  Catalpa; 
(6)  Chinese Elm (except Lacebark); 
(7)  Cottonwood (female); 
(8)  Eastern Red Cedar; 
(9)  Fruit trees (except fruitless); 
(10)  Hawthorn; 
(11)  Live Oak; 
(12)  Osage Orange (female); 
(13)  Pomegranate; 
(14)  Poplar; 
(15)  Russian Olive; 
(16)  Silver Maple; 
(17)  Tree of Heaven (Allanthus); 
(18)  Willow. 
(b)  Street trees shall be balled and burlapped or container grown and shall have a minimum trunk diameter of one and three-fourths (13/4) inches to two and one-half inches (21/2) measured at six (6) inches above the ground. The trees will be #1 grade stock. All trees shall be tagged and identified as to species, size and place of origin. Such tags shall not be removed prior to inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-165. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in section 2-163.5 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, thirty (30) feet; medium trees, forty (40) feet; and large trees, fifty (50) feet; except in special planting designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-166. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
(a)  On streets having a right-of-way of fifty (50) feet or less, trees shall not be planted within the public right-of-way. On streets with wider rights-of-way, trees in the right-of-way may be installed upon approval of the tree board after consulting with the city engineer about the type of location of underground and overhead utilities, consistent with sections 2-167 and 2-168 below. 
(b)  On streets having rights-of-way wider than fifty (50) feet, the installation of street trees shall also be in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three (3) species sizes classes listed in section 2-163.5 of this article and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than: small trees, two (2) feet; medium trees, three (3) feet; and large trees, four (4) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96; Ord. No. 2759, 1-20-04) 
Sec. 2-167. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. 
    No street trees shall be planted closer than thirty-five (35) feet from any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet from any fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-168. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 2-163.5 of this article may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utilities wire, or over or within ten (10) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-169. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public ground, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
    The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in any unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewer, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements or is affected with injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with section 2-163.5 through section 2-168 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-170. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be undesirable as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than the three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other cause, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical shall be exempted from this article. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-171. - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the sidewalk or thirteen (13) feet six (6) inches above the surface of the street. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign, such trimming to be confined to the area immediately above the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96; Ord. No. 2903, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 2-172. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within sixty (60) days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal to the property owner. Failure to pay may result in costs being assessed as a lien against the property tax notice at the Carter County Courthouse. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 2-173. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 12-3-96) 
Secs. 2-174-2-190. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-194. - Changing data prices. 
    The G.I.S. coordinator is given the authority to change any of the prices individually at any time that he determines that the current market for the data justifies the change. In making this determination the G.I.S. coordinator shall base his decision on the following factors: 
(1)  The age of the data and whether age makes a difference in its value. 
(2)  Whether the data is accurate enough by today's standards to justify its cost or can it be reproduced faster, cheaper and better than it can be purchased. 
(3)  Has technology advanced enough to render the existing data obsolete. 
(4)  Does the surrounding market for G.I.S data reflect its worth to local users. 
(5)  Is the city's product going to undercut the private sector, be in line with it, or be more expensive than others in similar markets with similar products. 
(6)  The cost associated in development, production, maintenance and marketing of the data. 
(7)  Whether the price list is based on what the local market will support as a fair and just price for the products. 
(Ord. No. 2660, § 4, 8-21-00) 
Sec. 2-195. - Data exchange. 
    The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to exchange G.I.S. data and products with other parties for information of similar worth. 
(Ord. No. 2660, § 5, 8-21-00) 
Secs. 2-196-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC RECORDS 

Sec. 2-201. - Fees for Copies of Public Records; Exceptions; Reproduction Fees; Search Fees; Posting of the Fee Schedule. 
A.  Payment of Fees. Persons desiring copies of ordinances and other public records of the City shall pay to the Director of Finance the fee provided below. When a request exceeds $20.00 in potential fees, payment in advance may be required. 
B.  Reproduction Fees: 
1.  Documents having dimensions of eight and one half inches by fourteen inches (81/2? × 14?) or smaller, shall be provided at a cost of Twenty Five Cents ($0.25) per page. The fee for certified copies shall be One Dollar ($1.00) per page. 
2.  Documents larger than eight and one half inches by fourteen inches (81/2? × 14?) shall be provided at actual cost of reproduction unless the document fee is described in Article X, Sections 2-191-2-195 of this Code (fees related to GIS documents). If the document fee is included in that section, it shall supersede this section. 
3.  Records that can be produced electronically may be provided on a DVD, CD, or other form of media at a cost of $3.00. 
C.  Search Fees: 
1.  If the request for copies of public records is solely for commercial purposes or clearly would cause excessive disruption of the public body's essential functions, then a search fee will be charged and paid to recover the direct cost of document search. This search fee will be based on the hourly wage of the person or persons performing the search and will be equal to the hourly wage × the amount of time taken to conduct the search. 
2.  In no case shall a search fee be charged when the release of said documents is in the public interest, including, but not limited to, release to the news media, scholars, authors and taxpayers seeking to determine whether those entrusted with the affairs of the government are honestly, faithfully and competently performing their duties as public servants. 
D.  Posting of the Fee Schedule: The City Clerk shall post a copy of the Fee Schedule on the Notice Board located at the entrance of City Hall and shall provide it to the Carter County Clerk. 
( Ord. No. 2983 , § I, 6-6-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2983 , § I, adopted June 6, 2016, enacted provisions designated as § 2-111 pertaining to fees for copies of public records; exceptions; reproduction fees; search fees; posting of the fee schedule. Inasmuch as § 2-111 already exists and said provisions were intended for inclusion in a new Div. 2 to Art. X, said provisions have been redesignated as § 2-201 at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 2-202-2-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - TRAILS AND GREENWAYS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-211. - Role of commission defined. 
    The role of the trails and greenways commission is to advise and assist the city with the design, development, financing and operation of the Ardmore Trails System. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-212. - Creation and establishment of the city trails and greenways commission. 
    It is hereby created and established a city trails and greenways commission which shall consist of nine (9) members and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00; Ord. No. 2675, § I, 3-5-01) 
Sec. 2-213. - Term of office. 
    Each member of the trails and greenways commission, appointed by the mayor, shall serve for a period of three (3) years, except initially the term of three (3) of the members of the trails and greenways commission shall be for only one (1) year, and initially the term of three (3) members of the trails and greenways commission shall be for two (2) years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. The city manager or his designee will serve as ex officio member of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-214. - Compensation. 
    Members of the city trails and greenways commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-215. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The city trails and greenways commission shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Identify and apply for available funding and grants for the purpose of acquiring rights-of-way, the building of trails and the ongoing maintenance of the trail system; 
(2)  Review and comment on draft trail plans; 
(3)  Promote and build support for local trail initiatives; 
(4)  Make recommendations to the city commission on proposed final trail plans; 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-216. - Operation. 
    The trails and greenways commission of the city shall meet at least four (4) times per year in public and open meetings. The commission shall keep a record of its proceedings. A copy shall be filed for public view at city hall. All meetings of the commission shall be opened to the public. Any person or his duly appointed representative shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter before the commission. The trails and greenways commission shall be empowered to adopt rules for the conduct of its business, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules or policies of the city commission. The trails and greenways commission shall elect a chair and a secretary. Five (5) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-217. - Review by the city commission. 
    The city commission shall have the right to review the plans, policies, conduct, acts and decisions of the trails and greenways commission. Any person may appeal, within fifteen (15) days of said action, any decision or recommendation of the trails and greenways commission to the city commission, who shall have final authority for all decisions, actions and recommendations of the trails and greenways commission. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 2-218. - Sunset provision. 
    The city trails and greenways commission shall terminate on July 1, 2005. 
(Ord. No. 2668, 12-4-00)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - DOWNTOWN AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016, § 1, enacted April 20, 1981, repealed Ord. No. 1988, adopted June 16, 1980, from which former Art. II, §§ 3-11-3-23, relative to the municipal airport advisory board, was formerly derived. Section 2 of said Ord. No. 2016 amended this Code by adding the provisions included herein as a new Art. II. 

Sec. 3-11. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an official Downtown Airport Advisory Board of the City of Ardmore to be called the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(a), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-12. - Composition; appointment, term of members. 
    All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular commission meeting each May. The Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall consist of five (5) members whose appointment shall be made by the mayor with the advice and approval of the city commission. The city manager and the President of the Ardmore Development Authority shall be ex officio members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(b), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2610, § I, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 2735, § 2, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 2928, § 1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 3-13. - Vacancies. 
    In the event of a vacancy on the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board, such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as provided in section 3-12 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(c), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 3, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-14. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor by and with the consent of the city commission may remove any member at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(d), 4-20-81) 
Sec. 3-15. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(e), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 4, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-16. - Meetings. 
    All meetings of the board shall be public and on or before the fifteenth day of December of each year the chairman shall submit to the city clerk a written statement designating the date and time of board's regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(f), 4-20-81) 
Sec. 3-17. - Attendance. 
    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on a semiannual basis, the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meeting during the six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(g), 4-20-81) 
Sec. 3-18. - Organization. 
    There shall be a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board, elected by the board and at its pleasure removed. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(h), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 5, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-19. - Rules. 
    The Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the government of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(i), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 6, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-20. - Record of proceedings. 
    The Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall keep and preserve a true record of all its proceedings and official acts, and said records of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(j), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 7, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-21. - Report to city commission. 
    The Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall, on or before the second Monday of April each year, make a report to the city commission concerning its activities during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(k), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 8, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-22. - Budget. 
    On or before February 1 each year, the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall prepare and submit, as the city shall determine, a budget for the airport. The budget shall include the necessary expenses for operation, maintenance, repair and improvements of the airport for the ensuing fiscal year. The mayor and city commission may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portions of the budget as are not defrayed from the income from the airport. 
(Ord. No. 2016, § 2(l), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 9, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-23. - Duties. 
    The duties of this board shall be to study and make factual reports and recommendations to the city commission toward the management of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport, and/or the utilization and operation thereof which will best serve the interests of the city, and to make such other recommendations as will in the opinion of said board be to the best interest of civil aviation. (Ord. No. 2016, § 2(m), 4-20-81; Ord. No. 2242, § 1, 12-1-86; Ord. No. 2735, § 10, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR DOWNTOWN ARDMORE AIRPORT[3] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Authority to adopt rules, regulations for use of municipal airport, 3 O.S. 1961, § 65.8(a).

Sec. 3-34. - Approval, confirmation. 
    The rules and regulations hereinafter enumerated, governing operations at the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport, having been duly and regularly approved by the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board are hereby approved and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 1512, § 1, 9-1-65; Ord. No. 2735, § 11, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-35. - Enumerated. 
(a)  All vehicles on this airport will move and park only in areas designated by the management of the airport. Under no circumstances are ground vehicles to move and park in areas other than those so designated without permission of the airport management. 
(b)  No aircraft shall fly across the field, other than for landing purposes, under one thousand (1,000) feet above ground level. 
(c)  All landings and takeoffs shall be made on runways only, except in an emergency. 
(d)  Northbound traffic using Runway 35 shall be right-hand pattern. Southbound traffic using Runway 17 shall be left-hand pattern. 
(e)  No person shall taxi an aircraft to or from the hangar line or to or from an approved parking space until he has ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with other aircraft, persons or objects in the immediate area. Aircraft shall be taxied at speeds that will insure complete control at all times. Aircraft shall not be taxied into or out of any hangar. No taxiing shall be done except on areas designated for taxiing. 
(f)  While running up aircraft engines, pilots shall not allow the propeller or jet stream to come in contact with building, airplanes, parking areas or areas reserved for spectators. No aircraft engine shall be operated unless a competent operator is at the controls. Any aircraft not equipped with locking brakes shall have the wheels adequately blocked to prevent movement of the aircraft before starting any engines. No aircraft engine shall be operated in any hangar. Engines shall be run up in designated areas only. No pre-take-off run up shall be carried out except in designated areas for this purpose. 
(g)  A person or firm desiring to offer charter service shall obtain approval from the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board and make the service available to the general public at nondiscriminatory rates and shall establish and maintain an FAA certified air taxi service as required by the equipment to be used. A person or firm desiring to offer flight instructions shall obtain approval from the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board and establish and maintain a FAA certified flying school. 
(h)  No person other than those authorized by the management will be allowed on the landing areas, or areas designated for taxiing. Properly certificated aircraft, operated by properly certificated personnel are hereby so authorized on these areas. 
(i)  When taxiways have been made available, no aircraft shall make a one hundred eighty (180) degree turn after landing on the runway. 
(j)  Aircraft owners, their pilots or agents, shall be responsible for the prompt disposal of disabled aircraft and parts thereof, unless required or directed by the airport management or the Federal Aviation Agency, in writing, to delay such action pending an investigation of an accident. Subsequent to forty-eight (48) hours notification, the airport manager may remove disabled aircraft at the expense of the aircraft owner. 
(k)  Any person damaging injuring or destroying airport property either by accident, or otherwise, shall be liable for the reasonable value of the property so damaged or destroyed. 
(l)  [Reserved]. 
(m)  The sale of oil, gasoline or other fuel on the airport is expressly prohibited, except from a fixed base operator on the airport. 
(n)  Any person desiring to engage in the sale or use of aviation gasoline or other fuels shall first be required to submit to the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board a plot plan showing the location and extend of the proposed facilities, which plant must be approved by the city commission prior to installation. All fuel storage tanks shall be constructed according to FAA, fire, and city building codes, and all sales of gasoline, either directly from pumps or through tank truck, shall be carried out in accordance with standard operating procedure with due care being given for the safety and convenience of the customers, other tenants and users of the airport. 
(o)  All Runway 35 departures shall make a right-hand turn as soon as safe and practicable. 
(p)  All approaches shall be made with the guidance PAPI approach system. 
(q)  Pattern altitudes shall be raised from eight hundred (800) feet to one thousand (1,000) feet above ground level. 
(r)  No intersection takeoffs will be permitted. 
(s)  Where practical, downwind legs shall be no further north than one-half (1/2) mile. 
(t)  No aircraft weighing in excess of federal published capacities shall land at the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport with the exception of: 
(1)  Distressed aircraft to save life or property. 
(u)  All flight patterns shall avoid populated areas as much as possible and in accordance with FAA rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1512, § 1, 9-1-65; Ord. No. 1771, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 1-6-75; Ord. No. 2563, §§ I-III, 9-15-97; Ord. No. 2676, 3-5-01; Ord. No. 2735, §§ 12, 13, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-36. - Unlawful to violate. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public offense for any person to commit any violation of any of the above and foregoing rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1512, § 2, 9-1-65) 
Secs. 3-37-3-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STANDARDS AND PROCEDURES FOR LAND AND FACILITIES USE AT DOWNTOWN ARDMORE-CARTER COUNTY AIRPORT 

Sec. 3-41. - Procedures and minimum standards adopted. 
    The following procedures and minimum standards are hereby promulgated and adopted for the use of any land or facility at said airport Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport. 
(Ord. No. 1591, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 14, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-42. - Definitions. 
    As used herein, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Airport. "Airport" shall mean the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport located on city, county and state lands and operated by the City of Ardmore, Carter County, Oklahoma. 
    Airport board. "Airport board" shall mean the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board, of the City of Ardmore as duly elected and constituted at any time. 
    Airport tenant. "Airport tenant" shall mean any individual, company, or corporation having a contract or lease with the City of Ardmore to conduct aeronautical activities on the airport. 
    Aeronautical activity. "Aeronautical activity" shall mean any activity which involves, makes possible, or is required for the operation of aircraft or which contributes to, or is required for, the safety of such operations and shall include, but not by way of limitation, all activities commonly conducted on airports, such as, charter operations, pilot training, aircraft rental and sightseeing, aerial photography, crop dusting, aerial advertising and surveying, air carrier operations, aircraft sales and services, sale of aviation, petroleum products, whether or not conducted in conjunction with other included activities, repair and maintenance of aircraft, sale of aircraft, parts, sale and maintenance of aircraft accessories, radio, communication and navigation equipment and any other activity which, because of its direct relationship to the operation of aircraft, can appropriately be regarded as an aeronautical activity. 
    City commission. "City commission" shall mean the board of city commissioners of the City of Ardmore as duly elected and constituted at any time. 
    Comprehensive plan. "Comprehensive plan" means the City of Ardmore Comprehensive Plan 2015 outlining overall goals of the city as approved by the city commission and as amended from time to time. 
    Fixed base operator. "Fixed base operator" (FBO) shall mean any individual, company, or corporation having a duly executed negotiated contract with the City of Ardmore to provide a full complement of airport terminal services to resident and itinerant aircraft owners and operators, including, but not limited to, fuel sales and services conforming to section 3-49(a), pilot lounge, and navigation aids. 
    Master plan. "Master plan" means the scaled dimensional layout of the entire airport property as originally prepared by Collins and Flood FAA (Project #9-34-061-6603) under date of April 25, 1966, indicating current and proposed usage for each identifiable segment as approved by the city commission and as amended from time to time. 
    Minimum standards. "Minimum standards" shall mean the qualifications established herein, as amended from time to time by the city commission upon recommendation of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board, setting forth the minimum requirements to be met as a condition for the right to conduct an aeronautical activity on the airport. 
    Person. "Person" shall mean any person, firm, general or limited partnership, corporation, trust or association making application for, leasing or using any land or facility at the airport. 
    Special events. "Special events" shall mean activities that are not routine to the operations of aircraft or the airport and are subject to approval of the city commission. Application for special events shall be submitted to the airport manager in a timely manner in conformance with section 3-44. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 1, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 15, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-43. - Restrictions on land and facility use. 
    No person shall be granted an exclusive right to conduct any aeronautical activity upon the airport; provided, however, that no person shall be permitted to use any land or conduct any aeronautical activity for commercial purposes, or the solicitation of business in connection therewith, unless such aeronautical activity is conducted in accordance with the standards herein established and as herein established and as hereinafter amended from time to time upon the recommendation of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board with the approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 2, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 16, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-44. - Applications for use of land, etc.-Filing; contents. 
    Any person wishing to acquire the use of land or establish or use any facility on the airport for an aeronautical activity or special events shall be furnished a copy of these standards and procedures, as amended from time to time, and shall thereupon make application in writing, filed with the airport manager, setting forth in detail the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The proposed land use, facility and/or activity sought. 
(3)  The names and the qualifications of the personnel to be involved in conducting such activity. 
(4)  The financial responsibility and ability of the applicant to carry out the activity sought. 
(5)  The tools, equipment, services and inventory, if any, proposed to be furnished in connection with such activity. 
(6)  The requested or proposed date for commencement of the activity and the term of conducting the same. 
(7)  The estimated cost of any structure or facility to be furnished, the proposed specifications for same, and the means or method of financing such construction or acquisition of facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 3, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 17, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-45. - Same-Notice and hearing. 
    Upon the filing of such an application with the city manager's office, it shall be immediately referred to the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board and considered at the next scheduled meeting of such Board; subject to notification requirements of the Oklahoma Open Meetings Act, and if no meeting is scheduled within thirty-six (36) days from the filing of such application, a meeting shall be called for considering the same and notice thereof given to the applicant. 
    If such application involves conducting of an aeronautical activity for commercial purposes, all other persons then conducting commercial aeronautical activities on said airport shall also be notified of the filing of such application and the time and place of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board meeting to consider the same. 
    Upon the consideration of the application, the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall determine whether or not the applicant meets the standards and qualifications as herein set out and whether or not such application should be granted in whole or in part, and if so, upon what terms and conditions, and shall make a written report and recommendation to the city commission concerning the same. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 4, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 18, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-46. - Action on application by written city commission. 
    Upon receipt of written recommendation of the Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board, the city commission shall include said matter upon the agenda of the next regular meeting of the city commission, subject to notification requirements of the Oklahoma Open Meetings Act and, at such meeting or at a subsequent meeting to which it may be passed, shall approve, modify or reject such recommendations and applications. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 5, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 19, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-47. - Lease or contract. 
    Upon the approval of any such application as submitted or modified, the city commission shall cause to be prepared suitable lease or contract agreement setting forth the terms and conditions of the land and/or facility use, which lease or contract shall in every instance be conditioned upon: 
(a)  Original and continued compliance with the standards required for each particular aeronautical activity approved; shall refer to and incorporate these standards by reference. 
(b)  That any structure or facility to be constructed or placed upon said airport shall be constructed in a manner to conform to all safety regulations of the State of Oklahoma and the City of Ardmore, and shall be in compliance with the requirements of current building codes and fire regulations of the City of Ardmore and commission regulations; and that any construction once commenced will be diligently prosecuted to completion. 
(c)  Shall reserve the right in the city commission to modify or add to the standards for operation of aeronautical activities at the airport; shall provide for termination or cancellation of the lease or contract upon failure to comply after notice. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 6, 10-1-68) 
Sec. 3-48. - Standard requirements for all activities. 
    Every applicant and person conducting activities at the airport shall satisfy the commission specifically: 
(1)  Aeronautical activities. 
a.  That such applicant has a history of management and personal ability in conducting the same or similar or comparable type of service or activity in a good and workmanlike manner. 
b.  That such applicant has the financial responsibility and ability to provide the facilities and services proposed. 
c.  That the applicant and/or his employees have secured or can reasonably secure necessary certificates from the FAA or other authority where the same are required for the activity proposed. 
d.  That the applicant has or can furnish suitable indemnity insurance or bond to protect and hold the city harmless from any liability in connection with the conduct of the activity proposed. 
(2)  Special events. 
a.  That applicant can provide evidence of good and reasonable cause for the special use of the airport. 
b.  The applicant can demonstrate appropriate planning and support for the event in a timely manner to minimize disruption of normal airport services. 
c.  That the applicant has or can furnish suitable indemnity insurance or bond to protect and hold the city harmless from any liability in connection with the conduct of the activity proposed. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 7, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 20, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 3-49. - Standards for specific activities. 
    In addition to meeting the requirements of section 3-48, every person conducting the following specific activities shall meet the additional requirements as hereinafter set out. 
(1)  Fuel and oil sales. Persons conducting aviation fuel and oil sales on the airport shall be a fixed base operator under contract with the City of Ardmore stipulating flowage fees, and shall provide: 
a.  Hard surface ramp space equivalent to existing taxiway and aprons accessible by taxiway with electric pumps and approved tank storage having a capacity equal to the minimum tank truck load deliverable for each grade of commonly used aviation fuels; including aviation grade unleaded (e.g. mogas), 100/130 grade aviation fuel (e.g. avgas), and standard jet fuel. 
b.  Properly trained line personnel on duty at least eight (8) hours every calendar day, seven (7) days a week, and on call by readily accessible telephone at other hours during the day or night. 
c.  Proper equipment for repairing and inflating aircraft tires, servicing oleo struts, changing engine oil, washing aircraft windows and windshields and for recharging or energizing discharged aircraft batteries and starters. 
d.  Conveniently located heated and air-conditioned lounge or waiting room for passengers, and crews of itinerant aircraft, together with sanitary rest rooms and public telephones. 
e.  Adequate towing equipment and parking and tie-down area to safely and efficiently move aircraft and store them in all reasonably expected weather conditions. 
f.  In conducting refueling operations, every operation shall install and use adequate grounding facilities at fueling locations to eliminate the hazards of static electricity and shall provide approved types of fire extinguishers or other equipment commensurate with the hazard involved in refueling and servicing aircraft. 
(2)  Self-fueling of aircraft. Persons conducting self-fueling of aircraft on the airport shall comply with FAA recommended procedures. 
a.  All aircraft will be positively grounded when being serviced with fuel. Aircraft being serviced by a fuel truck or vehicle will be grounded to the fuel truck and the vehicle will be positively grounded. 
b.  Fueling equipment will be operated and maintained in accordance with appropriate manuals as FAA standards determine. 
(3)  Aircraft charter and taxi service. Persons operating aircraft and taxi service from the airport shall be an airport tenant under contract or lease with the City of Ardmore and shall provide: 
a.  Adequate table, desk or counter for checking in passengers, handling ticketing or fare collection and handling of luggage. 
b.  Properly certificated suitable aircraft with properly certificated and qualified operating crew. 
*c.  Insurance meeting or exceeding FAA standards. 
*d.  A current FAA air taxi permit. 
* Letters c. and d. will also apply to transient operators. 
(4)  Aircraft engine and accessory maintenance. All persons operating aircraft engine and accessory maintenance facilities shall provide: 
a.  Sufficient hangar space to house any aircraft upon which such service is being performed. 
b.  Suitable storage space for aircraft awaiting maintenance or delivery after repair and maintenance have been completed. 
c.  Adequate shop space to house the equipment and machine tools, jacks, lifts and testing equipment to perform overhauls. 
d.  Storage capacity for aircraft undergoing repair and maintenance work; provided, however, that any aircraft or part thereof in a non-airworthy condition be screened or removed from ground level public view. 
e.  If spray painting of the aircraft is to be performed, the operator shall provide separately partitionable space with adequate exhaust fans and fire protection. 
(5)  Aircraft rental and sales. Persons conducting aircraft rental and sales activity from the airport shall be an airport tenant under contract or lease with the City of Ardmore, and shall provide: 
a.  Suitable office space for consummating sales and/or rentals and the keeping of proper records in connection therewith. 
b.  Hangar storage space for at least one aircraft to be used for sales or rental. 
c.  For rental, at least one airworthy aircraft suitably maintained and certificated. 
d.  For new sales activity, sales or distributorship franchise from a recognized aircraft manufacturer of new aircraft and at least one demonstrator model of such aircraft. 
e.  Adequate facilities for servicing and repairing the aircraft or satisfactory arrangements with other operators in the airport for such service and repair. 
f.  There shall be available a properly certificated pilot capable of demonstrating new and/or used aircraft for sale or for checking out rental aircraft. 
(6)  Flight training. All persons, resident and itinerant, conducting flight training activities shall register with the airport manager and provide evidence of: 
a.  Continuing ability to meet certification requirements of the FAA for the flight training proposed. 
b.  Adequate public liability and property damage insurance sufficient to protect the operator and the city from legal liabilities involved. 
(7)  Crop dusting and spraying. Persons seeking to conduct crop dusting and spraying of agricultural chemicals shall be required to satisfy the airport manager, that: 
a.  Suitable arrangements have been provided for the safe storage and containment of noxious chemical materials; no poisonous or inflammable materials shall be kept or stored in close proximity to other facility installations at the airport. 
b.  The operator shall have available properly certificated aircraft suitably equipped for the agricultural operation undertaken. 
c.  The operator shall make suitable arrangement for servicing the aircraft with adequate safeguards against spillage on runways and taxiways or pollution or disbursal of chemicals by wind to other operational areas on the airport. 
d.  He has been issued a current FAA agricultural license under FAR 137. 
e.  He has been bonded in the state and carries chemical liability insurance. 
f.  Operator shall provide adequate public liability insurance to protect the operator and the city from liability in connection with such operations. 
(8)  Combination activities. Any person conducting a combination of the specific activities listed hereunder shall not be required to duplicate the requirements of the individual activities, but where the requirements of one (1) activity is sufficient to meet the requirement of a separate activity to be conducted the one (1) facility shall be sufficient to meet both requirements. 
(9)  Self-service fueling stations (automated) shall be exempt from subsections 3-35(m) and 3-49(1). 
a.  In conducting refueling operations, every operation shall install and use adequate grounding facilities at fueling locations to eliminate the hazards of static electricity and shall provide approved types of fire extinguishers or other equipment commensurate with the hazard involved in refueling and servicing aircraft. 
b.  Fueling equipment will be operated and maintained in accordance with appropriate manuals as FAA standards determine. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 8, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 21, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 2911, 1-18-11) 
Sec. 3-50. - Persons to whom standards applicable. 
    The standards set forth in this article shall be equally applicable to all operators, persons, firms, partnerships or corporations, their assigns or sublessees. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 9, 10-1-68) 
Sec. 3-51. - Amendment of standards. 
    The Ardmore Downtown Executive Airport Board shall review the standards for conducting aeronautical activities at least annually and shall recommend such revisions or amendments as shall be deemed necessary under the use circumstances surrounding the airport to properly protect the health, safety and interest of the city and the public. Upon approval of any such amendments, the operators of aeronautical activities secured hereunder shall be required to conform to such amended standards. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 10, 10-1-68; Ord. No. 2735, § 22, 3-17-03) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
