Sec. 5-45. - Keeping unlicensed, unvaccinated dog; penalty. 
    Any owner who shall maintain or keep a dog more than six (6) months of age on any premises within the corporate limits of the city which has not been licensed and vaccinated, as required by this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1421, § 22, 12-17-62; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-46. - Refusing to deliver unlicensed, unvaccinated dog to pound man; penalty. 
    Any person who shall refuse to deliver any unlicensed or unvaccinated dog to the pound man or any of his deputies or any city policeman upon demand for impounding, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1421, § 23, 12-17-62; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-47. - Permitting to run at large; penalty. 
    Any owner, keeper or custodian of a dog who shall allow such dog to run "at large," as such term is herein defined, whether on public or private property, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1421, § 24, 12-17-62; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-48. - Right of entry by Animal Control Officer; penalty for refusal. 
    The Animal Control Officer or his authorized deputies shall have the right at any reasonable time to inspect any dog to determine if such dog is licensed and vaccinated as required by this article and shall have the authority to enter any premises for such purpose, and it shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entrance to such Animal Control Officer or his deputies or to impede, obstruct or exclude such Animal Control Officer or his deputies when attempting to enter such premises for the purpose of inspecting such dog, and any person who shall refuse entrance or impede or obstruct such Animal Control Officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1421, § 25, 12-17-62; Ord. No. 2784, § 29, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-49. - Dangerous and Potentially Dangerous Dogs. 
(a)  Compliance with City Requirements. No person owning or having a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall own, possess, keep, or harbor such animal except as provided for herein. This section contains necessary controls on the unrestrained activities of dangerous and potentially dangerous animals which threaten the safety and pleasantness of streets, parks, sidewalks, yards and all areas of the city; and the lack of knowledge of intent is not a defense in violation thereof. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  This section shall not apply to animals owned by the Police Department or other law enforcement agencies. 
(2)  Dogs shall not be declared dangerous or potentially dangerous if the threat, injury, or damage was sustained by a person or livestock who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass upon the premises or if the person was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog, or has in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Animal control authority means an entity acting alone or in concert with other local governmental units for enforcement of the animal control laws of the city, county, and state and the shelter and welfare of the animals. 
(2)  Animal control officer means any individual employed by or hired by the City for the purpose of controlling animals and enforcing this Chapter, and impounding and/or destroying animals as prescribed by law. 
(3)  Animal Shelter means a facility permitted and recognized by the City as an establishment operating for the purposes of, among others, impounding and caring for animals. 
(4)  Dangerous dog is defined as: 
a.  Any dog which attacks a human being one (1) or more times without provocation and causes severe injury on either public or private property; or 
b.  Any dog that has previously been found to be potentially dangerous, and the dog thereafter attacks any domesticated pet, fowl or livestock and the attack results in the severe injury or death of said domesticated pet, fowl, or livestock, either on public or private property; or 
c.  Any dog which has previously been found to be potentially dangerous, the owner having received notice, which thereafter bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of human beings either on public or private property. 
(5)  Exotic Livestock shall mean commercially raised livestock including animals of the families bovidae and cervida and antilocapriade or birds of the ratite group. 
(6)  Home Quarantine means the confinement of an animal at the owner's residence where the residence has the necessary fencing, shelter and supervision to ensure that the animal will be confined, isolated from the public, observed appropriately, and will have adequate care. This quarantine also requires an examination by a licensed veterinarian on the first and last day of confinement. 
(7)  Livestock means any cattle, bison, hog, sheep, goat, equine, domesticated rabbits, chicken or other poultry and shall include exotic livestock. 
(8)  Owner as used in this Section means any person, firm, corporation, organization, or department possessing, harboring, keeping, having an interest in, or having control or custody of an animal. 
(9)  Persons Lawfully on Premises means a person on the property in the performance of any duty imposed upon the person by the laws of this state, county, city, or the laws of the United States, or the postal regulations of the United States, or when reading meters, or making repairs to any public utility or service located on the premises, or when working on the property at the request of the owner or any tenant having a lease upon any portion of the property, or when on the property upon invitation, either expressed or implied, of the owner or lessee of such property, or when on the property for any other lawful purpose. 
(10)  Potentially dangerous dog is defined as any dog that, while the dog was allowed to run at large, off of the property of its owner, and when unprovoked, on more than one occasion, was found to be chasing or aggressively creating a substantial threat to the health, safety, and welfare of livestock or persons. 
(11)  Proper enclosure for a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog means that the animal, while on the owner's property, shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely closed and locked pen or structure with at least One Hundred Fifty (150) square feet of space for each dog kept there which is over six (6) months in age, and which is suitable to prevent the entry of children, and is designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Such pen or structure shall have a secure top and secure sides and shall provide the animal with protection from the elements. 
(12)  Provoke or Provocation means, with respect to an attack by an animal, that the animal was hit, kicked, agitated by teasing or struck by a person with an object or part of a person's body or that any part of the animal's body is pulled, pinched, or squeezed by a person. 
(13)  Public property means any and all public streets, sidewalks, alleyways, easements, buildings, parks, playgrounds, and recreational facilities, including dog parks, and any and all places of business, amusement or entertainment which are privately owned and open to the public wherein merchandise, property, services, entertainment or facilities are offered for sale, hire, lease or use. 
(14)  Severe injury means a physical injury that results in broken bones, lacerations requiring sutures or cosmetic surgery. 
(d)  Judicial Determination. When a report is made and a complaint filed alleging that a dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous, a case shall be filed in Municipal Court upon the endorsement of the City Prosecutor. The case shall be a matter of judicial determination. There is no fine associated with the determination case. However, fines, costs, and incarceration are possible consequences should an owner violate any conditions imposed by the Municipal Judge or violate an ordinance, including allowing the animal to run at large before a determination is made. 
(1)  When a complaint is filed in Municipal Court alleging that a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is owned, possessed, kept, or harbored, then the person against whom the complaint is filed, or any other person having control or custody of the dog shall immediately take necessary steps to ensure that the dog is isolated from the public. 
(2)  If the Court finds that the animal is dangerous or potentially dangerous using the definitions herein, the Court shall then determine whether the dog should be destroyed or if conditions of confinement shall be imposed to allow the owner to keep the dog. 
(3)  If the Court determines that the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog should be destroyed, the owner has a right to appeal the decision to Carter County District Court. If an appeal is filed within ten (10) days, the dog shall not be destroyed unless or until the appeal is heard. If the judgment is not appealed, the dog shall be immediately destroyed. 
(4)  The refusal of a postal carrier to deliver mail or parcels to an address because of the threat of an animal attack shall be prima facie evidence that the animal is dangerous or potentially dangerous. 
(5)  It shall be an affirmative defense to an allegation that a dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous if the injury at issue was sustained by a person who, at the time of the injury, was committing a willful trespass or other criminal act upon the premises of the owner, including assaulting the owner of the dog. 
(e)  Certificate of Registration and Conditions to Maintain a Dangerous or Potentially Dangerous Dog. The City shall provide a procedure to issue certificates of registration to owners of dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs. In order for an owner to obtain a Certificate of Registration for an animal, the owner must pay Ten Dollars ($10.00) to the City and the following conditions must be met: 
(1)  Notice. It shall be the duty of the owner or harborers of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog or dogs to post a notice on the premises where the dog is kept, conspicuously visible to the public in letters of not less than two (2) inches high, and stating "BEWARE OF DANGEROUS DOG." 
(2)  Liability Insurance. Owners or harborers of any dangerous or potentially dangerous dog or dogs, as defined by this section, must purchase and provide at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) worth of liability insurance for a single incident, should the dog attack anyone. A certificate of insurance must be provided to the City. 
(3)  Photograph and Location. The owner is also required to provide an identifying photograph of the dangerous or potentially [dangerous] dog or dogs located within the city limits; and the owner must provide all births, deaths or transfers of dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs, as defined herein, within the city limits. 
(4)  Proper Enclosure or Safety Measures Required at all Times. The owner must provide a proper enclosure for the animal as defined herein unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and remains under the physical restraint of a responsible person over the age of Sixteen (16) years. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any person or livestock. 
(f)  Violations. All dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs, as defined in this section, which are kept in violation of any of the provisions of this Section, are subject to being impounded by an Animal Control Officer or any police officer. No warrant is required to seize the animal if the dog is running at large at the time of seizure, if the officer has probable cause to believe the dog is dangerous and the threat to health, safety, and welfare of persons or livestock is continuing in nature, or if the owner has violated the conditions required by the Municipal Court. In the event that the owner has violated the conditions for maintaining a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog, including allowing the animal to run at large, the owner shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus costs and up to Sixty (60) days in jail. 
(g)  Killed or injured person. If a dog has been impounded for killing or seriously injuring a person, jurisdiction shall be proper in Carter County District Court pursuant to Title 4 of the Oklahoma Statutes. 
(h)  Harboring or concealing a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. Any person harboring or concealing a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog in violation of these provisions shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus costs and up to Sixty (60) days in jail. 
(Ord. No. 2267, § I, 9-8-87; Ord. No. 2784, § 31, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 21, 9-6-05; Ord. No. 2970 , § II, 7-20-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2970 , § II, adopted July 20, 2015, amended the catchline of § 5-49 to read as herein set out. The catchline of § 5-49 formerly read "Vicious dogs." 
Sec. 5-50. - Keeping of livestock. 
(a)  Livestock is defined as any animal normally kept for farm agricultural purposes, including but not limited to horses, mules, donkeys, cattle, goats, hogs or llamas. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, own, maintain, use or have in their possession or on premises under their control within the city limits any livestock, except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  All equine will be required to be vaccinated in accordance with state law. The health records should be available upon request by an Animal Control Officer or police officer to ensure public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 35, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 22, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-51. - Livestock within city limits. 
(a)  Within six (6) months of this section going into effect, all owners, keepers and caretakers of livestock in the city limits will be required to comply with this section. 
(b)  Livestock are prohibited on city streets and city parks. Livestock are permitted to use city streets during a parade that has been issued a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 36, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-52. - Zoning districts permissible for keeping livestock. 
    All livestock shall be kept only within the following zoning districts on lots of two (2) acres or more: RS-40, RR, AG, Industrial. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 37, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 22, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-53. - Total number of livestock allowed, acreage requirements and setbacks. 
(a)  All livestock shall be kept in a suitable enclosure substantially erected. A maximum of two (2) livestock may be kept on a lot of two (2) acres. A ground area of not less than five thousand (5,000) square feet of unobstructed space for each additional livestock shall be required on the site, lot or property. 
(b)  The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to commercial farm operations on a minimum of fifteen (15) acres conducted in accordance with provisions of the Unified Development Code. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 38, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 23, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-54. - Exceptions to keeping of livestock. 
    The temporary keeping of livestock shall be permitted in commercial, industrial, agricultural or public facilities and institutions zoning districts for the purposes and in the locations outlined below: 
(1)  Animal shows at the Hardy Murphy Coliseum; 
(2)  Care of animals at veterinary hospitals and clinics; 
(3)  Exhibitions at fairs, carnivals, circuses or stock shows; 
(4)  When offered for sale or trade at auction barns; 
(5)  When located on the property of a vocational school or research facility with facilities properly constructed as determined by the city; 
(6)  Slaughter establishments, when permitted by applicable zoning. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 39, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-55. - Impoundment of aggressive/abused and neglected animals. 
    The City Manager is empowered to authorize and/or designate the Animal Control Officer, the police department, and/or any other entity/or individual chosen by the City Manager, to impound an animal when, through verified complaint and/or probable cause there is a belief the animal has been aggressive and exhibited dangerous tendencies toward another animal, person or property. The power to impound and keep the animal in confinement also extends when there is a verified complaint and/or the probable cause to believe an animal has been abused or neglected. 
    For the animal to be impounded there must be a verified complaint, sworn under penalty of law and/or the facts which underlie the belief, which have been personally observed by a police officer of the city, and/or the animal control division. Said animal will continue to be impounded until either of the following has occurred: 
(1)  The authority empowered to confine said animal has been satisfied that no public safety issue exists, and/or that the animal would not be subject to abuse or neglect; 
(2)  The underlying complaint has been adjudicated in a court of proper jurisdiction, and the allegations of abuse/neglect and/or the animal is aggressive and/or vicious, have been found to the contrary. 
    This article is to be read in conjunction with the rest of the city ordinances of the city, but if any other ordinance in the city would conflict with this article, this article, authority and power is to supersede. 
    The City Manager is empowered to designate anyone with authority to enforce the ordinances of the city, to summons someone to court regarding said allegations. Anyone with the Ardmore Police Department, the animal control division, the development services department or any other person designated by the City Manager, may issue a summons, informing an individual of the allegations regarding the violation of the municipal ordinance, and informing them of the date they are to appear in the municipal court of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 30, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-55.1. - Impoundment of livestock. 
    Animal control shall impound equine, bovine, sheep, goats, llamas and chickens due to the public's safety when they are at large. 
(1)  There will be a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per trailer load; 
(2)  There will be a ten dollar ($10.00) per day per animal charge, for care, food, water, and shelter; 
(3)  If an animal needs medical treatment the owner of said animal shall be responsible for medical bills before the animal is released; 
(4)  After five (5) days the unclaimed livestock can be sold for no less than it has cost to care for said animals. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 41, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-55.2. - Interference with Animal Control Officer. 
    No person shall interfere with, hinder, delay, or obstruct in any manner whatsoever any Animal Control Officer in the performance of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2784, § 42, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2798, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 5-55.3. - Displaying for commercial purposes. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person displays any live animal for a commercial purpose on any roadside, public right-of-way, or commercial parking lot. Commercial purpose shall include, but not be limited to, intent to sell, trade, barter, lease, rent or give away any live animal. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if the person receives any live animal through sale, trade, barter, lease, rent, or give away conducted on any roadside, public right-of-way, or commercial parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 2883, 12-15-08)

ARTICLE V. - FIGHTING CHICKENS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2372, adopted March 2, 1992, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of § 1 as Ch. 5, Art. V, §§ 5-91-5-103, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings prescribed in this section except in those cases where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    At large means not securely confined by a fence or other means on premises under the control of or occupied by, the owner. 
    City enforcement officer means the city manager or his designee. 
    Fighting chicken means any chicken or other fowl, bred to fight or trained for fighting; more commonly known as a "fighting cock" or a "fighting rooster" or a "fighting chicken." 
    Owner means any person owning, harboring or keeping a fighting chicken as defined herein. The occupant of any premises on which a fighting chicken is located for a period of five (5) days or more shall be deemed to be harboring or keeping the chicken. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-92. - Running at large prohibited; impoundment. 
    No owner shall permit a fighting chicken owned, harbored or kept by him to be at large. Any fighting chicken running at large in violation of this section shall be taken up by the city and placed in the pound. A fighting chicken is "at large" as the term is used in this section, if such chicken is not securely confined in a coop or other enclosure located on the premises of the owner. Such coop or structure must be enclosed by chicken wire fencing no less than four (4) feet in height. The enclosure shall be no smaller than four (4) feet by six (6) feet and must contain a coop which has a roof and is enclosed on all sides except for one (1) opening. Only one (1) chicken may occupy the enclosure and coop. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-93. - Coop-condition generally. 
(a)  Every coop occupied by a fighting chicken shall be constructed of such material and in such manner that it can be kept clean and sanitary at all times. 
(b)  Every coop, if located within two hundred (200) feet of any residence, apartment house, restaurant, retail food store, school, church or residence other than that occupied by the owner or occupant of the premises upon which such animal is kept, shall be provided with a water-tight and fly-tight receptacle for manure of such size as to hold all accumulations of manure. Such receptacle shall be emptied sufficiently often and in such manner as to prevent it from being or becoming a nuisance and shall be kept covered at all times except when opened during the deposit or removal of manure or refuse. No manure shall be allowed to accumulate on such premises except in such receptacle. 
(c)  The floor of the coop must be of concrete or asphalt construction which will allow the coop to be cleaned easily and the manure to be kept in the water-tight receptacle mentioned hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-94. - License. 
    Every person harboring fighting chickens within the city limits of the City of Ardmore shall obtain a license. There shall be no charge for said license. The license shall be obtained from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-95. - Coops to be kept clean, sanitary, vermin, insect and rodent free. 
    Every coop or place where a fighting chicken is kept or permitted to be, shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, devoid of rodents, insects, vermin and free from objectionable odors. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-96. - Removal of manure. 
    Manure shall be hauled outside the city in a manner which does not jeopardize the public health. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-97. - City enforcement. 
(a)  The city enforcement officer may inspect any structure or place where any fighting chicken is kept at any time. He may issue any such reasonable order as he may deem necessary to the owner of such animal to cause the animal to be kept as provided in this chapter or in a manner so as not to constitute a nuisance. He may make a complaint before the municipal judge against any person for violation of any provision of this article or of any such reasonable order; but this shall not abridge the right of others to make such complaint. 
(b)  If it is determined by the municipal judge that the keeping of any fighting chicken or chickens constitutes either a private or public nuisance then the judge may enter an appropriate order abating the nuisance, including, but not limited to an order requiring all or a part of the fighting chickens be removed permanently. 
(c)  In addition, the city enforcement officer may apply to the District Court of Carter County for relief of the nuisance and may seek an injunction and other appropriate relief to abate any nuisance. 
(d)  The city enforcement officer shall have the right at any reasonable time to inspect any fighting chicken to determine if such fighting chicken is licensed as required by this article and shall have the authority to enter any premises for such purpose or for the purpose of establishing the fighting chicken is being kept in accordance with the provisions of this article, and it shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entrance to such officer or his deputies or to impede, obstruct or exclude such officer or his deputies when attempting to enter such premises for the purpose of inspection, and any person who shall refuse entrance or impede or obstruct such officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 5-98. - Keeping in an annoying manner. 
    It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within the city any fighting chicken or chickens which by crowing or otherwise, disturbs the peace and quiet of any person or persons. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-99. - Violation by owner. 
    Any person owning, harboring or having the care of any fighting chicken who violates any of the terms of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-100. - Violation generally; impoundment. 
    All fighting chickens, as defined in this section, which are kept in violation of any of the provisions of this section are subject to being impounded by the city enforcement officer, any of his deputies, the pound man or any city policeman. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-101. - Fighting chickens prohibited in certain zoning districts. 
(a)  The keeping of fighting chickens is prohibited in all residential, commercial and industrial districts within the city limits of Ardmore, Oklahoma. Fighting chickens may be kept in agricultural districts under the conditions set out in this article, subject to the approval of a conditional use permit and compliance with any other applicable city ordinances. 
(b)  The restrictions and regulations on fighting chickens set out herein are necessary controls on the unrestrained keeping of fighting chickens which threatens the safety, health and pleasantness of streets, parks, sidewalks, yards and all areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. A. 
Sec. 5-102. - Coops. 
    A coop or coops containing a fighting chicken or chickens shall not be constructed or maintained within two hundred (200) feet of any residential or commercial zoning district within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92) 
Sec. 5-103. - Removal. 
    All fighting chickens located in residential, commercial and industrial districts on the date this article is enacted shall be removed permanently within six (6) months from that date. 
(Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 3-2-92)

Sec. 6-3. - Certified welders to register with the city: Fee, expiration, renewal of registration. 
    All persons engaged in welding work within the city shall register with the city. The amount of such fee (or fees) shall be as established in Chapter 34, the General Schedule of Fees. 
    All registrations shall expire February 1st of each year. 
    If registrations have not been renewed within thirty (30) days after expiration date, the first year fee shall be charged. 
( Ord. No. 3046, § I, 8-20-18 ) 
Sec. 6-4. - Building inspector to enforce provisions; appointment by city manager. 
(a)  [Reserved]. 
(b)  The city manager shall appoint the building inspector. 
(Code 1959, § 3-3; Ord. No. 2753, 10-6-03) 
Cross reference- Duty of building inspector to inspect dangerous buildings, give notice to owner to abate condition, § 18-12. 
Sec. 6-5. - Fire limits. 
    The following shall be and are hereby declared to be the fire limits of the city: 
    Beginning at the center line of McLish Avenue and "E" St. SW; thence northerly along the center line of "E" St. SW to the center line of West main; thence make an easterly jog along the center line of Main to the center line of "E" St., NW to the center line of Broadway; thence making an easterly jog along the center line of Broadway to the center line of "E" St. NW; thence northerly to the intersection with Palmer and "E" St. NW, thence in a southeasterly direction with the center line of Palmer to the center line with "D" St. NW; thence making a southerly jog along the center line of "D" St. NW to an intersection with the south line of Lot 2, thru Block 301; thence along the south line of Lot 2 & 8 of Block 301 and parallel with Palmer St. to an intersection with "C" St. NW; thence making a southerly jog along the center line of "C" St. NW to the intersection of center line of "C" St. NW and extension of south line of Lot 4, Block 302; thence in a southeasterly direction and parallel with the center line of Broadway and along the south lines of Lot 4 and 10 of Block 302 and Lot 4 of Block 303 to an intersection with the center line of "A" St. NW; thence in a southeasterly direction along the south line of Lot 4 in Block 304 to the center line of the alley in Block 304; thence northerly to the center line of the alley in Block 304 to the center line of 2nd Avenue NW; thence northwesterly along the center line of 2nd Avenue NW to the intersection with "A" St. NW; thence northeasterly along the center line of "A" St. NW to the intersection of "A" St. NW and 3rd Avenue NW; thence along center line of 3rd Avenue NW in a southeasterly direction to a point intersecting 3rd Avenue NW and alley in Block 247 and 274; thence northeasterly to a point intersecting the south line of Lot 1, Block 248 and the west line of the C.R.I. & P Railway right-of-way; thence southwesterly along the west line of the C.R.I. & P Railway right-of-way to the center line of 3rd Avenue NW; thence southeasterly on a line parallel with the center line of 3rd Avenue NE to a point on the west line of the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway right-of-way; thence across the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway right-of-way to a point intersecting the east line of the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway right-of-way and 3rd Avenue NE; thence in a southwesterly direction along the east right-of-way line of the Gulf, Colorado & Santa Fe Railway to a point intersecting the extension of south line of Lot 3 of Block 321; thence along the south line of Lot 3, Block 321 to a point intersecting the center line of "D" St. NE; thence southeasterly to a point intersecting the center line of "E" St. NE and the extension of the south line of Lot 3, Block 319; thence southwesterly along the center line of "E" St. NE to the north right-of-way line of East Main St.; thence to a point intersecting the south right-of-way line and the center line of "F" St. SE; thence southwesterly to the intersection of the extension of the south line of Lot 14 and the center line of "F" St. SE; thence in a northwesterly direction along the south line of Lots 1-14, Block 388 to a point intersecting the center line of "E" St. SE; thence southwesterly to a point intersecting the extension of the south line of Lot 3 and the center line of "E" St. SE; thence in a northwesterly direction along the south line of Lots 1-3, Block 387 to the intersection of the center line of "D" St. SE; thence southwesterly along the center line of "D" St. SE to the intersection with 1st Avenue SE; thence northwesterly along center line of 1st Avenue SE to the intersection with the center line of "C" St. SE; thence along the center line of "C" St. SE to a point intersecting with center line of 2nd Avenue SE; thence northwesterly along the center line of 2nd Avenue SE to a point on the East line of Gulf, Colorado, & Sante Fe Railway right-of-way; thence in a northwesterly direction along the center line of 2nd Avenue SE to a point intersecting with the center line of Mill St. SE; thence northeasterly along the center line of Mill St. to a point intersecting with the center line of Stanley Avenue SE; thence in a northwesterly direction along the center line of Stanley Avenue SE & SW to a point intersecting with the center line of "A" St. SW; thence in a northeasterly direction along the center line of "A" St. SW to a point intersecting the center line of the alley in Block 411; thence in a northwesterly direction along the center line of the alley in Blocks 411 & 412 to a point intersecting the center line of "C" St. SW; thence in a northeasterly direction to the center line of Hinkle; thence in a northwesterly direction to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1959, § 3-5; Ord. No. 2705, 2-4-02) 
Cross reference- Trailer camps in fire zone prohibited, § 29-22. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prescribe fire limits, 11 O.S. 1961, § 658. 
Sec. 6-6. - Wood shingles outside fire limits; when permitted. 
    Notwithstanding Section 802.2 of the National Building Code, wood shingles may be used outside of the fire limits for roofing on dwellings and on buildings accessory to dwellings, such as private garages, barns, etc. 
(Code 1959, § 3-6) 
Sec. 6-7. - Walls, roofs and cornices within fire limits to be of incombustible material. 
(a)  Every building hereafter erected or enlarged within the fire limits, shall be enclosed on all sides with walls constructed wholly of stone, well burned brick, terra cotta, concrete, or other incombustible materials. 
(b)  The roof, top and sides of all roof structures, including dormer windows, shall be covered with incombustible materials. 
(c)  All cornices shall be of incombustible material. 
(Code 1959, § 3-7) 
Sec. 6-8. - Structures permitted within fire limits. 
    No frame or wooden structure shall hereafter be built within the fire limits except the following; and all roofs placed upon such buildings or structures shall have an incombustible covering. 
(a)  Temporary one-story frame buildings for the use of builders. 
(b)  One-story frame sheds open on the long side, not over fifteen (15) feet high, with sides covered with incombustible material, and with an area not exceeding five hundred (500) square feet. A wooden fence shall not be used to form the back or side of such sheds. 
(c)  Wooden fences not over ten (10) feet high. 
(d)  Piazzas or balconies not exceeding ten (10) feet in width nor extending more than three (3) feet above the second story floor beams. No such structure shall extend beyond the lot line, or be joined to any similar structure of another building. 
(e)  Bay windows when covered with incombustible material. 
(f)  Grain elevators, coal pockets or ice houses, as usually constructed. 
(g)  No frame building shall be moved from without to within the fire limits. 
(h)  Provided, that a small garage or storage room constructed of galvanized iron or other noncombustible material where, in the judgment of the building inspector, the same would not increase the fire hazard, may be erected for the sole use and convenience of the owner or occupant of the building in the rear of which the same is constructed. 
Provided that none of the buildings permitted in this section except as stated in subsection (a) of this section, shall be built nearer than one hundred (100) feet from any of the principal streets or nearer than thirty (30) feet to any other building. 
(i)  An office building consisting of not more than two hundred (200) square feet resting on a temporary foundation with a minimum twenty (20) foot clearance of any other building or structure is permissible, provided, however, that the interior, exterior and roof of said structure are constructed of noncombustible materials and wired according to the requirements contained in the electrical code of the city. 
(j)  Architectural and ornamental wood parts of structures located within the designated historical preservation district may be remodeled or replaced using like materials as prescribed by the currently adopted edition of the building code. 
(Code 1959, § 3-8; Ord. No. 1358, § 1, 12-15-60; Ord. No. 2650, § I, 6-5-00) 
Sec. 6-9. - Removal of damaged, decayed buildings-Required. 
    Any existing frame buildings within the fire limits, which may hereafter be damaged by fire, decay or otherwise to an amount greater than one-half (1/2) of its present value, exclusive of the foundation, shall not be repaired or rebuilt, but shall be removed. 
(Code 1959, § 3-9) 
Sec. 6-10. - Same-Committee to determine extent of damage. 
    In case the owner of the damaged building shall be dissatisfied with the decision of the board of commissioners that such building is damaged to greater extent than one-half (1/2) of its value, exclusive of the value of the foundation, then the amount and extent of such damage shall be determined upon an examination of the building by a committee of three (3) competent persons, one of whom shall be appointed by the board of commissioners, another of whom shall be appointed by the owner or owners of said premises, and another of whom shall be appointed by the two (2) so selected, and a decision of a majority of the committee, reduced to writing and sworn to, shall be conclusive. 
(Code 1959, § 3-10) 
Sec. 6-11. - Certain uses of buildings prohibited unless made of fireproof construction. 
    No building shall be used for a public garage, coffee roaster, bakery or dry cleaning establishment within the fire limits, unless it be of fireproof construction. 
(Code 1959, § 3-11) 
Sec. 6-12. - Building permit-Required. 
    No wall, structure, building or part thereof, shall hereafter be built, enlarged, altered or demolished within the corporate limits of the city, until a plan of the proposed work, together with a statement of the material to be used, shall have been submitted to the building inspector or the city engineer, who shall, if in accordance with the provisions herein contained, issue a permit for the proposed construction. 
(Code 1959, § 3-12; Ord. No. 1461, § 2, 4-1-64) 
Sec. 6-13. - Same-Fees for construction, remodeling, demolition and relocation. 
    A person making application for a permit for construction, alteration, repair, or demolition shall pay the city the fee. The amount of such fee (or fees) shall be as established in Chapter 34, the General Schedule of Fees. 
(Code 1959, § 3-12; Ord. No. 1461, § 2, 4-1-64; Ord. No. 2033, 9-21-81; Ord. No. 2239, § 1, 10-20-86; Ord. No. 2429, § 1, 2-7-94; Ord. No. 2601, 2-16-99; Ord. No. 2716, 6-17-02; Ord. No. 2927, 6-18-12, eff. 9-1-12; Ord. No. 3042, § I, 8-20-18 ) 
Sec. 6-14. - Same-Building inspector to keep records. 
    The building inspector or city engineer shall keep or cause to be kept a complete and correct record of permits issued, showing location of property, class of improvements, owner, contractor and cost of construction. 
(Code 1959, § 3-12; Ord. No. 1461, § 2, 4-1-64) 
Sec. 6-15. - Fees for inspections after normal business hours, on weekends and during holidays. 
    The building official shall charge, in addition to the normal fees for building permits and inspections, the following additional fees for inspections requested by property owners, contractors, and builders after normal city office hours (8:00-5:00 Monday through Friday), on weekends, and during holidays: 
(1)  After hours on weekdays ..... $30.00 
(2)  Weekends ..... 40.00 
(3)  Holidays ..... 50.00 
    The building official shall have the authority to determine if a public health and safety condition exists affecting the provision of basic utility service to existing occupants of a structure. If such a condition exists which is beyond the control of the individual requesting an inspection, the building official may determine that an additional after hours fee is not warranted and may not be charged. 
(Ord. No. 2488, § 1, 4-3-95) 
Sec. 6-16. - Same-Building, alteration to conform to zoning requirements prior to issuance. 
    The building inspector shall not grant a building permit unless the proposed building or alteration is in harmony with the zoning ordinance. The building inspector shall have the powers and duties prescribed for the enforcing officer of the zoning ordinance in sections 32-41 and 32-42 of this code. 
(Code 1959, § 3-13) 
Sec. 6-17. - Same-Penalty charge for failure to obtain. 
    Should any person actually begin construction, alteration, repair, removal or demolition of any building without first taking out a permit therefor, such person, when subsequently to the beginning of such work, shall take out a permit as herein required, shall pay in addition to the fees above described and provided, an additional fifty per cent (50%) of the fees above described and shall be subject to all the penal provisions of section 1-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1461, § 4, 4-1-64) 
Sec. 6-18. - Incorporation of fallout shelter in public buildings, structures. 
(a)  Every officer, board, department, commission or commissions of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, charged with the duty of preparing specifications, or awarding or entering into contracts for the design, erection, or construction of buildings, or other structures, including additions to existing structures, for the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, shall consider incorporating where practical or feasible in such buildings, or other structures, fallout protection for at least its normal anticipated population which shall meet or exceed the minimum space and fallout protection criteria recommended by the Office of Civil Defense, United States Department of Defense. 
(b)  It shall be the policy of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma that fallout shelter be incorporated in all public buildings of the City of Ardmore, to the fullest extent practicable, in order to provide protection against radiation for the greatest number of people in the event of nuclear attack. 
(Ord. No. 1592, §§ 1, 2, 10-15-68) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1592, §§ 1 and 2, being nonamendatory of this Code, has been included herein as § 6-18 at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 6-19. - General construction and location standards for state or federal penal institutions. 
(a)  Definitions. The word "penal institution" shall specifically include but not be limited to jails, prisons, penitentiaries, pre-release centers and reformatories. 
(b)  Any state or federal penal institution located in the City of Ardmore must be enclosed by a retaining wall of sufficient height to restrict the movements of the inmates within the walls in no event to be of less than twelve (12) feet in height. These walls shall completely enclose the facility and permit ingress and egress only through large steel gates capable of being security locked. 
(c)  No such facility shall be located within one thousand (1,000) feet from a private residence. 
(Ord. No. 1722, §§ 1-3, 9-24-73) 
Editor's note- Section 6-19 is derived from Ord. No. 1722, §§ 1-3. Said ordinance did not expressly amend this Code. 
Secs. 6-20-6-27. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOUSE MOVING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Provisions as to house moving, 69 O.S. 1961, § 611 et seq. 

Sec. 6-28. - When permitted. 
    No building of any class shall be moved from one lot to another within the fire limits, or from a location outside the fire limits into the fire limits, unless it be of a class, and meets with all the requirements of a new building of a class, permissible to be erected within such district; and provided, no building of any class which has deteriorated or has been damaged more than fifty-one per cent (51%) of its original strength, shall be moved through the streets of said city. 
(Code 1959, § 3-14) 
Sec. 6-29. - Permit-Required. 
    No building shall be moved in said city from one location upon any lot or tract of land to another location, nor from one lot or tract of land to another lot or tract, unless a written permit therefor has been previously had or granted within thirty (30) days of commencing such removal, by the city building inspector. 
(Code 1959, § 3-15) 
State Law reference- Permit required for house moving, 69 O.S. 1961, § 611. 
Sec. 6-30. - Same-Bond required prior to issuance. 
    No permit shall be issued or granted to any person to move any building along or across any thoroughfare of said city unless said person shall have previously entered into an approved bond or undertaking covering all permits issued to said person in the period for which it is executed, in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), payable to the city and conditioned that it may be sued upon by any aggrieved or injured party, and that the person applying for a permit will without delay recompense any, and pay all damage or injury which may be done to or sustained by said city, or any person or property within said city, by reason of injury to public or private improvements therein, occasioned by moving of buildings, whether such injury be the result of negligence or not. Such damages to include all injuries to paving, curbing, parking, grass, trees or other improvements of whatever kind or nature, the property of the city or private individuals. 
(Code 1959, § 3-16) 
Sec. 6-31. - Same-Unlawful to move without obtaining permit. 
    It shall be an offense and unlawful for any person in said city to move any building or structure along or across any thoroughfare of said city without having a permit therefor, as provided herein. 
(Code 1959, § 3-17) 
Sec. 6-32. - Same-Fees. 
    Fees for moving permits shall be as follows: 
    For one story frame house not exceeding nine hundred eighty (980) square feet floor space, five dollars ($5.00) for the first twenty-four (24) hours and three dollars ($3.00) for each additional twelve (12) hours or fraction thereof. 
    For houses larger than above, one dollar ($1.00) per day, additional for each one hundred ninety-six (196) square feet of floor space, or fractional part thereof, in excess of nine hundred eighty (980) square feet except as hereinafter provided. 
    Heights of buildings as above used shall be the vertical distance from surface of lowest floor to the highest point of roof. Enclosed space as above shall include any covered part of building which has more than two (2) walls adjacent thereto. No building in excess of two (2) stories in height or containing more than nine (9) rooms shall be moved without special permission from the board of commissioners. 
    Said fees shall be paid by the applicant for permit to the city clerk at the time of or before the issuance of the permit by the city building inspector. 
(Code 1959, § 3-18) 
Sec. 6-33. - Same-Designation of route and time to be listed 
    The permit issued by the city building inspector for the removal of any such building shall specifically designate the street or streets over which said building is to be moved, and shall fix the time when such removal shall commence and the time it is anticipated it will be completed. 
(Code 1959, § 3-21) 
Sec. 6-34. - Same-Copies to be furnished fire department, ambulance operators. 
    It shall be the duty of the city building inspector to furnish a copy of such permit to the city fire department and to all persons operating ambulances within said city. 
(Code 1959, § 3-21) 
Sec. 6-35. - Moving to be continuous. 
    After any building shall be moved upon the streets of the city, the moving thereof shall be continuous until such moving shall be completed and the building located on its new location. 
(Code 1959, § 3-21) 
Sec. 6-36. - Speed limits for vehicles; weight limitation. 
    When said building is being moved over a paved way the rate of any travel and the moving of any building shall not exceed three (3) miles per hour. Supporting truck wheels when not running on the track shall be limited to one and one-half (11/2) tons per wheel load; and when track ways are provided for wheels, the limit of load per wheel shall not exceed two and one-fourth (21/4) tons, provided that track for truck wheels shall not be less than three (3) inches thick, twelve (12) inches wide and twelve (12) feet long, of sound pine, free from knots, and be laid flat on the pavement surface. 
(Code 1959, § 3-19) 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations generally, Ch. 28. 
Sec. 6-37. - Removal of utility wires, poles. 
    Before any permit shall be issued for the moving of any building, the applicant for such permit shall make satisfactory proof to the city building inspector that proper arrangements have been made with public service companies whose wires or poles may be affected by such moving for the removal of obstructing wires or poles. 
(Code 1959, § 3-20) 
Cross reference- Utility poles, wires, etc., Ch. 30, Art. V. 
Sec. 6-38. - Unlawful to violate provisions of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carelessly or negligently move such building, so as to cause damage or injury to any public or private property or to violate any provision of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 3-17) 
Chapter 7 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Park and cemetery department established, § 2-27. 
State Law reference- Municipal cemeteries generally, 8 O.S. 1961, § 41 et seq.; authority of city to pass rules and ordinances regulating, protecting and governing cemeteries, 8 O.S. 1961, § 47. 
Annotation- Former § 44a of Chapter 8, Oklahoma Statutes which required county excise board to levy not to exceed one-half mill for cemetery purposes, was held unconstitutional as violating Const. art. 10, § 9, limiting ad valorem taxes to fifteen mills since the statute, in effect, undertook to raise taxes to 151/2 mills. City of Ardmore v. Excise Board of Carter County, 200 Oklahoma 516, 197p. 2d 961. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Rose Hill Cemetery-Boundaries, official name designated. 
(a)  The boundaries of Rose Hill Cemetery shall be as follows: 
    Lots 30 and 31, Block 3, Floradale Addition; West half of the Southwest Quarter of Southeast Quarter; the South 6 acres of Southwest Quarter of Northwest Quarter of Southeast Quarter; East Half of Southeast Quarter of Southwest Quarter; the South 6 acres of Southeast Quarter of Northeast Quarter of Southwest Quarter; and the West 17.13 acres of the West Half of Southeast Quarter of Southwest Quarter; and Southeast 4.3 acres of Southwest Quarter of Northeast Quarter of Southwest Quarter; all in Section 6, Township 5 South, Range 2 East, Carter County, Oklahoma, containing 90.93 acres more or less; and North Half of Northeast Quarter of Northwest Quarter of Section 7, Township 5 South, Range 2 East, Carter County, Oklahoma, containing 20 acres. 
(b)  Both of the above described tracts are officially named "Rose Hill Cemetery." 
(Code 1959, § 5-1) 
Sec. 7-2. - Same-Park and cemetery department to supervise. 
    The park and cemetery department, subject to the city manager, shall have control and supervision of the cemeteries belonging to the city, the same being what is known as Rose Hill Cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 5-1)

Sec. 7-4. - Clearview Cemetery-Boundaries. 
    The cemetery known as Clearview Cemetery, and hereby officially designated as such, shall consist of: 
    South Half of Southwest Quarter of Southwest Quarter of Section 21, Township 4 South, Range 2 East, Carter County, Oklahoma, consisting of twenty (20) acres. 
(Code 1959, § 5-3) 
Sec. 7-5. - Same-Park and cemetery department to supervise. 
    The Clearview Cemetery shall be under the direct supervision and control of the park and cemetery department, subject to the city manager. 
(Code 1059, § 5-3) 
Sec. 7-6. - Same-Burial spaces and prices therefor; charges for opening, closing graves and other services. 
(a)  Burial spaces and prices therefor in Clearview Cemetery are hereby established as follows:

(Ord. No. 1660, § 3, 2-15-71; Ord. No. 1861, §§ 1, 2, 8-15-77; Ord. No. 2050, § 3, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2241, § 1, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 2440, § 2, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95; Ord. No. 2682, § 3, 5-21-01)

No. 1660, § 4, adopted February 15, 1971; Ord. No. 1860, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 15, 1977 and Ord. No. 2050, § 4, adopted December 21, 1981. 
Sec. 7-6.2. - Charges for services in privately owned cemeteries. 
    Charges for opening and closing graves in privately owned cemeteries adjoining Rose Hill Cemetery shall be as follows:
