(Ord. No. 2050, § 5, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2241, § 1, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95; Ord. No. 2682, § 4, 5-21-01) 
Sec. 7-7. - City to have police power over cemeteries. 
    The city shall have police control of each of said cemeteries. The city manager shall have the power to, delegate to personnel of the park and cemetery department, the power of a policeman in arresting any person detected or seen violating any law or regulation pertaining to the cemetery over which they have charge. 
(Code 1959, § 5-5) 
Sec. 7-8. - Perpetual care fund; established; disposition of moneys. 
    Not less than twenty-five (25) per cent of all moneys received from the sale of lots and interments shall be segregated and set aside as a permanent fund to be known as a "perpetual care fund" together with the present perpetual care fund as formerly established. Said fund or any part thereof may by proper ordinance or resolution passed by the board of commissioners be invested in United States Government bonds or bonds of the state; and the interest received therefrom may be used in improving, caring for and embellishing the roads, walks, drives and parks and the necessary improvements on each respective cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 5-6) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see 8 O.S. 1961, § 51. 
Sec. 7-9. - Cemetery lots-City manager to supervise; certificate issued to purchasers. 
    All lots in the above described cemeteries will be under the supervision of the city manager. When a lot is sold by the city to a purchaser, a certificate will be issued to the person making the purchase granting to said purchaser the right and privilege of using said lot exclusively for the purpose of burying members of his family or any other person so designated by the owner of the lot in writing. A cemetery lot may be sold by the owner to another individual; however, this sale will not be deemed valid unless the original certificate is returned to the city and transfer fee is paid for new certificate issued. The city will redeem or repurchase three (3) or more consecutive grave spaces from the original owner or presentation of certificate to the city manager at three-fourths of the present price for the spaces. (Code 1959, § 5-7; Ord. No. 2134, § 1, 12-19-83; Ord. No. 2177, § 1, 11-5-84) 
State Law reference- Conveyance of lots by city, 8 O.S. 1961, § 46. 
Sec. 7-10. - Same-Application for purchase; designated by city manager. 
    Applicants interested in buying a lot shall contact the city manager or a representative appointed by the city manager to obtain a description of the lot and block desired, which said lot shall be purchased at a location designated by the city manager. The city manager or his designee shall keep a file of all lots showing the same by plat together with the cost of the lot. Such lot shall be sold on the same and equal terms to applicants on request to the city manager or his designee and upon payment of the price for the same without discrimination. The city manager or his designee shall issue the cemetery lot certificates mentioned in section 7-9 hereinabove. 
(Code 1959, § 5-8; Ord. No. 2339, § I, 10-1-90) 
Sec. 7-10.1. - Same-Legality and validity of certificates. 
    All cemetery lot certificates issued prior to the adoption of this section, as shown by the official certificate records maintained by the city, shall be deemed legal and valid. 
(Ord. No. 2339, § I, 10-1-90) 
Sec. 7-11. - Monuments and markers defined. 
    Any memorial structure rising above the surface of the ground shall be considered a monument. A marker is a stone or bronze tablet installed flush with the surface of the ground to indicate the location of the grave. Monuments and markers shall be constructed of granite, marble or bronze; or other material approved by the city manager or his designate. 
(Code 1959, § 5-9; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-12. - Flowers, vases, trees, bushes and shrubs. 
    In both Rose Hill and Clear View Cemetery, two (2) flower vases may be used. Flower vases must be attached to the monument base, monument concrete foundation, or a concrete foundation adjacent to the monument foundation. Flower vases not attached to the monument base, monument concrete foundation, or a concrete foundation adjacent to the monument foundation may, after a reasonable time, be removed by cemetery maintenance personnel. Flowers and decorations may be hung in "saddles" on the monument or upon the end of the monument base. 
    No permanent flowers, trees, bushes or shrubs may be planted in any section in either cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 5-10; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-13. - Markers; requirements generally. 
    All lots in Rose Hill Cemetery and Clear View Cemetery shall be so arranged that in addition to the monument there is room for one (1) marker for each burial space. Markers shall be not less than ten (10) inches or over twelve (12) inches in width and not less than eighteen (18) inches or over twenty-four (24) inches in length surface measurement and set flush with the surface of the ground, except in lots in the old section of the cemetery where new markers may be made to conform with those already erected or placed. Only one (1) marker shall be allowed to each grave and it shall be placed at the head of the grave flush with the ground, except as required in section 7-23. 
(Code 1959, § 5-11; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-14. - Monuments; requirements generally. 
    All monuments in Rose Hill Cemetery and Clear View Cemetery must have at least five (5) inches extension concrete base flush with the ground and be approved by the city manager or his designate before the monument is installed. All monuments with family name only placed on one-fourth (1/4) or one-half (1/2) lots must be placed at rear of lot, on all full lots the monument must be placed at the center of the lot. 
(Code 1959, § 5-12; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-15. - Curbs, grave covers, benches and height of mounds. 
    In both Rose Hill Cemetery and Clear View Cemetery, all cornerstones (lot markers) must be installed in concrete and must be installed flush with the ground. 
    No curbs shall be allowed and no mound shall ever be raised above the uniform grade of four (4) inches. The city manager or his designate shall have the authority to remove dangerous or unsightly curbs, cornerstones or other hazards from the cemetery. Concrete grave covers will not be permitted unless the grave cover is an integral part of the concrete burial vault or concrete grave liner. Benches will not be permitted unless bench is installed and inscribed to designate the burial space of an individual. The bench must meet the requirements of section 7-14. 
(Code 1959, § 5-13; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-16. - Monument and marker installation to be approved. 
    The installation of any monument, marker, vases, cornerstones or other structures shall be under the supervision of the city manager or his designate. The city manager or his designate shall be notified before the installation of any monument, marker, vases, cornerstones or other structures in the cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 5-14; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-17. - Opening, closing graves on Sunday-Prohibited; exception. 
    It is the policy of the city to prohibit the city and its employees from opening and closing graves on Sunday for the burial of the dead, except in extreme emergency affecting the health and safety of the community. 
(Code 1959, § 5-15) 
Sec. 7-18. - Same-Authority of city manager to permit. 
    In cases where the city manager finds that it is an extreme emergency to either open or close a grave on Sunday or a legal holiday, the city manager shall have the power and the right to declare an emergency and permit an exception to the above provisions and permit a grave to be opened and closed on Sunday or a legal holiday. 
(Code 1959, § 5-16; Ord. No. 2241, § 1, 11-17-86) 
Sec. 7-18.1. - Funerals on Sundays, legal holidays. 
    Except as is provided by sections 7-17 and 7-18 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Ardmore, funerals on Sundays and legal holidays are hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1660, § 5, 2-15-71) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1660, § 5 did not expressly amend this Code, hence its codification as § 7-18.1 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 7-19. - Burial of paupers. 
    When any person shall hereafter die within the city limits leaving no funds or other property out of which to pay the expense of a certificate for a cemetery lot for the burial of such person, upon an affidavit stating such facts being signed by the next of kin of such deceased person, or in lieu thereof, by the person in charge of the burial of such deceased person, and the presentation thereof to the city clerk, such city clerk shall, without charge, issue a burial certificate authorizing the burial of such deceased person on a lot, such lot to be designated by the city clerk, in Rose Hill Cemetery. Provided, however, if thereafter any assets of such deceased person be found sufficient to pay the customary charge for such burial certificate, the city shall have a first and prior lien upon any and all assets belonging to such deceased person until such charge is paid. 
(Code 1959, § 5-17) 
Sec. 7-20. - Speed limit on cemetery roads. 
    It shall be unlawful to ride or drive through any municipally owned cemetery except on the driveways therein, and then at a speed of not more than ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Code 1959, § 5-18) 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations generally, Ch. 28. 
Sec. 7-21. - Injuring, defacing, removing, etc. cemetery property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or remove any tree, shrub or plant, or to pluck flowers from any lot, or to deface any monument, tombstone, ornament on any grave, or any fence, curbing or railing around any grave, lot or part of lot, or to remove any ornament at any grave, or to damage anything whatsoever in such cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 5-18) 
Secs. 7-21.1, 7-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2499, § 1, adopted July 17, 1995, repealed §§ 7-21.1 and 7-22 which pertained to flowers, vases, trees, bushes and shrubs and jurisdiction outside city limits derived from Code 1959, § 5-19; Ord. No. 1660, § 6, adopted February 15, 1971 and Ord. No. 2178, § 1, adopted November 5, 1984. 
Sec. 7-23. - Rules and regulations governing third addition to Rose Hill Cemetery. 
(a)  The third addition to Rose Hill Cemetery has been platted into lots and blocks shown on the recorded plat and survey thereof. The blocks are numbered three (3) through twenty-six (26). Each lot in these blocks contains twelve (12) grave spaces. 
(b)  Monuments and markers of any size and type will be permitted only in the third addition of Rose Hill Cemetery. Markers must be flush with the ground and placed at the head of the grave in compliance with section 7-13. Monuments will be placed at the foot of the grave in compliance with Section 7-14. 
(Ord. No. 2120, § 1, 7-18-83; Ord. No. 2499, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-24. - Abandoned lots to be reverted to the municipality. 
    All abandoned lots or parts of lots located in any city-owned cemeteries shall revert to the Municipality. An abandoned lot is defined as a lot or any part thereof which has not been used for fifty (50) years from the date of its original sale by the City of Ardmore to the purchaser. Before any lot or portion thereof shall be deemed to have been abandoned and to have reverted to the city the following procedure shall be followed: 
    A notice shall be prepared naming the last known cemetery lot certificate holder, describing the particular cemetery lot it is alleged has been abandoned and stating that unless the certificate holder presents the certificate or other appropriate evidence of ownership to the office of the city manager of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, within ninety (90) days from the date of the first publication of the notice in the Daily Ardmoreite, that the cemetery lot or portion thereof will be deemed to be abandoned and the title to the lot will revert to the City of Ardmore free and clear of any claims, right or title of the certificate holder. That notice will be published in its entirety two (2) consecutive weeks in the Daily Ardmoreite. In addition, the notice will be mailed to the last known address of the certificate holder. After the ninety (90) days prescribed in the notice has expired the cemetery advisory board will make a recommendation as to whether the lot should be deemed abandoned to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore. The board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore will then determine if the lot or portion thereof is to be deemed abandoned. If so, the city's cemetery records will be amended to reflect that the lot has been abandoned and the title vested in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. The city will then have the right to sell or convey the lot or portion thereof to a new certificate holder who will take free and clear of any right of the previous certificate holder or his heirs, assigns or successors. 
(Ord. No. 2478, § 1, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 7-25. - Outside container requirements. 
    A concrete box minimum outside container will be required at Rose Hill Cemetery and Clearview Cemetery. The exception being pre-need plans sold prior to adoption of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2499, § 3, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 7-26. - Burial spaces for veterans. 
    Burial spaces in all City Cemeteries for Veterans of the Armed Forces of the United States of America are free in the veteran sections. Proof of military service must be provided to the city cemetery office before opening of grave site. Spouses of veterans may also reserve a space next to their spouse which grave site for spouses of veterans shall be paid in full to the cemetery department within ninety (90) days from the date of reservation. 
(Ord. No. 2640, § II, 3-6-00) 
Secs. 7-27-7-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL CEMETERY ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2055, adopted May 17, 1982, amended this Code, but did not specify the manner thereof; hence inclusion herein as Ch. 7, Art. II, §§ 7-31-7-45, was at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 7-31. - Created. 
    There is hereby established by the city commission a board which shall be known as the municipal cemetery advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-32. - Composition. 
    The municipal cemetery advisory board shall be composed of five (5) persons who shall be citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82; Ord. No. 2627, § I, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 7-33. - Appointment of board members. 
    The board shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city commission. All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular commission meeting each May. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-34. - Terms of members generally. 
    The members of the board shall serve a term of three (3) years provided, however, that on the first board two (2) members shall serve three (3) years, and two (2) members shall serve two (2) years, and two (2) members shall serve one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-35. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor by and with the consent of the city commissioners may remove any member at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-36. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board occasioned by removal, resignation, or otherwise shall be filled in like manner as original appointment, except that if the vacancy is for any unexpired term, the appointment shall be made for only the unexpired part of such term. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-37. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-38. - Meetings. 
    The board shall hold at least six (6) meetings per year and adjourn meetings when necessary; all meetings of the board shall be public. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-39. - Organization. 
    There shall be a president, vice-president, and secretary of the board, selected from the members of the board, elected by the board, and at its pleasure, removed. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-40. - Rules. 
    The board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the government of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-41. - Record of proceedings. 
    The board shall keep and preserve a true record of all of its proceedings and official acts, and said record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-42. - Report to city commission. 
    The board shall, on or before the second Monday of April each year, make a report to the city commission on the usage, conditions, operation and other information that may be requested by the commission or the board wishes to provide for better operations of the municipal cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-43. - Budget. 
    Immediately prior to April of each year, the board shall prepare and submit to the city commission an annual budget, which includes the necessary expenses for operation, maintenance, repair, and improvement of the municipal cemeteries for the ensuring fiscal year. The mayor and city commission may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portion of such budget as is not defrayed from the income of the municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-44. - Additional duties. 
    The board shall, in addition to the annual budget, make recommendations for the care and maintenance of the cemeteries, fees for services, charges for burial spaces, and policies and regulations for the general operation of the municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Sec. 7-45. - Attendance reports, replacement of members for failure to attend meetings. 
    The president of the board shall report to the mayor on a semiannual basis the attendance record of the members of the board. The president shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meetings during the six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2055, § 1, 5-17-82) 
Cross reference- Attendance at meetings by board members, § 2-3.1. 
Chapter 8 - CIVIL DEFENSE ORGANIZATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Civil defense generally, 63 O.S. 1961, Ch. 17; authority of city to establish local civil defense organization, 63 O.S. 1961, § 672. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Purpose; duty. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to create a civil defense organization for the city to be prepared for, and to function in the event of, emergencies endangering the lives and property of the people of such city. 
(b)  Duty. The duty of such civil defense organization shall be the protection of the lives and health of the citizens of the city and of property and property rights, both private and public, and to perform all functions necessary and incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 1, 9-15-61) 
Sec. 8-2. - Established; title; composition. 
    There is hereby established under the executive branch of the government of the city a civil defense organization, entitled the "Civil Defense Organization", which shall consist of: 
(a)  Director of civil defense. A director of civil defense who shall be appointed by the chief of police of the city and confirmed by the city manager and serve at his pleasure. 
(b)  Civil defense advisory committee. This committee shall consist of the city manager as chairman and five (5) members appointed by the chief of police and confirmed by the city manager and the city commission and serving at their pleasure. The committee shall select from its members a vice-chairman and secretary. It shall hold such meetings as are directed by the chief of police and its functions shall be to act in an advisory capacity as needed or requested by the chief of police or the director of civil defense. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 2, 9-15-61; Ord. No. 2514, § I, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 8-3. - Chief of police to be executive head; duties. 
    The chief of police shall be the executive head of the civil defense organization and shall be responsible for carrying out the civil defense program of the city on a city-county basis. He shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 3, 9-15-61; Ord. No. 2514, § I, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 8-4. - Director-Duties prescribed. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of civil defense as soon as practicable after his appointment to perfect an organization to carry out the purposes set forth in this chapter and he shall have all necessary power and authority to form committees or other bodies and to appoint and designate the chairman or chief officer of such bodies as may be necessary to perfect such organization. He shall have such further duty and responsibility to cooperate with all civil defense agencies of other governmental units including the state and federal government. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 3, 9-15-61) 
State Law reference- Local organizations to have director, 63 O.S. 1961, § 672. 
Sec. 8-5. - Same-Formulation of plans; records. 
    The director of civil defense is further authorized to formulate written plans and gather information and keep written record thereof to govern the functions of the civil defense organization. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 4, 9-15-61) 
Sec. 8-6. - Powers of police chief, director during emergency. 
(a)  In the event of an enemy-caused emergency or emergency resulting from natural causes, the director of civil defense after due authorization from the chief of police shall have the power and authority to enforce all rules and regulations relating to civil defense, and, if necessary, take control of transportation, communications, stocks of fuel, food, clothing, medicine, and public utilities for the purpose of protecting the civilian population. He shall cooperate in every way with the activities of other governmental agencies or civil defense organizations; and, if required by the commission, shall have control over any and all funds allocated from any source for the purpose of alleviating distress conditions in the city. 
(b)  The director of civil defense and other members of the civil defense organization created shall have the power and authority to enforce the laws of the state and ordinances of the city during the period of emergency and shall at such time have the further power to make arrests for violation of such laws or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1376, §§ 5, 6, 9-15-61; Ord. No. 2514, § I, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 8-7. - Compensation of members; liability of city. 
(a)  All members of the civil defense organization created hereunder, except the director, shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  The city shall not be liable for any personal injury received by any member of such organization while acting in the line of duty. 
(Ord. No. 1376, § 7, 9-15-61) 
Secs. 8-8-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ARDMORE/CARTER COUNTY CIVIL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2399, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-7 as Ch. 8, Art. II, §§ 8-21-8-27 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 8-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to create an Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management agency for the City of Ardmore to be prepared for, and to function in the event of, emergencies endangering the lives and property of the people of such city. The duty of such Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency shall be the protection of the lives and health of the citizens of Ardmore and of property and property rights, both private and public, and to perform all functions necessary and incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 1, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 8-22. - Membership. 
    There is hereby established under the executive branch of the government of the City of Ardmore, an Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency which shall consist of: 
(1)  A director of civil emergency management who shall be appointed by the chief of police and confirmed by the city manager and the city commission and serve at his pleasure. 
(2)  A civil emergency management advisory committee. This committee shall consist of the chief of police as chairman and five (5) members appointed by the chief of police and confirmed by the city manager and the city commission and serving at his pleasure. The committee shall select from its members a vice-chairman and secretary. It shall hold such meetings as are directed by the chief of police and its functions shall be to act in an advisory capacity as needed or requested by the chief of police or the director of civil emergency management. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 2, 12-21-92; Ord. No. 2514, § I, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 8-23. - Director-Designated; duties. 
    The city hereby establishes a civil emergency management agency entitled the Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency. The chief of police shall be the executive head of the Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency and shall be responsible for carrying out the civil emergency management program of the city on a city-county basis. He shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. It shall be the duty of the director of the civil emergency management agency as soon as practicable after his appointment to perfect an organization to carry out the purposes set forth in this ordinance and he shall have all necessary power and authority to form committees or other bodies and to appoint and designate the chairman or chief officer of such bodies as may be necessary to perfect such organization. He shall have such further duty and responsibility to cooperate with all civil emergency management agencies of other governmental units, including the State of Oklahoma and federal government. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 3, 12-21-92; Ord. No. 2514, § I, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 8-24. - Same-Authorized to formulate written plans and gather information and keep written record. 
    The director of the Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management agency is further authorized to formulate written plans and gather information and keep written record thereof to govern the functions of the civil emergency management agency. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 4, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 8-25. - Same-Enforcement of rules and regulations in the event of emergency. 
    In the event of an enemy-caused emergency or emergency resulting from natural causes, the director of civil emergency management, after due authorization from the city manager, shall have the power and authority to enforce all rules and regulations relating to civil emergency management, and, if necessary, take control of transportation, communications, stocks of fuel, food, clothing, medicine, and public utilities for the purpose of protecting the civilian population. He shall cooperate in every way with the activities of other governmental agencies or civil emergency management organization; and if required by the commission shall have control over any and all funds allocated from any source for the purpose of alleviating distress conditions in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 5, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 8-26. - Director and other members to have power to enforce laws of state and during emergency. 
    The director of the Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency and other members of the civil emergency management agency created shall have the power and authority to enforce the laws of the State of Oklahoma and ordinances of the City of Ardmore during the period of emergency and shall at such time have the further power to make arrests for violating of such laws or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 6, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 8-27. - Members other than director to serve without compensation. 
    All members of the Ardmore/Carter County Civil Emergency Management Agency created hereunder, except the director, shall serve without compensation and the city shall not be liable for any personal injury received by any member of such agency while acting in the line of duty. 
(Ord. No. 2399, § 7, 12-21-92) 
Chapter 9 - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1713, §§ 1-48, adopted July 2, 1973, is included herein as superseding former Ch. 9, §§ 9-1-9-40, setting forth the electrical code of the city. Said former Ch. 9 was derived from Code 1959, §§ 3-61-3-93, 3-95. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; gas code, Ch. 12; housing, Ch. 14; plumbing code, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 30; electric franchise, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  Electrical inspector shall mean the chief electrical inspector of the City of Ardmore, or any of his duly authorized assistants. 
(b)  Electrical contractor shall mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of installing, repairing or altering electrical wiring, or nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus in the City of Ardmore, and who has complied with the terms of this chapter. 
(c)  Journeyman wireman shall mean any person qualified under the provisions of this chapter to engage in the installing or repairing of electric wiring or installing nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus in the City of Ardmore, and who has complied with the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  Apprentice wireman shall mean any person who is learning the electric wiring trade and who is competent to assist, under the supervision of a journeyman wireman, in the work of installing or repairing electric wiring or installing nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus. 
(e)  Electric wiring. The term "electric wiring" as used in this chapter means the installation of electrical raceways, conductors or apparatus of any kind used, or to be used in or on any building for the transmission and distribution of electric current for electric light, heat or power, or nonportable electrical fixtures and apparatus of any nature to be connected to light, heat or power service; provided however, that the words "electric wiring", "electrical equipment" and "apparatus" shall not be deemed to include or refer to service lines, apparatus, and equipment for the sale, distribution, and regulation of electricity and remaining the property of the electric service company, or for telephone, telegraph, or other communication purposes, or in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 1, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-2. - Separability of provisions. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this code is, for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. The board of commissioners hereby declare that it would have adopted this code and each section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, clauses, phrases or portions, be declared invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 47, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-3. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this code or who shall do that which is prohibited or who shall refuse or fail to do that which is commanded, shall be cited for an offense and shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine in an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) including costs; provided that each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. Specifically, but not by way of limitation of the general penalty provision hereof, the following acts are prohibited, and any person convicted thereof shall be fined an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) including costs; provided that each of such violations shall constitute a separate offense: 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall do or cause to be done or permit any of its officers or employees to do any electrical work within the City of Ardmore without first having obtained an electrical construction permit thereof from the office of the electrical inspector. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall cause or permit any employee who is not a journeyman possessing a certificate of competency issued by the city electrical inspector or a registered apprentice as required under this code, to do any electrical work within the City of Ardmore. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall do any electrical work within the City of Ardmore, who is not a journeyman with a current certificate of competency as a journeyman electrician or who is not a registered apprentice as provided in this article. 
(d)  No person, firm or corporation shall permit one or more apprentices to work on any job or project without direct personal supervision by a journeyman electrician. 
(e)  No person, firm or corporation shall permit more than three (3) apprentices to work under the supervision of one journeyman electrician. 
(f)  No apprentice shall do any electrical work within the City of Ardmore except under the direct supervision of a journeyman electrician. 
(g)  No apprentice shall do any electrical work within the City of Ardmore in conjunction with more than two (2) other such apprentices under the supervision of the same journeyman electrician. 
(h)  No journeyman electrician or apprentice shall perform electrical work within the City of Ardmore unless he shall have on his person a current journeyman's certificate of competency or apprentice's certificate of registration, and no journeyman or apprentice, while performing electrical work within the City of Ardmore, shall refuse to display his certificate of registration upon request of the electrical inspector, an assistant electrical inspector or a police officer of the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 48, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-4. - Liability. 
    Inspections by City of Ardmore inspectors are made to determine in general if the work is proceeding in accordance with the ordinances of the City of Ardmore. 
    The City of Ardmore or city inspectors will not be responsible for the contractor's failure to carry out the work in accordance with plans and specifications and applicable regulations set forth by national, state, and local laws, codes and ordinances. 
    No officer, agent or employee of the City of Ardmore charged with the enforcement of the electrical code shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this code. No person who institutes, or assists in the prosecution of, a criminal proceeding under this code shall be liable to damages hereunder unless he acted with actual malice and without reasonable grounds for believing that the person accused or prosecuted was guilty of an unlawful act or omission. Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or employee of the municipality, as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this code, shall be defended by the legal representative of the municipality until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 46, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-5. - Office of chief electrical inspector created; appointment, qualifications of inspector. 
    There is hereby created the office of chief electrical inspector. The chief electrical inspector shall be appointed by the city manager. He shall have a state electrical contractor's license, and shall not be interested, either directly or indirectly in any firm or corporation engaged in electrical business within the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 48, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-6. - Duties of electrical inspectors generally. 
    The electrical inspector shall be charged with the duty of enforcing the electrical code as contained in the ordinances of the City of Ardmore. The electrical inspector shall have the power and it shall be his duty to inspect, or reinspect all overhead, underground and interior wires and apparatus conducting electrical current for any of the purposes set forth in the electrical ordinances of the City of Ardmore. When such conductors or apparatus are found to be unsafe to life or property, he shall notify the person, firm or corporation owning, using or operating the same, to place them in a safe condition. If the owner, user or operator of such defective wiring or equipment shall refuse or fail to comply with the requirements of the electrical inspector and correct all defects as directed within a specified time, it shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to notify, in writing, the service company, firm or individual furnishing the electric current to same. Upon receipt of such notice, the service company, firm or individual furnishing electric current to such defective wiring or equipment shall, within twenty-four (24) hours disconnect the service or feed wire and cease to supply current to the defective installation until the defects have been corrected. 
    When any portion or all of the wiring in or on any building or premises is ordered changed for any reason, the electrical inspector shall leave attached to the main switch or service equipment a tag or label showing the date of the order and a memorandum of the correction to be made, and the signature of the authority making the order. 
    The electrical inspector, in the discharge of his duties, may enter any building or premises at any time during business, or at any reasonable hours and upon the refusal of any owner, agent or occupant to allow such inspection as required of the electrical inspector, he or they shall be cited by law for an offense. 
    He shall also institute, by and with the advice of the city attorney, such prosecutions as may be necessary against any violators of any ordinance, with the enforcement of which he is charged. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 2, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2753, adopted Oct. 6, 2003, repealed § 9-7, which pertained to electrical board of appeal combined and derived from Ord. No. 1713, § 3, adopted July 2, 1973; Ord. No. 1924, § 1, adopted May 31, 1979; Ord. No. 1925, § 1, adopted May 31, 31, 1979; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, adopted March 20, 1984; and Ord. No. 2283, § II, adopted July 5, 1988. 
Sec. 9-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section I of Ord. No. 2283, adopted July 5, 1988, repealed § 9-8, relating to the electrical advisory board and originating from Ord. No. 1713, § 4, adopted July 2, 1973; and Ord. No. 2146, §§ 1, 2, adopted Mar. 20, 1984. 
Sec. 9-9. - Journeyman wiremen. 
    No person shall work as a journeyman wireman in the City of Ardmore, unless he shall have a valid state journeyman license, and shall have such license registered with the City of Ardmore, as provided by this code. 
(Ord. No. 1713, §§ 5, 6, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, §§ 1, 2, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-10. - Electrical contractors. 
(a)  License required. All persons engaged in electrical contractor's business, shall hold a valid state electrical contractor's license, and shall have such license registered with the City of Ardmore, as provided by this code. 
(b)  Effect upon firm of termination of employment. If the electrical contractor associated with a partnership, firm or corporation under the provisions hereof, shall resign, withdraw from or be discharged from such partnership, firm or corporation, then such partnership, firm or corporation shall not engage in business except to fulfill all binding contracts dated prior to termination. 
(c)  Installation or alteration of wiring by contractor. An electrical contractor's license shall not permit the holder thereof to personally install or alter electric wiring, unless he also holds a journeyman wireman's license. 
(d)  Bond requirements. If the applicant for electrical contractor's license shall be found qualified, he shall execute a bond, which he shall renew annually, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in favor of the city for the payment of all fines and penalties imposed upon said electrical contractor for any violation of ordinances of the city relating to electric wiring and all rules and regulations made thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1713, §§ 7, 8, 13, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, §§ 1, 2, 3-20-84) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2146, enacted March 20, 1984, repealed subsections (b), (c) and (e) of § 9-10. Remaining subsections (d), (f) and (g) were redesignated (b), (c) and (d), respectively, at the editor's discretion, as subsection (a) was included by § 1 of said ordinance. 
Sec. 9-11. - Maintenance electrician. 
    No person shall engage in the occupation of maintenance electrician without first being registered with the electrical inspector by the owner or owners of the building or buildings, or by the authorized representative of such owner or owners, such registration showing the name of the employer, the place or places of employment, and certifying that the maintenance electrician named is a regular employee giving his full time to this employer's service. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 9, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-12. - Apprentice. 
    No person shall do any electrical work within the corporate limits of the city who is not an apprentice having a current certificate of registration as an apprentice issued by the state and registered with the city. All apprentices shall carry on their persons at all times, while performing electrical work within the city, their certificates of registration "state and city." Upon request from the electrical inspector of the city or any assistant electrical inspector or police officer of the city, an apprentice performing electrical work shall display his current certificate of registration. The term "apprentice" as used herein includes any helper, laborer, assistant or any other person who does or is found to be doing any type of electrical work, including the installation or removal of any electrical equipment. No fee shall be required for such registration. The office of electrical inspector, upon acceptance for such registration, shall issue a certificate of registration to each registrant. Such registration shall authorize such apprentice to do electrical work in the city, provided such work is done under the direct personal supervision of a licensed journeyman at all times. Such supervision shall be defined as the doing of work within sight and audible communication with a journeyman electrician. No work shall be done by an apprentice when not in the presence of and under the supervision of a journeyman. No more than three (3) apprentices shall perform electrical work at the same time under the supervision of one (1) journeyman electrician. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 10, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-13. - Electricians to register with the city: Fee, expiration, renewal of registration. 
    All persons engaged in electrical work within the city shall register with the city. The amount of such fee (or fees) shall be as established in Chapter 34, the General Schedule of Fees. 
    All registrations shall expire June 30th of each year. 
    If registrations have not been renewed within thirty (30) days after expiration date, the first year fee shall be charged. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 11, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84; Ord. No. 2715, 6-16-02; Ord. No. 3043, § I, 8-20-18 ) 
Sec. 9-14. - Transfer of license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, holding a license to transfer same or allow the use of same, directly or indirectly by any other person for the purpose of obtaining a permit to do any of the electrical work herein specified. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 12, 7-2-73) 
Secs. 9-15-9-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS; INSPECTIONS; FEES 

Sec. 9-21. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall do, or cause to be done, any interior or exterior electrical wiring, or any electrical construction, electrical installation or alteration of any electrical wiring, apparatus or fixtures within the City of Ardmore without first having obtained an electrical construction permit number for the work from the office of the electrical inspector. A permit for such work shall not be issued to any person, firm or corporation that has failed to comply with the provisions of the ordinances of the City of Ardmore. Permits to do electrical work shall be issued only to licensed electrical contractors. Permits shall not be required for maintenance work or for repair work if the maintenance and repair work does not require alteration or rearrangement of electrical installation. 
    Applicants for permits, as required herein shall, prior to doing any work requiring a permit, call the office of the electrical inspector of the City of Ardmore, and give the name of the electrical contractor who is to do such work and the address where the work is to be done. 
    Any electrical contractor who proceeds to do work herein described requiring a permit, without following the provisions of this section shall be assessed double the amount of the fee which should have been paid, which sum shall be deducted from his bond if not otherwise paid. 
    If the electrical inspector of the City of Ardmore or any of his assistants finds electrical work in progress on any job for which no electrical construction permit has been issued, he shall immediately order all such electrical work to cease, and any person who thereafter does electrical work on such job before an electrical construction permit has been issued therefor shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 14, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-22. - Issuance of permit. 
    Upon compliance with the provisions of section 9-21 and prior to final inspection of said work by the electrical inspector, it shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to issue a permit permitting such person, firm or corporation to perform the electrical work covered by said application, provided the plans for same conform to or comply with the ordinances of the City of Ardmore and the office of the electrical inspector shall charge the electrical contractor with the amount of the proper fees. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 15, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-23. - Exemptions. 
    Inspections, certificates, licenses, permits, and bonds, as herein required, shall not be required in connection with work performed by or for electric utilities, electric railways, telephone or telegraph companies, engaged only in their own business and not engaged in performing electrical work as an electrical contractor for the public generally, where such electric wiring, devices, apparatus or equipment is an integral part of the facilities used in rendering public utility service. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 16, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-24. - Plans and specifications. 
    The office of the electrical inspector may require from any electrical contractor, a set of plans and specifications for any proposed electrical job, in order that the electrical inspector may check such plans and specifications to determine if the proposed electrical installations will comply with the ordinances of the City of Ardmore. If requested by the electrical contractor, the electrical inspector may render a decision in writing on such plans and specifications within five (5) days, after receiving the same, as to whether or not the electrical installation, as set out in such plans, complies with the ordinances of the City of Ardmore. 
    The electrical inspector shall have and is hereby given authority to refuse to issue a permit for the installation of electric wiring, as herein provided, or for any additions or extensions to any electrical wiring in or on any building where the wiring done or proposed to be done is shown to be unsafe or not in accordance with the provisions of this code. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 17, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-25. - Building permits. 
    Approval of plans and specifications for purpose of issuing an electrical permit by the City of Ardmore shall not relieve the owner or his agents of responsibility for errors of any kind in drawings and specifications and for compliance with applicable codes. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 18, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-26. - Inspection required. 
    When any electrical work is done for which a permit is required under section 9-21 then said work shall be inspected by the electrical inspector or one of his assistants. There shall be a rough-in and final inspection required and a temporary service inspection if needed. If such work is not done in such a manner and with such materials as required by this electrical code, the inspector shall require the work to be redone to comply with the electrical code, and if such work is not redone to comply with the electrical code, then the electrical inspector may order the electric utility company to disconnect electrical service to the premises in which such defective work is situated. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 19, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-27. - Request for inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of electrical contractors and any others holding permits to do electrical work, to notify the office of the electrical inspector as soon as any electrical work is ready for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 20, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-28. - Time of inspection. 
    The electrical inspector, or one of his assistants, shall in all cases, inspect any and all new electrical wiring within twenty-four (24) hours after receipt of notice from the permit holder that the work is complete and ready for inspection, said period not to include Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 21, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-29. - Temporary certificate. 
    When, for good and sufficient cause, it is necessary to have electrical energy available at any installation before a final certificate can be issued, the electrical inspector shall, if the parts to which the current is to be applied are in safe and satisfactory condition, issue a temporary certificate. The issuance of such temporary certificate shall constitute the grant of authority to the electric utility company to provide electrical energy to the installation. When a temporary service is installed satisfactorily to the electrical inspector, the electric utility company will not be permitted to make a connection to permanent service until after a final inspection certificate has been issued. There shall be a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each temporary certificate issued, to be renewed each thirty-day period with a fee of three dollars ($3.00) each time until such time permanent service has been approved. In the event an appeal is taken to the electrical board of appeal of a decision of the electrical inspector, while temporary service is being supplied, there will be no fee assessed. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 22, 7-2-73; Ord. No. 2146, § 1, 3-20-84) 
Sec. 9-30. - Final certificate. 
    On the completion of the work covered by a permit as herein set forth, if such work is performed according to the provisions of this electrical code, the electrical inspector shall issue a certificate of approval and therein certify that the electrical work is in accordance with the electrical code of the City of Ardmore. Provided, however, that whenever a permit is issued for any new wiring as an addition to old existing wiring or work, which existing work does not comply with this electrical code, but is of at least No. 14 size wire on fifteen (15) ampere circuits, then said electrical inspector shall issue a certificate of approval without requiring the replacement of such existing wiring and other electrical fixtures, provided the new work for which the permit was issued complies with this electrical code, and provided, further that the existing wiring is of sufficient capacity so as not to be dangerous to life or property. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 23, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-31. - Turn-on of electricity. 
    No electric utility company shall connect to any electrical installation of any kind whatsoever, until furnished with a certificate of approval providing for such connection duly executed by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 24, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-32. - Notice of rejection. 
    When a job has been rejected by the office of the electrical inspector or electrical work condemned by the electrical inspector, a letter shall be delivered to the owner of the premises on which the inspection work is done, or the electrical contractor doing the electrical work, or both, specifically setting out what it required to place the electrical portion of the premises in condition for approval by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 25, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-33. - Alteration after inspection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter any electric work after its final inspection without obtaining a permit, the same as required for original installation, repair or alteration. 
(Ord. No. 1713, § 26, 7-2-73) 
Sec. 9-34. - Inspection fees. 
    In order to secure a permit for the installation of electric wiring, any licensed electrical contractor, before beginning any electrical work, shall make application to the electrical inspector and shall pay the inspection fee required by the following schedule: 
Fee 
Roughing in and finishing outlets: 
5 outlets or less ..... $3.50 
All outlets over 5 ..... 0.25 
Minimum charge for any inspection ..... 7.50 
Motors: 
0 to 3 hp ..... 2.00 
Over 3 hp to 71/2 hp ..... 3.00 
Over 71/2 hp to 20 hp ..... 3.50 
Over 20 hp to 100 hp ..... 4.50 
Over 100 hp ..... 6.00 
Generators: Same as motors: 
Compute into hp using 750 watts per hp 
Electric range: 
Up to 1500 watts, each ..... $1.00 
Over 1500 watts, each ..... 1.00 
Electrical heating equipment: 
Each 5 kw ..... 1.00 
First transformer ..... 2.00 
Each additional transformer ..... 1.00 
Elevators: Stipulated fee for motors
