At the time of mailing of notice to any property owner or mortgage holder, the city shall obtain a receipt of mailing from the postal service, which receipt shall indicate the date of mailing and the name and address of the mailee. However, if neither the property owner nor mortgage holder can be located, notice may be given by posting a copy of the notice on the property, or by publication notice in the Daily Ardmoreite. Such notice must be published once not less than ten (10) days prior to any hearing or action by the city pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(2)  A hearing shall be held by the governing body to determine if the property is dilapidated and has become detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the general public and the community, or if said property creates a fire hazard which is dangerous to other property. 
(3)  Pursuant to a finding that the condition of the property constitutes a detriment or a hazard and that the property would be benefited by the removal of such conditions, the governing body may cause the dilapidated building to be torn down and removed. The governing body shall fix reasonable dates for the commencement and completion of the work. The municipal clerk shall immediately file a notice of dilapidation and lien with the county clerk describing the property, the findings of the municipality at the hearing, and stating that the city claims a lien on said property for the destruction and removal costs and that such costs are the personal obligation of the property owner from and after the date of filing of said notice. The agents of the city are granted the right of entry on the property for the performance of the necessary duties as a governmental function of the city if the work is not performed by the property owner within dates fixed by the governing body. 
(4)  The governing body shall determine the actual cost of the dismantling and removal of dilapidated buildings and any other expenses that may be necessary in conjunction with the dismantling and removal of the buildings, including the cost of notice and mailing. The municipal clerk shall forward a statement of the actual cost attributable to the dismantling and removal of the buildings and a demand for payment of such costs, by mail to the property owner. In addition, a copy of said statement shall be mailed to any mortgage holder at the address provided for in paragraph (1) of this section. At the time of mailing of the statement of costs to any property owner or mortgage holder, the city shall obtain a receipt of mailing from the postal service, which receipt shall indicate the date of mailing and the name and address of the mailee. If a city dismantles or removes any dilapidated buildings, the cost to the property owner shall not exceed the actual cost of the labor, maintenance, and equipment required for the dismantling and removal of the dilapidated buildings. If dismantling and removal of the dilapidated buildings is done on a private contract basis, the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best bidder. 
(5)  When payment is made to the city for costs incurred, the municipal clerk shall file a release of lien, but if payment attributable to the actual cost of the dismantling and removal of the buildings is not made within six (6) months from the date of the mailing of the statement to the owner of such property, the municipal clerk shall forward a certified statement of the amount of the cost to the county treasurer of the county in which the property is located. Said costs shall be levied on the property and collected by the county treasurer as are other taxes authorized by law. Until finally paid, the costs and the interest thereon shall be the personal obligation of the property owner from and after the date of the notice of dilapidation and lien is filed with the county clerk. In addition the cost and the interest thereon shall be a lien against the property from the date the notice of the lien is filed with the county clerk. Said lien shall be coequal with the lien of ad valorem taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and shall be prior and superior to all other titles and liens against the property. The lien shall continue until the cost is fully paid. At the time of collection, the county treasurer shall collect a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each parcel of property. Said fee shall be deposited to the credit of the general fund of the county. At any time prior to collection as provided for in this paragraph, the city may pursue any civil remedy for collection of the amount owning and interest thereon including an action in personam against the property owner and an action in rem to foreclose its lien against the property. A mineral interest, if severed from the surface interest and not owned by the surface owner, shall not be subject to any tax or judgment lien created pursuant to this section. Upon receiving payment, the municipal clerk shall forward to the county treasurer a notice of such payment and shall direct discharge of the lien. 
(6)  The planning and development department is designated to carry out the duties of the governing body specified in this section. The property owner shall have the right of appeal to the municipal governing body from any order of the planning and development department. Such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the municipal clerk within ten (10) days after the administrative order is rendered. 
(7)  For the purposes of this section, "dilapidated building" means a structure which through neglect or injury lacks necessary repairs or otherwise is in a state of decay or partial ruin to such an extent that said structure is a hazard to the health, safety, or welfare of the general public. "Owner" means the owner of record as shown by the most current tax rolls of the county treasurer. 
(8)  Nothing in the provisions of this section shall prevent the city from abating a dilapidated building as a nuisance or otherwise exercising its police power to protect the health, safety, or welfare of the general public. 
(9)  The officers, employees or agents of the city shall not be liable for any damages or loss of property due to the removal of dilapidated buildings performed pursuant to the provisions of this section or as otherwise prescribed by law. 
(10)  The provisions of this act shall not apply to any property zoned and used for agricultural purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1796, Art. 5, § 4, 12-1-75; Ord. No. 2286, § II, 8-1-88; Ord. No. 2379, §§ 1, 2, 5-18-92) 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARDING AND SECURING UNSECURED BUILDINGS 

Sec. 14-45. - Responsibility of property owner. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of an unsecured structure to board and secure such a structure. If the owner fails to board and secure a structure, the city may cause an unsecured structure to be boarded and secured. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-46. - Notice to property owner. 
    Before the city takes action to board and secure an unsecured structure, the property owners and mortgage holders shall be given notice of the pending action in accordance with the applicable state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-47. - Owner's consent. 
    The owner of the property may give written consent to the city authorizing the boarding and securing of such unsecured building and to the payment of any costs incurred thereby. By giving said written consent, the owner waives his right to a hearing by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-48. - Public hearing. 
    If the property owner does not give written consent to such actions, a hearing may be held by the commission to determine whether the boarding and securing of such unsecured building would promote and benefit the public health, safety or welfare. The commission may order the boarding and securing of the unsecured building when the boarding and securing thereof would make such building less available for transient occupation, decrease a fire hazard created by such building or decrease the hazard that such building would constitute an attractive nuisance to children. Upon making the required determination, the commission may order the boarding and securing of the unsecured building. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-49. - Notice of lien. 
    After the commission orders the boarding and securing of such unsecured building, the city shall immediately file a notice of lien with the county clerk describing the property stating the findings of the commission at the hearing at which such building was determined to be unsecured and stating that the city claims a lien on said property for the costs of boarding and securing such building. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-50. - Entering the property. 
    Pursuant to the order of the commission, the agents of the municipality are granted the right of entry on the property for the performance of the boarding and securing of such building and for the performance of all necessary duties as a governmental function of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-51. - When work is performed by city or by lowest responsible bidder. 
    After an unsecured building has been boarded and secured, the city shall determine the actual costs of such actions and any other expenses that may be necessary in conjunction therewith. The city shall forward a statement of the actual costs attributable to the boarding and securing of the unsecured building and a demand for payment of such costs by certified mail with return receipt requested to any property owners and mortgage holders. If city employees board and secure any unsecured building, the cost to the property owner shall not exceed the actual cost of the labor, materials and equipment required for the performance of such actions. If such actions are done on a private-contract basis, the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best bidder. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-52. - Collection of unpaid costs. 
    When payment is made to the city for costs incurred, the city shall file a release of lien; but if payment attributable to the actual costs of the boarding and securing of the unsecured building is not made within thirty (30) days from the date of the mailing of the statement to the owner of such property, the city shall forward a certified statement of the amount of the costs to the county treasurer. Said costs shall be levied on the property and collected by the county treasurer as are other taxes authorized by law. The costs and the interest thereon shall be a lien against the property from the date the notice of lien is filed with the county clerk. Said lien shall be coequal with the lien of ad valorem taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and shall be prior and superior to all titles and liens against the property. The lien shall continue until the costs and interest are fully paid. At any time prior to collection as provided for in this section, the city may pursue and civil remedy for collection of the amount owing and interest thereon. Upon receiving payment, the city shall forward to the county treasurer a notice of such payment and shall direct discharge of the lien. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 14-53. - Designation of administrative officer. 
    The board of commissioners authorizes the city manager to appoint an administrative officer to carry out the duties of the city as provided for in this article. The property owners or mortgage holder shall have the right of appeal to the commission from any order of the administrative officer of administrative body. Such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the administrative order is rendered. 
(Ord. No. 2338, § II, 8-27-90) 
Secs. 14-54-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - INTERPRETATION 

Sec. 14-61. - Effect of partial invalidity. 
    If any section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter should be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter, which shall remain in full force and effect; and to this end the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 1796, Art. 7, § 1, 12-1-75) 
Sec. 14-62. - Conflict of provisions. 
    Any ordinance now in effect that conflicts with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be invalid and to no effect insofar as it shall conflict with the provisions herein contained. 
(Ord. No. 1796, Art. 7, § 2, 12-1-75) 
Chapter 15 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- License required to sell nonintoxicating beverages, § 4-36; license for dogs, § 5-25 et seq.; license required for journeyman wireman, § 9-9; for electrical contractors, § 9-10; obstructing sidewalks, streets, etc., with goods, wares, merchandise, § 25-8; taxicab license, § 31-11 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to levy and collect a license tax on certain occupations, 11 O.S. 1961, § 651; penalty for failure to pay tax, 11 O.S. 1961, § 652; licenses to expire on last day of April 11, O.S. 1961, § 653. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, exercise or pursue any of the following vocations, professions, trades, business or privileges, as set out in this chapter, within the corporate limits of the city, without first having obtained and paid for a license therefor, from the proper city authorities. 
(Code 1959, § 4-1) 
Sec. 15-2. - License and regulations for carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions. 
    All carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows must obtain a license, pay a fee and comply with the provisions of this section before operating within the city limits of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
    The license requirements shall be as follows: 
(1)  Carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows having ten (10) or less concessions and rides must obtain the prior approval of the police chief and the city engineer before the license may be issued by the city clerk. No games of chance of any kind will be permitted, and the operation of the carnival, circuses and other exhibitions and shows must conform to all applicable local, state and federal laws and ordinances. Carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows having (10) ten or less concessions and rides may be held on the parking lots of the various shopping centers throughout the city so long as they do not occupy parking lot space in a manner which would diminish the availability of parking to the shopping center to such an extent it would cause a traffic safety problem or overflow onto the public streets and highways of the community. 
(2)  Carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows having more than ten (10) rides and concessions must obtain the prior approval of the police chief, the city engineer, the fire chief, the public works director and the city manager before the necessary license will be issued by the city clerk. Carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows having more than ten (10) rides and concessions may be held only at the Hardy Murphy Coliseum/Fairgrounds. 
(3)  All carnivals, circuses and other exhibitions and shows shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the city that a public liability insurance policy in amounts of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for claims by one (1) claimant for any loss arising out of a single act, accident or occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any number of claims arising out of a single accident or occurrence and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for any claim for loss of property arising out of a single act or occurrence, shall be in force and effect before said carnival, circus, or other exhibition or show is issued a license. All insurance shall name the City of Ardmore as the insured. 
(4)  Carnivals, circuses, exhibitions and shows having ten (10) or less concessions and rides shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day of operation with said sum to be paid at least five (5) days in advance. Carnivals, circuses, exhibitions and shows having more than ten (10) concessions and rides shall pay a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day of operation with said sum to be paid at least five (5) days in advance. The maximum length of any carnival, circus, exhibition and show outside of the Hardy Murphy Coliseum/Fairgrounds shall be no longer than fourteen (14) days. 
(5)  The city may revoke the license and close the operation of any carnival, circus or other exhibition or show regulated hereunder, upon discovering a violation of this section or any applicable local, state or federal law. 
(6)  If a license is denied the applicant shall have a right to appeal that administrative decision to the Board of Commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1959, § 4-1; Ord. No. 1768, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-74; Ord. No. 2375, § 1, 4-20-92; Ord. No. 2439, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 15-3. - Revocation of licenses. 
    The board of commissioners may, at any time, for the protection of the morals, peace, health or safety of the people of the city or for the violation of the ordinances of the city, revoke any license granted under the ordinances of the city. The amount that may have been paid to the city for such license, after deducting the amount due for the time expired, shall be refunded. 
(Code 1959, § 4-2) 
Sec. 15-4. - Transfer of licenses; restrictions; clerk to record. 
(a)  No license shall be sold or otherwise transferred except in the manner prescribed by the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Any person who is a legal holder or owner of any unexpired occupation license issued in accordance with the ordinances of this city, except as otherwise provided by ordinance, shall be hereby authorized to transfer the same on the books of the city clerk. 
(c)  The assignee or purchaser of such unexpired occupation license shall be authorized to pursue such occupation, profession or privilege under such unexpired occupation license for and during the unexpired portion thereof; provided, that such assignee shall, before following such occupation, profession or privilege, comply in all respects with all the requirements of the city ordinances provided for in the original application for such licenses; and provided further, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed as to authorize two (2) or more persons, firms, corporations or associations of persons to follow the same occupation under one license at the same time; and provided further, that such occupation license shall, under no circumstances, be transferred more than one time. 
(d)  The city clerk shall procure a well bound book in which he shall record all such transfers of occupation license, showing to whom the original was issued and to whom transferred, and he shall indorse such transfer on the face of said license, over his official signature, and no transfer shall be valid without such indorsement. 
(Code 1959, §§ 4-2-4-5) 
Sec. 15-5. - Lost, destroyed licenses; duplicate to be issued. 
    Whenever any original occupation license shall have been lost or destroyed, it shall be the duty of the city clerk on application in writing of the owner thereof to issue a duplicate of the same; provided that such owner will make and file with the city clerk an affidavit that such license has not been transferred, that the same has been lost or destroyed without any connivance on his part, and that he has made diligent search for the same and has not been able to find it. 
(Code 1959, § 4-6) 
Sec. 15-6. - Separate licenses for each place of business required. 
    Every person having more than one place of business or who shall exercise or follow more than one profession, calling, occupation or business, shall pay for each separate license tax except as may otherwise be specifically provided. 
(Code 1959, § 4-7) 
Sec. 15-7. - License to be displayed on premises. 
    It shall be the duty of any person, after having obtained an occupation license as required by ordinance, to have the same placed in a secure manner in some part of their place of business where the license may be readily seen at all times by any person entering said place of business. 
(Code 1959, § 4-8) 
Sec. 15-8. - Barbershops-Days of operation prescribed. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or lessee of any barbershop within the city, or for any agent or employee of such owner or lessee to open, or permit such barbershop to be opened, for the business of barbering, either for revenue, or otherwise, during night or day on the Sabbath and on the following holidays: Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanks-giving Day, Christmas Day. 
(Code 1959, § 4-35) 
Sec. 15-9. - Same-Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or lessee of any barbershop in the city or for any agent or employee of such owner or lessee, to open or permit such barbershop to be open for barbering prior to 8:00 a.m. on any day, or to keep the same open after 6:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, when the same does not precede any of the aforementioned holidays, and subsequent to 8:00 p.m. on Saturdays and any weekdays which may immediately precede any of the aforementioned holidays. 
(Code 1959, § 4-36) 
Sec. 15-10. - Fortunetelling, etc.; charge of fees prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person pretending or professing to tell fortunes by the use of any subtle craft, means or device whatsoever, either by palmistry, clairvoyance or otherwise, plying his or her trade, art or profession within the city, to make any charge therefor either directly or indirectly or to receive any gift, donation or subscription by any means whatsoever for the same. 
(Code 1959, § 4-38) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see 21 O.S. 1961, § 931. 
Sec. 15-11. - Purchase of automobile accessories-Daily report to police required. 
    Any person who purchased any hubcaps, mirrors, fender skirts or other accessories or automotive parts and/or equipment from individuals not in the lawful business of selling automobile parts and equipment shall prepare daily reports of such purchases for pick up by the chief of police or his representatives. 
(Code 1959, § 4-41) 
Cross reference- Police department generally, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 15-12. - Same-Contents of report. 
    Such report as provided by the preceding section above shall contain the name of seller, his age and address and any proof of ownership furnished to the purchaser by the seller as well as the license number and a description of the seller's car, if any. 
(Code 1959, § 4-42) 
Sec. 15-13. - Sale of goods, merchandise on vacant lots; restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person, including a civic or religious organization, to sell, barter, trade or transfer any merchandise, wearing apparel or other personal property of any kind on or in any vacant property in the city without the written consent of the owner or person in control of said property. 
(Code 1959, § 4-47) 
Sec. 15-14. - Contraceptives, prophylactics-Display of prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display or expose for sale any contraceptive device or any prophylactic rubber goods or any other articles for the prevention of venereal diseases and infection, or any sex-inciting device or contrivance in the city, or to display or expose any container or package containing or advertising the same. 
(Code 1959, § 4-44) 
Sec. 15-15. - Same-Sales by unauthorized persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than a druggist or physician duly licensed to practice in the state, to sell or offer for sale any contraceptive device or any prophylactic rubber goods or any other articles for the prevention of venereal diseases and infection in the city, except that the foregoing provision shall not apply to wholesale druggists, jobbers or manufacturers selling the same to retail drugstores for resale. 
(Code 1959, § 4-45) 
Sec. 15-16. - Same-Not to be distributed through vending machines, similar contrivances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain any vending machine or mechanical contrivance vending any of the before-described articles, or to sell, offer for sale or give away any of the before-described articles through the medium or a vending machine or similar mechanical contrivance. 
(Code 1959, § 4-46) 
Secs. 15-17-15-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND CONTRIBUTION SOLICITORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2070, § 1(A)-(N), adopted July 19, 1982, is included herein as superseding former Art. II, relative to peddlers, solicitors and itinerant vendors. 

Sec. 15-27. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler, transient merchant or contribution solicitor as defined in section 15-28 of this article within the corporate limits of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, without first obtaining a permit and license therefor or completing registration therefor as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(A), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-28. - Definitions 
(a)  The term "person" as used herein shall include the singular and plural and shall also mean and include any person, firm or corporation, association, club, co-partnership or society or any other organization. 
(b)  The term "peddler" as used herein means and includes door-to-door, street-to-street, place-to-place, temporary vendors, or sales or services without a fixed, determined and permanent location in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, at which he transacts his business, carries on his occupation or practices his profession, including vendors who do not sell from stock but exhibit samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery of sales or services. 
(c)  The term "transient merchant" as used herein shall include an itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, hawker or huckster and is defined as any person, firm or corporation whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee whether a resident of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, or not who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares or merchandise within said city and who in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure or shop for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise including any person, firm or corporation who, while occupying a temporary location does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery. 
(d)  The term "contribution solicitor" as used herein means and includes any person, group or organization which attempts, by request or plea, to obtain money from a person, not a member of the same group or organization, for any cause or purpose when made at other than the established place of meeting, business, service or activity of the group or organization. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(B), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-29. - Application for license. 
    Applicants for licenses for transient merchants, peddlers and contribution solicitors shall file a written application, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by a corporation officer if a corporation, with the city clerk, showing: 
(1)  A valid certificate, issued by the Oklahoma Tax Commission, which sets forth the account number assigned by said commission to the holder of said certificate for purposes of monitoring, governing and/or regulating certificate holders' collection and payment of sales taxes. In lieu of a valid certificate, the applicant shall provide proof that he has received the necessary forms from the Oklahoma Tax Commission to file his sales tax receipts as an occasional merchant. 
(2)  The name and address of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed to be carried on in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma; the location or address of such person or persons when engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act; the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated. 
(3)  In the case of an itinerant merchant, the application shall include the place or places in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business. 
(4)  The period of time during which the applicant wishes to solicit or sell in the city. 
(5)  A statement of the character of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold if offered for sale by the applicant in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma; whether the same are intended to be sold from stock in possession or by sample; such other reasonable information as to the indentity or character of the person or persons having management or supervision of the applicant's business; or the method or plan of doing business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(6)  The applicant must provide written permission from the owner of the property where the temporary business is to be located for that business to occupy the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(C), 7-19-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-30. - Contribution solicitation registration. 
    A fraternal, religious, veterans or other nonprofit organization now covered by Title 18, Oklahoma Statutes, Section 552.4 may apply for registration as a contribution solicitor by filing with the city clerk a written application signed by an authorized representation of such group showing: 
(1)  The name of the organization, its purpose, its officers and directors, period of solicitation and solicitor's form or remuneration. 
(2)  The applicant's certification that the group is one of the persons or organizations exempt from the licensing requirements of the Oklahoma Solicitation of Charitable Contributions Act, Title 18, Oklahoma State Statutes, Section 552.1 through 552.18. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(D), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-31. - Investigation approval or disapproval. 
(a)  All applicants for licensing shall be immediately referred to the city clerk and by him, or other persons acting in his stead, shall be investigated as to the qualifications of the applicant and as to the truthfulness of his application. The city clerk shall have two (2) business days within which to investigate and take action thereon. However, any applicant who has held an itinerant merchant license within the preceeding three (3) years prior to the date of application shall be exempt from the two-day waiting period. 
(b)  If the city clerk finds no past history of the applicant indicating violations of this article, and that the application is properly made and truthful, he shall forthwith advise the applicant. The city clerk shall issue a license to the approved applicant, upon payment of the fee therefor and the filing of the required bond. 
(c)  In matters of denial of the license by the city clerk, the applicant shall be forthwith advised thereof, in writing, setting out the reason or reasons for the denial; and the application shall be referred to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore and considered by it at its next regular meeting. The applicant shall be given an opportunity to be heard at such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(E), 7-19-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-32. - License fees for transient merchants and peddlers. 
(a)  Fees for licenses granted to transient merchants and peddlers shall be as follows: Fifty dollars ($50.00) for the license per month, and ten dollars ($10.00) for each week of operation, or fraction thereof. 
(b)  The fee for the license requirement to permanent local businesses who lease space to itinerant merchants and who wish to have said itinerant merchants exempt from license fees shall be one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1,800.00) per year if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The local business is in compliance with all city building codes and zoning ordinances. 
(2)  The local business agrees to verify days of operation for the itinerant merchant and all other requirements under section 15-30 of this article on forms prescribed by the city clerk. 
(3)  The local business has obtained the necessary sales tax permits from the Oklahoma Tax Commission for the purpose of reporting sales tax receipts of any and all itinerant merchants who lease space from said permanent business. 
(4)  The local business has not, within the last twelve (12) months, failed to meet the reporting requirements of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(F), 7-9-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-33. - Bond for license. 
    Before any license as provided by this article shall be issued such applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the City of Ardmore as follows: 
(a)  A person engaging in business as a transient merchant, a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) secured by the applicant, as principal and two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the State of Oklahoma. 
(b)  A person engaging in business as a peddler, a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) secured by the applicant, as principal and two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the State of Oklahoma. 
(c)  All such bonds shall be approved as to form by the city attorney and conditioned that said applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, and the statutes of the State of Oklahoma regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deceptive practice by any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentation or deception was made or practiced by the owner or by their service, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. The bond may be an approved surety bond or cash or an irrevocable letter of credit. Any action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(G), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-34. - Term of license. 
    Any license issued under this article shall be valid for thirty (30) days from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(H), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-35. - Transfer of license. 
    No license shall be transferred. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(I), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-36. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution solicitor to engage in such business or activity for an unlawful business or organizational purpose or activity. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution solicitor to practice harassment, nuisance, theft, deceit or menacing, troublesome or otherwise unlawful activities during the course of such business or activities. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to enter or attempt to gain entrance, to residential premises displaying at such entrance a sign with the words "Peddlers and Solicitors Prohibited" or "Solicitors Prohibited." 
(d)  It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to refuse to leave any premises when requested by the owner, lessee or person in charge or possession thereof. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution solicitor to carry on any of the permitted activities under this article before 8:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m. without first obtaining written permission from the chief of police and the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(J), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-37. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each day the violation continues. Each day's violation that is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(K), 7-19-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-38. - License to be displayed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person with a stand to engage in any activity allowed in this article, unless his valid license is displayed on the stand in a conspicuous position. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(L), 7-19-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-39. - Exemptions from article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business. 
(2)  Sales made under authority and by order of law. 
(3)  Vendors of farm or dairy products which are locally grown. 
(4)  Vendors, sixty-five (65) years of age or older, of farm or dairy products. 
(5)  Sales made by a person who has established a permanent residence in the City of Ardmore, Carter County, Oklahoma, which residency has been continuously established for not less than three (3) months prior to the application for an exemption under this article. The exemption will only be valid as long as that permanent residence is maintained, and the exemption will terminate upon the permanent residence being ended. 
(6)  Sales by itinerant merchants who are sponsored by charitable organizations approved by the city clerk for periods not to exceed seven (7) days. 
(7)  Permanent businessmen who set up a temporary business where the temporary business is of the same or similar type and nature as the permanent business. 
(8)  Sales by itinerant merchants who lease space from permanent businessmen and have obtained a transient merchant license as provided in section 15-32. 
    Persons or entities who are exempt under the terms of this article shall be required to comply with the licensing provisions set out in this article other than the payment of license fees. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(M), 7-19-82; Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87; Ord. No. 2291, § I, 9-7-88) 
Sec. 15-40. - Construction of article. 
    This entire article is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience, privacy, quiet and protection of the city and the citizens thereof; and all of the provisions hereof shall be construed for the accomplishment of such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2070, § 1(N), 7-19-82) 
Sec. 15-41. - Owner of property or his agent to ensure compliance of article by transient merchant. 
    The owner of property, or his authorized agent, where a transient merchant is carrying on a business subject to the provisions of this article, shall not knowingly permit said transient merchant to locate and carry on the business on his premises without first determining that the transient merchant has complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-42. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    Any permit or license issued pursuant to this article may be suspended for a period of up to ninety (90) days by the city clerk or may be revoked by the board of commissioners of the city after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the conduct of the business; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Operating the licensed business for immoral or illegal purposes; or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace; or in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance; or in such a manner as to constitute a menace to the public health, safety and general welfare. 
    In any situation which is grounds for revocation or suspension of a license as set out above and further constituting such a threat to the public health, safety or general welfare as to require immediate action, the city clerk may suspend the license effective immediately upon delivery of the order of suspension to the location of the licensed business or to any owner or manager or agent thereof; and upon receipt of such suspension order, the licensed business shall immediately cease and desist in its operations. The suspension order shall be in writing, shall set out the reason for the suspension and shall give the date, time and place at which the licensee may appear before the city clerk for a hearing on whether the suspension shall remain in effect, which hearing shall be held no later than two (2) business days from the date the order is served on the licensee. 
    If it is determined that grounds exist for the revocation of a license, then the matter shall be put on the agenda of the city board of commissioners' regular meeting; and written notice shall be delivered to the licensee, setting out the reasons for the revocation and the date, time and place of the hearing before the board of commissioners and shall advise the licensee that he has the right to appear there with counsel and any witnesses he desires for a hearing as to whether the license should be revoked, with said notice to be delivered to the licensee or his agent, servant or employee at his place of business or by mail to the address for the licensee shown on his application at least three (3) days prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 15-43. - Appeals. 
    Any person grieved by the city clerk in regard to the denial of an application for a license, or in regard to the suspension of a license, shall have a right to appeal to the board of commissioners of the city. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written notice of appeal with the board within ten (10) days after notice of the decision of the city clerk has been mailed or otherwise delivered to such person. The board of commissioners shall set the time and place for the hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearings shall be given to such person in the same manner as notice of revocation is required to be made. Such hearing shall not be later than the next regularly scheduled board of commissioners meeting after receipt of the notice of appeal, subject only to the requirements of the open meeting law of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2268, § I, 11-2-87) 
Secs. 15-44-15-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POOLROOMS AND DOMINO PARLORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy, collect tax on billiard tables, 11 O.S. 1961, § 651. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-53. - Hours of operation. 
    Each poolroom or domino parlor so licensed under the provisions of this article shall remain closed on weekdays between the hours of 12:00 p.m. midnight and 7:00 a.m., and on Sundays during the entire day; provided, however, that pool hall and domino parlor operators may allow patrons who have started games prior to 12:00 p.m. midnight to finish the same, but in no event shall such games continue after 12:30 a.m. 
(Code 1959, § 4-12) 
Sec. 15-54. - Employment of minors, persons convicted of certain crimes prohibited. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years nor any person who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude, shall be employed in said room or in any business operated in connection therewith. 
(Code 1959, § 4-13) 
Sec. 15-55. - Loitering, playing on premises by minors prohibited. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall be permitted to play or loiter in such poolroom or domino parlors. 
(Code 1959, § 4-14) 
Cross reference- Loitering on premises where alcoholic beverages sold, § 4-2; loitering around premises where gambling is being conducted, § 19-18; loitering in railroad station, bus station, etc., § 19-26. 
Sec. 15-56. - Obstruction of view by blinds, windows, partitions, etc. 
    No blinds, screens, partitions, counters, showcases or other obstructions shall be placed in said building in such a manner as to obstruct in whole or in part, the view from the street to any such poolroom or domino parlor. 
(Code 1959, § 4-15) 
Cross reference- Premises where nonintoxicating beverages sold to be open to public view, § 4-39. 
Sec. 15-57. - Permitting violation of laws, drinking of intoxicating liquors on premises. 
    The owner or operator or any employee thereof shall not violate or permit to be violated in said poolroom or domino parlor any of the laws of the state or the ordinances of this city, nor shall they or any of them drink or permit to be drunk upon said premises any intoxicating liquors of any kind whatsoever. 
(Code 1959, § 4-15) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages generally, Ch. 4. 
Secs. 15-58-15-62. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 15-63. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a poolroom or domino parlor in the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk; provided that the city clerk may not issue the license until the board of commissioners of the city approve it. 
(Code 1959, § 4-9) 
Sec. 15-64. - Application; to be accompanied by fee. 
(a)  Licenses for operating poolrooms or domino parlors in the city shall be issued only upon application therefor in writing by the person, firm or corporation desiring to operate the same, and shall not be transferable under any condition. The application therefor shall be in writing directed to the city clerk. 
(b)  Each application to operate a poolroom or domino parlor must be accompanied by a certified check for the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for one pool hall or one domino parlor, or for both domino parlor and pool hall the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) a year. 
(Code 1959, § 4-10) 
Sec. 15-65. - Board of commissioners to approve; qualification of licenses. 
    Such license shall only be approved by the board of commissioners for a person or persons of good character and who bear a good reputation at the time of the application; and the board of commissioners shall be the sole judges of the fitness and character of such applicant or applicants. 
(Code 1959, § 4-10) 
Sec. 15-66. - Notice of application to be published. 
    When such application is filed, public notice of such fact shall be given in some newspaper of general circulation and published in the city once each week for at least two (2) weeks, giving the date upon which said application shall be heard by the board of commissioners, which date shall be not less than fifteen (15) days from the date of filing of such application. 
(Code 1959, § 4-11) 
Sec. 15-67. - Revocation; procedure. 
    Any such license so issued for operation of a poolroom or domino parlor, may be canceled by said board for the violation of any such rules or regulations, in the following manner only: A charge in writing shall be filed with the clerk of said city, in which there shall be outlined briefly and clearly the rule or rules it is charged have been violated, whereupon the mayor or acting mayor shall set a day for hearing such charge, and notice of such hearing together with a copy of such charge shall be served upon such licensee or some of his employees, at least ten (10) days before such hearing. The city attorney shall present such charges and evidence in support thereof, and the licensee may introduce such evidence bearing upon the truth or falsity thereof, as he sees fit, and may be represented by counsel. Said charges and the evidence thereon shall be heard by the board of commissioners, and if a majority of such board shall determine after such hearing that the rules and regulations herein outlined, or any of them, have been violated by any such licensee, it shall be their duty to revoke such license. If a majority of such board fail to find that such rules or some of them have been violated, then such charges shall be dismissed. Such hearing shall be presided over by the mayor. 
(Code 1959, § 4-16) 
Secs. 15-68-15-77. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOWLING ALLEYS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy, collect tax on bowling alleys, 11 O.S. 1961, § 651. 

Sec. 15-78. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person or persons to operate a bowling alley within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1959, § 4-17) 
Sec. 15-79. - Issuance of license; qualifications of licensee. 
    A license for such purpose shall be issued only upon written application to the city clerk accompanied by a certified check in the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), and a permit shall be issued only to person or persons of good moral character, the same to be determined by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1959, § 4-18) 
Sec. 15-80. - License fee. 
    Each bowling alley so licensed shall pay in advance a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per annum. 
(Code 1959, § 4-19) 
Secs. 15-81-15-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AUCTION SALES OF JEWELRY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to levy tax on auctioneers, 11 O.S. 1961, § 651. 

Sec. 15-91. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, dispose of, offer for sale or cause to be sold in the city at public auction, any gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks or jewelry of any kind whatsoever, whether the same shall be their own property or whether they shall sell the same as an employee of others, without first having obtained a permit from the city clerk of the city to conduct such auction. 
(Code 1959, § 4-27) 
Sec. 15-92. - Application for permit; contents. 
    Application for permission to conduct an auction shall be made to the city clerk of the city which application shall contain the following: 
(1)  A full and true invoice of the stock of goods on hand for which permission is sought to be sold at auction; 
(2)  The name of applicant, and the business name of his business; 
(3)  The length of time he has been engaged in such business in the city; 
(4)  A statement that no goods have been or will be received for the purpose of selling at said auction; 
(5)  That the applicant will permit no goods to be sold on misrepresentation during said auction, which said application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(Code 1959, § 4-31) 
Sec. 15-93. - Permit fees. 
    A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for each permit issued herein and a further fee of five dollars ($5.00) per day for each day in which said auction is held. 
(Code 1959, § 4-34) 
Sec. 15-94. - Applicant to have been in business for twelve prior months. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to hold an auction of above described goods, who has not been engaged in the business of selling said goods in the city for a period of twelve (12) months prior to the date of said application. 
(Code 1959, § 4-28) 
Sec. 15-95. - Forfeiture of permit upon violation of provisions. 
    Any violation of the terms of this article of this code shall forfeit the permit to hold the auction herein contemplated. 
(Code 1959, § 4-32) 
Sec. 15-96. - Permit to be issued only to owner of merchandise; responsibility of owner. 
    A permit shall be issued only to the owner of the stock of goods sought to be sold at auction, which owner shall be responsible for the conduct of said auction, whether conducted by himself or by agents, servants or employees. 
(Code 1959, § 4-30) 
Sec. 15-97. - Merchandise; requirements for sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell at auction a stock of goods that has not been owned by said applicant for a period of at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of said application. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to sell at said auction any goods brought in for the purpose of sale at said auction. 
(Code 1959, § 4-28) 
Sec. 15-98. - Misrepresentation of merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person conducting said auction, whether as owner, auctioneer, manager, clerk or employee thereof, to represent any goods or wares to be of superior value, better grade, standard or carat than said goods, wares or merchandise really are, or to sell or offer the same for sale on such misrepresentations. 
(Code 1959, § 4-29) 
Sec. 15-99. - Limitations on number, duration and date of auctions. 
    No such auction shall be held by any person more than once during any one year, and no auction shall extend over a period of more than two (2) weeks, nor shall any auction be held during the months of November or December of any year. 
(Code 1959, § 4-33) 
Secs. 15-100-15-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SALES OF DISTRESSED GOODS, WARES AND MERCHANDISE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1639, adopted April 20, 1970, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion herein of §§ 1-18 as Art. VI, §§ 15-110-15-127, was at the discretion of the editors. Secs. 19 and 20, severability and emergency provisions, were not codified. 

Sec. 15-110. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Goods shall include any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
    Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, company or organization of any kind. 
    Sales as herein defined and regulated shall mean "method of merchandising" as distinguished from "transfer of title" and are hereby classified and described as follows: 
(a)  Fire, freight damaged or other altered goods sale is a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the owner will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water, freight handling or other means. 
(b)  Distress sale is a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale is occasioned by circumstances beyond the control of the owner of the goods which are the object of the sale. 
(c)  Going out of business sale is a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business holding such sale will cease and be discontinued, including but not limited to sale which may be designated as: adjuster's; adjustment; alteration; assignee's bankrupt; bankrupt stock; benefit of administrator's; benefit of creditors'; benefit of trustee; building coming down; closing; creditor's committee; creditors; end; executor's; final days; forced out; forced out of business; insolvents; last days; lease expires; liquidation; loss of lease; mortgaged sale; receiver's; trustee's; quitting business. 
(d)  Removal of business sale is a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 1, 4-20-70) 
Editor's note- The words, terms and phrases defined in § 15-110 were alphabetized by the editors to facilitate reference and use. 
Sec. 15-111. - License required. 
    A license issued by the city licensing officer shall be obtained by any person selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be one of the following kinds: 
(a)  Fire, freight damaged or other altered goods sale; 
(b)  Distress sale; 
(c)  Going out of business sale; 
(d)  Removal of business sale. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 2, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-112. - Established business requisite. 
    Any person who has not been the owner of a business advertised or described in the application for a license hereunder for a period of at least six (6) months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a going out of business or removal of business license hereunder; provided, however, that upon the death of a person doing business in this city, this section shall not be applied to prevent his or her legal representative, or his or her heirs, devisees, legatees or surviving partner from applying for and receiving a license hereunder in the administration and settlement of his or her estate, or in the dissolution and settlement of the affairs of a partnership occasioned by such death. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 3, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-113. - Interval between sales. 
    Any person who has held a going out of business or removal of business sale, as regulated hereunder, at the location stated in the application, either directly or indirectly, within one year last past from the date of such application shall not be granted a going out of business or removal of business license. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 4, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-114. - Restricted location. 
    Where a person applying for a license hereunder operates more than one place of business the license issued shall apply only to the one store, or branch specified in the application and no other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with it, or in any way participating in the licensed sale, nor shall the store or branch conducting the licensed sale advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the licensed sale. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 5, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-115. - Persons exempted. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(a)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
(b)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
(c)  An individual conducting a sale of personal property owned by him but not acquired for the purpose of resale, where such sale is held at the residence of the owner; 
(d)  Persons conducting a sale of the type regulated herein on the effective date of this article, unless such sale is continued for a period of more than fifteen (15) days from and after such effective date, in which event, such person, at the lapse of the said fifteen (15) day period, shall comply with the provisions of this article; 
(e)  Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication or radio station, television station or other advertising media, who publishes in good faith, any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 6, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-116. - Written application required; contents. 
    A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the licensing officer setting forth and containing the following information. 
(a)  The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale; 
(b)  The true name and address of the supplier or suppliers, not exceeding the ten (10) principal suppliers from whom he purchased the goods to be sold and if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition; 
(c)  The address of the place where such sale is to be held; 
(d)  The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; 
(e)  The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted; 
(f)  A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted; 
(g)  The approximate cost, plus freight, to seller of the goods to be sold. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 7, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-117. - Inventory requirements. 
    A complete and itemized inventory of all the goods to be offered at such sale as disclosed by the applicant's records must be verified by oath of the applicant and must be attached to and become part of the required application. Such inventory shall indicate in detail the quantity of each inventoried item therein that actually is on hand and in stock at the location of the proposed sale as of the date application for permit is made. All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment. Goods to be included in such sale which were purchased and received during the sixty (60) day period immediately prior to the day of making application for license shall be listed separately. Such inventory shall not include goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated hereunder. Any unusual purchase, or additions to the stock of goods of the business hereby regulated within sixty (60) days before the filing of an application hereunder shall be deemed to be goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated hereunder and shall be deleted from a going out of business or removal of business sale. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 8, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-118. - License fee. 
    The fee to be charged for each license issued hereunder shall consist of a base charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the sale licensed, plus an additional charge of one dollar ($1.00) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of inventory value as shown by subdivision (g) of the application required to be filed by section 15-116 thereof. The fee to be charged for extension of the time of the sale as provided herein shall be computed at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of the revised inventory required herein. The said schedule of fees hereby set forth is hereby levied, and shall be paid in advance of the issuance of any license or extension thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 9, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-119. - Licensing period. 
    The license shall authorize the sale described in the application period of not more than ninety (90) consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, following the issuance thereof, provided that no sales authorized by said license shall be conducted on any Sunday during the original or renewal term of said license. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 10, 4-20-70; Ord. No. 2474, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 15-120. - Renewal procedure. 
    The licensing officer shall renew a license for one period of time only, such period to be in addition to the thirty (30) days permitted in the original license and not to exceed thirty (30) days, Sundays and holidays excluded, when he finds: 
(a)  That facts exist justifying the license renewal; 
(b)  That the licensee has filed an application of renewal; 
(c)  That the licensee has submitted with the application for renewal a revised inventory showing the items listed on the original inventory remaining unsold and not listing any goods in the original application and inventory; 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, any application for a license under the provisions of this article covering any goods previously inventoried as required hereunder, shall be deemed to be an application for renewal. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 11, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-121. - Nature of sale. 
    The license shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named therein. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 12, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-122. - Goods permitted to be sold. 
    The license shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 13, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-123. - License nontransferable. 
    Any license herein provided for shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 14, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-124. - Duties of licensee. 
    A licensee hereunder shall: 
(a)  Adhere to inventory. Make no additions whatsoever, during the period of the licensed sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for license. 
(b)  Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. 
(c)  Adhere to advertising. Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incident thereto. 
(d)  Keep duplicate inventory. Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application and shall present such duplicate to inspecting officials upon request. 
(e)  Display license. Post in a prominent place upon the premises where the sale is conducted the license issued hereunder and show the license number in all advertising relating to the sale. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 15, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-125. - Fraud and deceit. 
    No person engaged in the sale of merchandise as herein classified and regulated shall misrepresent the true nature of such sale in any form of advertising. Any person advertising said sale, who, by virtue of such advertising either: 
(a)  Suggests as a fact that which is not true and who does not believe it is true; or 
(b)  Asserts as a fact that which is not true and who has no reasonble ground to believe it to be true; or 
(c)  Advertises as being attached at said sale items of merchandise not included in the inventory attached to the application for license, 
shall be deemed to have misrepresented the true nature of said sale. (76 O. S. 1961, Sec. 3) 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 16, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-126. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the city licensing officer to supervise the administration of the provisions hereof. He shall make or cause to be made by his qualified deputies, all inspections and verification of inventory herein requested as he deems necessary to fulfill such duty, and he or his deputy is hereby authorized in proper cases of violations hereof to file complaints against offenders in the municipal court of said city, provided that every such complaint shall set forth by number with exactitude the section or sections hereof alleged to have been violated, and at the trial of said complaint the licensing officer or his qualified deputy shall produce inspection reports or other records as may be in his possession as evidence in support of such complaint. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 17, 4-20-70) 
Sec. 15-127. - Violations and penalties. 
    Violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed twenty dollars ($20.00), including costs. Where such violation is a continuing one, each day thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1639, § 18, 4-20-70) 
Secs. 15-128-15-137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FAMILY RECREATION CENTERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1604, §§ 1-14, adopted Feb. 17, 1969, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion herein as Art. VII, §§ 15-138-15-151, was at the discretion of the editors. Catchlines were added by the editors to facilitate indexing and reference and "ordinance" has been changed to "article" where appropriate. Secs. 15 and 16, repealer and emergency provisions, have not been codified. 

Sec. 15-138. - Authorized; purpose of provisions. 
    Family recreation centers may be established, maintained and operated in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, under the terms and conditions as hereinafter set forth in this article, but only after obtaining a conditional use permit as required in the Ardmore Zoning Ordinance #1701, section 15-22 for commercial districts. Said regulations are for the purpose of providing a place for all members of family to participate together in recreation and entertainment to preserve the public morals, peace and safety of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 1, 2-17-69; Ord. No. 2396, § 1, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 15-139. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person as proprietor, owner or agent, or person in charge of said recreation center to conduct or operate the same until such person shall first duly be licensed for such purpose. Granting of a license may be done at the same time a conditional use permit is authorized by the Ardmore City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 2, 2-17-69; Ord. No. 2396, § 1, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 15-140. - Application for license; contents; persons to whom license will not issue. 
    Applications for a license to conduct or operate a family recreation center shall be made to the city clerk and said application shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, the street number of the place where the recreation center will be conducted. No license as herein provided shall be granted to any person who has been convicted in a court of record of having violated any of the laws of the State of Oklahoma commonly called "Prohibition Laws", or habitually violating any of the laws of the state or who has been granted any license to sell intoxicating liquors or 3.2 beer, or has been granted a gambling stamp by the United States. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 3, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-141. - Submission of application to city commission; approval, rejection thereof. 
    All applications for a license to conduct or operate a family recreation center which are made to the city clerk as provided herein shall be by the city clerk submitted to the board of city commissioners for their approval or rejection, and no license shall be issued to any person until the city commission has in open session authorized the issuance thereof; and the city commission shall have authority to refuse to issue a license to any applicant when in the opinion of the said commission it is to the best interests of the inhabitants of said city that said license be refused. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 4, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-142. - License fee; display of proof of payment. 
    An annual license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year shall be charged to operate a family recreation center. This fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall authorize the operation of not more than ten (10) amusement devices (music devices, amusement boards, games, pool tables, billiard tables, domino tables and other amusement devices). For each amusement device operated in excess of ten (10) there shall be a fee charged of ten dollars ($10.00) per year. The fees herein provided shall be paid in advance prior to operation of the recreation center or of any amusement device. 
    Proof of payment of such license fees, as herein provided, shall be prominently displayed within the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 5, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-143. - Suspension, revocation of license; grounds; notice of revocation. 
    The license of any operator of a family recreation center may be suspended for not more than ten (10) days by the chief of police for disorderly or immoral conduct on the premises or for the violation of any of the provisions of this article. Said license may be revoked by the board of city commissioners at any time for disorderly or immoral conduct on the premises or for the violation of the provisions of this article, provided that no license shall be revoked by the board of commissioners except upon ten (10) days notice in writing to the operator of said family recreation center. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 6, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-144. - Maintenance of center; restrooms. 
    All family recreation centers shall be kept in a clean, healthful and sanitary condition at all times and shall be adequately equipped with separate restrooms for males and females. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 7, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-145. - Duty of operator to comply with article provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of the operator of said family recreation center to enforce all of the provisions of this article and to see at all times that the provisions of this article are complied with in every respect. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 8, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-146. - Intoxicated persons, alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
    No intoxicated person shall be permitted to loaf [linger] or loiter about said recreation center, and no alcoholic beverages or 3.2 beer shall be allowed or sold or consumed on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 9, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-147. - Admission of minors to center. 
    All minors of any age may be admitted to said family recreation center if they are accompanied by their parents or guardian or by some other person over the age of sixteen (16) years. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 10, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-148. - Gambling, gambling devices prohibited. 
    All games of recreation may be conducted by the person operating said center, but no gambling or gambling device may at any time be operated within said center. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 11, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-149. - City's right of entry; inspection of centers. 
    All family recreation centers may at any time be entered by the city police or any other city official for the purpose of inspecting the same and determining whether the center is operated in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 12, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-150. - Hours of operation. 
    All family recreation centers shall be closed on or before 12:00 o'clock midnight of each night and shall not be opened until 7:00 a.m. the following morning except on Sunday morning when the same shall not be opened until 1:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 13, 2-17-69) 
Sec. 15-151. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article, either by doing anything which is prohibited or by failing to do anything which is commanded, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any amount not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) including costs, provided that each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1604, § 14, 2-17-69) 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of Code, § 1-4. 
Secs. 15-152-15-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OIL AND GAS WELLS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1784, enacted April 7, 1975, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1-4 herein as Art. VIII, §§ 15-161-15-164, was at the discretion of the editors. 
Cross reference- Oil and gas wells, App. C, § 15-28.27. 

Sec. 15-161. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, persons or other business entity to operate an oil and/or gas well or facility appurtenant thereto or other facility used in the production or distribution of oil or gas within the corporate limits of the City of Ardmore without having first obtained a license therefor as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1784, § 1, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 15-162. - Application; issuance of license. 
    The license required herein shall be issued only upon written application to the city clerk of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, which application shall include the owner and operator of the proposed facility, its location, a brief description of the type and anticipated use of the facility and other appurtenant information required by the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a certified check in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 1784, § 2, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 15-163. - License fee. 
    Each facility licensed herein shall pay in advance an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall pay a like license fee on the anniversary date each year thereafter as long as said facility is in use. 
(Ord. No. 1784, § 3, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 15-164. - Penalties. 
    Operation of any facility requiring a license hereunder without a license shall be deemed a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by fine. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1784, § 4, 4-7-75) 
Secs. 15-165-15-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PAWNBROKERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1884, § 1, enacted June 5, 1978, amended Ch. 15, but did not specify the manner thereof, hence inclusion herein as Art. IX, §§ 15-171-15-176, was at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 15-171. - Definitions. 
    Pawnbrokers: "Pawnbroker" means a person engaged in the business of making pawn transactions. 
    Pawn transaction: "Pawn transaction" means the act of lending money on the security of pledged goods or the act of purchasing tangible personal property on condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 15-172. - License required; fee; issuance; revocation. 
    No person shall carry on or engage in the business of a pawnbroker in the City of Ardmore without first having obtained a license therefor in said city said license to cost twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per annum. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association or corporation to engage in pawnbroking to be defined hereinafter without paying the required license fee and securing and possessing a valid license therefor. The license shall be issued by the city clerk after proper application to said city clerk, payment of the license tax and fulfillment of any other conditions which may be prescribed by law and/or ordinance. Conviction in the City of Ardmore Municipal Court of offense against this article or other ordinance under which a pawnbroker's license is issued or regulations governing the same shall operate as a revocation of the license or privilege of any person holding same, and in the event of such conviction, such license or privilege may be restored only by petition and favorable action thereupon by the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 15-173. - Record to be kept and report made. 
(a)  Every person, firm or corporation engaging in business as a pawnbroker in this city shall keep a record in which shall be written legibly in ink or typed at the time any loan or purchase is made by such pawnbroker, an accurate account and description of the goods or chattels or property so pawned, pledged, mortgaged or purchased, the amount of money loaned thereon or paid therefor, the time the same were received, and the name, residence, description, and signature of the person pawning, pledging, mortgaging or selling the same, which record shall be written in the English language and which record shall be readily accessible during normal business hours and subject to inspection of the chief of police or his authorized representative. This record is to be kept for a period of no less than four (4) years or no less than two (2) years from the final disposition, whichever the longer period. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker in the city to have the records required in subsection (a) above available to be picked up by the chief of police or his duly authorized representative at the beginning of each work day. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 15-174. - Identification of pledgors.
