    Every person who applies to any pawnbroker for a loan for the security of which he offers the hypothecation or possession of personal property, or who offers to sell any personal property, shall, before the property be received or taken or the loan or purchase be made, be identified by drivers license, military I.D., or the physical description including age, weight, height, sex, and race must be included. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 15-175. - Restrictions on disposal of property. 
    No pawnbroker shall sell or otherwise dispose of or permit to be taken from his establishment any personal property of which a record of purchase is required to be kept in section 15-173 (a) set out above pertaining to purchase within forty-eight (48) hours after said purchase. This section shall not apply to pawn transactions. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 15-176. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any property purchased from manufacturers, wholesale dealers or from any other person having an established place of business. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Secs. 15-177-15-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - MASSAGE THERAPISTS AND MASSAGE THERAPY ESTABLISHMENTS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2584, adopted August 3, 1998, repealed the former Art. X and set out a new Art. X as set out herein. The former article pertained to massage parlors and similar establishments and derived from Ord. No. 1918, §§ 1-19, adopted May 7, 1979. 

Sec. 15-181. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(a)  Massage therapy: Any method or pressure on or friction against or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating of the external tissues of the body with the hands or with other parts of the body or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniment, antiseptics, oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used in this practice. This article and this definition shall not include massage therapy as performed by a licensed practitioner of the healing arts, including but not limited to physicians, M.D.s or D.O.s, R.N.s or licensed practical nurses, chiropractors, and licensed physical therapists. 
(b)  Massage therapy establishment: Any establishment having a fixed place of business where any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or carries on or permits to be engaged in or carried on any of the activities mentioned in this article. 
(c)  Massage therapist: Any person who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage therapy as herein defined. 
(d)  Employee: Any and all persons, other than the massage therapists, as defined herein, who render any service to the permittee, who receive compensation directly or indirectly from the permittee, and who have no physical contact with the customers and clients. 
(e)  Person: Any individual, co-partnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation or combination of individuals of whatever form or character. 
(f)  Recognized school: Any school or institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, method, profession or work of massage therapy, which school requires a resident course of study of not less than one hundred (100) hours of training to be given in no more than three (3) calendar months before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school or institution of learning following the successful completion of such course of study of learning. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-182. - Massage therapist permit required; filing of application; fee. 
    Any person, who engages in the practice of massage therapy as herein defined, shall file an application for a massage therapy permit with the office of the city clerk upon a form provided by said city clerk and shall pay a filing fee of fifty dollars ($50) which shall not be refundable if the permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-183. - Application form for massage therapy permit. 
    The application for a massage therapy permit shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and residence address. 
(2)  Social security number. 
(3)  Applicant's weight, height, color of hair and eyes, and fingerprints. 
(4)  Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(5)  Business, occupations or employment of the applicant for three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(6)  Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime except minor traffic violations. If any person mentioned in this subsection has been so convicted, a statement must be made giving the place and court in which the conviction was obtained and the sentence imposed as a result of such conviction. 
(7)  The name and address of the recognized school attended, the date attended, and a copy of the diploma or certificate of graduation awarded the applicant showing the applicant has successfully completed not less than one hundred (100) hours of instruction. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-184. - Issuance of massage therapy permit. 
    The city clerk may issue a massage therapy permit within fourteen (14) days following application, unless the city clerk finds that the applicant for a massage therapy permit has been convicted of: 
(1)  A felony; 
(2)  An offense involving sexual misconduct with children; 
(3)  Obscenity, keeping or residing in a house of ill fame, solicitation of a lewd or unlawful act, prostitution or pandering. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-185. - Revocation of massage therapy permit. 
    A massage therapy permit issued by the city clerk shall be revoked or suspended after a public hearing before the city clerk where it appears that the massage therapist has been convicted of any offense enumerated in section 15-184. The city clerk, before revoking or suspending any massage therapy permit shall give the massage therapist at least ten (10) days written notice of the examination into his conviction record and the opportunity for a public hearing before the city clerk at which hearing the city clerk shall determine the relevant facts regarding the occurrence of the conviction. In such cases, the charges shall be specific and in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-186. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Every portion of a location where massage therapy is performed, including appliances, apparatus and personnel shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition. 
(b)  All massage therapists shall be clean and wear clean outer garments. 
(c)  All massage therapists must be modestly attired. Transparent clothing is prohibited. Clothing must cover the massage therapists chest and genital areas at all times. 
(d)  The private parts of patrons must be covered by towels, cloths, or undergarments when in the presence of a massage therapists. Any contact with a patron's genital area is strictly prohibited. 
(e)  All location where massage therapy is performed shall have clean laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use thereof and stored in a sanitary manner. 
(f)  All wet and dry heat rooms, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-187. - Daily register. 
    Every massage therapist shall keep a daily register, approved as to form by the chief of police or his authorized representative, of all patrons, with names addresses and hours of arrival and, if applicable, the rooms or cubicles assigned. Said daily register shall at all times during business hours be subject to inspection by the chief of police or his authorized representative and shall be kept on file for one year. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 2766, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 15-188. - Inspection of premises. 
    The chief of police or his authorized representative may from time to time make an onsite inspection of any location where massage therapy is performed, for the purposes of determining the provisions of this article are complied with. Such inspections shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It shall be unlawful for any permittee to fail to allow such inspection or to hinder the chief of police or his representative in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-189. - Transfer of permit. 
    No permit issued hereunder shall be transferable except with the written consent of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-190. - Applicability of regulations to existing massage therapists. 
    Massage therapists in operation at the time of the enactment of this article are required to comply with all provisions of this article within one (1) year of the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-191. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes, sanitariums, or person holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the State of Oklahoma or to persons working under the direction of any such person or in any such establishments. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-192. - Annual renewal fee. 
    The permit issued under this article must be renewed annually. The annual renewal fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 15-193. - Continuing professional education courses. 
    Every person who holds a permit under this article shall be required to attend and pass continuing professional education courses in the practice of massage therapy for a minimum of six (6) hours on an annual basis. Each permit holder shall provide proof of attendance to the city clerk on an annual basis. Failure to attend the required continuing professional courses shall result in suspension or revocation of the permit after a public hearing by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 2820, 7-17-06) 
Sec. 15-194. - Violation and penalty. 
    Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by this article, who gives massage therapy without first obtaining a permit and paying a license fee to do so from the city, or who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Upon conviction such person shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus costs. Each separate violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2584, 8-3-98) 
Secs. 15-195-15-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - AMUSEMENT ARCADES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1942, enacted Aug. 6, 1979, amended this Code, but did not specify the manner thereof, hence inclusion of §§ 1-8 as Art. XI, §§ 15-211-15-217, was at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 15-211. - License required. 
    No person, firm, partnership or corporation shall keep within the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, any amusement arcade unless such person, firm, partnership or corporation shall have first procured an amusement arcade license as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 1, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-212. - Definitions. 
    Amusement arcade means the operation by any person, firm, partnership or corporation of twenty (20) or more coin-operated amusement devices as hereinafter defined, for public use upon premises solely within one enclosure. 
    Coin-operated amusement device means any amusement machine or device which is operated or put into operation in whole or in part by the insertion of a coin, token or similar object. The term does not include coin-operated musical devices, bona fide vending machines in which gaming or amusement features are not incorporated, any gambling device or slot machine. Nothing herein shall be construed to permit the use of any device prohibited by law or the use of any device in any manner prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 1942, §§ 2, 3, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-213. - License to be in lieu of that required by sections 15-138 to 15-151; exemption from provisions of sections 15-138 to 15-151. 
    No person, firm, partnership or corporation shall own, operate or permit operation of an amusement arcade on premises owned, leased or operated by him, or engage in the business of operating an amusement arcade, in the city unless an annual amusement arcade license has been obtained. Such amusement arcade license shall be in lieu of any other license required by sections 15-138 to 15-151 of Article VII. A person, firm, partnership or corporation licensed as an amusement arcade is exempt from all other provisions of sections 15-138 through 15-151 of Article VII. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 4, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-214. - Application for license; fee; term of license; inspections. 
(a)  Such amusement arcade licenses shall be obtained upon application to the city clerk and the payment of an annual license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each amusement arcade. Such fee shall be in lieu of any other fee required by sections 15-138 to 15-151 of Article VII. 
    Amusement arcade licenses shall cover an annual period from January 1st through December 31st for each year hereafter; provided, however, that the initial amusement license fee for each applicant shall be prorated as of the date of the application therefor. 
    The application must be signed and sworn to by the applicant in the case of a sole proprietorship. In case the applicant is a partnership, all partners must sign and verify the application. In case the applicant is a corporation, all officers must sign and verify the application and indicate their official position. The information required in the application form must be furnished as to each person signing the application. Each application shall be accompanied by the required licensing fee and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's full name. 
(2)  The applicant's residence address. 
(3)  The applicant's business address. 
(4)  The address of the proposed amusement arcade. 
(5)  The name and address of every person who has any interest in the amusement arcade, and the nature of that interest. 
(6)  Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, or of pandering, gambling, operation of a gambling device, operation of a gaming house or being a keeper of a house of ill fame, or any other misdemeanor. 
(7)  Whether or not the applicant is at the time of making the application keeping or in any way connected with a gaming house or a house of ill fame. 
(8)  Whether or not the applicant or his or her spouse, or any member of the applicant's household is a member or employee of the police department of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, whether or not any member or employee of the police department of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, is interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the license applied for, the devices, or the operation of the same; and whether or not the applicant has received or borrowed money or anything else of value or accepted credit from any member or employee of said police department or the spouse of any member of the household of any such member or employee. 
(9)  A statement that the applicant, if requested by the city manager, will permit a record of his fingerprints to be made by the police department of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, for the purpose of additional investigation to determine whether or not the application should be granted. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the application and the fee, the city clerk shall refer the application to the chief of police of the city, who shall cause the arcade to be inspected promptly and report to the city clerk whether the coin-operated amusement device, or devices, in the arcade are equipped for operation or are actually operated in violation of the laws of the state or the city. If the police chief finds that the coin-operated amusement devices in the arcade are not so equipped or operated, the inspecting officer shall place a sticker on each machine showing the date of inspection and so report to the city clerk. The city clerk shall then issue a license for the arcade, and the number of the license shall be placed on the sticker on each coin-operated amusement device in the arcade. 
    The police chief shall make at least one additional inspection of each coin-operated amusement device in the arcade during the license year to determine whether the machines are operated or equipped for operation in violation of the law of the state or city, and may make additional inspections at any time. The date of each inspection shall be shown on the sticker of each machine. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 5, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-215. - Change of location. 
    If any coin-operated amusement device is moved from the arcade, the new location shall be reported promptly to the police chief, and if not so reported, the amusement arcade license shall be automatically revoked without notice of further action. No license shall be valid except for the location shown in the application or in such change of location. 
    If any coin-operated amusement device is moved from a different location to the arcade, the arcade licensee shall notify the police chief, who shall cause the new machines to be inspected promptly and report to the city clerk whether the coin-operated amusement device in the arcade is equipped for operation or is actually operated in violation of law. If the police chief finds that the coin-operated amusement device in the arcade is not so equipped or operated, he shall place a sticker on that machine, bearing the number of the arcade license, showing the date of inspection and so report to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 6, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-216. - Restrictions. 
(a)  No amusement arcade nor any coin-operated amusement device or coin-operated musical device therein shall be operated so as to constitute a public nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to maintain order on the licensed premises at all times. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to see that the licensed premises do not become overcrowded so as to constitute a hazard to the health or safety of persons therein. 
(d)  The licensee shall provide a full-time adult attendant upon the licensed premises during business hours. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of operating an amusement arcade to sell, offer for sale, or knowingly permit to be sold or offered for sale or to be dispensed or consumed or brought on the licensed premises any alcoholic beverages, narcotics or other controlled substance. 
(f)  The licensed premises shall be located in an enclosed mall regional type shopping center with no exterior entrances or exits leading directly to any parking area. 
(g)  The licensed premises shall be open for business only in conformity with the hours as designated by the shopping center. 
(h)  The shopping center of which the licensed premises are a part shall provide uniformed security throughout same. 
(i)  Every amusement arcade licensed under this article shall have affixed on its premises in plain view a decalcomania evidencing the issuance of its license. 
(j)  The license required and described in this article shall be purely a personal privilege and shall not constitute property. It is not transferable in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 7, 8-6-79) 
Sec. 15-217. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Any person, firm, partnership or corporation operating an amusement arcade shall be subject to a fine of not more than thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for each violation of this article. 
(b)  Revocation or suspension. The city manager may revoke or suspend any license issued under this article for any violation of any provision of this article or for any violation of state law. 
(Ord. No. 1942, § 8, 8-6-79) 
Secs. 15-218-15-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - BUYERS OF CERTAIN PERSONAL PROPERTY[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1975, §§ 1A-13, adopted March 17, 1980, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1A-13 herein as Art. XII, §§ 15-226-15-238, was at the discretion of the editors. Sections 14 and 15 of said ordinance, severability and emergency provisions, were omitted from codification. 

Sec. 15-226. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a buyer, as defined in section 15-227 set out hereafter, to engage in business within the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 1A, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-227. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article a "buyer" is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in the business of buying silver, gold, copper or tin in any form, coins, jewelry, scrap metal (wrecked or damaged motor vehicles excluded from the provisions of this article) aluminum, oil field drilling bits and sucker rods, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, motels, apartments, shops or any street, alley or other place within the city; provided. that such definition shall not be construed to include pawnbrokers or persons selling new or used property nor shall this article apply to the purchase of any motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 2, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-228. - Application for license. 
    Applicants for license under this article, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the city clerk, showing: 
(a)  The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the City of Ardmore; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
(b)  Three (3) letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the County of Carter, Oklahoma, certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the city clerk good character and business responsibility of such person or persons; 
(c)  The place or places in the City of Ardmore where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted; 
(d)  The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of said application conducted a business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(e)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be purchased by applicant in the City of Ardmore; 
(f)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the city clerk, copies of all said advertising, whether by handbills, circular, newspaper advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as exhibits thereto; 
(g)  Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(h)  Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and 
(i)  Such other reasonable information as to the identify or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 3, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-229. - Investigation of applicant; issuance, denial of application. 
    Upon receipt of such application, the city clerk shall cause such investigation of such person's or persons' business responsibility or moral character to be made as he deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the city clerk shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued by the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a full record in his office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of said license, the place where said business may be carried on under said license, and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 4, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-230. - Exhibition of license. 
    The license issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses must be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 5, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-231. - License fee. 
    Licensees under this article shall pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 6, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-232. - Transfer of license. 
    No license shall be transferred from one location to another or from one person or entity to another without written consent from the city clerk showing to whom or where the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 7, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-233. - Duty of police to enforce article provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the City of Ardmore to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this article, to determine if this article has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 8, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-234. - Records. 
    The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of the license, together with a license number, with the chief of police; the chief of police shall report to the city clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and any conviction for violation of this article; the city clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. In addition, every licensee shall keep a record in which shall be written legibly in ink or typed at the time any purchase is made by said licensee, an accurate account and description of the goods or chattels or property so purchased, the amount of money paid therefor, the time the same was received, the name, residence, description and signature of the person selling the property to the licensee, which record shall be written in the English language and which record shall be readily accessible during normal business hours and subject to inspection by the chief of police or his authorized representative. This record is to be kept for a period of no less than two (2) years, and if the licensee leaves town that record is to be left with the chief of police. It shall further be the duty of the licensee to have the records required in this section available to be picked up by the chief of police or his duly authorized representatives at the beginning of each business day. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 9, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-235. - Advertisements. 
    The licensees herein are prohibited from indicating in any advertisements they may use that purchase will be confidential. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 10, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-236. - Merchandise purchased to remain in the city thirty-six hours. 
    All property purchased by any licensee under this article shall remain within the city limits of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, for thirty-six (36) hours from the time it is purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 11, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-237. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the purchasing of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 11, 3-17-80) 
Sec. 15-238. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed thirty-five dollars ($35.00). Each day said violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 1975, § 12, 3-17-80) 
Chapter 16 - MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation generally, Ch. 13; regulation and inspection of restaurants, § 13-12. 
State Law reference- Rules, regulations relative to milk and milk products, 63 O.S. Supp. 1965, Art. 13. 

Sec. 16-1. - Milk ordinance-Adopted by reference 
    The production, transportation, processing, handling, sampling, examination, grading, labeling, and sale of all milk and milk products sold for the ultimate consumption within the City of Ardmore, or its police jurisdiction; the inspection of dairy herds, dairy farms, and milk plants; the issuing and revocation of permits to milk producers, haulers, and distributors shall be regulated in accordance with the provisions of the Milk Ordinance, 1965 Recommendations of the Public Health Service Revised to Comply with Oklahoma State Statutes, a certified copy of which shall be filed in the office of the appropriate official: provided, that Sections 9, 16, and 17 of said unabridged ordinance shall be replaced, respectively, by the provisions of section 16-2. 
(Ord. No. 1573, § 1, 1-15-68) 
Sec. 16-2. - Same-Amendments. 
    The following sections of the milk ordinance, adopted by reference in section 16-1, are hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 9. Milk and Milk Products which may be sold. 
"From and after 6 months from January 15, 1968, only Grade A pasteurized milk and milk products shall be sold to the final consumer, or to restaurants, soda fountains, grocery stores, or similar establishments: provided, that in an emergency, the sale of pasteurized milk and milk products which have not been graded, or the grade of which is unknown, may be authorized by the health authority; in which case, such milk and milk products shall be labeled 'ungraded'." 
(Ord. No. 1573, § 2, 1-15-68) 
Section 16. Penalty. 
"Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200) and/or such persons may be enjoined from continuing such violations. Each day upon which such a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation." 
(Ord. No. 1573, § 4, 1-15-68) 
Section 17. Repeal and date of effect. 
"All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance shall be repealed 6 months after the adoption of this ordinance, at which time this ordinance shall be in full force and effect, as provided by law." 
(Ord. No. 1573, § 5, 1-15-68) 
Sec. 16-3. - Administration and enforcement of chapter provisions. 
    All sampling, examining, grading, and regarding of milk and milk products, and all inspections, and issuing and suspension or revocation of permits shall be done by the director of the county health department or his authorized representative, who shall be a registered professional sanitarian, or the county superintendent of health if there is no county health department. 
(Ord. No. 1573, § 3, 1-15-68) 
Chapter 17 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of board to regulate duties and functions of municipal court, § 7(9); municipal court, Art. V, § 33. 
Cross reference- General penalty for violations of code, § 1-4; department of law established, § 2-13; appointment of city attorney, § 2-14; duties of court relative to disposition of vicious dogs, § 5-44. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts generally, 11 O.S. 1961, § 751 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2981 , § I, adopted June 6, 2016, repealed former § 17-2, pertaining to law enforcement officers training fund reimbursement and derived from Ord. No. 2126, § 1, adopted Oct. 3, 1983; Ord. No. 2127, § 2, adopted Oct. 3, 1983; and Ord. No. 2337, § I, adopted July 20, 1990, and § 17-3, pertaining to automated fingerprint identification system reimbursement and derived from Ord. No. 2337, § II, adopted July 2, 1990; renumbered former § 17-4 as § 17-2; and added a new § 17-3 as set out herein. 

Sec. 17-1. - Municipal criminal court. 
    There is hereby established in said city a municipal criminal court pursuant to 11 O.S. 1961, Sections 958.1 through 958.25. (Res. No. 1490, 5-1-63) 
( Ord. No. 3019, § I, 11-6-17 ) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to establish municipal criminal court, 11 O.S. 1961, § 958.1. 
Sec. 17-2. - "Convicted" as used in this section. 
    Convicted means any final adjudication of guilt, whether pursuant to a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or otherwise, and any deferred judgement or suspended sentence. 
(Ord. No. 2337, § III, 7-2-90; Ord. No. 2981 , § I, 6-6-16; Ord. No. 3019, § I, 11-6-17 ) 
Sec. 17-3. - Court Costs and Fees. 
A.  Municipal Court Costs. Court costs in the amount of Thirty Dollars ($30.00), plus the fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses, shall be charged and collected by the Municipal Court Clerk in all cases other than those in which the defendant is acquitted or found not guilty or those which are dismissed upon motion of the defendant or the City Attorney. 
B.  Drug Related Offense Fee. The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of Five Dollars ($5.00), which shall be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties provided for by this section or code upon any conviction of the crime of possession of marijuana or the crime of possession of drug paraphernalia. The Court Clerk shall remit the monies in the fund on a monthly basis directly to the Bureau of Narcotics Drug Education Revolving Fund. 
C.  CLEET Fee. The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of Ten Dollars ($10.00), which shall be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties provided for by this section or code, upon conviction of any offense, including traffic offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more. The court clerk shall remit on a monthly basis a portion of every fee imposed to the Council on Law Enforcement Education and Training as required. Any remaining amount shall be retained by the City. 
D.  AFIS Fee. The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of Ten Dollars ($10.00), which shall be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties provided for by this section or code, upon conviction of any offense, including traffic offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more. The Court Clerk shall remit the monies on a monthly basis to the AFIS fund. 
E.  Forensic Fee. The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of Ten Dollars ($10.00), which shall be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties provided for by this section or code, upon conviction of any offense, including traffic offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more. The Court Clerk shall remit the monies on a monthly basis to the Forensic Science Improvement Revolving Fund. 
F.  Alcohol Related Offense Fee. The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of Fifty Dollars ($50.00), which shall be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties provided for by this section or code, upon conviction of any alcohol related offense. This Fifty Dollar ($50.00) fee shall also be assessed in the event that an alcohol related offense results in a deferral. The Court Clerk shall remit the monies to a fund of the City that shall be used to defray costs for enforcement of laws relating to juvenile access to alcohol, other laws relating to alcohol and other intoxicating substances, and traffic related offenses involving alcohol or other intoxicating substances. 
G.  Deferral Fee. When a deferred sentence is imposed, the Court Clerk shall charge an administrative fee of up to Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) for any traffic-related offense related to speeding or parking, or up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for all other offenses, as directed by the Court, in addition to any deferral fee otherwise authorized by law. In no event shall the deferral fee assessed exceed the amount of the maximum fine allowed for that particular offense under state law. 
( Ord. No. 2981 , § I, 6-6-16; Ord. No. 3019, § I, 11-6-17 ) 
Secs. 17-4-17-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - YOUTH COURT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Former Art. II, §§ 17-12-17-15, pertaining to the youth court and derived from Ord. No. 1388, §§ 1-4, adopted March 15, 1962, was amended in its entirety to read as herein set out in §§ 17-12-17-15 by Ord. No. 2228, § 1, enacted Oct. 20, 1986. 
Cross reference- Unlawful for minor to neglect or refuse to attend school, § 19-1.1. 

Sec. 17-12. - Establishment of jurisdiction. 
    There is hereby established within the city a youth court with jurisdiction to try juvenile offenders not over eighteen (18) years of age, who are charged with misdemeanor offenses under state law if they were charged as adults or with violations of the code of Ordinances of the City of Ardmore. Any case referred to youth court must have the written consent of the juvenile's parents or legal guardian. Any case referred to youth court must also have the written consent of either the municipal judge of the City of Ardmore or the district attorney of the Twentieth Judicial District of the State of Oklahoma. No juveniles charged with felonies may appear in youth court. 
(Ord. No. 2228, § 1, 10-20-86; Ord. No. 2274, § I, 1-19-88; Ord. No. 2324, § 2, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 2419, 11-1-93) 
Sec. 17-13. - Proceedings to be held in strict confidence. 
    All proceedings held in youth court are to be held in strictest confidence. No permanent record will be kept of proceedings in youth court. 
    All records used in the proceedings will be expunged or turned over to the juvenile according to procedures established by the executive board. No one may have access to the records in youth court except with the written approval from a judge of the district court of the 20th Judicial District, City of Ardmore, Carter County, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2228, § 1, 10-20-86; Ord. No. 2274, § I, 1-19-88; Ord. No. 2324, § 3, 12-18-90) 
Sec. 17-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 17-14 pertained to rules, regulations and procedures, was repealed by § 1 of Ord. No. 2324, adopted Dec. 18, 1989, and originated from Ord. No. 2228, adopted Oct. 20, 1986. 
Sec. 17-15. - Executive board. 
(a)  Composition. The operations of youth court shall be overseen by an executive board which shall consist of no more than eleven (11) members who shall be appointed as follows: three (3) members shall be members of youth court, consisting of the chief prosecutor, the chief defense counsel, and the chief judge; two (2) members shall be members of the Ardmore Police Department and shall be appointed by the chief of police; two (2) members shall be members of the Carter County Bar Association and shall be appointed by the president of said association; one (1) member-at-large shall be appointed by the city manager, said member-at-large shall be a citizen of the City of Ardmore; one (1) member shall be an employee of the district attorney's office of the Twentieth Judicial District and shall be appointed by the district attorney; one (1) member shall be an employee of the department of human services and shall be appointed by the department of human services director for Carter County; one (1) member shall be the executive director of youth court who shall be appointed by the city manager. The executive director may also serve as one of the other ten (10) positions on the executive board. The city manager shall be an ex-officio member of the executive board who shall be allowed to vote only in case of a tie vote among the other voting members of the executive board. 
(b)  Terms of office. A member of the executive board shall hold office until one of the following transpire: 
(1)  The member resigns; 
(2)  The member is no longer a member of the group from which he or she was appointed; 
(3)  The member is removed by majority vote of the executive board; 
(4)  The member is absent from three (3) consecutive executive board meetings. 
(Ord. No. 2228, § 1, 10-20-86; Ord. No. 2324, § 4, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 2419, 11-1-93) 
Secs. 17-16-17-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL COURT CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2739, §§ I-III, adopted April 21, 2003, amended this Code, but did not specify the manner thereof, hence inclusion herein as § 17-26 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 28. 

Sec. 17-26. - Procedures and guidelines for complaints-Motor vehicles. 
(a)  The court clerk cannot make any changes on a complaint involving an automobile accident. The court clerk or the deputy court clerk may take a plea of guilty or nolo contendre' and may receive the amount of the scheduled fine for the complaint. The court clerk or the deputy court clerk may not grant a deferred sentence or a reduced amount of fine and costs in complaints involving automobile accidents. That can only be done by the municipal judge. 
(b)  In any other moving traffic violation not involving an accident, the court clerk or the deputy court clerk shall first inquire concerning other tickets which the offender may have received. This should be confirmed by a check of the city's computer and/or the department of public safety's computer. If the offender has no prior tickets then the court clerk or the deputy court clerk may grant a deferred sentence for no less than three (3) months and reduce the scheduled amount of the fine in one-half (1/2). If the offender has prior tickets they shall see the municipal judge in regard to a plea involving a deferred sentence or a reduction in the fine. 
(c)  The court clerk may dismiss tickets for no drivers' license, expired tag, no insurance offenses, and defective motor vehicle. For the no drivers' license and no insurance, a dismissal with no costs shall be given if the offender has in their possession proof of a valid drivers license and valid insurance in effect at the time of the ticket, but which they were unable to show to the officer at the time the ticket was written. A dismissal with no costs for defective motor vehicle and expired tag will be granted if the offender corrects the defective condition or obtains a valid tag within ten (10) working days from the date they receive the ticket. The offender must show proof that the defective condition has been remedied or the tag renewed properly to the court clerk or the deputy court clerk. After the ten (10) day period, the ticket can be dismissed with costs, if the offender shows proof that the defective condition has been corrected or the tag properly renewed. No moving violation ticket shall be dismissed without the municipal judges approval. 
(Ord. No. 2739, §§ I-III, 4-21-03) 
Chapter 18 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to enforce local legislation for summary abatement and removal of nuisances, § 3. 
Cross reference- Accumulations of trash or weeds, § 11-51 et seq.; offenses generally, § 19-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to clean, mow property for weeds, trash, 11 O.S. 1961, § 20; authority of cities to define and summarily abate nuisances, 50 O.S. 1961, § 16. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    Nuisance: As used in this code of ordinances a "nuisance" shall be defined as unlawfully doing an act, or omitting to perform a duty, or as any thing, condition, act, occupation or use of property which either: 
(1)  Annoys, injures or endangers the peace, health, safety, comfort or repose of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage, any lake basin, stream, creek, gully, street, sidewalk, alley, park or other public property; 
(4)  In any way, renders other persons insecure in life or in the use of property. 
    Public nuisance: A nuisance which affects, at the same time, an entire community, neighborhood, street, area or any considerable number of persons, although the extent of the annoyance or damage inflicted upon the individuals may be unequal. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
    Private nuisance: Any nuisance which is not described above. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Sec. 18-2. - General Applicability. 
    The fact that certain acts, conditions or other things are declared in this article to be nuisances shall not be construed to deny that any other act, fact, condition or thing shall not be a nuisance, if such act, fact, condition or thing would have been a nuisance under this Code or any other ordinances of the City in the absence of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Sec. 18-3. - Nuisances prohibited. 
    It is a violation for any person to create or maintain a nuisance within the City, or to permit a nuisance to remain on premises under his/her control or which he/she owns or leases. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Sec. 18-4. - Person responsible. 
    Every successive owner, manager or responsible person in charge of property who neglects to abate a continuing nuisance upon or in the use of such property, created by a former owner, is liable therefor in the same manner as the one who first created the nuisance. No lapse of time can legalize or in any way permit a nuisance amounting to an actual obstruction of a public right or a public health or safety hazard. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Sec. 18-5. - Remedies against nuisances. 
    The remedies against any nuisance may include: 
(1)  Prosecution on summons and complaint before the Municipal Court; 
(2)  Prosecution on information, complaint or indictment before another appropriate court; 
(3)  Civil action; or 
(4)  Abatement: 
a.  By any person injured as provided in 50 O.S. 1971 Article 12, 14 and 15, as amended or under any other applicable state or federal law, or 
b.  By the city in accordance with the city code of ordinances Section 1-4, as amended or under any other applicable city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Sec. 18-6. - Certain public nuisances defined. 
    In addition to other nuisances declared by other sections of this code of ordinances, the following are hereby declared to be public nuisances. The enumeration hereof of certain public nuisances shall be cumulative and not limit other provisions of law or ordinances defining public or private nuisances either in more general or more specific terms. 
(1)  The sale of unwholesome or unhealthy food or drink, or the keeping of a place where such sales are made. 
(2)  The sale, offering for sale or furnishing of intoxicating beverages in violation of state law or city ordinance, or the keeping of a place where such acts occur. 
(3)  The keeping of a place where persons gamble, in violation of city or state law. 
(4)  The keeping of a place where activities in violation of state law or city ordinance are practiced or permitted to exist. 
(5)  The continued making of loud or unusual noises which may annoy persons of ordinary sensibilities, or the keeping of an animal which makes such noises. 
(6)  Any fire or explosion hazard which endangers the public safety. 
(7)  All trees, vegetation, signs, buildings or other objects which prevent persons driving vehicles approaching an intersection of a public roadway or driveway from having a clear view of traffic and pedestrians approaching such intersection from a cross street, for thirty (30) feet along such cross street measured from the curb line. 
(8)  All buildings and all alterations to buildings made or erected within the fire limits in violation of the applicable regulations concerning the manner and materials of construction. 
(9)  Any use of the public right-of-way which causes large crowds of people to gather, thereby obstructing traffic and the free use of streets and sidewalks, except as may be authorized by law. 
(10)  Any structure or pole which shall become unsafe or dangerous from fire, decay or other cause, or shall become hazardous by reason of age, construction, location, or shall be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the city or its inhabitants from any cause. 
(11)  Any rank weeds, grass, carcasses, accumulations of feces, garbage, refuse, litter or trash as defined in Section 11-52 of the city code, which are or likely to be, breeding places for flies, mosquitoes, rats, snakes, vermin, germs or disease, and the premises on which such exists. 
(12)  Any vehicle, boat or trailer, whether in operating condition or not without a current and valid license plate, when stored or kept in a residential zoning district or kept in a retail commercial zoning district without being screened from view from the public street; and storage of more than one inoperable junk or salvaged car or truck on residentially used lots, whether licensed and/or inspected or not. 
(13)  Maintaining any premise where the sale, distribution, manufacture, keeping or using of any illicit drug or controlled or dangerous substance as defined by Oklahoma Statutes is practiced or carried on in violation of any city or state law. 
(14)  Any graffiti, including writings, drawings, inscriptions, figures or marks of paint, ink, chalk, dye or other similar substances on public or private buildings, structures or places which are not authorized by the property owner or which are not permitted under the city code of ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2503, § 1, 8-24-95) 
Secs. 18-7-18-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-11. - Dangerous buildings-Deemed public nuisance. 
    The leaving standing of any building which shall have been or may hereafter be damaged by fire, explosion, floods, decay or otherwise, to such an extent as to be in a condition that is dangerous to the health or safety of the citizens of Ardmore, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the owner of any property so damaged shall destroy or remove the same at once. 
(Code 1959, § 12-1) 
Sec. 18-12. - Same-Building inspector to inspect; notice to owner to abate condition. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the building inspector of the city to inspect any and all such buildings. In the event he finds same to be a menace either to the health or safety of the citizens of Ardmore, he shall cause such notice to be given to the owner as is consistent with the emergency, and in the event the danger is imminent and immediate, he shall proceed forthwith to abate the same. In the event the danger is not immediate, said building inspector is hereby directed to notify the owner to abate same, by giving notice to said owner; and in the event the owner fails or refuses to abate same within five (5) days, said building inspector is hereby authorized to enter upon said premises and abate said nuisance by destroying or removing said building. It shall be unlawful for anyone to interfere with him in the lawful exercise of this duty. The expense of said removal shall be charged to the owner of the property so damaged or destroyed. 
(Code 1959, § 12-2) 
Cross reference- Appointment of building inspector, § 6-4. 
Chapter 19 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Injuring, defacing, etc., cemetery property, § 7-21; municipal court, Ch. 17; nuisances, Ch. 18. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Failure to Obey Promise or Notice to Appear, Failure to Comply with a Court Order, and Contempt. 
(a)  Failure to Obey a Promise or Notice to Appear. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate his written promise or notice to appear in the Municipal Court. A written promise or notice to appear may be complied with by an appearance of counsel. Any person who shall violate this provision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, up on conviction, shall be punished by a maximum fine of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus costs, and/or by imprisonment for a maximum of sixty (60) days. 
(b)  Failure to Comply with a Court Order. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate, disobey, or otherwise fail to comply with an order of a Municipal Court Judge. Such orders may include, among other things, orders to pay fines and costs and to abate nuisances. Any person who shall violate this provision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, up on conviction, shall be punished by a maximum fine of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus costs, and/or by imprisonment for a maximum of sixty (60) days. 
(c)  Contempt of Court. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit disorderly or insolent behavior during any session of the Court, to refuse to be sworn as a witness, to refuse to answer any legal or proper question, to cause any breach of the peace, cause noise or disturbance which is so near the court as to interrupts its proceedings, to wilfully disobey any process or order lawfully issued or made by the Court, or to wilfully resist the execution of a lawful order or process of the Court. Any person who shall violate this provision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, up on conviction, shall be punished by a maximum fine of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus costs, and/or by imprisonment for a maximum of sixty (60) days. 
( Ord. No. 2975 , § I, 9-8-15) 
Sec. 19-1.1. - Unlawful for minor to neglect or refuse to attend school. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any child who is over the age of five (5) years and under the age of eighteen (18) years, and who has not finished four (4) years of high school work to neglect or refuse to attend and comply with the rules of some public, private or other school, or receive an education by other means, for the full term the schools of the district are in session. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful for a parent, guardian, custodian or other person having control of a child who is over the age of five (5) years and under the age of eighteen (18) years, and who has not finished four (4) years of high school work, to neglect or refuse to cause or compel such child to attend and comply with the rules of some public, private or other school, unless other means of education are provided, for the full term the schools of the district are in session. 
(c)  Provided, that this section shall not apply: 
(1)  If any child is prevented from attending school by reason of mental or physical disability, to be determined by the board of education of the district upon a certificate of the school physician or public health physician, or, if no such physician is available, a duly-licensed and practicing physician; 
(2)  If any such child is excused from attendance of school, due to an emergency, by the principal teacher of the school in which such child is enrolled, at the request of the parent, guardian, custodian or other person having control of such child. 
(d)  This section may be enforced by any police officer of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, who may take into custody any child he determines to be absent from school in violation of this section and deliver the child to the attendance officer or other appropriate official of the school district. 
(e)  Any minor violating the provisions of this section shall be dealt with in accordance with Youth Court Ordinance No. 2228. Any parent, guardian, custodian, or other person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 2365, § I, 1-6-92) 
Cross reference- Youth court, § 17-12 et seq.; presence and conduct of minors on streets and public places, §§ 19-101 et seq. 
Sec. 19-2. - Offense defined. 
    Offense, or misdemeanor, is hereby defined to mean (1) the doing of some act prohibited, or failure to perform some duty commanded, by the charter or ordinances of the city, and (2) which is declared unlawful or for the violation of which a penalty or punishment is provided. 
(Code 1959, § 13-1; Ord. No. 1434, § 2, 5-1-63) 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of code, § 1-4. 
Sec. 19-3. - Abandoned refrigerators, similar containers-Unlawful to leave where accessible to children. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling or any place accessible to children in the city any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door or lock which may not be released for opening from the inside of said icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1959, § 11-11) 
Sec. 19-4. - Same-Locks to be removed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling or any place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight snap lock or other device on it without first removing the doors from said icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1959, § 11-12) 
Sec. 19-5. - Advertising, distributing handbills, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the fire limits of the city to promiscuously distribute or hand out to persons on the sidewalks or streets, free handbills, circulars or papers, or to place the same in automobiles upon the street without the permission of the owners of such automobiles. 
(Code 1959, § 4-39) 
Sec. 19-6. - Aiding in commission of offense. 
    When no punishment for counseling or aiding in the commission of a particular offense is expressly prescribed by ordinance, every person who counsels or aids another in the commission of such is guilty of an offense, or other misdemeanor, and punishable in the same manner as the principal offender. 
(Code 1959, § 13-3) 
Sec. 19-7. - Aiding prisoners to escape. 
    It is unlawful for any person, in any illegal manner, to set at liberty, rescue or attempt to set at liberty or rescue, any prisoner or prisoners, from any officer or employee of the city having legal custody of the same or from the city jail or other place of confinement by the city, or to assist such prisoner in any manner to escape from such prison or custody. 
(Code 1959, § 13-40) 
Sec. 19-8. - Assault and battery. 
(a)  Assault defined. An assault is any wilful and unlawful attempt or offer with force or violence to do a corporal hurt to another. 
(b)  Battery defined. A battery is any wilful and unlawful use of force or violence upon the person of another. 
(c)  Prohibited. It is unlawful to commit an assault or an assault and battery within the city, and any person committing an assault or an assault and battery within the city, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1959, § 13-33) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prevent assaults, 11 O.S. 1961, § 655. 
Sec. 19-9. - Attempts to commit offense. 
    Every person who attempts to commit an offense against the charter or ordinances of the city, and in such attempt does any act toward the commission of such offense, but fails or is prevented or intercepted in the perpetration thereof, is guilty of an offense and shall be punished in the manner prescribed for the attempted offense itself. 
(Code 1959, § 13-2) 
Sec. 19-10. - Climbing on moving trains. 
    It is unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to or in any manner attach himself to, any railway train, locomotive or railway car, while such is in motion, within the city, unless such person is acting in line of duty. 
(Code 1959, § 19-20) 
Sec. 19-11. - Disturbing public assemblies. 
    It is unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful public gathering or assembly by making noise, by rude, indecent or improper behavior, by profane, improper or loud language, or in any other manner, either within the place of assembly or within hearing distance thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 13-31) 
Sec. 19-12. - Disturbing religious assemblies. 
    It is unlawful for any person to disturb any congregation or assembly of persons meeting for religious worship by making noise, by rude, indecent or improper behavior, by profane, improper or loud language, or in any other manner, either within the place of worship or within hearing distance thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 13-30) 
Sec. 19-13. - Disturbing the peace. 
    It is unlawful for any person to disturb the peace of another or others by violent, obstreperous or improper conduct or carriage, by loud or unusual noise, or by unseemly, obscene, offensive or abusive language. A person shall be guilty of disturbing the peace if he or she: 
1.  Uses obscene, offensive, abusive, profane, vulgar, threatening, violent or insulting language or other disorderly conduct; 
2.  Makes loud and/or offensive noises or uses any loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other electrical or mechanical device intended to increase volume of sound at any place or places within the City in such a manner which unreasonably, continuously, or substantially annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others; 
3.  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of safety of his/her life, limb, or health or whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; or 
4.  Causes, provokes, or engages in any fight, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger life, limb, or health or whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. 
    Any person violating this Section shall be punished by a fine of up to Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) plus court costs or by imprisonment for up to thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1959, § 13-29; Ord. No. 3009, § I, 8-21-17 ) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit breaches of the peace and disturbances, 11 O.S. 1961, § 22-110. 
Sec. 19-14. - Escaping from custody. 
    It is unlawful for any person confined in the city jail or other place of confinement by the city, or working upon the streets or other public places of the city in pursuance of any judgment, or otherwise held in legal custody by authority of the city, to escape or attempt to escape from any such jail, prison or custody. 
(Code 1959, § 13-41) 
Sec. 19-15. - False fire alarms. 
    It is unlawful for any person to turn in a false fire alarm, or in any manner to deceive or attempt to deceive the fire department or any officer or employee thereof with reference to any fire alarm, or to cause the fire department or its officers or employees to make a useless or unnecessary run. 
(Code 1959, § 13-43) 
Sec. 19-16. - False representations to city officer, agency. 
    It is unlawful for any person knowingly to make any material misrepresentation to any officer or agency of the city government in any official application to, or official dealing or negotiation with, such officer or agency; or to commit perjury before any tribunal or officer of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 13-44) 
Sec. 19-17. - Gambling-Prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to play, to open or cause to be opened, or to operate, carry on or conduct, whether for hire or not, any game of faro, monte, poker, roulette, craps, any banking, percentage or other game played with dice, cards or any device, for money, checks, chips, credit or any other thing of value; to set up, operate or permit to be operated, any slot machine or other device whatsoever where money, checks, chips, credit or any other thing of value are played, where the act of playing the same might result in a loss to the party playing; or to gamble knowingly in any other manner; or to gamble in any manner; or knowingly to permit his or its premises, houses, lot or other property to be used in connection with, or for, any act declared unlawful in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 13-4) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prevent, suppress gambling houses, 11 O.S. 1961, § 654. 
Sec. 19-18. - Same-Loitering around premises prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to loiter about in the immediate vicinity where a person or persons are gambling, whether by playing games, operating a slot machine or other device, or otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 13-5) 
Cross reference- Loitering on premises where intoxicating beverages sold, § 4-2; loitering, playing on poolroom or domino parlor premises by minors, § 15-55. 
Sec. 19-19. - Illicit conduct; consorting; loitering around house of prostitution. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in illicit sexual intercourse or any other immoral act, or knowingly consort with a prostitute or other person of immoral vocation, or to consort with another for an immoral purpose, whether in a public or private place in the city, or to loiter about a house or place of prostitution or a house or place devoted to lewd or immoral acts. 
(Code 1959, § 13-14) 
Sec. 19-20. - Illicit sexual relations. 
    Illicit sexual intercourse is sexual intercourse with any person other than one's lawful husband or wife. 
(Code 1959, § 13-12) 
Sec. 19-21. - Immoral movies, shows. 
    It is unlawful for any person to exhibit any immoral moving picture, to produce an immoral performance or show of any kind, or to permit such a picture, performance or show to be shown or given in or about his premises or place of business. 
(Code 1959, § 13-7) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prevent indecent shows, exhibitions or concerts, 11 O.S. 1961, § 655. 
Sec. 19-21.1. - Display of lewd or indecent publications or materials in places frequented by minors. 
(a)  Every person who shall wilfully or knowingly engage in the business of selling, lending, giving away, showing, advertising for sale or distributing to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years or who has in his possession with intent to engage in the said business or to otherwise offer for sale or commercial distribution to any individual under the age of eighteen (18) years or who shall display at newsstands or any other business establishment frequented by minors under the age of eighteen (18) years or where said minors are or may be invited as a part of the general public any motion picture, live show, or any still picture or photograph or any book, pocket book, pamphlet or magazine the cover or content of which exploits, is devoted to, or is principally made up of descriptions or depictions of illicit sex or sexual immorality or which is lewd, lascivious, or indecent, or which consists of pictures of nude or partially denuded figures posed or presented in a manner to provoke or arouse lust or passion or to exploit sex, lust or perversion for commercial gain or any article or instrument of indecent or immoral use shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(b)  For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  "Description or depictions of illicit sex or sexual immorality" shall mean: 
a.  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
b.  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy. 
c.  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, public region, buttock or female breast. 
(2)  "Nude or partially denuded figures" shall mean: 
a.  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
1.  Human genitals; 
2.  Public regions; 
3.  Buttock; 
4.  Female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola. 
b.  Human male genitals in a discernably turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(3)  "Knowingly" shall mean having knowledge of the character and content of the publication or failure on notice to exercise reasonable inspection which would disclose the content and character of the same. 
(Ord. No. 1917, §§ 1-4, 5-7-79) 
Sec. 19-21.1.1. - Location of adult novelty shops. 
    Adult novelty shops cannot be located within one thousand (1,000) feet of: 
(1)  Any building primarily and regularly used for worship services and religious activities; 
(2)  Any public or private school; 
(3)  Any public park or playground; 
(4)  Any public library; or 
(5)  Any land zoned or used for residential purposes. 
    "Adult novelty shop" means a commercial establishment that displays, sells, or offers for sale instruments, devices, or paraphernalia designed or marketed primarily for use to stimulate human genital organs or for use in connection with sadomasochistic practices; and 
    "Sadomasochistic practices" means flagellation or torture by or upon a person clothed or naked, or the condition of being fettered, bound or otherwise physically restrained on the part of one so clothed or naked. 
    Provided, that if any such building used for worship and religious activities, any public or private school, any public park or playground, any public library or any land zoned or used for residential purposes shall be established within one thousand (1,000) feet of any such premises after the premises have been established, this shall not be a bar to the continuation of the business so long as it has been in continuous force and effect. The distance indicated in this section shall be measured from the nearest property line of such church or school to the nearest public entrance door to the premises of the adult novelty shop along the street right-of-way line providing the nearest direct route usually traveled by pedestrians between such points. For purposes of determining measured distance, property situated on the opposite side of the street from such church or school shall be considered as if it were located on the same side of the street with such church or school. 
(Ord. No. 2764, § I, 4-19-04) 
Sec. 19-22. - Impersonating city officer, employee. 
    It is unlawful for any person to impersonate any officer or employee of the city, falsely represent himself to be an officer or employee of the city, or exercise or attempt to exercise any of the duties, functions or powers of an officer or employee of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 13-42) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 19-23. - Indecent exposure. 
    It is unlawful for any person to appear in any public place in the city in a state of nudity or in any offensive, indecent or lewd dress; or to make an indecent public exposure of his or her person. 
(Code 1959, § 13-19) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit public indecencies, 11 O.S. 1961, § 654. 
Sec. 19-24. - Indecent, lewd conduct. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct himself or herself in an unseemly, lewd or indecent manner or in a manner offensive to the good morals of the city, in any public or private place within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 13-20) 
Sec. 19-25. - Injuring, destroying, etc. public or private property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to destroy, injure, deface, besmear or molest any structure, building, outbuilding, fence or other appurtenance thereof, or any other property, real or personal, public or private, not belonging to himself. 
(Code 1959, § 13-36) 
Sec. 19-26. - Loitering in railroad station, bus station, etc. 
    It is unlawful for any person not acting within line of duty, not having any proper business or not being on any proper mission requiring his presence there, to loiter within a railroad station or other railway building, bus station or other transportation facility. 
(Code 1959, § 19-21) 
Cross reference- Loitering on premises where alcoholic beverages sold, § 4-2; loitering, playing on poolroom or domino parlor premises by minors prohibited, § 15-55. 
Sec. 19-27. - Loud noises, music. 
    It is unlawful for any person to disturb the peace and quietude of any part of the city by operating, having operated or permitting to be operated, any contrivance, whether electric or not, with or without a loudspeaker, in such a manner as to emit loud music or noise. 
(Code 1959, § 13-32) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prevent noises, 11 O.S. 1961, § 655. 
Sec. 19-28. - Misrepresentation of weights and measures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, any food, fuel, clothing or any other commodity which does not weight or measure fully as much, according to standard weights and measures of the state, as that for which it is sold or offered for sale. 
(Code 1959, § 4-43) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prescribe rules for weighing, measuring commodities, 11 O.S. 1961, § 662. 
Sec. 19-29. - Motor vehicles; tampering with, unlawfully driving, etc. 
    It is unlawful for any person to crank, start, or otherwise meddle with, molest, enter, occupy, loiter in, take or drive away any automobile or other vehicle belonging to another when it is within the city, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 13-35) 
Sec. 19-29.1. - Motor vehicle operators not to elude police officers. 
    Any operator of a motor vehicle who has received visual and audible signal, a red light and a siren, from a police officer driving a motor vehicle showing the same to be an official police patrol car directing the said operator to bring his vehicle to a stop and such operator who unlawfully increases his speed or extinguishes his lights in an attempt to elude or escape from such police officer or who unlawfully attempts in any other manner to elude such police officer or who does elude or escapes such police officer is guilty of an offense against the public. 
    Upon arrest and conviction, such operator shall be fined or imprisoned in accordance with the general penalty, Code of the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 1641, §§ 1, 2, 5-18-70) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1641, §§ 1 and 2, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion herein as § 19-29.1 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 19-30. - Drugs, paraphernalia, and inhalants. 
(a)  Definitions. The definitions shall be the same as those used by the State of Oklahoma which can be found in 63 Ok. St. §2-101 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Drugs. It shall be unlawful to sell, use, possess or purchase narcotic drugs, narcotic drug preparations, barbiturates, amphetamines or marihuana in violation of the laws and statutes of the state. Every person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by a fine of up to Eight Hundred Dollars ($800.00) plus court costs or by imprisonment for up to sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  Paraphernalia. The use, possession, distribution, and manufacture of drug paraphernalia are declared hazardous and detrimental to the public health and well-being of the citizens of the City. No person shall use or possess drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled dangerous substance in violation of the Uniform Controlled Dangerous Substances Act. Every person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by a fine of up to Eight Hundred Dollars ($800.00) plus court costs or by imprisonment for up to sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  Inhalants. It shall be unlawful to disturb the peace of any person while intoxicated by any cause including by deliberately smelling, inhaling, breathing, drinking or otherwise consuming any compound, liquid, chemical, narcotic, drug, or any other substance or chemical containing any ketones, aldehydes, organic acetones, ether, or chlorinated hydrocarbons, such as gasoline, glue, fingernail polish, adhesive cement, mucilage, dope, or any other substance or combination thereof containing solvents releasing toxic vapors which can cause the conditions of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, elation, stupefaction, paralysis, irrationality, dulling of the brain or nervous system, or any other changing, distorting or disturbing of the eyesight, thinking processes, judgment, balance or coordination of the person. Every person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) plus court costs or by imprisonment for up to thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
1.  Exceptions. This provision shall not apply to any person who inhales, breathes, or drinks, or otherwise consumes any of the substances specified pursuant to the direction of any lawful prescription of a licensed medical professional, nor to the consumption of intoxicating liquor or beer in a place and manner as authorized by law.
