No member of this board may serve for more than one (1) five-year term consecutively, provided that any person who is appointed to serve an unexpired term of less than three (3) years may be reappointed to serve an additional five-year term. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83; Ord. No. 2282, § 1, 7-18-88) 
Sec. 21-43. - Vacancies. 
    In the event of a vacancy on the public golf course board, such vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term as provided in section 21-42 above. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-44. - Removal of members. 
    The board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore may remove any member at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-45. - Meetings. 
    All meetings of the board shall be public and on or before the fifteenth day of December of each year the chairman of the board shall submit to the city clerk a written statement designating the date and time of the board's regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-46. - Attendance. 
    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on a semi-annual basis, the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meeting during the preceding six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-47. - Organization. 
    There shall be a chairman, vice chairman and secretary of the public golf course board, elected by the board, and serving at the board's pleasure. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-48. - Rules. 
    The public golf course board shall make such rules as may be necessary for the governing of such board, not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules of the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-49. - Record of proceedings. 
    The public golf course board shall keep and preserve a true record of all proceedings and official acts, and said record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-50. - Report to the board of commissioners. 
    The public golf course board shall, on or before the second Monday of April of each year, make a report to the board of commissioners concerning its activities during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-51. - Budget. 
    On or before the second Monday of April of each year, the public golf course board shall prepare and submit to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore a budget. The budget shall include the necessary expenses for operation, maintenance, repair, and improvements of the golf course for the ensuing fiscal year. The board of commissioners may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portions of each budget as are not defrayed from the income from the golf course. 
    A fund shall be established and created for the accounting and management of the golf course. 
    All revenues shall be to the exclusive use of the golf course for maintenance, operation and improvements. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Sec. 21-52. - Duties. 
    The board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore and the city manager shall consult with the public golf course board regarding the planning, construction, improvements, furnishings and equipment of any new and existing golf course facilities, and shall give due consideration to the recommendations of the public golf course board on any matter relating to the golf course. 
    The public golf course board shall, subject to the review of the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, have control of expenditures of all monies collected and placed to the credit of the public golf course board, and shall be accountable for all monies spent. 
    The public golf course board may review applications for the employees of the golf course and may participate in the screening of all applicants and they may recommend to the city manager the hiring of employees at the golf course. The public golf course board shall establish those rules and regulations pertaining to the golf course and its operation and management as they deem appropriate. 
    The public golf course board may receive gifts or bequests of money, other personal property and real estate for the benefit of the golf course and all such property shall be used solely for the purpose or purposes for which it was given. 
    The public golf course board shall have the control of the public golf course, subject only to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore. 
    The public golf course board shall review all claims submitted concerning the public golf course and make recommendations for their payment or denial to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2135, § 1, 12-19-83) 
Secs. 21-53-21-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 21-61. - Created. 
    There is hereby created within the city a park and recreation advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-62. - Composition. 
    The park and recreation advisory board shall be composed of nine (9) persons who shall be citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2604, § 1, 3-1-99) 
Sec. 21-63. - Appointment of members. 
    The president, or its designee, of the H.F.V. Wilson Community Center Board, the chairman, or its designee, of the city lakes board and the chairman, or its designee, of the public golf course board shall be members of the park and recreation advisory board. The remaining members of the park and recreation advisory board shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city commission. All annual appointments to the board shall be made on the second regular commissioner meeting each May. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79; Ord. No. 2622, § I, 9-7-99) 
Sec. 21-64. - Terms of members. 
    The citizen members of the park and recreation board shall serve for a term of three (3) years provided, that in the case of the first board under this article, three (3) shall be appointed for one year, and four (4) for two (2) years and four (4) for three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-65. - Removal of member. 
    The mayor may, by and with the consent of the commission, remove any member of the park and recreation board for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-66. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board, occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise, shall be reported to the city commission and be filled in like manner as original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-67. - Compensation of members. 
    No member of the park and recreation board shall receive compensation as such for his services. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-68. - Attendance of members. 
    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on a semiannual basis the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) per cent unexcused absences from the regular meetings during the six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-69. - Meetings. 
    The park and recreation board shall hold at least one meeting per month, and adjourn meetings when necessary. All meetings of the board shall be public. On or before the fifteenth day of December of each year the chairman shall submit to the city clerk a written statement designating the date and time of the board's regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-70. - Organization. 
    The park and recreation board shall, immediately after its appointment, meet and organize by the election of one of their number as president, and such other officers as they deem necessary and establish a day and time for regular monthly meetings. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-71. - Rules, regulations, bylaws. 
    The park and recreation board shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its guidance not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any rules or policies of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-72. - Annual report. 
    The park and recreation board shall make, on or before the second Monday in April, an annual report to the city commission stating the conditions of the parks, the amount of money received and spent and for what purposes, the recreation programs offered and number of participants in each of the proposed recreational programs for the coming year, give recommendations for park and recreation improvements and any other information that may be requested by the commission or the board may deem as general interest. 
(Ord. No. 1931, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 21-73. - Civic auditorium. 
    The parks and recreation advisory board shall have the general oversight of the civic auditorium as part of their duties and responsibilities. The board shall, among other things, recommend revenue sources, fees and charges to be paid for use of the premises, policies concerning uses in relation to the charges to be made and improvements and funding to the board of commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2604, § 2, 3-1-99) 
Secs. 21-74-21-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY LAKES ADVISORY BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2222, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1986, amended the Code by the addition of §§ 21-34-21-34.11, which provisions have been redesignated and included by the editor herein as Art. V, §§ 21-81-21-92, to facilitate classification. 
Cross reference- Fishing, hunting and boating, § 21-15 et seq. 

Sec. 21-81. - Created; name. 
    There is hereby created a city lakes advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-82. - Composition; appointment; term of members. 
    The city lakes advisory board shall consist of seven (7) members whose appointment shall be made by the mayor with approval of the city commission. The city manager, the water and municipal lakes superintendent, and the parks director shall be ex officio members of the board. All members of the board shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. Three (3) members of the board shall initially be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Two (2) members of the board shall initially be appointed for a term of two (2) years. Two (2) members of the board shall be initially appointed for a term of one (1) year. Thereafter, each member shall serve for a term of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-83. - Vacancies. 
    In the event of a vacancy on the city lakes advisory board, such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-84. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor of the City of Ardmore may, with the consent of the city commission, remove any or all members at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-85. - Meetings. 
    The city lakes advisory board shall hold at least one meeting per month, and special meetings when necessary. All meetings of the board shall be held in accordance with the open meeting laws of the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-86. - Organization. 
    There shall be a chairman, vice chairman, and secretary of the city lakes advisory board, elected by the board, and serving at the board's pleasure, and such other officers as they deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-87. - Compensation of members. 
    No member of the city lakes advisory board shall receive compensation of any kind for his services while serving on this board. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-88. - Attendance. 
    The chairman of the board shall report to the mayor on a semiannual basis, the attendance records of the members of the board. The chairman shall request the replacement of any member who has had more than fifty (50) percent unexcused absences from the regular meetings during the preceding six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-89. - Rules. 
    The city lakes advisory board shall keep and preserve a true record of all proceedings and official acts, and said record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-90. - Report to the city commission. 
    The city lakes advisory board shall, on or before the second Monday of April of each year, make a report to the board of commissioners concerning its activities during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-91. - Budget. 
    On or before the second Monday of April of each year, the city lakes advisory board shall prepare and submit to the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore a budget. The budget shall include the necessary expenses for operation, maintenance, repair and improvements of the city lakes for the ensuing year. The city commission may appropriate from the revenues of the city such portions of each budget as are not defrayed from the income of the city lakes. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Sec. 21-92. - Duties. 
    The board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore and the city manager may consult with the city lakes advisory board regarding the planning, construction, improvements, furnishings, and equipment of any new and existing lakes and/or facilities, and shall give due consideration to the recommendations of the city lakes advisory board. 
    The city lakes advisory board shall advise the board of commissioners on expenditures of one hundred (100) percent of all monies collected and placed to the credit of the hunting and fishing special fund. 
    The city lakes advisory board may review applications for the employees of the city lakes and may participate in the screening of all applicants, and they may recommend to the city manager the hiring of employees at the city lakes. The city lakes advisory board shall make recommendations to the city commission establishing those rules and regulations pertaining to the city lakes for fishing, hunting, wildlife management, water recreation, and its operation and management as they deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-4-86) 
Cross reference- Fishing, hunting and boating, § 21-15 et seq.

Chapter 23 - PLUMBING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2778, adopted Feb. 7, 2005, amended Ch. 23 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 23, §§ 23-1-23-18, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2067, § 2, adopted June 21, 1982; Ord. No. 2103, §§ 1, 2, adopted April 18, 1983; Ord. No. 2238, §§ 2, 3, adopted Oct. 20, 1986; Ord. No. 2284, § II, adopted July 5, 1988; Ord. No. 2715, adopted June 16, 2002. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 6; electrical code, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; international mechanical code, Ch. 12; health and sanitation, Ch. 13; housing maintenance code, Ch. 14; utilities, Ch. 30. 

Sec. 23-1. - [Adoption of International Plumbing Code.] 
    That a certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of Ardmore, being marked and designated as the International Plumbing Code, 2015 edition, including Appendix B, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the City of Ardmore, in the State of Oklahoma, regulating and governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said plumbing code on file in the office of the City of Ardmore are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this legislation, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 23-2 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 1, 2-7-05; Ord. No. 3037, 8-6-18 ) 
Sec. 23-2. - [Amendments.] 
    The following sections are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1. Insert: City of Ardmore 
Section 106.6.2. Insert: Chapter 34 Ardmore Code of Ordinances 
Section 106.6.3. Insert: 50%; 50% 
Section 108.4. Insert: Misdemeanor; $500 
Section 108.5. Insert: $200; $500 
Section 305.4.1. Insert: 12inches; 12 inches 
Section 903.1. Insert: 12 inches 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 2, 2-7-05; Ord. No. 3037, 8-6-18 ) 
Sec. 23-3. - Plumbing inspector-Office created, appointment. 
    The office of plumbing inspector is hereby created. The plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 8, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-4. - Same-Qualifications. 
    Any person appointed as plumbing inspector shall have not less than five (5) years practical experience in the plumbing field, be certified within one (1) year, by a state approved agency, as a plumbing inspector, and shall not be interested either directly or indirectly in any firm or corporation engaged in the plumbing business. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 9, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-5. - Plumbing review board combined. 
    The plumbing review board formerly governed by this section has been combined with the mechanical board: Designated as the plumbing/mechanical code board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 11, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-6. - Plumbers to have State of Oklahoma plumbing contractor license. 
    No person shall engage in the plumbing business or contract plumbing in the city or connect to any city sewer or water outside of the city without holding a state plumbing contractor license. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 12, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-7. - Plumbers to register with the city: Fee, expiration, renewal of registration. 
    All persons engaged in plumbing within the city shall register with the city. The amount of such fee (or fees) shall be as established in Chapter 34, the General Schedule of Fees. 
    All registrations shall expire August 1 of each year. 
    If registrations have not been renewed within thirty (30) days after expiration date, the first year fee shall be charged. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 13, 2-7-05; Ord. No. 3045, § I, 8-20-18 ) 
Sec. 23-8. - Apprentice plumbers. 
    [An apprentice plumber is] any person sixteen (16) years of age or over who, as his principal occupation, is engaged in learning and assisting in the installation of plumbing under the direct supervision of a licensed journeyman plumber or plumbing contractor. All apprentices shall be registered with the State of Oklahoma's Construction Industries Board and shall be able to show proof of registration at any time while working as an apprentice plumber. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 14, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-9. - Plumbing trucks to bear firm's name and license number. 
    Every truck, car or pickup used in the business of installing plumbing shall have a sign of the outside of both of the front doors bearing the firm's name and Oklahoma plumbing contractor license number. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 15, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-10. - Landscape irrigation systems-installation exempt from provisions. 
    The installation of landscape irrigation systems in, on or under lawns, yards, shrubbery or other locations outside of any structure or structures is hereby declared to be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 16, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-11. - Same-Connection to city water lines; inspection required. 
    After such landscape irrigation system has been installed and before such system is connected to the city water lines, the plumbing inspector of the city shall examine the same and issue a permit for the connection of such valves system to the city water lines. Such system shall include a back siphon vacuum breaker or breakers as required by such inspector. Connection of said system to the city water lines shall be made and done by a licensed plumber. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 17, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-12. - Same-Installers not to interfere with sewer, gases or water lines. 
    No person installing such landscape irrigation system shall interfere with, connect to, or work in any way in connection with the sewer lines, gas lines, water lines, or other plumbing lines. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 18, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 23-13. - Plumbing inspector to decide disagreements. 
    Any disagreement between a plumbing contractor and the gas company shall be referred to the city plumbing inspector, and his decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2778, § 19, 2-7-05) 
Chapter 24 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Daily report to police of purchases of automobile accessories required, § 15-11; municipal court, Ch. 17; offenses generally, § 19-1 et seq.; impersonating city officer, § 19-22; refusing to assist city officers, § 19-39; resisting police officer, § 19-40; chief of police to issue taxi operators permit, § 31-13. 
State Law reference- Authority of police chief, 11 O.S. 1961, § 574; powers of police officers generally, 11 O.S. 1961, § 575; removal, 11 O.S. 1961, § 577. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Established. 
    There shall be an administrative department entitled the police department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-9) 
Sec. 24-2. - Chief of police to supervise, control; appointment of chief. 
    The head of the police department shall be the chief of police. The city manager shall appoint the chief of police with approval of the board of commissioners. Subject to supervision and control by the city manager, the chief of police shall have supervision and control of the police department. 
(Code 1959, § 1-9) 
Sec. 24-3. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department: 
(a)  To have charge of the city jail and any other prisons which the city may establish; 
(b)  To apprehend and arrest on view or on warrant and bring to justice all violators of the Charter and ordinances of the city; 
(c)  To suppress all riots, affrays and unlawful assemblies which may come to their knowledge, and generally to keep the peace; 
(d)  To serve all warrants, writs, executions and other processes properly directed and delivered to them; 
(e)  To apprehend and arrest persons for violations of federal and state law, as provided by law, and to turn them over to proper authorities; 
(f)  And in all respects to perform all duties pertaining to the offices of policemen. 
(g)  Investigation of suspected arson. 
(Code 1959, § 1-10) 
Sec. 24-4. - Disposition of lost, stolen property. 
(a)  Lost abandoned property. Lost or abandoned property which may be found by any officer or employee of the city shall be turned over to the police department. All such property which comes into the custody of the police department shall be disposed of by the chief of police as provided in 15 O. S. 1961, sections 511 through 518, as amended, or any applicable provisions of law enacted thereafter. 
(b)  Stolen, embezzled property. Stolen or embezzled property coming into hands of policemen, shall be disposed of as provided in 22 O. S. 1961, sections 1321 through 1325 as amended, or any applicable provisions of law enacted thereafter. 
(Code 1959, § 1-11) 
Sec. 24-5. - Police records kept on file. 
    That all records of the city police department older than ten (10) years and not otherwise mentioned or limited by the provisions of Title 11 Ok. St. Ann. § 22-131 may be destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 2672, § I, 2-5-01) 
Secs. 24-6-24-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE RESERVE FORCE 

Sec. 24-15. - Established; membership; police chief to head. 
(a)  Established. An auxiliary police force to be known as police reserve is hereby established. 
(b)  Membership. It shall be composed of personnel who have volunteered to join the organization and whose application for membership has been accepted and who have complied with all the rules, regulations and orders provided for the conduct and control of the members thereof. It shall be composed of not to exceed fifty (50) members. 
(c)  Police chief to head. The police reserve shall be separate and distinct from the police department of this city, the commanding officer of which shall be appointed by the chief of police, but shall be headed by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-16. - Members to be under control, etc. of chief of police. 
    The members of the police reserve shall be under the authority, control and command of the chief of police subject to all of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 2, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-17. - Appointment of members. 
    Members of the police reserve shall be appointed from a list of eligibles compiled as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 2, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-18. - Qualifications of members; application; oath required. 
    A list of eligibles accompanied by a complete set of fingerprints or supplemented immediately by fingerprinting by the police division, which fingerprints shall be checked by the identification bureau to ascertain any criminal record of such person. The applications shall state the residence of the applicant. Each applicant shall be an actual resident of Carter County, Oklahoma, and shall furnish satisfactory proof of good character, temperate habits, freedom from communicable diseases and physical ability to perform the duties of the position for which he seeks appointment. He shall furnish three (3) references and attach letters of recommendation from said references, to the application. The application shall be on the form prescribed by the chief of police and approved by the city manager. All names upon a list of eligibles shall subscribe to an oath that he will observe and obey the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of this State, and the laws of this Nation, this state and this city and that he will carry out the duties of a member of the police reserve force of this city to the best of his ability. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 3, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-19. - Duties. 
(a)  The duties of the police reserve force, subject at all times to the direction, supervision and control of the chief of police, shall be to assist the regular members of the police department of this city in the enforcement of laws and the maintenance of peace and order during periods of emergency designated by the chief of police. The chief may by order establish rules and regulations to govern the police reserve force, to fix the specific duties of its members, and to provide for the maintenance of discipline. He may change such orders from time to time, and he may command members of the police reserve force to obey instructions of regular police officers in carrying out their duties. 
(b)  The chief may prescribe other duties than those mentioned herein to be performed by the police reserve force, not inconsistent with the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 4, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-20. - Identification card, insignia to be carried. 
    An identification card and such other insignia or evidence of identity as the chief may prescribe shall be issued to each member, who must carry the card and other identification at all times while on duty. Each member shall surrender the card and other identification upon the termination of his membership. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 5, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-21. - Renewal of commission. 
    All commissions shall expire automatically at midnight on the thirty-first day of December in any year. A renewal of said commission for any next ensuing year may be had by the filing of an application by any holder of any commission. Said application shall consist of a post card properly filled out by the applicant giving his full name and address and giving the number of his existing commission. This application shall be filed with the chief of police. If application for renewal is not presented on or before January thirty-first of the year for which renewal is sought, then anyone desiring the commission as a member of the police reserve shall make application as in the first instance where an applicant did not hold a commission. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 5, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-22. - Removal of members; resignations. 
    Membership of any person may be terminated by the chief of police at any time for any cause deemed sufficient by the chief of police. Any member may resign from the police force reserve at any time, but it shall be the duty to notify the chief of his resignation. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 6, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-23. - Authority of chief to increase, diminish size of force. 
    The chief of police may by order diminish or expand the membership of the police reserve force as emergency may require within the limit hereinbefore established. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 7, 7-15-67) 
Sec. 24-24. - Power, authority of force. 
(a)  Carrying of firearms. Members of the police reserve force shall, while on duty, carry firearms on the express written order of the chief of police. 
(b)  Breaking and entering. No member of the police reserve force shall break into or otherwise forcefully enter upon any private property or enter the dwelling or habitation of another person without the consent of the owner or occupant except when immediately accompanied by a regular member of the police department of this city, who then and there requests his aid in the enforcement of the law. 
(c)  Power of arrest. A member of the police reserve force shall have the following powers of arrest and none others: 
(1)  He may arrest for a public offense committed in his presence. 
(2)  He may arrest a person who had in fact committed a felony, although not in his presence. 
(3)  When a felony has in fact been committed, he may make an arrest when he has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it. 
(4)  He may go lend physical aid to any regular member of the police department in making any lawful arrest, when authorized by the chief of police, or requested by any regular member of the police department of this city. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 8, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-25. - Dismissal for violation of rules, regulations, etc. 
    In addition to the penalties provided by law, any violation of law under color of the performance of his duties as a member of the police reserve force, and any breach of the rules and regulations established by the chief of police, shall subject any member to summary expulsion and the fact thereof may be published at the order of the chief. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 9, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-26. - Impersonation of police reserve member; penalty. 
    It shall be misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) for any person to wear, carry or display a police reserve force identification card or otherwise deceitfully represent himself to be connected with the police reserve force, unless he is in fact a member thereof in good standing. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 10, 5-15-67) 
Sec. 24-27. - Chief to prescribe uniform, badges. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe the uniform and badges for the members of the police reserve force and direct the manner in which the same shall be worn. Any person other than a member of said force who shall wear such uniform or badge as may be prescribed shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 11, 5-15-67) 
Secs. 24-28-24-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT FUND[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to adopt a pension and retirement plan, § 7(4). 
Cross reference- Firemen's relief and pension fund, § 10-38; employee retirement system, Ch. 20, Art. III. 
State Law reference- Pension and retirement fund generally, 11 O.S. 1961, § 541 et seq. 

Sec. 24-38. - System established. 
    A police pension and retirement system of the city is hereby created for the purpose of providing pension retirement allowances and other benefits for the policemen of the city, their wives and children, in accordance with 11 O.S. 1961, sections 541 through 541w, as amended, and as may be amended and all other provisions of law relating thereto. 
(Code 1959, § 1-47) 
Sec. 24-39. - Board of trustees-To administer system. 
    There shall be a board of trustees of the police pension and retirement system, which shall be constituted and be organized as provided by state law, and which shall have the powers and duties prescribed by state law. Said system shall operate in all respects in accordance with state law, and all provisions of state law relating thereto are hereby adopted. 
(Code 1959, § 1-47) 
Sec. 24-40. - Same-Membership; election; term. 
    The annual election of a member of the police department to serve for three (3) years on the board of trustees of the police pension and retirement system shall be held every year on the day that the original election was held to elect the three (3) policemen to serve on the board originally. Not more than ten (10) days and not less than five (5) days prior to the election, the city clerk shall call the election and place in the United States Mail a notice thereof properly addressed to each member of the police department. The call and notice shall state the place and the hour or hours of said election. Only policemen as defined by law shall be permitted to vote. The election shall be by secret ballots, which shall be placed in a ballot box provided by the city. The city clerk and city treasurer shall conduct said election, canvass and count the ballots and certify the results to the board of commissioners of the city, who shall by motion or resolution declare the policeman who is elected to the board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 1-48) 
Sec. 24-40.1. - Same-Annual election of policeman members; date board to meet to approve disbursements. 
(a)  On the first Monday of May of each year, an election shall be held for the election of one policeman to serve on the board of trustees of the police pension and retirement board. 
(b)  On the first Monday of each month, the board of trustees of the police pension and retirement board will hold a meeting to approve disbursements. 
(Ord. No. 1934, § 1, 5-31-79) 
Sec. 24-41. - Same-Vacancies; bond required of members. 
(a)  Vacancies. In case of a vacancy in one of the places on the board of trustees held by a policeman, a special election shall be called and held, and the vacancy filled, as nearly as may be in the manner prescribed above in this section for the regular annual election. 
(b)  Bond required. Every policeman elected to serve on the board of trustees shall take an oath of office to faithfully perform the duties of his office, and shall execute a bond to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) on condition that he will faithfully perform the duties of said office and faithfully account for, and deliver, all funds, money, bonds or other property in his custody belonging to the police pension and retirement system to his successor. 
(Code 1959, § 1-48) 
Sec. 24-42. - Same-Secretary to furnish annual report, other reports. 
    In addition to the annual report required by law, the secretary shall also report to the board of trustees the true condition of the system at any time on request of the board of trustees or of its chairman; and a copy of the annual report and all other reports shall be delivered to the board of commissioners of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 1-49) 
Sec. 24-43. - Eligibility for pension; amount. 
    The board of trustees is hereby authorized and empowered to pay out of any funds in the police pension and retirement system a service pension of (50) fifty per cent of his average final yearly compensation to any policeman eligible as hereinafter provided; provided that in no event shall such pensions exceed the amount of money in such funds. 
    In order for a policeman to be eligible for such service pension, he must have reached the age of sixty (60) years or more, and his service with the police department must have ceased. He must have served a period of over twenty (20) years or more in some police department in the state of a standard equivalent to that of the police department of the city, five (5) years of which service shall have been consecutive immediately preceding the end of such period in the city. He must have complied with any agreement as to contributions by him and other policemen to the funds of the police pension and retirement system provided for by ordinance. 
    Provided, however, that where a policeman has served for the necessary number of years and is otherwise eligible except as to being sixty (60) years or more of age, if he is discharged without cause, or his office is abolished, he shall be eligible for pension. When a policeman reaches the age of seventy (70) years, he must retire unless at the request of the chief of police, the board of trustees, grants him an extension of one year, which can be further extended for one year periods only at the request of the chief of police. In the event of the death of any policeman who has been awarded a pension under the provisions of this article, his widow, child or children shall be paid the pension so awarded, provided that the same shall cease as to the widow when she shall marry, or as to the child or children when they become eighteen (18) years of age. Such payment shall be divided equally between said child or children and widow. In order for a widow to receive such pension as provided by ordinance, she must have been the wife of the policeman at the time of his retirement. 
(Code 1959, § 1-50) 
Sec. 24-44. - Right of members to withdraw from system. 
    Any policeman who has served in the police department of the city for a period of more than one (1) year, and has contributed to said fund for said period of time, and has served less than twenty (20) years in the police department of the city or any other city or town in the state having standards equivalent to those required by the city, and who has entered into any pension and retirement agreement provided for by law and ordinance, may withdraw from said agreement, and shall be paid one-half (1/2) the amount of his contributions less all benefit payments made to him under the provisions of the ordinances of this city. After such withdrawal said policeman shall not receive any of the benefits provided for by law and ordinance. Any policeman after having withdrawn from any agreement as provided herein, may be reinstated in the police pension and retirement system as provided by ordinance by entering into any agreement provided for by ordinance and by the payment in cash to the board of trustees of the police pension and retirement system of all money received by said policeman at the time of his withdrawal from any agreement as provided for by ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 1-51) 
Sec. 24-45. - Disability allowances. 
    The city is hereby authorized and empowered to pay out of any funds in the police pension and retirement system a disability allowance to policemen eligible as provided by law an amount of money equal to one-half (1/2) of the average final compensation of any such policeman; provided that in no event shall such allowance exceed the amount of money in such funds. The eligibility of a policeman to receive such disability allowance shall be governed by law, and the procedure shall be as prescribed by law. Such disability allowance shall cease under the condition established by law. 
    In case death results from an injury or sickness sustained by any such policeman while in, and in consequence of, the performance of his duty as such policeman, and the board of trustees shall find this to be true, after requiring certificates and other evidence of his disability as provided by law, it shall allow a pension not exceeding one-half (1/2) of the final yearly compensation of any such policeman to be paid to such policeman's widow, child or children, in equal parts, but to cease as to the widow when she shall marry, or as to the child or children when becoming of the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Code 1959, § 1-52) 
Sec. 24-46. - Payments for temporary disability. 
    The city is hereby authorized and empowered to pay out of funds in its police pension and retirement system, a temporary disability allowance, to any policeman eligible as provided by law, not exceeding in any event the amounts in this section provided. The eligibility of a policeman to receive such temporary disability allowance shall be governed by law, and the procedure shall be as prescribed by law. 
    Upon compliance with the provisions of law relative to temporary disability allowances for policemen, the board of trustees shall, if funds are available in the police pension and retirement system, pay the necessary hospital care and professional nursing expenses of such policeman during such time as such sickness or disability requires such care or professional nursing. The salary of any such policeman shall continue, while he is so necessarily confined to such hospital or bed and necessarily requires care and professional nursing on account of such sickness or disability, for a period of not more than three months; after which said period the other provisions of the law and ordinances may apply. 
(Code 1959, § 1-53) 
Sec. 24-47. - Pension for death of member; amount. 
    The city is hereby authorized and empowered to pay out of any funds in its police pension and retirement system a pension to the widow or child or children under the age of eighteen (18) years of any policeman where requirements for eligibility for such pension are met as provided by law. Such pension shall in no event exceed the amount of money in such funds and shall be one-half (1/2) of the average final yearly compensation of any such policeman. The eligibility of widows and children to receive such pension shall be governed by law, and the procedure shall be as prescribed by law. Such pension shall be discontinued as to the widow when she shall marry and as to the child or children when becoming eighteen (18) years of age. Such pension so granted shall be divided equally between the child or children if there be any and the widow. 
(Code 1959, § 1-54) 
Sec. 24-48. - Procedure when city becomes disqualified from participating. 
    If the city subsequently becomes disqualified by failure to meet the minimum requirements of the police pension and retirement system as provided by law and ordinance, the city clerk of said city shall immediately transfer to the general fund of the city any balance to the credit of the funds of the police pension and retirement system; and the balance which is to the credit of the policemen shall be paid to each of them in such proportions as each of the said policemen have contributed to said fund by deduction from their salaries or otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 1-55) 
Sec. 24-49. - Retirement support fund; revenue restrictions. 
    The retirement support fund shall not be considered in computing any levy when the municipality makes its estimate to the excise board for needed appropriations. 
    This money may be expended only to defray the city cost of the new retirement plan. 
    Any and all revenues derived from the retirement support fund shall not be used or considered for any personnel-related expenses. 
(Ord. No. 2532, § I, 6-17-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2532, adopted June 17, 1996, amended the Code, but did not specify the manner thereof; hence, inclusion of § I of such ordinance as § 24-49 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. 27. 
Secs. 24-50-24-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MINIMUM STANDARDS 

Sec. 24-59. - Established. 
    The following minimum qualifications are hereby established for the employment of police department employees, except department heads. 
(Code 1959, § 1-12) 
Sec. 24-60. - Weight requirements. 
    Weight must be in proportion to height as determined by the examining physician. 
(Code 1959, § 1-14) 
Sec. 24-61. - Citizenship. 
    Each applicant must be a citizen of the United States at the time his application is filed. 
(Code 1959, § 1-15) 
Sec. 24-62. - Educational requirements. 
    Each applicant must have a high school education or its equivalent at time of filing his application. 
(Code 1959, § 1-16) 
Sec. 24-63. - Residence within city limits required; exception. 
    All applicants for positions with the police department must reside within the corporate limits of the city at the time of their appointment unless such resident requirement is waived by the concurrence of the chief of police and the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 1-17; Ord. No. 1456, § 2, 2-3-64) 
Sec. 24-64. - Work experience. 
    No specific experience shall be required, but work that has kept applicant physically active and agile and has required initiative, honesty and sense of responsibility is an asset. Previous experience in either police department work is not essential. 
(Code 1959, § 1-18) 
Sec. 24-65. - Physical requirements; examination required. 
(a)  Each applicant must be in excellent physical condition. Any physical disability or defect of the limbs or organs that would restrict normal body functions is disqualifying. 
(b)  Vision must be at least 20/30 in each eye and correctable to 20/20 . Hearing must be normal. Diseased tonsils, actual or potential hernia or heart disease, history of tuberculosis, ulcers or varicose veins are disqualifying. 
(c)  Thorough medical examinations are given before appointments are made. These examinations are made by physicians selected and paid by the city, and their decisions are final. 
(Code 1959, § 1-19) 
Sec. 24-66. - Character requirements. 
    Each applicant must have good moral character and the highest personal integrity. Addiction to gambling, use of alcohol or drugs is disqualifying. Any police record of other than minor traffic violations may be disqualifying. 
    The applicant's background and character will be carefully investigated by the police department before he is appointed. 
(Code 1959, § 1-20) 
Sec. 24-67. - Relationship to department head, other city officers, to disqualify applicant. 
    No applicant shall be employed by any department head of the police department, if such applicant is related by blood or marriage within the third degree to such department head, the mayor, any of the members of the board of commissioners or the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 1-21) 
Secs. 24-68-24-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POLICE BOARD OF REVIEW[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1758, adopted Aug. 5, 1974, did not amend this Code. Inclusion of §§ 1-5 of said ordinance herein as Art. V, §§ 24-71-24-75, was at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 24-71. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Police Board of Review Ordinance of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma." 
(Ord. No. 1758, § 1, 8-5-74) 
Sec. 24-72. - Establishment of board. 
    The City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, has a police pension and retirement system and according to the requirements of 11 O.S. 1961, Section 541s, shall establish a board of review to hear appeals concerning the discharge of policemen and police officers. Therefore, the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma hereby establishes a police board of review according to the terms of the state statute referred to above. 
(Ord. No. 1758, § 2, 8-5-74) 
Sec. 24-73. - Membership of board. 
    The membership of the police board of review shall consist of the mayor, ex officio, of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, who shall be a voting member, and four (4) members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, as follows: 
(a)  Two (2) policemen, retired or active, from the police department of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma; 
(b)  One attorney and one licensed physician residing in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, provided, that whenever persons meeting the qualifications of an attorney or licensed physician are unavailable for appointment, the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, shall, in lieu thereof, make the appointments from the governing board of the City of Ardmore, except that neither the police chief nor any person having direct appointed authority for police personnel shall be eligible for appointment to said board. Appointive members of the board shall serve at the pleasure of the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 1758, § 3, 8-5-74) 
Sec. 24-74. - Procedure relative to review. 
    Upon any policemen or police officers of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, being discharged, he shall have a right to appeal to the police board of review established herein. The board shall meet within ten (10) days from the date of said discharge with the time and place of said meeting to be given in writing to the city manager of the City of Ardmore and to the discharged policeman. Both parties may appear before the board at that time and present evidence. The board of review shall issue its recommendations within five (5) days from the date the hearing is terminated. 
(Ord. No. 1758, § 4, 8-5-74) 
Sec. 24-75. - Appeals from board decisions. 
    Appeals from decisions of said board of review may be taken in the manner provided for in 11 O.S. 1961, Section 541v. 
(Ord. No. 1758, § 5, 8-5-74) 
Chapter 25 - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- As of February, 2001, the title of chapter 25, formerly known as "Streets and Sidewalks" has been changed, at the city's discretion, to "Public Rights-of-Way" as currently set out herein. 
Cross reference- Street department, § 2-23; change in street names, § 22-8; dedication of streets and alleys, § 22-9. 
State Law reference- Street improvements by cities generally, 11 O.S. 1961, § 81 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Procedure for street improvements. 
    The board of commissioners is hereby empowered to establish and change the grade of any streets, avenues, lanes, alleys and other public places, improve same by paving, macadamizing, curbing and guttering and draining the same, including the installation of all manholes, catch basins, and necessary drainage and sewer pipes, whenever in its judgment the public convenience may require such improvements; and such improvements shall be performed in the manner and pursuant to the procedure set forth in 11 O. S. 1961, sections 81 through 117 and sections 151 through 158, as amended, and any other relevant state laws now existing or which may be enacted in the future. All of said sections of the Oklahoma Statutes are hereby adopted and declared to be in force as the procedure governing the board of commissioners and the city in street improvements hereinbefore referred to. 
(Code 1959, § 17-1) 
Sec. 25-2. - Authority to improve streets, assess costs. 
    The city, through its board of commissioners, shall have the power and right to make street improvements as herein specified with its own personnel and with its own equipment, and assess a portion of the costs thereof against the abutting property benefiting thereby in like manner as if let by contract; provided further, that the city shall not be or become liable for the payment of any assessment or assessments so made, whether the work is done either by the city or contractor, except on property belonging to the city. 
(Code 1959, § 17-2) 
Sec. 25-3. - Drainage culverts-Size. 
    All drainage culverts hereinafter installed shall be of sufficient cross-section to carry the storm water flowing through them as determined by the design criteria of the city engineer. In no case shall a driveway culvert be less than a twelve (12) inch pipe or a box of equivalent cross-section. 
(Code 1959, § 17-3) 
Sec. 25-4. - Same-Materials. 
    All materials used in driveway culverts shall be approved by the street superintendent or city engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 17-4) 
Sec. 25-5. - Same-Unsafe, inadequate culverts to be replaced; notice to owner. 
    Existing culverts which become structurally unsafe or are inadequate to carry storm water properly shall be removed and replaced with an adequate culvert in thirty (30) days upon the receipt of written notice by the street superintendent or city engineer. Material shall be furnished by the property owner. 
(Code 1959, § 17-5) 
Sec. 25-6. - Same-Use of concrete slabs; approval required. 
    No concrete slabs shall extend into the drainage ditch of a city street unless approved by the street superintendent and city engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 17-6) 
Sec. 25-7. - Trees and shrubbery-Duty of owner to keep trimmed. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the owner of any premises, abutting on any street or avenue of this city, to cut and trim all trees and shrubbery growing in the parkings between the sidewalks and the driveways of any such streets or avenues, and all trees and shrubbery growing on any part of said premises and adjacent to the sidewalks or any street or avenue, in such manner that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not obstruct free and convenient passage and travel along the sidewalks, streets and avenues; and when such premises shall be occupied by some other person than the owner, it shall be the duty of such occupant to cut and trim the trees and shrubbery in the same manner as hereinbefore required of the owner. 
(Code 1959, § 17-16) 
Sec. 25-8. - Obstructing sidewalks, alleys, etc., with goods, wares, merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon or permit to be placed upon the sidewalks and parkways of the streets and alleys of the city, any goods, wares, articles of merchandise or any other obstruction, and leave same upon sidewalks and parkways, with the exception of the conditions outlined in section 25-14 of this Code. 
(Code 1959, § 17-18; Ord. No. 2698, § 1, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-9. - Obstructing pedestrian and motor vehicle traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or obstruct the sidewalks of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with pedestrian traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct the streets and alleys of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with lawful traffic and parking thereon. 
(Code 1959, § 17-19) 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations generally, Ch. 28. 
Sec. 25-10. - Depositing trash, etc., on streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, throw or sweep into or upon the public streets and sidewalks of the city, any paper, rubbish, grass, weeds, dirt, trash, crates, boxes or other refuse of any kind. 
(Code 1959, § 17-20) 
Cross reference- Cross reference-Littering, § 19-52. 
Sec. 25-11. - Riding on certain streets, alleys, etc., upon roller skates, skateboards, etc., prohibited; exception. 
    No person upon roller skates, skateboards, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall ride any such vehicle upon any streets, alleys, sidewalks or city-owned property, including private parking lots and other private property where properly posted "Skateboards or Roller Skates Not Allowed," in an area bounded as follows: 
    On the north by the northside of 2nd Avenue; 
    On the west by the eastside of G Street NW and SW; 
    On the south by the southside of 1st Street and SW and SE; 
    On the east by the westside of A. T. & S. F. Railroad. 
    This section shall not apply to any street, while set aside as a play street, as authorized by resolution passed by the board of commissioners of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(Code 1959, § 17-21; Ord. No. 2262, § 1, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 25-11.1. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed forty dollars ($40.00) for each offense. Each violation that is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2262, § 1, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 25-12. - Water, grease, etc., from filling stations, other businesses. 
    It is unlawful for any owner or operator of a filling station or other place of business, or any agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow water, grease or other fluid refuse to flow or drain into, on, over or across any sidewalk, parking, street, alley or other public way. 
(Code 1959, § 17-22) 
Sec. 25-13. - Parades and street meetings generally. 
(a)  Permit required. No person or persons shall conduct, or cause to be conducted, any parade or public meeting or celebration on any of the streets, highways, bridges or alleys of the city, without first having obtained a permit from the city manager. 
(b)  Application. At least fourteen (14) days before any person or persons conduct any parade or public celebration for which a permit is required by the provisions of this section, a written application shall have been filed with the city manager. The application shall be accompanied by a written statement, giving the route, date and time of the parade, or the location of the area to be occupied for the requested public celebration. 
    At least forty-eight (48) hours before any person or persons conduct any block party for which a permit is required by the provisions of this section, a written application shall have been filed with the city manager. The application shall be accompanied by a written statement giving the date, time and street to be closed. 
(c)  Investigation and issuance. 
(1)  The city manager shall, upon receipt of an application pursuant to the provisions of this section, make such investigation and inquiry as he deems necessary to determine whether any regular municipal service will be hampered, obstructed or delayed and the probable extent of extra policing, traffic control or other protective service of the city will be required thereby. If such interruption of municipal service or extent of service is found to be unreasonable, or detrimental to the interest of public safety, he shall endorse such findings on said application and refuse to grant a permit. 
(2)  Before any permit shall be issued hereunder, the time, date and route of the parade or location of the proposed public celebration shall be approved by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2269, Art. I, §§ I-III, 11-16-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2269, adopted Nov. 16, 1987, amended the Code by adding provisions as herein set out, which provisions have been codified as § 25-13 by the editor. 
Cross reference- Disturbing public assemblies, § 19-11; unlawful assembly, § 19-43; parades and processions, § 28-18.1 et seq. 
Sec. 25-14. - Outdoor cafe permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to create, establish, operate, maintain or otherwise be engaged in the business of running an outdoor cafe upon the sidewalks or public property fronting on Main Street, within the CD zoning district, unless he/she shall hold a currently valid permit issued under the terms of this section. 
(b)  The outdoor cafe permit is a temporary license, which may be denied for any reason and may be suspended or revoked for any conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this section or for conduct of a business that constitutes a public nuisance or is inconsistent with the health, safety and welfare of the public. No property right is created by this section and the decision of the director shall be final, unless appealed to the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed in them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means the development services director, the person authorized to enforce the provisions contained in this section. 
    Encroachment means stands, tables, umbrellas, chairs, displays, signs, banners, flags, and appurtenances or objects related to the business on public property. 
    Outdoor cafe means the placing, locating or permitting of the placing or locating of chairs, tables, and other appurtenances on the right-of-way, such as sidewalks, adjacent to a business licensed to operate as an eating establishment where food, beverages, and/or other refreshments are served, or upon public property within designated areas. 
    Permittee means the recipient of an outdoor cafe permit under the terms and provisions of this section. 
    Sidewalk means that area of the public right-of-way between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines reserved for pedestrian traffic, not including street crossings. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.2. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Application for the permit required by this section shall be made at the development services department on forms provided by the city. Such application shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Name, home and business address and telephone number of the applicant, and the name and address of the owner of the business, if other than the applicant. 
(2)  Name, home address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's permit. 
(3)  Proof of current liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, protecting the licensee and the city from all claims for damage to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the encroachment permit. The general liability insurance policy shall be in the minimum aggregate amount of $1,000,000.00 total limits. The policy renewal shall be received by the city at the time of annual permit renewal. 
(4)  A sketch, to scale, of the proposed location, showing the layout and dimensions of the existing public areas and adjacent private property, including tables, chairs and all other appurtenances. 
(5)  Evidence in writing that all required licenses or health permits required by the county and/or state have been obtained. 
(6)  Photographs, drawings or manufacturer's brochures fully describing the appearance of the proposed perimeter fencing, tables, chairs, umbrellas or other appurtenances related to the business, as to weight, color, style and other similar standards. 
(b)  Public Comment. Upon initial receipt of an application for an outdoor cafe, the city shall notify by mail, the owners of property lying within a three hundred (300) foot radius of the encroachment area specified on the application. The notification shall provide for a ten (10) day period in which public comments will be received regarding the application and its specific contents and proposals. No notice or period of comment shall be required upon receipt of a renewal application. The applicant shall provide a property owners list taken from the county assessor's records. 
(c)  Not later than twenty (20) days after the filing of a completed application for an outdoor cafe permit, the applicant shall be notified by the director of the decision on the issuance or denial of the permit. If the permit is issued, said permit shall be renewed annually upon the date of the initial issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.3. - Conditions of permit. 
    The issuance of an outdoor cafe permit shall contain the following conditions: 
(1)  Each permit shall be effective for one (1) year with renewal each July 1. 
(2)  The permit issued shall be personal to the permittee only and shall not be assigned or transferred. 
(3)  The permit may be temporarily suspended upon notice by the director when necessary to clear the public property for the safety of the public in accordance with a community or special event authorized by a permit issued by the city. 
(4)  The director may temporarily suspend the permit or require the removal of items within the encroachment area when street, sidewalk, common area or utility repairs necessitate such action. 
(5)  The permit shall be specifically limited to the area shown on the exhibit attached to and made part of the permit. 
(6)  The encroachment area covered by the permit shall be maintained in a neat and orderly appearance at all times, and the area shall be cleared of all debris on a periodic basis during the day, and again at the close of each business day. 
(7)  No advertising shall be permitted except for menus. 
(8)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas, fencing and any other appurtenances shall be of high quality of design, materials, and workmanship. 
(9)  No glass containers shall be used within the encroachment area. 
(10)  No permittee may block or restrict the passageway to less than five (5) feet in width, or block ingress or egress to or from any building. In areas of congested pedestrian activity, the director is authorized to require a wider pedestrian path, as circumstances dictate. Also, no items or appurtenances shall be placed in a manner as to block any driveway, or crosswalk. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.4. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  Grounds for revocation. The director or his designee may revoke a permit issued under this section at any time. 
(1)  Any required business or health permit, or license has been suspended, revoked or cancelled. 
(2)  The permittee does not have insurance in force which is correct and effective in the minimum amount as specified in this section. 
(3)  Conditions of pedestrian or vehicular traffic cause congestion, necessitating removal of the encroachment. 
(4)  Violations of this section or breaches of conditions of this permit have occurred. 
(5)  The permittee has failed to make modifications upon receipt of the director's notice to make such modifications delivered in writing to the permittee. 
(6)  There is a failure to maintain the primary food or beverage service use. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.5. - Removal of property. 
    Tables, chairs and other appurtenances of the business may be removed by the public works department, and a reasonable fee charged for labor, transportation and storage, should the permittee fail to remove the items upon written notice to do so for any reason provided for under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.6. - Notice of denial or revocation. 
    Upon denial or revocation, the director shall give notice of such action to the permittee, in writing, stating the action which has been taken and the reason therefor. The action shall be effective upon the receipt of such notice by registered mail or hand delivery if that is feasible. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 25-14.7. - Appeals. 
    The permittee shall have the right to appeal the decision of the director to the board of commissioners within five (5) working days from receipt of notice. An appeal does not stay the denial or revocation of the outdoor cafe permit. The hearing before the commission shall be held at the next regularly scheduled meeting. The decision of the commission shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 12-3-01) 
Secs. 25-15-25-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 25-23. - City engineer to enforce provisions. 
    Inspection, enforcement and supervision required under this article shall be under the direction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 17-15) 
Sec. 25-24. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, damage or open or cause to be cut, damaged or opened any streets, avenues or sidewalks or alleys within the city limits for any purpose without first obtaining a permit to do so from the office of the city engineer, except in the event of an extreme emergency, in which event, such person shall procure such permit as soon as practical as hereinafter set out. 
(Code 1959, § 17-7) 
Sec. 25-25. - Application for permit; issuance by city engineer. 
    The application for such permit required in the preceding section shall include the following: 
(1)  Purpose; 
(2)  Location; 
(3)  Type of construction of such street, avenue, alley or sidewalk; 
(4)  Contemplated dimension of such cut, damage or opening. 
    The city engineer shall issue a permit to such applicant, which permit shall be in force and effect for a period of thirty (30) days from date of issuance. 
(Code 1959, § 17-8) 
Sec. 25-26. - Copy of permit to be furnished city manager. 
    Upon the issuance of such permit the city engineer shall furnish a copy of same to the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 17-9) 
Sec. 25-27. - Permit to be kept on job premises. 
    Such permit or copy thereof, shall be available for inspection by the proper officer of the city during the course of time such work is being accomplished. 
(Code 1959, § 17-10) 
Sec. 25-28. - Requirements generally for making cuts. 
    All cuts, openings or damage in such streets, avenues, alleys or sidewalks shall be made and completed in the following manner: 
(a)  All cuts in concrete paving or sidewalks shall be marked out with a concrete saw making a minimum one and one-half (11/2) inch cut thereof unless break is made at regular joints. 
(b)  Cuts in asphalt paving shall be cut in straight regular lines. This may be done with a chisel or asphalt ax, if satisfactory straight regular cuts are made. If not, cuts shall be sawed with a concrete saw. 
(c)  The person making such cut, damage or opening in any street, avenue, sidewalk or alley shall backfill it to the top of the trench or opening with selected sand or sandy material free from clods or lumps, thoroughly mechanically tamped in layers of six (6) inches with optimum moisture for maximum compaction and shall remove all surplus dirt or material thereof. 
(d)  Any cut, opening or damage done or caused to be done to dirt streets, alleys or parkways may be compacted by flushing, but cut or opening must be protected by barricades and lights until stable enough to support traffic. 
(e)  Such cuts, openings or damage in gravel streets, alleys, avenues or drives after being thoroughly compacted shall be graveled and all surplus dirt shall be cleaned from the gravel surface abutting the cut, to the end that such street, alley, avenue or drive shall be returned to its original condition or as near thereto as practical. 
(f)  Cuts, openings or damage in parkway shall be replaced, repaired and restored to its original condition or as near thereto as practical. 
(Code 1959, § 17-11) 
Sec. 25-29. - Barricades, safety devices required. 
    During the time such work is being accomplished such person shall place or cause to be placed sufficient barricades and safety devices to properly safeguard the public. 
(Code 1959, § 17-12) 
Sec. 25-30. - Cuts to be assessed. 
    On or before January 1st of each year, the city engineer shall prepare a schedule of costs to be charged for the repairs of streets, alleys, avenues or other public property to cuts or excavations or other damages. 
    Such schedule of costs shall be based upon prevailing costs of labor, machines and material and shall be presented to the city commission for their prior approval. 
(Code 1959, § 17-13; Ord. No. 1987, § 1, 6-16-80) 
Sec. 25-31. - Street department to make repairs upon completion of work. 
    Immediately upon being notified of such completion of said work the office of the city engineer shall inform the street department of the city who shall forthwith repair such street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, and do so in the following manner: 
(a)  All repairs shall be accomplished in kind except brick or asphalt type construction. Brick or asphalt streets, avenues, alleys, or sidewalks shall be repaired as directed by the city engineer. 
(b)  Concrete used in repairs shall contain not less than seven (7) sacks of Portland cement per cubic yard of concrete and shall be a minimum of six (6) inches thick in any paving or paving base. 
(Code 1959, § 17-14) 
Secs. 25-32-25-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM STREET DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 25-41. - Compliance. 
    All street improvements in the city shall be in accordance with the minimum standards set forth in this article, except as provided by section 25-42. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(1), 11-3-80; Ord. No. 2200, § 1, 10-14-85) 
Sec. 25-42. - Modification. 
    The standards provided in this article may be modified by the city commission for reconstruction of existing streets which do not meet the minimum widths, upon recommendation of the city engineer. These standards may also be modified by the city commission in other exceptional cases, but before any modification can be made for new streets or streets in new subdivision developments, the city commission must make an affirmative finding of facts which show that a modification is called for by sound and good engineering judgement. In making such finding of facts, the city commission shall receive the recommendation from both the planning commission and the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(2), 11-3-80; Ord. No. 2200, § 2, 10-14-85) 
Sec. 25-43. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer, public works director, street superintendent, and all officers and employees of the city, and all contractors and subcontractors working under contract with the city to see that the provisions of this article are rigidly enforced. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(3), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-44. - Minimum widths. 
    The minimum width for each type of public street in the city shall be as follows: 
(a)  Expressways and freeways. Right-of-way width and pavement width shall conform to the requirements of the Oklahoma Department of Highways and/or as specified by the approved engineering plans. 
(b)  Arterial streets. Right-of-way width of eighty (80) feet and pavement width of forty-eight (48) feet where parking is prohibited. 
(c)  Commercial and industrial (urban). Right-of-way width of seventy (70) feet and pavement width of sixty (60) feet. 
(d)  Collector streets. Right-of-way width of sixty (60) feet and pavement width of thirty-eight (38) feet. 
(e)  Residential streets. Right-of-way width of fifty (50) feet and pavement width of twenty-eight (28) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(4), 11-3-80; Ord. No. 2148, §§ 1, 2, 4-2-84) 
Sec. 25-45. - Minimum pavement specifications. 
    The lowest type or specification of pavement which will be accepted and maintained by the city shall be constructed in accordance with the typical sections as set forth in Exhibit "A" [2] and as follows: 
(a)  Expressways and freeways. To be determined by Oklahoma Department of Highways and/or as specified by the approved engineering plans. 
(b)  Arterial streets, commercial and industrial (urban), commercial collector streets. Arterial streets, commercial and industrial (urban), and commercial collector streets shall be constructed as follows: 
(1)  The lime treated subgrade shall be constructed in accordance with Section 307, 1976 Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Oklahoma Department of Highways or the latest revisions thereof. The lime shall be applied in sufficient amounts, established by the city engineer's office, and a certified soil testing laboratory, to uniformly have a plasticity index of fifteen (15) and be compacted to standard proctor density of ninety-five (95). 
(2)  Eight (8) inches of Portland cement, concrete pavement with integral curb and gutter. Concrete pavement shall be placed on subgrades compacted to ninety-five (95) standard proctor density. Portland cement concrete shall be a six (6) sack mix and be constructed in accordance with Sections 414 and 701, as specified by the 1976 Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Oklahoma Department of Highways or the latest revisions thereof. 
(3)  Eight (8) inches of asphaltic concrete pavement with two (2) feet, zero (0) inches standard Portland cement curb and gutter. This shall be placed on two (2) inches of hot sand asphalt that extends at least twelve (12) inches behind the curb. This ten (10) inches of asphaltic concrete shall be placed on subgrades compacted to ninety-five (95) standard proctor density. The asphaltic pavement shall consist of two (2) inches of hot sand asphalt extending twelve (12) inches behind the curb, and six (6) inches of type "A" asphaltic concrete and two (2) inches of asphaltic concrete (type "C") wearing surface. Asphaltic pavements shall be constructed in accordance with Sections 411 and 708 and Portland cement concrete curb and gutter with Sections 609 and 701 as specified by the 1976 Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Oklahoma Department of Highways or the latest revisions thereof. 
(c)  Local residential and collector residential streets. Residential streets shall be constructed as follows: 
(1)  Local: The same material and construction specifications shall be used. The street shall have a lime stabilized subbase with five and one-half (51/2) inches of six (6) sack Portland cement concrete pavement or four (4) inches of type "A" asphaltic concrete, with a surface course of two (2) inches of type "C" asphaltic concrete. Curb and gutters, with approval from the city engineer's office, may be mountable type, otherwise barrier type. [3] (see sheet (7) exhibit "A"). 
(2)  Collector: The same material and construction specifications shall be used. The street shall have a lime stabilized subbase with seven (7) inches of six (6) sack Portland cement concrete pavement or two (2) inches of hot sand asphalt, and four (4) inches of type "A" asphaltic concrete and a surface course of two (2) inches of type "C" asphaltic concrete. All curb and gutter shall be barrier type. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(5), 11-3-80; Ord. No. 2148, §§ 1, 2, 4-2-84) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Exhibit A is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

--- (3) --- 
Note- See sheet 7, Exhibit "A", which is not set out herein. 

Sec. 25-46. - Curb and gutters to be concrete. 
    Portland cement concrete curb and gutters shall be mandatory for all streets. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(6), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-47. - Water distribution facilities. 
    All water lines, where possible, shall be relocated in back of curb lines, with across street water service line being installed prior to lime stabilization and compaction of subgrades. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(7), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-48. - Sanitary sewer facilities. 
    Prior to lime stabilization and compaction of street subgrades, the sanitary sewer facilities shall be evaluated for inflow/infiltration and repair. All sewer service laterals shall be watertight, adjusted to grade, with a "behind the curb" sewer lateral cleanout installed on each lateral. A sanitary sewer lateral shall be located and provided for each undeveloped platted lot adjacent to any new street construction and be provided with a "behind the curb" cleanout. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(8), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-49. - Connection with storm drainage system. 
    In the construction of all streets, where a storm drainage system is reasonably accessible, the city or developers shall connect with such storm drainage system and shall do all grading and provide all drainage structures that are necessary to properly carry surface water. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(9), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-50. - Surface water to be controlled. 
    All streets shall be constructed so as not to permit surface water to pond or cross the pavement at low areas.
