(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(10), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-51. - Manholes and valve boxes shall be to finished grade of street. 
    All manholes and valve boxes shall be installed to the finished grades of all streets, sanitary sewer manholes shall have closed, tight-fitting, heavy duty manhole covers. Valve boxes shall be vertically aligned, centered over the valve stems and valve operating nut, and brought to finished grade of street. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(11), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-52. - Annual appropriation of funds for street improvements. 
    On or before the first day of January the city commission shall each year establish by resolution the amount to be set aside for street construction to be appropriated within annual general fund budget, beginning July 1st each year. 
(Ord. No. 2006, § 1(12), 11-3-80) 
Sec. 25-53. - Minimum driveway standards. 
(A)  TERMS USED. 
(1)  Frontage: The length along the street right-of-way line of a single property tract or roadside development area between the boundary edges of the property. Corner property at a street intersection has a separate frontage along each street. 
(2)  Frontage boundary line: A line, normal to the street centerline, at each end of the frontage, extending from the right-of-way line to the edge of through-traffic lane. 
(3)  Driveway: Property used for motor vehicle access to private property from public streets. 
(4)  Driveway width: Narrowest width of driveway measured parallel with the edge of traveled way. 
(5)  Driveway angle: The angle of ninety (90) degrees or less between the driveway center line and the edge of the traveled way. 
(6)  Edge clearance: The distance measured along the edge of the traveled way, between the frontage boundary line and tangent projection of the nearest edge of driveway. 
(7)  Corner clearance: At an intersection street or highway, the dimensions measured along the edge of the traveled way between the frontage boundary line opposite the intersection of the two (2) right-of-way lines and the tangent projection of the nearest edge of driveway. NOTE: No driveway radius is to fall within a corner radius. 
(8)  Outside radius: The outside or larger curve radius on edge of driveway. 
(9)  Inside radius: The inside or smaller curve radius on edge of driveway, used when substantially less than ninety (90) degrees. 
(10)  Buffer area (border area): That portion of land between the right-of-way line and the curbline, or if none, the outside edge of shoulder, or roadway, if no shoulder. 
(11)  Distance between double driveways: The distance measured along the right-of-way line between the tangent projections of the inside edges of two (2) adjacent driveways to the same frontage. 
    General. For simplicity, the above definitions are stated in terms of single radius curves of edge of driveways or intersecting streets. Where compound curves or tapers are used, an equivalent single radius curve may be used as a control guide. 
    The above definitions recognize that shoulders on all streets will not always be surfaced and therefore driveways are considered to extend to the outer edge of through traffic lane. Where the major street includes a hard-surfaced all-weather shoulder on the right, or where there are established curb lines, the dimensions shall be measured along the outer edge of shoulder or curb line. 
(B)  CONTROL DIMENSIONS. 
(1)  Edge clearance: 
(a)  General: All portions of the driveway shall be within the frontage boundary line. 
1.  For driveways with angles of about ninety (90) degrees the edge clearance shall not be less than the radius of curvature for the junction of the driveway and pavement (shoulder) edges. 
2.  Residential: Five (5) feet minimum. 
3.  Commercial: Fifteen (15) feet minimum. 
(2)  Width: 
(a)  Residential: 
1.  Ten (10) feet minimum. 
2.  Twenty (20) feet maximum for garages that have a capacity of up to two (2) vehicles. 
3.  Thirty (30) feet maximum for garages that have a capacity of more than two (2) vehicles, subject to the following conditions. 
A.  That the driveway is onto a residential street other than a collector or arterial street as shown on the city's street classification plan. 
B.  That any driveway shall not cover more than fifty (50) per cent of the required street yard setback. 
C.  That any driveway shall not take up more than fifty (50) per cent of the lot frontage along the street. 
D.  An exception to B and C above may be administratively approved for lots on cul-de-sac and "eyebrow" locations where reduced street frontage exists. 
(b)  Commercial: Twenty-five (25) feet maximum. Larger drives can be granted should design features justify the additional width. 
(3)  Driveway angle: 
(a)  Driveways for two-way operation: Ninety (90) degrees to minimum sixty (60) degrees for maximum sight distance. 
(b)  Driveways for one-way operation: Driveway used by vehicles in both directions of travel on streets, same as for two-way operation. Driveways, used by vehicles in one direction of travel on streets (right turn only): Sixty (60) degrees maximum; forty-five (45) degrees minimum. 
(4)  Radius of curvature or junction of driveway and pavement: 
Classification Radius Minimum Residential 5 feet Commercial 25 feet  
(5)  Distance between double driveways: Fifteen (15) feet minimum, or if parallel island is present, same as length of island-whichever is the longer. 
(6)  Corner clearance: The corner clearance for all driveways shall be a minimum of thirty (30) feet. 
(C)  NUMBER OF DRIVEWAYS. 
(1)  Residential lots: No residential lot shall have more than two (2) driveways on each street of which the lot has frontage. 
(2)  Nonresidential lots: Not more than two (2) driveways shall be used for each one hundred (100) feet or fraction thereof of street frontage on any street. 
(D)  DRIVEWAY PROFILE. 
(1)  No street edge curb, cut section: 
(a)  From edge of traveled way to outer edge of shoulder, gradient same as shoulder pitch. 
(b)  From outer edge of shoulder to low point at ditch line or over culvert, maximum downward gradient five (5) to eight (8) per cent. 
(c)  Beyond ditch line, maximum gradient five (5) to eight (8) per cent for commercial driveways or ten (10) to fifteen (15) per cent for others. 
(2)  No street edge curb, fill section: 
(a)  Slope across shoulder, gradient same as shoulder pitch. 
(b)  Beyond outer edge of shoulder maximum gradient five (5) to eight (8) per cent for commercial driveways or ten (10) to fifteen (15) per cent for others. 
(3)  With street edge curbs: Driveway profile should slope upward from gutter line to meet the sidewalk, if any, with maximum difference between downward cross slope of traveled way and upward slope of driveway of eight (8) to ten (10) per cent; beyond outer edge of walk of equivalent maximum gradient plus five (5) to eight (8) per cent for commercial driveways or plus ten (10) to fifteen (15) per cent for others. 
(4)  Vertical curve: As flat as feasible. To prevent drag, vertical curves shall avoid a hump or dip greater than about six (6) inches within wheel base length of ten (10) feet. For recent model passenger cars, to prevent center or overhang drag, with some allowance for load and bounce, crest vertical curves shall not exceed a three and one-quarter (31/4) inch hump in a ten-foot chord and sag vertical curves shall not exceed a two-inch depression in ten-foot chord. 
(E)  CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. When curb sections of publicly owned streets are removed for driveway purposes, Portland cement concrete driveways shall be constructed. Such concrete driveways shall extend from a minimum of two (2) feet from the back of the curb toward the private property. From that point to the private property line, the driveway shall be constructed of Portland cement or asphaltic concrete. (Note: Required sidewalks must be constructed of Portland cement). Residential driveways shall taper from a depth of six and one-half (61/2) inches at the curb to a depth of four (4) inches at the private property line. Commercial driveways shall taper from a depth of six and one-half (61/2) inches at the curb to a depth of six (6) inches at the private property line. 
(Ord. No. 2058, § 1, 5-17-82; Ord. No. 2651, 9-5-00) 
ARTICLE IV. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY OCCUPANCY MANAGEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Chapter 12 of Appendix C (Unified Development Code) of this Code has been redesignated, at the city's discretion, to Chapter 25, Article IV, §§ 25-80-25-98 and §§ 25-100-25-103, as currently set out herein. 

Sec. 25-80. - Name and scope. 
    Title [Article IV], Ardmore Code of Ordinances, Chapter 25, shall be known and may be cited as "The Rights-of-Way Occupancy Management Ordinance." Except as otherwise provided herein or prohibited by applicable law, this chapter shall apply to all rights-of-way occupants, except those operating under the authority of a franchise. This chapter shall not apply to leases for the use of public property, other than rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and abbreviations shall have the meanings given herein, unless otherwise expressly stated. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense; words in the plural number include the singular number; words in the singular number include the plural number; and words defined in upper and lower case shall have the same meaning as words in all lower case. 
    Words used in the masculine gender comprehend, as well, the feminine gender and neuter. The words "and" and "or" may be read conjunctival or disjunctively. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory, and "may" is permissive. Unless otherwise expressly stated, words not defined in this chapter shall be given the meaning set forth in Title 47 of the United States Code, and, if not defined therein, their common and ordinary meaning. References to governmental entities (whether persons or entities) refer to those entities or their successors in authority. References to laws, ordinances or regulations shall be interpreted broadly to cover government actions, however nominated, and include laws, ordinances and regulations now in force or hereinafter enacted or amended. 
(a)  Affiliate means a person that directly or indirectly owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with, another person. 
(b)  City means the City of Ardmore. 
(c)  Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life or health, of a significant loss of property, or requires immediate repair or replacement in order to restore service to a customer. 
(d)  Excavate means to dig into, around or under, or in any way remove or physically disturb or penetrate any part of the rights-of-way, including but not limited to boring, blasting, pushing, and drilling holes for the installation of poles, conduit or other facilities. 
(e)  Facilities means all or any part of a collective system of tangible things including but not limited to pipelines, conduits, copper or fiber optic cabling, pedestals, guy wires, anchors, vaults, junction boxes, utility poles and electrical wiring, that is partly or entirely located in the rights-of-way and is used for the transmission of goods or services, including but not limited to natural gas, steam, chilled or potable water, electricity, cable television service or telecommunications service, regardless of whether the services are provided for a fee, or provided to the general public, to a limited group of private users, or solely for the benefit of the owner of the system. 
(f)  Obstruct means to place any tangible object or material in the rights-of-way in a manner that stops, hinders, disrupts or otherwise interferes with free and open passage over a specific area or part of the rights-of-way. 
(g)  Occupancy permit means a grant of authority, renewable annually, from the city to occupy the rights-of-way for the purposes of placing, owning, operating, managing or otherwise using facilities in the rights-of-way. 
(h)  Occupancy permit holder means any person holding an occupancy permit. 
(i)  Permittee means any person to whom a ROW use permit has been issued. 
(j)  Person means any natural or corporate person, business association or other business entity including but not limited to a partnership, a sole proprietorship, a political subdivision, a public or private agency or authority of any kind, a utility, a successor or assign of any of the foregoing, or any legal entity, but not the city. 
(k)  Pre-engineered project means a large, planned project or major maintenance activity consisting of significant excavation or major long-term obstruction or as defined by the city engineer. 
(l)  Private carriage means the provision of the telecommunications to persons other than the general public, whether or not for a fee. 
(m)  Rights-of-Way authorization or ROW authorization means a grant of authority to occupy the rights-of-way for the purpose of providing a general public service, telecommunications, cable television service or open video system. 
(n)  Rights-of-way occupancy fee means an annual charge that recovers an apportioned share of the actual costs to the city of acquiring and maintaining the rights-of-way. 
(o)  Rights-of-way use permit or ROW use permit means an authorization to excavate in or obstruct rights-of-way at a specific place and time, for the purposes of installing, constructing or maintaining facilities within a specified portion of the rights-of-way. 
(p)  Rights-of-way occupant or ROW occupant means a person that owns, manages, operates, leases, provides service over, or in any way uses facilities located in the right-of-way, including but not limited to telephone corporations, occupancy permit holders and city departments. 
(q)  Rights-of-way means the surface, the air-space aboveground, and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, parkway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, or similar property in which the city now or hereafter holds any property interest, which, consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, or otherwise obtained, may be used for the purpose of constructing, installing, operating and maintaining facilities of any kind, including but not limited to conduits, pipelines, cables, utility poles, junction boxes, and duct banks. Rights-of-way does not include buildings, parks, or other property owned or leased by the city, its trusts, or authorities, but does include all rights-of-way. No reference herein, or in any franchise agreement or occupancy permit, to rights-of-way, shall be deemed to be a representation or guarantee by the city that its interest or other right to control the use of such property is sufficient to permit its use for such purposes, and a franchise holder or occupancy permit holder shall be deemed to gain only those rights to use as are properly in the city and as the city may have the undisputed right and power to give. 
(r)  Telecommunications means the transmission, between or among points specified by the user, of information of the user's choosing, without change in the form or content of the information as sent and received, as defined in the Telecommunications Act of 1996. 
(s)  Telecommunications service means the offering of telecommunications for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public, regardless of the facilities used. 
(t)  Transfer means any transaction in which: 
(1)  All or a portion of a ROW occupant's facilities is sold or assigned; 
(2)  There is any change, acquisition, direct or indirect transfer of control of the ROW occupant; or 
(3)  The rights or obligations held by the ROW occupant are transferred, sold, assigned, or leased, in whole or in part, directly or indirectly, to another party. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-82. - Administration. 
(a)  ROW administrator. The ROW administrator shall be the principal city official responsible for the administration of the registration of ROW occupants, issuance of occupancy permits, calculation of and invoicing for ROW occupancy fees, maintenance of facilities information, administration records and all other duties related to the maintenance of records on ROW occupants. 
(b)  City engineer. The city engineer shall be the principal city official responsible for administration and enforcement of matters related to rights-of-way use permits and the enforcement of engineering standards as outlined in this chapter. 
(c)  Director of finance. The director of finance shall be the primary city official responsible for administration and enforcement of all bonding, insurance requirements and collection activities provided for in this chapter. 
(d)  Public works director. The public works director shall be the primary city official for oversight of permit holders activities conducted in the city rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-83. - Authority to occupy the rights-of-way. 
(a)  General. Any person wishing to construct, install, operate or maintain any facilities in the rights-of-way shall first obtain proper authorization, as described in this section. 
(b)  Occupancy permits. Any person that desires to provide telecommunications service or private carriage by means of facilities located in the rights-of-way shall first obtain an occupancy permit pursuant to section 25-85. Any person that desires to occupy the rights-of-way to provide any type of service not expressly authorized by a ROW authorization or a grant of prior rights shall obtain the applicable form of ROW authorization, if no such form of ROW authorization is available for the type of service, the person shall obtain an occupancy permit and pay the right-of-way occupancy fee. 
(c)  Prior Right. Any person occupying the rights-of-way by virtue of a contractual agreement in existence prior to the enactment of this chapter, shall be deemed exempt from its provisions to the extent provided in said contractual agreement, provided that any such person shall comply fully with the registration requirement pursuant to section 25-84. This does not grant rights to expand or alter facilities without written permission from the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-84. - Registration. 
(a)  Initial Registration. Every ROW occupant, including any city department and any city trust or authority, regardless of the authority under which the person occupies the rights-of-way, must register with the city manager no later than ninety (90) days after the effective date of this chapter. Thereafter, all new ROW occupants shall register upon completion of a new facilities installation, or April 15, whichever is sooner. 
(b)  Contents. To register, a person shall submit, on a form approved by the city manager or the city manager's designee, the following information: the name of the ROW occupant; the street and mailing addresses of the ROW occupant's main office and any local office; telephone numbers, fax numbers, pager numbers, mobile numbers, e-mail addresses, and any other information needed to contact representatives of the ROW occupant responsible for the supervision and conduct of the ROW occupant's activities in the city; certification of membership in the Oklahoma One-Call System, Inc. ("CALL OKIE" 1-800-522-6543); a current copy of any valid certificate of authority issued by the Oklahoma Corporation Commission to the ROW occupant related to the ROW occupant's activities in the city; identification of the ROW occupant's authority to occupy the rights-of-way, if already obtained, or evidence that the ROW occupant has applied for such authority; documentation of the location of existing facilities owned, operated, managed or leased by the ROW occupant as of the end of the city's most recent fiscal year including the total feet of rights-of-way occupied and the number of feet of arterial rights-of-way occupied; and any other information that the city manager deems necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. 
(c)  Registration Renewal. Every ROW occupant shall renew its registration annually by submitting any changes to the information in its initial application on or before April 15 of every year. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-85. - Occupancy permits. 
(a)  Application. Each ROW occupant other than a franchise holder, or a holder of prior rights as defined in section 25-83(d), shall apply for an occupancy permit. The application shall include at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number and form of business of the applicant, and the name and addressees of all persons authorized to act on behalf of the applicant with respect to the application; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's facilities; 
(3)  The name, addresses of the ten (10) largest holders of an ownership interest in the applicant and affiliates of the applicant, and all persons with five (5) per cent or more ownership interest in the applicant and its affiliates, and the persons who control those persons, to the ultimate parent; all officers and directors of the applicant and its affiliates; and any other business affiliation and system ownership interest of each named person; 
(4)  A demonstration of the applicant's technical ability to construct and operate the proposed or existing facilities, including identification of key personnel; 
(5)  A demonstration of the applicant's legal qualifications to construct and operate any proposed or existing facilities, including but not limited to a demonstration that the applicant has the necessary authority under Oklahoma law to construct a facility. The applicant shall not be issued an occupancy permit if it files materially misleading information in the application or intentionally withholds information that the applicant lawfully is required to provide; 
(6)  A demonstration of the financial qualifications of the applicant, including but not limited to a certified statement prepared by a certified public accountant regarding the applicant's financial ability to complete any construction proposed, and to meet any time frame proposed. If any applicant is a joint venture or partnership, the same information shall be provided for each participant in the joint venture or partnership; 
(7)  A description of the applicant's prior experience in facility ownership and construction, and an identification of each locality in which the applicant or any of its principals have, or have had, a license, franchise, or other authorization or any interest therein, including the name, address and phone number of each local authority, and references from each authority; 
(8)  A detailed description of the physical facilities proposed to be installed within the city, including but not limited to an engineering site plan showing the proposed locations of the applicant's facilities, including any manholes or overhead poles, the size, type and proposed depth of any conduit or other enclosures, and the relationship of the system to all existing poles, utilities, sidewalks, pavement, telecommunication facilities, and other improvements within the rights-of-way; 
(9)  The technical standards that the applicant proposes to follow in constructing the facilities; 
(10)  To the extent an applicant is in any respect relying on the financial or technical resources of another person, including an affiliate, the proofs required under paragraph 4 and 6 shall be provided for that person; 
(11)  Copies of any agreements which the applicant has entered into or proposes to enter into with any other person relating to any facilities installed, to be owned, operated, managed, or leased by the applicant; 
(12)  Any additional information the city may require; 
(13)  An affidavit or declaration of the applicant or an authorized officer certifying the truth and accuracy of the information in the application, acknowledging the enforceability of application commitments, and certifying that the application meets all federal and state law requirements; and 
(14)  A declaration that the applicant agrees to comply with this chapter, as it may be amended from time to time. 
To the extent that the applicant proposes to resell the services of, or lease existing facilities of, another entity occupying the public rights-of-way, the application may omit the data required under paragraphs 2, and 4 through 9 of this subsection. 
(b)  Filing requirements. Written applications for an initial occupancy permits shall be filed with the ROW administrator. To be accepted for filing, a fully completed, signed original application shall be submitted as provided for in section 25-85(a). If the application is complete, the application for an occupancy permit shall be accompanied by the required filing fee, the amount of which shall be fixed from time to time by ordinance. 
(c)  Review of Application. If the information provided in an application for an occupancy permit is complete and meets all the requirements of this chapter, the city manager shall evaluate the application, and evaluating an application shall consider: 
(1)  The applicant's technical, financial, and legal qualifications to construct or operate the proposed facilities; 
(2)  The nature of the proposed facilities and equipment; 
(3)  The ability of the applicant to make efficient use of the rights-of-way and to justify any inconvenience of the public attendant thereto; 
(4)  The effects of a grant of an occupancy permit on the present and future use of the rights-of-way, including any foreclosure of future uses of the rights-of-way; and 
(5)  Such other factors which may be unique to the application which the city manager deems relevant. 
(d)  Term and renewal. Occupancy permits shall be issued for a maximum term of one (1) year, and shall be renewable annually upon registration pursuant to section 25-84 and payment of the annual occupancy fee as defined in section 25-85(e) of this chapter. Failure to register or to pay the occupancy fee shall render any occupancy permit invalid. 
(e)  Occupancy fees. 
(1)  Except as provided below in this section, every occupancy permit holder shall pay an annual occupancy fee to reimburse the city for the cost of acquiring, maintaining, and managing the arterial rights-of-way unless otherwise exempted by the rights-of-way administrator. The occupancy fee shall be computed in accordance with this section. Each occupancy permit holder shall be notified of the amount of the fee and the basis on which it was calculated no later than July 1 of the year for which the occupancy fee is owed. Payment shall be due thirty (30) days after notification is mailed by the city. 
(2)  Franchise holders and holders of prior rights shall not be liable for the occupancy fee. Such persons shall pay compensation to the city for the right to occupy the rights-of-way in the form of franchise fees, permit fees, or inspection fees. The amount of such franchise, permit, or inspection fees shall be specified in each franchise, permit or contractual agreement, or by ordinance. city departments and agencies also shall not be liable for the occupancy fee. 
(3)  The occupancy fee shall be per annum. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-86. - Right-of-way use permits. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall obstruct or excavate any portion of any right-of-way without first obtaining a rights-of-way use permit from the city engineer as provided in this section. This section does not apply to a governmental unit or entity in the official act of maintaining any element of its transportation system, including but not limited to the state of Oklahoma, the City of Ardmore and the U.S. Government. 
(b)  Permit requirement. To apply for a rights-of-way permit, an applicant shall furnish the following: 
(1)  Name of the owner or operator of the facility; and 
(2)  A sketch or drawing of the project; and 
(3)  Dates of the construction activity, the proposed start and stop times and any proposal to temporarily reopen any roadway for any "peak hour" period; and 
(4)  The names of any subcontractors working on the proposed project under the applicant's responsibility and authority; and 
(5)  Proof of payment of all money due the city for occupancy fees, franchise fees, cable permit fees, right-of-way permit fees, and any invoiced cost, loss, damage, or expense suffered by the city as a result of the applicant's prior construction activity including but not limited to any emergency action taken by the city; and 
(6)  Evidence that the applicant has obtained the bonds and the insurance coverage required by section 25-89 of this title; and 
(7)  A traffic control plan in compliance with Section 25-88(f) of this title [appendix]; and 
(8)  A list of the applicant's emergency providers, including name of company, local contact person, mailing and e-mail address, 24-hour emergency phone number, and pager or fax number. This information shall be kept current by written notice to the public works director. 
(9)  For pre-engineered projects, as defined by section 25-81 of this title, the following are also required: 
a.  Detailed engineering plans. The plans shall show the location and area of the proposed project, the locations of all existing and proposed equipment and facilities, the heights and/or depth of the proposed equipment and existing facilities, and the spatial relationship with any adjacent infrastructure, right-of-way line, easement, utility, and/or other physical features. The plans shall be prepared under the direction of and signed by a registered professional engineer, and shall meet the size and scale as set forth in the city development codes; and 
b.  A copy of the engineering plans in an electronic format acceptable to the city engineer; and 
c.  The applicant shall meet with the city engineer and the public works director for a pre-work conference prior to issuance of rights-of-way occupancy and use permit. 
(c)  Application and permit fees. Upon submission of the permit applications, an application fee of One Hundred Fifty Dollars ($150.00) shall be paid to the director of finance. This fee is non-refundable and must be collected before review of the application begins. Upon approval of the rights-of-way use permit, the applicant shall remit to the director of finance a permit fee. The fee shall be calculated based on the following components: 
(1)  Permit and licensing system maintenance fee. A surcharge of two dollars ($2.00) shall be charged for each permit to maintain the permit and licensing system; and 
(2)  Record retention fee. A surcharge of one dollar ($1.00) per page shall be charged for each permit for retention of permits and associated data by microfilming, computer imaging or other method of storage of records; and 
(3)  Inspection fee. A charge of one dollar and eighty cents ($1.80) per 100 feet of project area as defined in the application shall [be] charged as an inspection fee; and 
(4)  Traffic disruption fee. A traffic disruption fee which shall consist of the number of days traffic will be disrupted multiplied by the number of obstructed lanes multiplied by $0.021. for each vehicle delayed. The number of vehicles delayed shall be determined by the city engineer. 
(5)  Project plans review fee. A permit fee for a pre-engineered project shall also consist of a plans review fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per sheet. The minimum plan review fee is one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  Permit terms and conditions. Each rights-of-way use permit shall describe the general location of the permitted project, the size of the obstructed area, the duration of the permit, which shall be based on the amount of time estimated for completion of the permitted activity, and any special conditions or other information deemed relevant by the city engineer. A rights-of-way use permit shall be issued or denied within thirty (30) days of submission of a completed application and payment of all required fees. In the event of denial, the city engineer shall advise the applicant of all steps necessary to secure approval of the permit. 
(e)  Emergency permits. 
(1)  An emergency rights-of-way use permit is available for projects. Emergency excavation may commence with a two-hour notification to the public works director or city engineer subject to an application being submitted by the end of the next working day. The notification shall consist of the following: 
a.  Anticipated date, duration, proposed start and stop time, location (site address if possible) including nearest cross street; and 
b.  Size of the obstruction and work area less any normal traffic control in advance; and 
c.  Applicants company name; and 
d.  Facility owners name; and 
e.  Local contact information; and 
f.  General description of the type of construction activity and/or facilities installed. 
(2)  Holders of emergency permits shall notify the public works director upon the completion of the project. All persons, engaged in an activity within the rights-of-way not specifically exempt in this section, must notify the public works director that an obstruction will occur. 
(3)  In order to qualify for an emergency permit, a permittee must register for pre-certification with the city engineer. Pre-certification will consist of reviewing bonding requirements and establishing an escrow account with the city's finance department. 
(f)  Permit conditions. A permittee shall adhere to the following requirements: 
(1)  All current engineering requirements and construction standards as described in section 25-88 of this chapter; and 
(2)  All current rights-of-way use permits shall be maintained on each work site, with a copy prominently displayed in the window of each vehicle associated with the activity. All rights-of-way use permits shall be presented upon request to any representative of the public works director or the city engineer; and 
(3)  Excavation projects are subject to the requirements of section 25-88 of this chapter; and 
(4)  All restoration work required of any roadway pavement by any permit holder, shall be performed by the city's Public Works department. 
(g)  Failure to apply. Any person that fails to comply with this section shall be precluded from obtaining any rights-of-way use permit or performing any further construction within the city's rights-of-way for up to twelve (12) months from the date of notification in addition to any monetary penalty imposed pursuant to section 25-102 of this chapter. 
(h)  Renewal. In the event that a permitted project does not conclude prior to expiration of the rights-of-way use permit under which it is being performed, the permittee shall apply [to] the city engineer for an extension of the permit. 
(1)  The following information shall be submitted: 
a.  Statement from the permittee indicating the reason for the delay in completion of the project; and 
b.  Date that the permittee anticipates the project to be completed. 
c.  Any applicable permit fees established at the time of issuance of the original permit. 
(i)  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), excluding costs, fees and assessments. Each day's continuance of any violation as defined in this section shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-87. - Appeals. 
    Any person that has been: denied registration, denied a rights-of-way use permit, has had a rights-of-way use permit revoked or believes that any fee imposed pursuant to this chapter is invalid, may have the denial, revocation or fee imposition reviewed upon written request to the ROW administrator. The ROW administrator shall reply to the written request within seven (7) working days, and shall render a decision within fourteen (14) working days. A response from the ROW administrator shall be made in writing, and shall be supported by written findings establishing the reasonableness of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-88. - Engineering standards. 
(a)  Allocation of space in the public rights-of-way. The city engineer shall have the power to prohibit or limit the placement of new or additional facilities within the rights-of-way if there is insufficient space to accommodate all of the requests of ROW occupants. In making such decisions, the city engineer shall strive to the extent possible to accommodate all existing and potential users of the rights-of-way, but shall be guided primarily by considerations of the public interest, the public's needs for the particular utility service, the width and physical condition of the rights-of-way, the protection of existing facilities in the rights-of-way, and future city plans for public improvements and development projects which have been determined to be in the public's interest. 
(b)  Underground policy. Facilities may be installed above ground in areas where existing utility facilities are above ground and shall be installed underground in areas where existing facilities are installed underground, subject to all applicable safety codes. The city encourages the sharing of underground and overhead facilities. Leasing of excess space in ducts, conduits and on poles is a matter between interested parties; however, lessees of such physical facilities must still comply with the terms of this chapter, unless otherwise expressly exempted by the city engineer. 
(c)  Location criteria. 
(1)  Corridors. The city engineer shall assign specific corridors within the rights-of-way, or any particular segment thereof as may be necessary, for each type of facility that is now or as the city engineer concludes may in the future be located within the rights-of-way. The city engineer shall establish an ideal cross section identifying the lateral and vertical position of each class of potential user. ROW occupants shall have the right to occupy only one corridor or section of each rights-of-way within the vertical zone established for the applicable class of user, as established by the city engineer. Additional corridors in the same portion of the rights-of-way may be granted only upon consideration of future utility uses and a demonstration by the requesting party that its current corridor does not afford sufficient space to install its facilities. All permits issued by the ROW administrator involving the installation, replacement or modifications of existing facilities and equipment shall be reviewed by the city engineer as to the proper corridor for the facility. 
(2)  Interference. A ROW occupant shall not place any fixtures or equipment where the same will interfere with any existing facility. A ROW occupant shall locate its lines and equipment in such a manner as not to interfere unnecessarily with the usual traffic patterns (vehicular or pedestrian) or with the rights or reasonable convenience of owners of property that abuts any rights-of-way. 
(d)  Construction standards. 
(1)  Depth. The depth of conduit, measured from the top of the conduit to the surface of ground, shall be a minimum of 42 inches in soil and a minimum of 60 inches at a ditch crossing. Beneath any roadway pavement, the depth from the top of the conduit to the surface of the road shall be a minimum of 48 inches. Other depths may be required where future grading is anticipated. 
(2)  Encasement. Within the rights-of-way, with the exception of roadways, road crossings and driveways, as a minimum a 4-inch PVC conduit or its equivalent, with 2 innerducts, encased with a 4-inch cap of concrete or other approved protective and warning materials, shall be used to enclose any wire, cable or linear device, unless otherwise modified by the city engineer. Under all roadway pavement, road crossings and driveways a minimum 4-inch, black steel pipe shall be installed to encase the facility. Roadway and driveway crossings shall be accomplished by jacking or boring or a method approved by the city engineer. Direct burial of bare wire or sheath cable within the public right-of-way shall be prohibited. 
All new underground facilities shall be marked with the installation and use of a continuous locator wire or strip directly above the buried equipment at appropriate intervals as determined by the city engineer, in order to enhance detection equipment. 
(3)  Backfilling/testing. Excavations shall be promptly backfilled with earth and tamped with a mechanical tamper at 6-inch lifts, so that the earth is restored to original grade to assure no hazard to vehicular, animal or pedestrian traffic. The permittee shall perform all necessary compaction tests in accordance with the latest design and construction specifications of the Oklahoma Department of Transportation or those approved and disseminated by the city engineer setting forth requirements for backfill and paving cut repairs (e.g., standard concrete pavement cut and repair; standard asphalt pavement cut and repair, etc.). The Department of Public Works shall be notified orally within twelve (12) hours of completion of the backfill, and in writing within two (2) days of such completion to allow for inspection by the Department of Public Works and the scheduling of the pavement restoration. 
No further work shall be performed until the inspector approves the backfill. The excavated area and any other disturbed rights-of-way shall be sodded, if necessary, by the permittee. 
(4)  Pavement cutting. Except in the case of an emergency, all sides of a proposed paving cut shall be sawn parallel or perpendicular with existing joints with a concrete saw to full depth. In the case of an emergency, paving may be removed without sawing however, proper saw cuts shall be required as a condition of any subsequent permit. Sections of sidewalk shall be removed to the nearest existing joint in all directions. 
(5)  Replacement. The replacement of the driving surface and the base of any roadway shall comply with Oklahoma Department of Transportation Standards, and may require additional removal to the nearest joint in all directions. This removal and all pavement restoration shall be the responsibility of the Public Works Department or its assigned contractor at the expense of the ROW occupant. The actual cost of the pavement restoration shall be a cost item first estimated within the permit charges and invoiced to the permittee upon final actual measurements. 
This section shall not apply to the replacement or repair of a sidewalk, unless sidewalk cuts are made in conjunction with a paving cut. 
(6)  Trenching. A permittee shall not proceed with additional trench work exceeding a maximum of five hundred (500) feet of open trench without the approval of a city engineering inspector. 
(7)  Crossing. All underground crossings of paved roadways shall be made by the directional bore method, unless the Department of Development Services approves an alternate method prior to the construction. Any alternate method shall be submitted through the ROW administrator for recommendation from the director of public works. Voids and all holes shall be properly grouted. Crossings shall be at approximately right angles to the roadway and in no case shall any facility be placed in any culvert or drainage pipe or within five (5) feet of a closed point of a culvert. 
(8)  Erosion. Erosion prevention measures shall be incorporated into all work within the public way. All gutters, ditches, pavements and other drainage features shall be maintained free and unobstructed of sediment, dirt and debris. The handling, grading, excavating, or moving of excess construction materials or the movement or cleaning of construction vehicles or equipment shall be conducted in such a manner that materials and washout will not be deposited into catch basins, gutters, ditches, or areas where runoff may carry materials into any public or private stormwater system. 
(e)  Dimension and location criteria. Maximum dimensions and location of associated, aboveground equipment (Junction boxes) shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  The "elevation view" or product of the equipment's height and width shall not exceed twenty (20) square feet without written approval of the city engineer. 
(2)  Associated equipment shall not be installed in such a manner so as to obstruct the view of drivers upon or entering a public street. 
(3)  No equipment, including poles and wires, shall block or obscure any traffic control device, fire hydrant, ramp or other safety device. 
(4)  No equipment, including poles and guy wires, shall be placed so as to obstruct the flow of pedestrian traffic, and in no case result in less than four (4) feet of clear sidewalk, without the approval of the city engineer. 
(f)  Traffic control and safety. 
(1)  Any permittee occupying any portion of public rights-of-way shall erect a barrier around the perimeter of any excavation and provide any and all traffic control devices, signs, and lights appropriate to the level of complexity of the activity, in order to protect, warn, and guide the public (vehicular and pedestrian) through the work zone. 
(g)  Miscellaneous standards. 
(1)  Nuisance. One year after the passage of this chapter, any equipment found in the rights-of-way that has not been registered shall be deemed to be a nuisance. Upon thirty (30) days' public notice published in a newspaper of general circulation, the city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including but not limited to abating the nuisance by taking possession of the facilities and restoring the rights-of-way. 
(2)  Identification. The ROW administrator, at his discretion, may require any new facility (aerial or underground) installed, replaced, or repaired by or for a ROW occupant, after the effective date of this chapter be permanently identified with the name or logo of the ROW occupant on but not limited to manhole covers, tags, poles, posts, and signs. In addition, when the facilities are placed under asphalt or concrete, the ROW administrator may require permanent markers be embedded in the surface of the pavement directly above the installation. The maximum spacing shall be no less than five hundred (500) feet for paved roadways and walkways. Other standards shall be established from time to time by the ROW administrator. All ROW occupants shall make all reasonable efforts to ensure that all existing facilities shall be marked during the normal course of business. 
(3)  Construction zone identification. Any permittee occupying any portion of the public ROW shall erect a 3 ft.× 3 ft. temporary sign having white background and 3 in. black, red or blue lettering, displaying the following information: the names of the ROW occupant, any contractors and/or subcontractors involved in the project. The sign shall be visible from the adjacent traffic lane and shall be maintained throughout the duration of the project. 
(4)  Vehicle identification. All vehicles used, parked or stored by or on behalf of a ROW occupant or permittee within a permitted construction zone shall be clearly marked, providing the name of the facility's owner and the permittee, including any and all subcontractors, if different from the owner. All personnel employed by a ROW occupant, permittee or subcontractor shall possess identification, providing the employee's name and the name and telephone number of the ROW occupant or permittee. Any unmarked vehicles shall be subject to all moving and parking ordinances. Private vehicles shall not be permitted to be parked or stored within any permitted work zone at any time. 
(5)  Permit. A current rights-of-way use permit shall be maintained on each work site, with a copy prominently displayed in the window, or other conspicuous place, of each vehicle used, parked, or stored in conjunction with a permitted construction project. The rights-of-way use permit shall be presented upon request to any city representative. 
(6)  Tree trimming. A rights-of-way occupant shall have the authority to trim trees upon or overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and rights-of-way so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the ROW occupant. 
(7)  Moving permit. A ROW occupant shall, at the request of any person holding a city or state moving permit, temporarily raise or lower its aerial wires to permit the moving of an over-height vehicle. The expense of such temporary removal or raising and lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting same and the ROW occupant shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. A ROW occupant shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(8)  Due care. A ROW occupant shall at all times employ due care during the installation and maintenance process and use commonly accepted standards, methods and devices including but not limited to safety standards of OSHA, NEC, FCC, and the city preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damages, injuries or nuisances to the public. All structures and all lines, equipment and connections in, over, under and upon the streets of the city, wherever situated or located, shall at all times be kept and maintained in a safe, suitable, and substantial condition, and in good order and repair. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-89. - Insurance and bonding. 
(a)  Insurance required. Each ROW occupant and permittee shall furnish an owner's protective policy, with the city as the named insured, issued by the same insurance company as the issuer of the ROW occupant's or permittee's liability coverage in the amounts set forth below: 
Comprehensive General Liability: 
    (other than automobile) Combined Single Limit Personal injury, each person $ 100,000.00 Property damage, each person   100,000.00 Aggregate amount, each occurrence  1,000,000.00 Automobiles and Truck Liability: 
(owned, hired and non-owned) Combined Single Limit Personal injury, each person   100,000.00 Property damage, each person   100,000.00 Aggregate amount, each accident  1,000,000.00 Professional Liability Insurance 
for Contractors: Project Category Minimum Insurance Coverage Studies and Reports   100,000.00                     Construction Projects Less than $500,000 cost   100,000.00 $500,000 to $1,000,000 cost   250,000.00 More than $1,000,000 cost   500,000.00 Workers' Compensation Insurance as required by law  
(b)  Endorsement. All insurance policies and certificates maintained pursuant to this chapter shall contain the following endorsement: 
    'It is hereby understood and agreed that this insurance coverage may not be canceled by the insurance company nor the intention not to renew be stated by the insurance company until thirty (30) days after receipt by the city Clerk, by Certified Mail, Return Receipt Requested, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew.' 
(c)  Qualifications of sureties. All insurance policies required to be maintained by a ROW occupant or permittee shall be with sureties qualified to do business in the state of Oklahoma, with an A-1 or better rating of insurance by Best's Key Rating Guide, Property/Casualty Edition, and in a form approved by the city attorney. 
(d)  Approval. All policies of insurance, indemnification agreements and bonds executed to the city [shall] be with the city Clerk who shall ascertain whether the surety is authorized to do business in the state of Oklahoma, then submitted to the city attorney for approval as to form, then submitted to the city manager for approval. 
(e)  Additional insured; prior notice of policy cancellation. All liability insurance policies shall name the city, its elected and appointed officials, officers, boards, commissions, commissioners, agents, and employees as additional insured and shall indemnify the city and shall further provide that any cancellation or reduction in coverage shall not be effective unless thirty (30) days' prior written notice thereof has been given to the city Clerk. No ROW occupant or permittee shall cancel any required insurance policy without submission of proof that it has obtained alternative insurance satisfactory to the city Clerk that complies with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-90. - Bonding. 
(a)  Requirement of bond. Prior to initial construction or installation of a telecommunications system, cable system, other public utility system, or facilities of any nature in the rights-of-way, a ROW occupant shall establish in the city's favor an irrevocable performance bond or bonds that shall be in a sum not less than the amount of the contract; and shall provide that the contractor shall pay all indebtedness incurred for labor or materials furnished for the project. The city reserves the right to require a greater amount, depending on the nature and scope of the planned construction, as a condition of any ROW authorization. The performance bond shall be in place throughout the period of any construction and for a time appropriate to determine whether the work performed was safely completed, which shall be determined with consideration of the nature of the work performed. The city may allow the ROW occupant to maintain a bond indefinitely in lieu of obtaining individual bonds when applying for individual rights-of-way use permits. 
(b)  Recovery under performance bond. In the event a ROW occupant fails to complete any construction or other work in the rights-of-way in a safe and timely manner in accordance with the provisions of its ROW authorization and this chapter or other applicable law, there shall be recoverable, jointly and severally from the principal and the surety of the bond, any damages or loss suffered by the city as a result thereof, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost of removal or abandonment of any property of the ROW occupant, or the cost of completing or repairing the construction or other work in the rights-of-way, plus a reasonable allowance for attorneys' fees up to the full amount of the bond. 
(c)  Issuance of bond. All performance bonds required by this section shall be issued by a surety with an A-1 or better rating of insurance in Best's Key Rating Guide, Property/Casualty Edition; shall be subject to the approval as to form by the city attorney; and shall contain the following endorsement: 
    "It is hereby understood and agreed that this bond may not be canceled by the insurance company, nor allowed to lapse, nor the intention not to renew be stated by the insurance company until sixty (60) days after receipt by the city Clerk by Certified Mail, Return Receipt Requested, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew." 
(d)  Definition of bonds required. No right-of-way use permit shall be issued until the applicant files evidence that it has obtained one or more [bonds] to secure the applicant's overall performance, maintenance, payment or removal obligations defined in this section, with each of the following requirements, as applicable to the project: 
(1)  Maintenance. For a period of one (1) year after acceptance by the city of the work performed, the permittee shall, in the manner prescribed, repair any breaks or defects arising from defective construction or materials and shall repair any damage, resulting from settling. 
(2)  Payment. The permittee shall pay, and submit evidence thereof, all indebtedness incurred for labor or materials furnished in the construction or repair of any facility, sidewalk, driveway or curb in the city. In addition, the permittee shall pay any person to whom there is any money due for furnishing labor or materials upon such work, and shall have a right of action against the principal and his surety as prescribed in 61 O.S. Supp. 1998, § 2, as amended. 
(3)  Removal. The removal bond for a ROW occupant which already has facilities or equipment in the rights-of-way shall be in an amount sufficient to cover the cost of removing the ROW occupant's facilities and restoring the rights-of-way thereafter, and where applicable, as required in section 25-88, relating to abandoned or unusable equipment or facilities. A ROW occupant who is seeking to place equipment or facilities, whether for the first time or in addition to existing equipment or facilities, shall provide a removal bond as required by this section. 
(4)  Performance. A permittee shall safeguard the public by issuance of a bond to ensure the prompt and proper completion of any excavation or disturbance of the rights-of-way in order to place said rights-of-way back in its original condition. This requirement may be met by submission of evidence that the applicant has obtained a bond or bonds applicable only to the project for which the permit is requested, or by submission of evidence that the applicant has obtained a bond or bonds covering all of its activities in the rights-of-way, pursuant to section 25-88. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-91. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Each ROW occupant and permittee shall, at its sole cost and expense, release, indemnify, hold harmless, and defend the city, its elected and appointed officials, officers, boards, commissions, commissioners, agents, employees, and volunteers against any and all claims, suits, causes of action (whether frivolous or otherwise), proceedings, and judgments for damages or equitable relief arising out of the installation, construction, maintenance, or operation of facilities by the ROW occupant or permittee; the conduct or presence of the ROW occupant's business in the city; or in any way arising out of the ROW occupant's enjoyment or exercise of the privileges granted by the city or applicable law, regardless of whether the act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by the city, other applicable law, or the terms of any grant to occupy the rights-of-way. 
(b)  Each ROW occupant and permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city, and its elected and appointed officers, officials, boards, commissions, commissioners, employees, agents, and volunteers from and against any and all claims, demands, suits, or causes of action (whether frivolous or otherwise) of any kind or nature, and the resulting losses, costs, expenses, reasonable attorneys' fees, liabilities, damages, orders, judgments, or decrees sustained by the city or any third party arising out of, or by reason of, or resulting from or of the acts, errors, or omissions of the ROW occupant or permittee, or its agents, independent contractors, or employees related to or in any way arising out of the construction, operation or repair of the facilities in question. 
(c)  The indemnity provision of this section 25-91 includes, but is not limited to, the city's reasonable attorneys' fees incurred in defending against any such action, claim, suit (whether frivolous or otherwise), or proceeding, as well as the reasonable value of any services rendered by the city attorney, or city staff or employees. 
(d)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to waive any immunity the city enjoys under applicable law, or the Oklahoma Constitution. 
(e)  Acceptance of the provisions of this section shall be a condition of all rights-of-way use permits and ROW authorizations. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-92. - No limits on liability. 
    Neither the provisions of this chapter nor any damages recovered by the city shall be construed to limit the liability of a ROW occupant or permittee for damages to the city, its elected and appointed officials, officers, boards, commissions, commissioners, agents, employees, volunteers and any other person or persons. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-93. - Record maintenance. 
(a)  Access to records. The city shall have the right to inspect and copy the documents, books, records, maps, plans, income tax returns, proof of performance tests, and other like materials of a ROW occupant at any time during normal business hours, and as otherwise provided pursuant to applicable law. Access to records and other materials shall not be denied by a ROW occupant on the basis that said records and materials contain proprietary or confidential information. Refusal to provide information required herein shall be grounds for revocation of a franchise or permit. All such information received by the city shall remain confidential insofar as permitted by applicable law. 
(b)  System mapping. Each ROW occupant shall maintain accurate maps and improvement plans showing the location, size, and a general description of all facilities, equipment and service drops installed in the rights-of-way and any power supply sources (including voltages and connections). Facilities and equipment shown shall include, but not be limited to, cables, conduits, electric lines, pipelines, fiber optic cables, electric transformers, gas meters and junction boxes. The ROW occupant shall provide a system map to the city engineer showing the horizontal and approximate vertical location of its facilities, relative to the boundaries of the rights-of-way or section lines, in such detail and scale as may be directed. Maps shall be submitted in a digital format acceptable to the city, unless otherwise exempted. 
(c)  As-built plans. Preliminary plans shall be submitted for each new construction project at the time of application for a rights-of-way use permit. After completion of construction on each project, final as-built construction and acquisition facility maps shall be submitted to the city engineer. Such as-built maps shall be based upon post-construction inspection to verify location. Copies of as-built maps in a digital format acceptable to the city engineer, including a copy certified by a registered professional engineer, shall be submitted to the ROW administrator, unless otherwise exempted. 
(d)  Initial plan submittal. Each person occupying the public rights-of-way as of the effective date of this chapter shall submit a plan to the ROW administrator as part of its initial registration pursuant to section 25-84(a), specifying in detail the steps it will take to comply with the requirements of this section to document existing facilities. The plan shall provide for the submission of all mapping data for existing facilities along or within: 
(1)  The downtown business district within six (6) months after the effective date of this chapter; and 
(2)  The major arterial street system within twelve (12) months after the effective date of this chapter; and 
(3)  The remainder of the city within twenty-four (24) months after the effective date of this chapter. 
The ROW administrator may grant extensions of the time periods described above for good cause shown. Notwithstanding the foregoing, new facility mapping submissions shall commence for all new projects immediately after the effective date of this chapter. In lieu of submitting a plan, anyone occupying the rights-of-way that already has the required mapping information may submit such information at the time of initial registration. 
(e)  New ROW occupants. New ROW occupants shall submit complete accurate mapping data for all their equipment at the earlier of initial registration, or at the time of any rights-of-way use permits are sought under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-94. - Relocation of equipment and facilities. 
    A ROW occupant or permittee must promptly and at its own expense, with due regard for seasonal working conditions, permanently remove and relocate its equipment and facilities in the rights-of-way upon notification by the city engineer. 
    The ROW administrator shall forward a recommendation upon careful determination at the best interest of the health, safety, and welfare of the public regarding any such removals or relocations. Such removal shall include restoring the rights-of-way to the same condition it was in prior to said removal or relocation, in accordance with the terms of this chapter. A ROW occupant shall promptly, at its own expense, protect, temporarily disconnect, or modify any part of its facility when required by the city by reason of traffic safety, public safety, road construction, change of street grade, installation of water, stormwater, or sanitary pipes, traffic signal devices, or any other types of city improvement projects. The ROW administrator may recommend such actions in order to prevent interference by the ROW occupant's facilities with: a present or future city use of the rights-of-way; or a capital improvement project funded and scheduled to be undertaken by the city; or an economic development project in which the city has an interest or investment. The ROW administrator may also recommend such actions: when the public health, safety and welfare require it; or when necessary to prevent interference with the safety and convenience of ordinary travel over the rights-of-way, both vehicular and pedestrian; or when aboveground equipment is located in such a manner as to create an obstruction to a driver's line of sight. 
    The foregoing does not alter a ROW occupant's obligations within an existing easement established prior to the dedication of public rights-of-way in establishing the party responsible for the expense of any required relocation of equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-95. - Pre-excavation location of equipment. 
    Before a ROW occupant or permittee shall commence to excavate or discharge an explosive in a roadway, street, alley or other rights-of-way as defined in this chapter, such ROW occupant or permittee, unless otherwise exempt by state statute, shall first notify all operators in the city who are on file with the county clerk as to having underground facilities within the county, pursuant to the Underground Facilities Damage Prevention Act, 63 O.S. 1991, §§ 142.1, et seq., said notice shall be either directly or by notice to a one-call notification center of which such operator is a member or participant. Each ROW occupant served with notice in accordance with 63 O.S. 1991, § 142.6, shall locate and mark or otherwise provide the location of the underground facilities of the operator in such a manner as to enable the excavator to determine the precise location of the underground facilities in advance of excavation. In any event, the city shall be indemnified from liability from any damage that should occur due to the failure on the part of either the excavator or the ROW occupant. 
    Once a route is marked for excavation, the ROW occupant or permittee is responsible for taking reasonable steps to maintain these marks through the life of the project. Upon notification by an excavator that the excavation shall be directly over the marked route, defined as a two (2) foot strip on either side of such underground facility a ROW occupant shall determine the precise location of said facility and identify proper steps to protect the facility. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-96. - Damage to other facilities. 
(a)  Damage to other facilities. Each ROW occupant or permittee shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of-way which it or its equipment damages resulting from the ROW occupant or permittee's failure to properly protect the other facilities in compliance with the Oklahoma Underground Facilities Damage Prevention Act. Each ROW occupant or permittee shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any damage to the equipment of any ROW occupant caused during the city's response to an emergency occasioned by the ROW occupant or permittee's equipment. Damage to fences, lawns, shrubbery, drives, mail boxes and other private property caused by any permitted construction, maintenance, or operational activity including vehicular damage and surface rutting shall be immediately repaired to the satisfaction of the property owner. The ROW occupant or permittee shall exercise care to avoid disturbing or damaging survey monuments. Survey monuments shall be restored as directed by the city engineer. 
(b)  Emergencies. Should activities in the rights-of-way result in damage to existing facilities, the ROW occupant or permittee shall notify the operator of the damaged facility and the city's ROW administrator. The ROW occupant or permittee shall take immediate action to protect life, health or property. The ROW occupant or permittee shall delay any backfill of the damaged underground facilities until repaired as authorized by the operator. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-97. - Rights-of-way vacation. 
    In the event that application of any provision of this title requires the vacation of a street or other public way, such vacation shall be accomplished in accordance with Title 11, Section 42-101 et seq. of Oklahoma Statutes, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-98. - Reservation of regulatory and police powers. 
    No provision of this chapter, nor any action taken by the city pursuant to this chapter, shall be deemed to surrender, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights to regulate the occupancy of the rights-of-way that now or may be hereafter vested in the city under the Constitution and statutes of the State of Oklahoma or under the Charter of the city. By accepting a rights-of-way use permit, or a ROW authorization, or by registering under section 25-85, a permittee or ROW occupant is deemed to acknowledge that its rights are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary for the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city, pursuant to such powers. Unless otherwise expressly provided in a ROW authorization or rights-of-way use permit, any conflict between the provisions of any such authorization and any other present or future lawful exercise of the city's regulatory or police powers shall be resolved in favor of the city. 
    If a regulatory body or a court of competent jurisdiction should determine by a final, nonappealable order that any franchise, permit, right or registration issued under this chapter or any portion of this chapter is illegal or unenforceable, then any such franchise, permit, right or registration granted or deemed to exist hereunder shall be considered as a revocable permit with a mutual right of either party to terminate without cause upon giving sixty (60) days' written notice to the other. The requirements and conditions of such a revocable permit shall be the same requirements and conditions as set forth in the franchise, permit, right or registration, respectively, except for conditions relating to the term of the permit and the right of termination. If a franchise, permit, right or registration shall be considered a revocable permit as provided herein, the permittee must acknowledge the authority of the city council to issue such revocable permit and the power to revoke it. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-99. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-100. - Transfers. 
(a)  Approval required. No transfer of a ROW authorization, or a transfer of control of a ROW occupancy or a ROW authorization shall occur without prior applications to and approval by the city council. An application to transfer a ROW authorization must meet the requirements of sections 25-84 and 25-85, as applicable, and provide complete information on the proposed transaction, including the legal, financial, technical and other pertinent qualifications of the transferee. No approval of the city shall be required for a transfer in trust, by mortgage, by other hypothecation, or by assignment of any rights, title or interest of occupancy in this chapter or facilities in order to secure indebtedness of the ROW occupant. 
(b)  Applicable factors. Before approving transfer of a ROW authorization, the city may consider without limitation the legal, financial, and technical qualifications of the transferee to operate the facilities in questions, and whether operation by the proposed ROW occupant will create any risk of nonperformance of a ROW authorization, or otherwise be contrary to the public interest. Before approving a transfer of an interest in a ROW occupant, the city may consider without limitation whether the transferee's interest will have any effect on the ROW occupant's operation of the system, the ROW occupant's qualifications, or the public interest. No transfer shall become effective until the transferee shall have agreed in writing with the city to become responsible for the full performance of all the conditions, liabilities, covenants and obligations contained in this chapter. 
(c)  No waiver or release. Approval by the city of a Transfer of a ROW authorization shall not constitute a waiver or release of any of the rights of the city under this chapter or any ROW authorization. 
(d)  Recovery of costs. The city may impose a charge, in addition to any occupancy fee or other compensation authorized by this chapter or applicable law, to cover the city's costs in excess of the filing fee in considering an application for a transfer of a ROW authorization. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-101. - Exemptions. 
    This chapter applies, to the greatest extent permissible under applicable law, to all ROW occupants. If, on the effective date of this chapter, a person holds a franchise, or has prior rights under a contract, and the terms of this chapter conflict with the franchise or contract, the terms of the franchise shall control, to the extent required by the franchise or contract and applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-102. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Remedies for violations. If a ROW occupant violates any provisions of this chapter or its ROW authorization, the ROW administrator may take one or more of the following actions: 
(1)  Impose liquidated damages in the amount, if any, provided in the ROW authorization, whether per day, incident, or other measure of violation. Payment of liquidated damages by the ROW occupant does not relieve the ROW occupant of its obligation to meet the requirements of this chapter or its ROW authorization; 
(2)  Impose penalties pursuant to section 25-103; 
(3)  Enforce the terms of the performance bond required by this chapter; 
(4)  Reduce the duration of the ROW authorization on any basis the city determines is reasonable and affords the ROW occupant reasonable due process; 
(5)  Revoke the ROW authorization pursuant to its terms or applicable law. 
(b)  ROW administrator's discretion. In determining which remedy or remedies are appropriate under subsection (a), the ROW administrator shall consider the nature of the violation, the person or persons bearing the impact of the violation, the nature of the remedy required in order to prevent further violations, and any other matters the ROW administrator determines are appropriate. The proposed remedy is recommended to the city manager. In addition to or instead of these remedies, the city manager may seek legal or equitable relief from any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Opportunity to cure. Before initiating a remedy under this section, other than revocation of the ROW authorization, the city manager shall give the ROW occupant written notice of the violations claimed and at least twenty (20) working days to correct the violations. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99) 
Sec. 25-103. - Penalties. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to assess penalties against a ROW occupant for failure to comply with the terms of its ROW authorization or this chapter. If the ROW occupant fails to remedy the deficiency by the end of the 20-day period provided in section 25-102(c), the penalty amounts shall begin to accrue and shall continue to accrue until the date that the deficiency is corrected. 
(1)  For effecting or attempting to effect a transfer without approval: one hundred dollars ($100.00) a day for each violation for each day the violation continues; 
(2)  For failure to comply with requirements for public, educational and governmental use of the ROW Occupant's system, or to provide other lawful in-kind compensation to the city: One hundred dollars ($100.00) a day for each violation for each day the violation continues; 
(3)  For failure to supply information, reports, or filings lawfully required under the terms of a ROW authorization or applicable law or by the city: One hundred dollars ($100.00) a day for each violation for each day the violation continues; 
(4)  For failure to pay Occupancy Fees or other fees imposed by this Ordinance: One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day; 
(5)  For failure to restore or repair damages to private property: One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, in addition to the cost of the restoration; 
(6)  For any other violations of the city Code, a ROW authorization, a Rights-of-Way Use Permit, or other applicable law: One hundred dollars ($100.00) a day for each violation for each day the violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 11-1-99)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFSITE IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1613, §§ 1-6, adopted June 16, 1969, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion herein as Art. II, §§ 26-11-26-16, was at the discretion of the editors. Catchlines have been altered or added by the editors where necessary to facilitate indexing and reference, "ordinance" has been changed to "article" where appropriate and § 7, emergency provisions, has not been codified. 

Sec. 26-11. - Building permit not to issue until offsite improvement plans submitted and approved. 
    No building permit shall be issued by the building inspection department until plans are submitted for offsite improvements planned for the project, conforming with the City of Ardmore standards and specifications and requirements. Plans for offsite improvements shall be submitted with all other building plans. 
    Building plans are to be presented to and approved in writing by the building inspection department. Offsite improvement plans are to be presented to and approved in writing by the engineering department. Approval of both departments is required prior to issuance of a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 1, 6-16-69) 
Sec. 26-12. - "Offsite improvements" defined. 
    "Offsite improvements" include any construction or reconstruction including grading and excavating, within the public right-of-way. Offsite improvements include, but are not limited to construction of one-half (1/2) (minimum eighteen (18) feet pavement width) the width of all boundary streets, including curb, gutter, and sidewalk. The construction and/or extension of public water, sewer, gas, electric power, telephone, T.V. cable, and drainage facilities to City of Ardmore standards, and as required by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 6-16-69) 
Sec. 26-13. - Performance bond or cash deposit in lieu of offsite improvements.
