    Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation, record, report, plan or other document filed with the city or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article is hereby declared to be in violation of this article and subject to the civil liabilities imposed under section 30-126 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-131. - Requirements for design and construction of sewer lines. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a sewer line, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling of the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or amplifications thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in the appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and state health department shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
DIVISION 3. - SEWER CONNECTIONS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS 

Sec. 30-132. - Connecting sewers outside city boundaries must comply with city standards. 
    No sanitary sewer constructed outside the city boundaries, the flow of which is discharged or is to be discharged into the sanitary sewer system of the city, shall be connected with the sanitary sewer system of the city unless such sanitary sewer shall have been constructed in compliance with all the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-133. - Sanitary sewer connection plans to be submitted to the City of Ardmore. 
(a)  General requirements. Whenever it is proposed to construct any sanitary sewer outside city boundaries and connect with the sanitary sewer system of the city, the complete plans, specifications, and estimate of costs of such sewer shall be submitted to the city. 
(b)  Authorization of construction. If the city finds from an examination of such plans and specifications that the proposed sanitary sewer complies with the laws of this state and that the design of the sewer is such that it will be practical to connect the same with the sanitary sewerage system of the city, then the construction of such sewerage system shall be authorized. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-134. - Contract to provide for maintenance of sewer. 
    Prior to the authorization provided in this article, the person desiring to construct said sewer shall enter into a contract with the city to provide for the O & M of such sewer for such a period as it remains beyond the city boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-135. - Engineering and inspection fees for sewer construction. 
(a)  Inspection and engineering fee paid to city. For any sanitary sewer to be hereafter constructed outside the city boundaries, if such sewer is to be connected directly or indirectly with the sanitary sewer system of the city, then an inspection and engineering fee shall be paid to the city at the time of the submission of the plans and specifications of such sewer to the city. 
(b)  Amount of fee. Such fee shall be an amount based on the estimated cost of such construction and inspection and shall be computed as provided for in the General Schedule of Fees approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-136. - Inspection by the city. 
(a)  Commencing sewer construction; inspector required. Whenever the owner of a proposed sanitary sewer shall commence the construction of such sewer, he shall notify the city, and the city shall thereupon have a qualified inspector to make the necessary inspections during the construction of such sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Duties of inspector. Such inspector shall see that such sewer is constructed in compliance with the laws of this state, and in accordance with the plans and specifications as approved by the city. 
(c)  Authorization of connection. When such sewer is completed, if the city finds that such sewer has been in all respects constructed as provided for in this article, and that all fees as provided for in this article have been paid, then the city, upon the request of the owner of such sewer, shall authorize the connection of such sewer with the sanitary sewer system of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-137. - Filing of original tracings of sewer plans. 
    Upon completion, final acceptance by the City of Ardmore and the connection of such sewer with the sanitary sewer system of the city, the original tracing of all plans and profiles for the construction of such sanitary sewer shall be corrected by the engineer who prepared the same to show such sewer as it is actually built, and all of such original tracings of the plans and profiles shall be filed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-138. - City not liable for sewer maintenance outside city boundaries. 
    The city shall assume no liability or obligation for the O & M of the sanitary sewer system as long as the user served by such sewer remains outside the city boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-139. - Sewer subject to regulations. 
    After the sewer has been connected with the sanitary sewer system of the city, all the terms of this article shall be in full force and in effect and shall apply to all persons in the district served by such sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-140. - Incorporated city seeks sanitary sewer connection to city. 
(a)  Option to use own services. When the sanitary sewer that is proposed to be connected to the sanitary sewerage system of the city is to be constructed by an incorporated city or town, such city or town shall have the option of using the engineering and inspection services of the city, upon payment of the fees provided for herein, or such city or town may provide its own engineering and inspection services. 
(b)  Standards to be met. If the city or town elects to provide its own engineering and inspection services, then such engineering inspection shall be performed by a registered professional engineer, and the construction shall be equal to the standard specifications of this city. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-141. - Sewer connections outside city. 
(a)  Special sewer connection permit required. No person shall connect, or authorize to be connected, any premises that are located outside the city limits to, or with, any sanitary sewer that shall connect directly or indirectly with the sanitary sewer system of the city, without first obtaining a special sewer connection permit. 
(b)  Permit application; approval by city commission. Any person desiring to obtain a special sewer connection permit shall make application to the city and furnish a detailed plan of the desired connection. After inspection of the plan and existing sewer facilities, the application will be presented to the city commission. Special sewer connection permits shall be issued only with the approval of the city commission. 
(c)  Payment of fee for permit. Upon approval by the city commission of the issuance of the permit, the applicant therefore shall first pay to the city the fee as prescribed in the general schedule of fees approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-142. - Service outside city limits. 
    All sewer service furnished outside of the corporate limits of the city shall be furnished to the consumer at the rate of fifty (50) per cent higher than the rates charged within the city limits, and the user shall be subject to all the provisions of this article relating to sewer service charges. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
DIVISION 4. - USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

Sec. 30-143. - Sewer User Charges. 
    For the purpose of providing revenue for the operation, maintenance and construction of the sanitary sewer system of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, each respective user who discharges waste into the City's sanitary sewer system shall pay a sewer user charge based on the following schedule of rates. 
A.  1.  The following rates shall be effective beginning on the 1st day of July, 2017, and ending on the 30th day of June, 2018. 
Monthly Readiness to serve charge:

2.  An additional sewer user charge shall apply at the rate of three dollars and eight cents ($3.08) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water consumed for all residential, commercial, and industrial accounts. 
3.  For all nonindustrial or noncommercial users, the monthly wastewater contribution shall be determined from a percentage of water returned as wastewater, set at one hundred (100) per cent of the average water usage during months of November, December and January of the preceding year, as the water is measured by a water meter or meters of a type approved by the City, or as the wastewater contribution is otherwise currently established. The sewer rates will be adjusted according to the above formula on or about April 1 of each and every year. 
4.  For industrial and commercial users, the monthly waste water contribution shall be determined from a percentage of water returned as wastewater, set at ninety (90) per cent, unless wastewater volume is measured with an approved volume measuring device in the control manhole. 
5.  No charge is assessed for water meters installed for the exclusive use of lawn sprinklers, swimming pools, and other such related uses whereby water usage does not enter the sanitary sewerage system. 
6.  Each user of the City sanitary sewerage system who converts a substantial part of the water used into a manufactured project for sale, but does not return such part to the City sewerage system at the plant site, a deduction may be made of the part of water going into the manufactured product for the purpose of arriving at a sewer service charge. Such deductions shall be made only from approved meter furnished by the user and approved by the City Manager. 
7.  In the event a lot, parcel of land, premises, or facility discharging sewage industrial wastewater or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into the City's sewer system, or which ultimately enters the sewerage system, is supplied either in whole or in part, with water from wells, or any source other than the City water department, then such wells or other source of supply shall be registered with the City water department on or before January 1, 1984; and if the water from said wells or other supply is not measured by a water meter, the owner or occupant shall, at his cost, install and maintain a meter on said supplies in such a location and in such a manner as is satisfactory to the City water department. These meters shall serve as a basis for the establishment of the sewer user charge and shall be read monthly or bimonthly by the City meter readers. If, in the opinion of the city, the installation of a residential domestic meter would be impractical, water consumption will be estimated at one hundred (100) gallons per capita per day. 
8.  For nonresidential users of the City's sewage system, the City does not obligate itself to furnish sanitary sewer service unless it is reasonably within its financial ability to do so. 
9.  The City Manager shall have the authority to apply the prior year's average water usage in calculating a user's sewer rate where the user is a new customer who has not established a previous year's water usage and in other situations where equity would require it. 
10.  The City Manager shall have the authority to have the option to place certain commercial users on a residential sewer rate where those customers by their very nature have a seasonal water and sewer usage pattern similar to a residence. In no event, however, is this option to be made available to any commercial or industrial user who uses in excess of an average water usage of two hundred fifty thousand (250,000) gallons during the three-month period from November through January on which sewer rates are calculated. 
11.  The City Manager shall have the authority to allow an ice plant to be charged either at the commercial rate or the residential rate. 
B.  Effective the 1st day of July, 2017 and the beginning of each fiscal year thereafter, sewer usage rates for all users (i.e. residential, commercial, industrial...) will increase by the previous year's consumer price index (CPI). 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92; Ord. No. 2456, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-94; Ord. No. 2496, §§ 1, 2, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 2559, §§ I, II, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 2578, §§ 1, 2, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 2616, § II, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 2770, § I, 7-6-04; Ord. No. 2792, § I, 6-20-05; Ord. No. 2796, § 1, 8-1-05; Ord. No. 2822, § I, 8-7-06; Ord. No. 2968 , § I, 6-15-15; Ord. No. 2987 , § I, 6-6-16; Ord. No. 3004, § I, 5-15-17 ) 
Sec. 30-143.5. - Surcharge for industrial users. 
(a)  Any wastewater discharged into the City of Ardmore sanitary sewer system which contains concentrations of conventional pollutants in excess of the allowable quantities as defined in section 30-89 shall be subject to a surcharge, in addition to any other sewer use charges. 
(b)  The industrial user's surcharge shall be calculated by the following formula: 
C s = [(B c (B) + S c (S) + O c (O) + D c (D) + A c (A)]V u 
Where: 
C s = Industrial user's monthly surcharge for wastewaters of excessive strength. B c = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of one pound of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD). B = Concentration of BOD in pounds per million gallons in excess of the allowable concentration. S c = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of one pound of total suspended solids (TSS). S = Concentration of TSS in pounds per million gallons in excess of the allowable concentration. O c = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of one pound of oil and grease. O = Concentration of oil and grease in pounds per million gallons in excess of the allowable concentration. D c = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of one pound of chemical oxygen demand (COD). D = Concentration of COD in pounds per million gallons in excess of the allowable concentration. A c = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of one pound of ammonia. A = Concentration of ammonia in pounds per million gallons in excess of the allowable concentration.  
Unit costs shall be calculated as follows: 
B c = C b /B t S c = C s /S t O c = C o /O t D c = C d /D t A c = C a /A t  
Where: 
C b = Portion of annual operation and maintenance cost of wastewater treatment plant attributable to BOD. C s = Portion of annual operation and maintenance cost of wastewater treatment plant attributable to TSS. C o = Portion of annual operation and maintenance cost of wastewater treatment plant attributable to oil and grease. C d = Portion of annual operation and maintenance cost of wastewater treatment plant attributable to COD. C a = Portion of annual operation and maintenance cost of wastewater treatment plant attributable to ammonia. B t = Annual total BOD loading to the wastewater treatment plant in pounds. S t = Annual total TSS loading to the wastewater treatment plant in pounds. O t = Annual total oil and grease loading to the wastewater treatment plant in pounds. D t = Annual total COD loading to the wastewater treatment plant in pounds. A t = Annual total ammonia loading to the wastewater treatment plant in pounds.  
(c)  An industrial user may, at his own cost, install an approved wastewater flow measuring device in an acceptable location, as provided for, to accurately measure wastewater flow for purposes of determining the monthly contribution of wastewater volume to the sanitary sewer system. Should an industrial user's wastewater flow be measured by a recording meter of a type approved by the city, and if such industrial user maintains such device in a proper condition to accurately measure such flow, then the industrial user's monthly wastewater contribution (V u ), in thousands of gallons, shall be that volume measured by the recording device. Should no measuring device be in use, a percentage of water consumption shall be the basis for estimating for estimating wastewater flows, such percentage of water returned as wastewater being determined by the city. When water is contained in a product or is evaporated, an application may be made for a reduction in the percentage of water returned as wastewater to the sanitary sewer system; provided that supporting data satisfactory to the city are furnished. These data shall include a flow diagram, destination of water supply or wastes, supported by metered data, from meters installed on such process piping at the expense of the private owner. 
(d)  The surcharge for BOD, TSS, oil and grease, COD, and ammonia shall be based upon the analyses required by section 30-105. The applicable surcharge determined by such tests shall be assessed and shall continue for twelve (12) months unless subsequent tests determine that the surcharge should be changed. 
(e)  The surcharge shall be calculated using the total annual operation and maintenance cost of the wastewater treatment plant, the annual loading rates of surchargeable pollutants at the wastewater treatment plant and percentage of costs required to remove one pound of each pollutant. The surcharge shall be recalculated every August following completion of the city's fiscal year. 
(f)  Billing shall be by the month, shall be shown as a separate item on the regular bill for water and sewer charges, and shall be paid monthly in accordance with existing practices. 
(Ord. No. 2494, § 1, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 30-144. - Charges for extraneous flows. 
    Operations and maintenance costs for extraneous flows not directly attributable to users (i.e. infiltration/inflow) shall be proportionately distributed among all users of the sanitary sewer system based on wastewater volume of the users. The city shall adjust the percentage of water returned as wastewater for all users as necessary to recover these costs. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-145. - Initial basis for sewer user charge. 
    New or transfer residential users who are unable to establish an average water consumption basis for December, January, and February, preceding the billing date, can elect their first three-month period as the average basis. If their average usage during the first three-month period is greater than fourteen thousand (14,000) gallons, then charges will be limited to the equivalent of fourteen thousand (14,000) gallons usage times the monthly usage charge. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-146. - Annual review of user charge rates. 
    The basis for determining the sewer user charge rates shall be reviewed annually and shall be adjusted as necessary to reflect any increase or decrease in wastewater treatment costs based on the immediately preceding years' experience. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-147. - Capital Fee Sewer User Charge. 
    For the purpose of providing needed capital improvements, maintenance, and construction of the sanitary sewer system of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma, beginning July 1, 2016, each respective residential user who discharges waste into the City's sanitary sewer system shall pay a Capital Fee sewer user charge in the amount of $5.83 per month; and each respective commercial and industrial user who discharges waste into the City's sanitary sewer system shall pay a Capital Fee sewer user charge in the amount of $20.00 per month. 
    Effective the 1st day of July, 2017 and the beginning of each fiscal year thereafter, the capital fee sewer user fee for all users will increase by the previous year's consumer price index (CPI). 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92; Ord. No. 2792, § II, 6-20-05; Ord. No. 2822, § II, 8-7-06; Ord. No. 2968 , § II, 6-15-15; Ord. No. 2987 , § II, 6-6-16; Ord. No. 3004, § I, 5-15-17 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2968 , § II, adopted June 15, 2015, amended the catchline of § 30-147 to read as herein set out. The catchline of § 30-147 formerly read "Minimum sewer user charge." 
Sec. 30-148. - Record keeping of user charges. 
    Records will be maintained on the following items: 
(1)  Originally approved user charge system and all documentation related thereto. 
(2)  Annual review of the user charge system and all documentation related thereto. 
(3)  Annual OM&R costs for the sanitary sewer system. 
(4)  Names and address for industrial users of the sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-149. - Billings; water resales. 
    If water is sold by the city and metered to a person for resale to water consumers who are users of the city sewerage system, such first purchaser shall be responsible to the city for the billing and collecting of all sewer user charges of said consumers and shall account to the city for all such sewer user charges at the time such first purchaser pays his water bill. If requested by the city manager, a purchaser of water for resale to consumers shall furnish and certify the number and addresses of all of his water customers who are users of the city's sanitary sewerage system. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-150. - Billing for sewer service. 
(a)  General requirements. Billings for sewer service shall be rendered at the same time and on the same bills issued for water service, but shall be shown as a separate item from the charge for water. 
(b)  Prorated billings. If sewer service is commenced or terminated during a period for which bills will be rendered, billing shall be prorated on a daily basis. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-151. - Date of payment. 
    The sewer user charge shall be due and payable from and after the date on the bill on which such charge is shown. Payment shall be made to the city clerk, but the city clerk shall not accept payment for any sewer user charge without payment of the water bill on which said charge is shown; nor shall payment of any water bill be accepted without payment of any sewer user charge shown thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-152. - Water deposits. 
    All deposits made by users of city water, as required by the city ordinances to guarantee payment of water bills, may also be applied to pay delinquent or defaulting sewer user charges of the user who made the deposit. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-153. - Penalty for failure to pay. 
    Failure to pay a sewer user charge in connection herewith shall be cause for discontinuing and disconnecting either the sewer connection or water connection or both. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 30-154. - Inconsistent agreements. 
    The user charge system shall take precedence over any terms or conditions of agreements or contracts, between the city and users of the sanitary sewer system, which are inconsistent with the requirements of Section 204(b)(i)(a) of the Clean Water Act and Federal Register 40 CFR Part 35.2140. 
(Ord. No. 2376, § 3, 5-18-92) 
ARTICLE VIII. - GREASE TRAP REQUIREMENTS FOR COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 30-155. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise stated in the context of this article, the following terms and abbreviations will have the meanings given hereafter: 
    Director means the Ardmore City Manager or his/her designee. 
    Facility means a commercial business that generates FOGs. May also be referred to as a generator. 
    Fiscal year means the accounting period for twelve (12) months, which begins July 1 and ends June 30 for the City of Ardmore. 
    FOGs means fats, oils, and greases. 
    Generator means any facility that produces FOGs. May also be referred to as a facility. 
    Grease interceptor means a device that separates, traps and holds FOGs from the wastewater discharge from a facility to prevent the FOGs from entering the POTW. May also be referred to as a grease trap. 
    New construction restaurant means a commercial business that is building a new facility. 
    NOV (Notice of violation) means a control authority document notifying a facility that is has violated Grease Trap Ordinance _______ standards and requirements. 
    POTW means publicly owned treatment works. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 30-156. - Purpose. 
    This article will set forth the standards and requirements concerning the installation of grease interceptors for all commercial facilities, which prepares or serves food, that may potentially discharge any solid or viscous pollutants into the POTW (public owned treatment works). The purpose of this article is to control the discharge of "solid or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause obstruction to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference" [CFR 403.5(b)(3)]. A violation of this article does not require a criminal mental state or is ignorance an excuse. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99) 
Sec. 30-157. - Scope and applicability. 
    This chapter will be directed towards all facilities that generate FOGs who are connected to the POTW and the transporters of the wastes that are created that must comply with all local, state and federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 2, 3-17-03) 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[6]

Secs. 30-158-30-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GENERAL INTERCEPTOR REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 30-161. - Design size and location. 
(a)  On or after the effective date of this article, all new facilities with food preparation areas listed in Section 1003.3.1 in the International Plumbing Code 2000 will be required to install a one thousand (1,000) gallon underground grease trap. Any facility not listed in Section 1003.3.1 will be sized on a case-by-case scenario by the City of Ardmore Department of Development Services. Any existing structure facility that has limited space to install a one thousand (1,000) gallon underground grease trap may receive a variance and will be sized on a case-by-case scenario by the City of Ardmore Department of Development Services. All grease traps installed will conform to Section 1003.3.4 of the International Plumbing Code 2000. 
(b)  Any facility that does not have a grease trap that causes more than one bypass or has been determined to be the cause of more than three (3) work orders due to grease blockages in any twelve (12) month period will be required to install a grease trap. This order will be issued by the industrial pretreatment department and given to the department of development services for all sizing and installation according to section 30-161(a) of the City of Ardmore Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2734, §§ 3, 4, 3-17-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2734, § 3, adopted March 17, 2003, repealed the former § 30-161. Section 4 of said ordinance enacted a new § 30-161 as set out herein. The former § 30-161 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2619, adopted July 19, 1999. 
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS AND ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 30-162. - Permits. 
(a)  General. All facilities that prepare or serve food that may potentially introduce FOGs into the POTW will be required to obtain a grease discharge permit. Under this section it will be considered unlawful for any facility to knowingly discharge FOGs in amounts that may cause obstruction to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference. False or misleading information on an application will result in the termination of the application or permit if it has been issued. 
(b)  Length of permit. When an application has been reviewed and approved by the industrial pretreatment department according to all rules in this article and all appropriate fees are paid, all permits will be issued for a period of not more than five (5) years from the date of an applicant's approval. The permit holder will apply for a re-issuance of their permit a minimum of one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the permit's expiration date. A permit may be terminated at any time when the director or his designee finds that the permit holder has violated their permit conditions. 
(c)  Permit transfer. All permits are approved and issued to individual services and facilities. None of the permits issued will be reassigned, transferred or sold due to a new owner or a new facility location. 
(d)  Modifications. The director or his designee has the ability to modify or change any permits issued and includes, but will not be limited to the following: 
(1)  To revise standards to keep in compliance with changing local, state and federal regulations, requirements and standards that may apply; 
(2)  Due to a violation of any terms of the permit; 
(3)  A change in the permit holder's process; 
(4)  To reflect a change in ownership or facility location; or 
(5)  A request from the permit holder to have their permit modified, reissued, or terminated. 
a.  A request from a facility for modifications of their permit must be received in writing by the industrial pretreatment department explaining in detail the permit holder's reasons for a modification. 
(e)  Duty to comply. The permittee must comply with all conditions of this permit. Failure to comply with the requirements of this permit shall be grounds for enforcement remedies as described in section 30-169(b) of this article. 
(f)  Duty to mitigate. The permittee shall take all reasonable steps to minimize or correct any adverse impact to the POTW or the environment resulting from noncompliance with the permit issued, including such accelerated or additional monitoring as necessary to determine the nature and impact of the noncompliance. 
(g)  Permit termination. An issued permit may be terminated for, but not limited to, the following reasons: 
(1)  Refusing to allow timely access to the facility premises and records; 
(2)  Failure to pay fines; 
(3)  Failure to pay fees; 
(4)  Failure to meet compliance schedules. 
(h)  Property rights. The issuance of a permit does not convey any property right of any sort, or an exclusive privilege, nor does it authorize any injury to private property or any invasion of personal rights, nor any violation of federal, state, or local laws or regulations. 
(i)  Compliance with applicable laws, standards, and requirements. Compliance with an issued permit does not relieve the permittee from its obligations regarding compliance with any and all applicable local, state and federal laws, standards, and requirements, including any such standards or requirements that may become effective during the term of this permit. 
(j)  Compliance date. Every facility and generator will be in compliance with all the standards and requirements of this article within one hundred eighty (180) days of its approval. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 5, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 30-163. - Requirements for generators. 
(a)  Maintenance. It will be the responsibility of the facilities to properly maintain, operate and clean their grease interceptors. This includes the complete removal or pumping of all liquids, sludge, solids and wastewater on the surface and the bottom of the grease interceptor. Generators will not be allowed to decant or pump the supernatant or liquid fraction back into the grease interceptor for purposes of reducing the volume of waste to be disposed of. The facility will only use the transporters that have been permitted by the City of Ardmore. A list of these transporters may be received from the industrial pretreatment department. Grease interceptors will be pumped out according to a schedule determined by the industrial pretreatment department. 
(b)  Manifest log. It is mandatory that all facilities with a grease interceptor keep a record of all manifests and maintain a current manifest log for a period of three (3) years. This log will include the transporter used, city permit #, vehicle tag #, date and time pumped and must be signed by the transporter and the representative of the facility. This log will be kept in a conspicuous location for inspections and will be immediately available to a representative of the City of Ardmore who may be performing such inspections. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 6, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 30-164. - Requirements for transporters. 
(a)  Pumping. It will be the responsibility of the transporters to properly clean the grease interceptors as required by this chapter. The cleaning of the grease interceptor will be the complete pump out of the contents of the grease interceptor. Decanting of the supernatant back into the interceptor will not be allowed. Discharging of the grease interceptor waste back into any part of the City of Ardmore POTW is prohibited. The transporter will dispose of the grease interceptor waste in accordance with all local, state and federal regulations. 
(b)  Manifest. The manifest will be used to track the grease interceptor waste from the initial generation of the waste to the final disposal. It will be the responsibility of the transporter to oversee the manifest. A book of manifests will be issued to each transporter which has been permitted by the City of Ardmore. The transporter will ensure that all parts of the form are completed entirely. The transporter will leave the appropriate copies of the manifest with the generator, industrial pretreatment department and the disposal site. All generators and transporters will keep their copies of manifests on file for a time period of three (3) years. The manifests will be kept in a conspicuous location for inspection and will be immediately available to a representative of the City of Ardmore who may be performing such inspections. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 7, 3-17-03) 
DIVISION 5. - FEES, CHARGES AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 30-165. - Purpose. 
    It will be the sole purpose of this section to recover any costs incurred by the City of Ardmore from the generators and transporters. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 2734, § 8, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 30-166. - Manifest fees. 
    Manifest fees will be established to recover any costs incurred by the City of Ardmore. 
(Ord. No. 2734, § 10, 3-17-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2734, § 9, adopted March 17, 2003, repealed the former § 30-166. Section 10 of said ordinance enacted a new § 30-166 as set out herein. The former § 30-166 pertained to permit fees and derived from Ord. No. 2619, adopted July 19, 1999. 
Secs. 30-167, 30-168. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2734, § 9, adopted March 17, 2003, repealed §§ 30-167, 30-168, which pertained to surcharge fee and exemption fee and derived from Ord. No. 2619, adopted July 19, 1999. 
Sec. 30-169. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Recovery of costs incurred. Any permittee violating any of the provisions of an issued permit or the industrial pretreatment ordinance or causing damage to or otherwise inhibiting the City of Ardmore wastewater disposal system shall be liable to the City of Ardmore for any expense, loss, or damage caused by such violation or discharge. The cost incurred by the City of Ardmore for any cleaning, repair, or replacement work caused by the violation will be added to the permittee's monthly water bill for payment. Refusal to pay the assessed costs will be handled by the City of Ardmore Customer Services Department. 
(1)  Any facility with or without a grease trap causing a sanitary sewer overflow (bypass) due to the discharge of FOGs will be liable to the City of Ardmore for any expense, loss, or damage incurred. Any facility without a grease trap will then automatically be required to install, operate, and maintain an underground grease trap or retrofit as cited in section 30-161. 
(2)  Any facility whose collection line becomes restricted and requires flushing due to the discharge of FOGs will be liable to the City of Ardmore for any expense, loss, or damage incurred. 
(b)  Violations and fines. Any permittee violating any of the provisions of an issued permit shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to applicable fines and costs. All fines and costs will be assessed to the permittee's monthly water bill. 
(1)  Generators.

ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Note- See editor's note at Art. I. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 31-3. - Purpose and scope. 
    It is the intent of this article to regulate the operation and control of taxicabs within the corporate limits of the City of Ardmore, pursuant to the authority granted by the Oklahoma Statutes, Title 11, Section 22-118, and any duly enacted legislation amendatory or supplementary thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. II, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-4. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(1)  License shall mean a certificate issued by the city council, authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business in the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
(2)  Driver shall mean every person in direct or immediate possession of, in charge of or operating a taxicab. 
(3)  Major traffic violation shall mean any hazardous moving traffic violation. 
(4)  Manifest shall mean a daily record prepared by the taxicab driver of all trips made by the driver, showing time, place of origin, destination, number of passengers and the amount of fare of each trip. 
(5)  Owner shall mean every person, firm, partnership, association or corporation having proprietary use, ownership or control of any taxicab or fleet of taxicabs. 
(6)  Rate card shall mean a card for display on each taxicab which contains the rates of fare then in force. 
(7)  Taxicab shall mean a motor-propelled vehicle which is used for the transportation of passengers for hire over and along the public streets, not over a defined route and destination in accordance with and under the direction of the person hiring such vehicle, for compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. II, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-5. - Liability under state torts act. 
    No duty described in this article shall be considered a mandatory duty for the purpose of the political subdivision Tort Claims Act, O.S. Title 51, Section 151 et seq. Specifically, the failure of the City of Ardmore to inspect any taxicab pursuant to this chapter or the negligent inspection of any taxicab by the City of Ardmore shall not create liability on behalf of the City of Ardmore under this chapter (51 O.S., 155(13)). 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. II, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-6. - Schedule of fees. 
    A schedule of fees for the licenses required by this article is hereby fixed and levied in amounts established by ordinance, which ordinance is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. II, 4-20-87) 
Secs. 31-7-31-10. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 31-11. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation to engage in the business of operating any taxicab within the City of Ardmore without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-12. - Responsibility for operating vehicles under license. 
    Ownership of all vehicles licensed under this article shall be at the option of the holder of the license and may be company-owned, leased or independently owned. The license holder shall be responsible for all vehicles operating under its certificate and any violations by an operator of a vehicle, whether leased or independently owned, shall be deemed a violation by the license holder. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-13. - Application. 
    Applicants for a license to operate a taxicab business shall file with the city clerk a verified application which shall set forth: 
(1)  Name, address, business name and any established place of business of applicant, including address and location of dispatcher. 
(2)  The number of vehicles applicant intends to operate as taxicabs. 
(3)  The make, type, year of manufacture and passenger-seating capacity of each taxicab for which application for license is made. 
(4)  A description of the color scheme, insignia or any other distinguishing characteristics of the taxicab. 
(5)  Proof of financial responsibility as herein described and as provided by Oklahoma Statutes, Title 41, Section 8-104. (See section 31-52) 
(6)  A schedule showing passenger fares to be charged. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-14. - Sale or transfer of licensed taxicabs. 
    If an owner sells or transfers title to a taxicab for which a permit has been issued pursuant to a license granted under the provisions of this article, the owner to whom such a permit has been issued shall surrender to the city clerk; provided, however, such owner may, upon proper application therefor, in accordance with the provisions of this article, apply for another permit for any new taxicabs which such owner proposes to operate, pursuant to said license, so long as the total number of permits does not exceed that number of permits authorized by said license. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-15. - Transfer of license prohibited. 
    No license to operate a taxicab company may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise be transferred by the person to whom it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-16. - Revocation or suspension procedure. 
(a)  The City of Ardmore may at anytime, pursuant to the revocation or suspension proceedings as herein described, revoke or suspend the license granted under this article, if it makes any of the following determinations: 
(1)  If the owner fails to operate taxicab in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  If the owner discontinues or suspends service for a period of ten (10) days, without first obtaining permission from the city clerk. 
(3)  If the owner refuses to accept a request for service within the corporate limits of the City of Ardmore, while having vehicles and drivers available. 
(4)  If taxicabs are operated at a rate of fare other than that specified and on file with the city clerk. 
(5)  If the license holder operates, or permits to be operated, any taxicab for which the required insurance coverage has not been secured and is not in full force and effect. 
(b)  The city clerk shall initiate revocation or suspension proceedings by giving written notice to such owner that a public hearing will be held by a commission consisting of the city manager, the city clerk and the chief of police. Such notice shall be given at least five (5) days prior to the date of such hearing and shall specify the grounds upon which revocation or suspension proceedings will be conducted. At such public hearing said panel shall consider all relevant testimony before making its determination thereon. An owner may appeal from an adverse ruling by the panel to the city council as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-17. - Surrender of license. 
    All permits or license which shall have been suspended or revoked by the commission, chief of police or his authorized representative shall be surrendered to the city clerk, and the operation of all taxicabs covered by such permits or license shall cease and be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. III, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Secs. 31-18-31-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 

Sec. 31-26. - Identification card; required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a taxicab which originates trips within the city without first obtaining an identification card to do so from the chief of police or his authorized representative. To secure such permission, a prospective taxicab driver shall file a written application with the chief of police or his authorized representative. Application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable processing fee in the amount of five dollars ($5.00). An identification card shall be issued by the chief of police or his authorized representative. Said identification card shall not be transferable. The permittee shall post the identification card in the taxicab in view of the passengers therein during all working hours. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 2, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-27. - Application. 
    Any person may apply to the city for a permit to operate a taxicab by filing with the chief of police or his authorized representative, upon forms supplied by the city, an application containing the following information: 
(1)  Name (including all aliases or previously used names), addresses and date and place of birth of applicant. 
(2)  Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony and the date of such conviction. 
(3)  Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a misdemeanor within five (5) years prior to the application and the date and place of such conviction. 
(4)  The endorsement of the owner by whom the applicant is to be employed as a driver. 
(5)  Number, class and expiration date of State of Oklahoma commercial chauffeur's license. 
(6)  Whether a driver's license issued to the applicant by any state has ever been revoked and the reason for such revocation. 
(7)  Such other information regarding the health, mental stability and experience of the applicant as may be necessary or desirable to enable the chief of police or his authorized representative to determine applicant's qualifications for a driver's permit. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 3, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-28. - Grounds for denial. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a driver's permit, the chief of police or his authorized representative shall conduct an investigation of the applicant and, on the basis of such investigation, shall either approve or deny the application. No permit shall be issued to any of the following persons: 
(1)  Any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(2)  Any person convicted of a felony or misdemeanor offense which reasonably and directly indicates a potential risk to the public. This restriction shall apply to misdemeanor convictions occurring within five (5) years of the date of the application. 
(3)  Any person convicted of a hit-and-run driving, reckless driving or driving in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or any drug within two (2) years of the date of the application, or upon conviction of any two (2) or more of these offenses within five (5) years of the date of the application. However, no permit shall be issued to any person convicted of any offense described herein if such person was driving a motor vehicle for hire at the time the offense was committed. 
(4)  Any person not possessing a valid State of Oklahoma driver's license of the class required by the state law for the operation of taxicabs. 
(b)  The restriction in this section shall apply both to persons possessing a driver's permit and to persons seeking renewal of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 4, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-29. - Form of permit; period of validity. 
(a)  Upon approval of an application for driver's permit and upon payment of the fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00), the chief of police or his authorized representative shall issue a permit to the applicant. Such permit shall bear the name and photograph of the applicant, date of expiration of the permit and the name of the owner for which the driver is authorized to operate a vehicle. Such permit shall be delivered to the driver named therein and shall be valid only so long as said driver continues in the employ of such license holder. 
(b)  Upon the termination of any driver's employment, the owner by whom such driver has been employed shall immediately give the police department written notice of such termination and the reason therefore. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 5, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-30. - Revocation or suspension; reporting of driver's offenses. 
(a)  Any person issued a driver's permit who subsequently is convicted of any felony or misdemeanor offense or who ceases to possess a valid State of Oklahoma commercial chauffeur's license of the class required by state law for the operation of taxicabs shall immediately so inform his employer and the chief of police or his authorized representative. 
(b)  The chief of police or his authorized representative shall revoke the driver's permit of any driver who ceases to possess a valid driver's license or is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor when such conviction results in the driver being unable to drive a taxicab, or the chief of police or his authorized representative determines that such conviction reasonably and directly indicates a potential risk to the public. 
(c)  The chief of police or his authorized representative my revoke or suspend any driver's permit if the driver's State of Oklahoma Department of Motor Vehicles record includes three (3) or more moving violation within the preceding twelve-month period, or if the chief of police or his authorized representative determines the driver is a danger to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 6, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-31. - Notice of intent to deny permit; hearing. 
(a)  Whenever the chief of police or his authorized representative intends to deny an application or revoke a permit for driving a taxicab, he shall give the applicant or permit holder written notice of intent to deny or revoke such driver's permit, stating grounds upon which denial or revocation is contemplated and shall inform such applicant or permit holder that he/she has ten (10) days to file a written request for a hearing. The application may be denied or the permit revoked if a request for hearing is not received within a ten-day period. 
(b)  If the applicant or permit holder files a timely request for a hearing, the chief of police or his authorized representative shall set a time and place for the hearing and shall consider all relevant evidence and testimony prior to making a decision thereon. The decision of the chief of police or his authorized representative to revoke a permit or deny an application may be appealed to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 7, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-32. - Renewal of driver's permit. 
    The applicant shall be required to meet the same standards as set forth in this article for initial permit. No refund shall be made for any reason and no permit fee shall be prorated. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. IV, 4-20-87) 
Secs. 31-33-31-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TAXICAB BUSINESSES 

Sec. 31-36. - Business license required. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation which has applied for and received a license shall, before commencing the operation of a taxicab company, pay the city clerk of a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for such license. Said license shall be renewed annually. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. V, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-37. - Vehicles, inspections, maintenance, equipment. 
(a)  Vehicle to meet standards before any license is issued. Prior to the use and operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this article, the vehicle shall be thoroughly inspected by the police department in accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed by this section. 
(b)  Periodic inspections. Every vehicle operating under this section shall be periodically inspected by the police department at such intervals as shall be established by the chief of police or his authorized representative to ensure the continued maintenance of safe operating conditions. If, upon inspection, it is found that the vehicle operating under this article does not meet the requirements established herein, the chief of police or his authorized representative shall cause the vehicle license to be suspended, until such a time as the vehicle has been made to comply. 
(c)  Cleanliness and working order. Every vehicle under this article shall be kept clean and the upholstery in good repair. 
(d)  Standard equipment. All vehicles to be licensed and used as taxicabs shall have as standard equipment: 
(1)  Four (4) wheel brakes in good operating condition. 
(2)  Parking brake in good operating condition. 
(3)  Front and rear bumpers. 
(4)  Heater, defroster. 
(5)  Right and lift side review mirror. 
(6)  Speedometer exposed in view and in good operating condition. 
(7)  Windshield wipers. 
(8)  Tires with a minimum of 2/32 -inch tread. 
(9)  Factory-recommended shock absorbers. 
(10)  Properly operating turn indicators. 
(11)  All glass shall be safety-glazed glass equal to manufacturer's standard specification. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. V, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 8, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 31-38. - Overall taxicab service required. 
    All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the City of Ardmore operating under the provisions of this article shall render an overall service to the public desiring the use of a taxicab. License holders of a taxicab business shall maintain a central place of business which is kept open twenty-four (24) hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching cabs. They shall answer all calls as soon as they can do so. If service can not be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall notify the prospective passenger as to how long it will be before the call can be answered. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. V, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-39. - Manifests. 
(a)  Every taxicab driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which is recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of the trip and amount of fare. All completed manifests shall be returned to the owner at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished to the driver by the owner and shall be of a character approved by the chief of police or his authorized representative. 
(b)  Every holder of a license to operate a taxicab company shall maintain all taxicab manifests in a safe place for one (1) year, and such manifests shall be available to the police department upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. V, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2767, § 9, 6-21-04) 
DIVISION 5. - RATES AND FARES 

Sec. 31-40. - Rates and notice of increase to be filed with city clerk. 
(a)  The rate schedule specifying the rates and charges established for operation of a taxi service shall be filed by the owner or operator of such service with the city clerk. No rates or charges other than those specified in such rate schedule shall be made by the owner or operator. The owner or operator shall file a notice of any rate adjustments at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective dates of any rate change or adjustment with the city clerk, setting for the rates or changes then in effect and the proposed rates or changes and the date they are to take effect. 
(b)  In addition to filing notice with the city clerk, the owner or operator shall cause notice of such rate increase to be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VI, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-41. - Posting rates. 
    Rates and charges shall be posted in each taxicab in a place visible to passengers. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any taxicab or public transportation vehicle in the city to charge or collect for service at a rate more or less than that specified in the rate schedule on file with the city clerk. 
Sec. 31-42. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - OPERATING EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 31-43. - Vehicle maintenance. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner to ensure that every taxicab operating under its license is in safe working order and meets the requirements of the Vehicle Code of the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-44. - Most direct route required. 
    Any driver employed to transport passengers to a definite point shall take the most direct route that will take the passengers to their destination safely and expeditiously. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-45. - Receipts on request. 
    If requested, every driver of a taxicab shall give a receipt upon payment of a correct fare. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-46. - Refusal of service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver to refuse, when vehicle is in service and not otherwise engaged, to transport any person who requests such service in a sober and orderly manner and for a lawful purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-47. - Additional passengers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver to permit any other person to occupy or ride in a taxicab, unless the first person employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of additional passengers. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-48. - Seating capacity not to be exceeded. 
    No driver shall permit more passengers to be carried in a taxicab than the rated seating capacity of such taxicab, as statement issued for such taxicab. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-49. - Display of permit required. 
    Each taxicab shall have located in the driver's compartment and in view of the passengers therein a copy of the "Permit to Operate" issued to such taxicab and the permit of the driver. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-50. - Dispatcher. 
(a)  Each owner shall provide and maintain a dispatcher to receive calls for service. All requests for service inside the corporate limits will be answered as soon as practicable. 
(b)  Notice of change of business or dispatch address or telephone number shall be provided to the chief of police at least seventy-two (72) hours prior to such change. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-51. - Identification on outside of vehicle. 
    Every taxicab operated in the city shall bear the following identification: The owner's name, monogram or insignia approved pursuant to the license, together with the taxicab identification number and the owner's telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 31-52. - Insurance requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful for an owner or driver to operate a taxicab within the corporate limits of the city unless such owner or driver shall first have filed with the city clerk proof of financial responsibility as defined in Oklahoma Statutes Title 47, Section 8-104, and any duly enacted amendment thereto. If at any time the policy of insurance is cancelled by the company issuing the same, or the authority of the company to do business in the state shall be revoked, the city clerk shall replace such policy with another policy satisfactory to the city attorney; and, in default thereof, the owner's permission to operate a taxicab shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2252, Art. VII, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2318, § I, 10-2-89) 
Secs. 31-53-31-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUSES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2252, Art. I, adopted Apr. 20, 1987, added new §§ 31-3-31-52; thus, previous §§ 31-30-31-34 of Art. III were renumbered as 31-60-31-64 at the editor's discretion to facilitate the inclusion of the new provisions. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate operation of buses, 47 O.S. 1961, § 224. 

Sec. 31-60. - Board to regulate operation; grant permission to operate by resolution. 
    The right to use any street or alley of this city for the operation of any vehicle carrying passengers is hereby declared to be a privilege subject to the control and regulation of the board of commissioners of this city and will not be granted except by application to said board and a resolution adopted upon said application granting said right. 
(Code 1959, § 19-12) 
Sec. 31-61. - Application for permit. 
    All persons desiring such permits shall file application thereof in writing with the city clerk, and said route or routes shall be controlled by said resolution. 
(Code 1959, § 19-13) 
Sec. 31-62. - Transfer of permit; board to approve. 
    No such permit shall be transferred without permission of the board of commissioners granted by resolution entered of record in its minutes. 
(Code 1959, § 19-15) 
Sec. 31-63. - Insurance required. 
    If the board of commissioners shall determine to grant a permit, it shall require said applicant to deposit with the city clerk a policy or policies of insurance issued by some reliable insurance company or to be approved by the board of commissioners which shall obligate the insurance carrier to pay all damages not to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any one (1) person and not to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one (1) accident, to which any person whether passenger on said vehicle or not may become entitled as a result of personal injuries sustained in the course of operation of such vehicle and in addition thereto to pay any amount not to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any person who may sustain damages to property as a result of the operation of such vehicle. Said policy shall be for a term of at least one (1) year, and the permit shall be in effect from date issued subject to termination at any time that said insurance shall lapse or may not be renewed in which case said permit shall automatically terminate. 
(Code 1959, § 19-14) 
Sec. 31-64. - Compliance with provisions required; revocation of permit for failure to comply. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle along a fixed route or upon a fixed schedule within the city limits for the purpose of carrying persons for hire without having complied with all requirements of this article and resolutions adopted by the commissioners granting right to operate buses. In addition to any punishment imposed by the municipal judge, the board of commissioners may at its discretion revoke and terminate such permit as an additional punishment for such violation. 
(Code 1959, § 19-16) 
Chapter 32 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - CABLE TELEVISION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2673, § I, adopted Feb. 20, 2001 repealed the provisions of former §§ 32-1-32-44. Ord. No. 2674, § I, adopted Feb. 20, 2001 replaced those provisions with the similar provisions of §§ 32-1-32-44 as currently set out herein. Former §§ 32-1-32-44 derived from Ord. No. 2655, § I, adopted July 3, 2000. 

Sec. 32-1. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Ardmore Cable Television Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2674, § I, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 32-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein unless otherwise defined by federal or state law. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory, and "may" is permissive. Words not defined herein shall be given the meaning set forth in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, the Telecommunications Act of 1996 and as may hereinafter be further amended, and if not defined therein, such words shall have their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Access channel means any channel on a cable system which, by the terms of this article or otherwise, is required to be kept available without charge by franchise for partial or total dedication to public, educational and/or local government use and over which franchisee exercises no editorial control. 
    Affiliate means an entity which owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with franchisee. 
    Application means any proposal, submission or request to: 
(1)  Construct and operate a cable system within the city; 
(2)  Transfer a franchise or control of a franchise; 
(3)  Renew a franchise; 
(4)  Modify a franchise; or 
(5)  Seek any other relief from the city pursuant to this article, a franchise agreement, the Cable Act as amended, or the FCC rules and regulations. 
    Cable Act means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended, the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, as amended and all applicable provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. 
    Cable Internet service means only cable service offered by franchisee whereby persons receive access to the Internet through the cable system. 
    Cable service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of 
(1)  Video programming; or 
(2)  Other programming services, such as digital audio, together with any subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video, programming or other programming service. 
To the extent consistent with applicable law, cable service shall include cable Internet service and other interactive services including, but not limited to game channels, information and enhanced services made available to subscribers by franchisee. 
    Cable system shall mean, a facility, consisting of a set of transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and other communications services which are provided to multiple subscribers within the city. It shall include, without limitation, all of the components, physical operation and programming elements of a network of cable, electrical and electronic equipment, designed, constructed, wired or used for purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying and transmitting by coaxial cable, fiber optics, microwave or other means audio and/or audio/visual electrical impulses of television, radio and other intelligences, either analog or digital, including, but not limited to, cable television for sale to the inhabitants and businesses of the city. The term does not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to re-transmit the television signals of one (1) or more television broadcast stations; 
(2)  A facility that serves subscribers without using any public right of way; 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, except that such a facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621 of such Act) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; 
(4)  An open video system that complies with Section 653 of Title VI of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended; or 
(5)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
    City means the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    City attorney is the city attorney for the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    City clerk is the city clerk of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    City engineer is the city engineer of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    City manager means the city manager of Ardmore, Oklahoma or his duly authorized representative. 
    Converter means a device used for changing the frequency of a television signal. It may also include descrambling or decoding capabilities. 
    City commission or commission is the governing body of the City of Ardmore, Oklahoma. 
    Drop means the cable or wire that connects the distribution portion of a cable system to a subscriber's premises. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Franchise or permit means the right granted by the city to a franchisee to construct, maintain and operate a cable system under, on and over streets, roads and all other public ways and easements within the city. 
    Franchise or permit agreement means the contract entered into in accordance with this article, and sets forth the terms and conditions under which the franchise will be exercised. 
    Franchisee or permittee means any person granted a franchise or permit pursuant to this article and shall include any successor thereto. 
    Gross revenues means: 
(1)  Any and all revenues, including but not limited to, all cash, credits, amounts earned or accrued, property or other consideration of any kind or nature, received directly or indirectly by the franchisee, its subsidiaries, affiliates or other person or entity in which franchisee has a financial interest or which has a financial interest in franchisee, or is in any way affiliated with franchisee, arising from, attributable to, or in any way derived from the sale or exchange of cable services by franchisee or resulting from the operation of the cable system within the city. Gross revenues shall include, but not be limited to: monthly fees charged subscribers for basic service; additional tiers any optional, pay per view, premium, per-channel or per-program service or charges for any other type of service; installation, disconnection, and change in service fees; leased channel fees; fees, payments or other consideration received from programmers for carriage of programming; program guides, converter and equipment fees, rentals or sales; remote controls, additional outlets and other Subscriber premises equipment, advertising revenues; revenues from home shopping channels; revenues from revenue sharing arrangements; revenues from the sale and/or lease of high speed data modems and Internet access or service; data transmission and interactive service; fees from use of access channels, revenues from studio rental, production fees and equipment charges when applicable. Gross revenues shall not include any sales, excise or other taxes or fees which are imposed directly on any cable service subscriber by any governmental unit or agency and which are collected by the franchisee on behalf of such governmental unit or agency. The franchise fee shall not be deemed such a tax and shall be includable in gross revenues. Exchange or other non-monetary compensation shall be includable in gross revenues at the retail value of the compensation received by the franchisee. 
(2)  Revenue, including advertising revenue, which can not be attributed to a particular subscriber, shall be allocated to the city based on the percentage of subscribers within the city compared to the subscribers served or reached source of the revenue by the entire system of the franchisee. 
(3)  This definition is intended to be as inclusive as possible consistent with existing applicable law. If there is a change in the law subsequent to the effective date of any franchise permitting additional revenues to be subject to this definition, this definition shall automatically be amended to include such revenues. However, if such change shall have the effect of excluding revenues such change shall not impact this gross revenue definition unless specifically preempted. 
    Normal business hours means those hours during which most similar businesses in the community are open to serve customers. In all cases, normal business hours must include some evening hours at least one (1) night per week and/or some weekend hours. 
    Normal operating conditions means those service conditions which are within the control of the franchisee. Those conditions which are not within the control of the franchisee include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions. Conditions which are ordinarily within the control of the franchisee include, but are not limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular peak or seasonal demand periods, and maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. 
    Ordinance means the Ardmore Cable Television Ordinance, unless the context shall indicate otherwise. 
    Permanent pavement is any pavement which, when installed, met the then existing pavement standards of the city. In cases of conflict as to what constitutes permanent pavement, the city engineer's opinion shall prevail. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, association, joint venture, organization or legal entity of any kind, and any lawful trustee, successor, assignee, transferee or personal representative thereof. 
    Public way means the surface, the air space above the surface and the area below the surface of any public street, road, thoroughfare, alley or other public right of way or including, without limitation, public utility easements dedicated for compatible use within the city. 
    Service area means the present municipal boundaries of the city and any additions thereto by annexation or other legal means. 
    Service interruption means any loss of picture or sound on one (1) or more cable channels. 
    Subscriber means any person who legally receives cable service delivered over the cable system. 
    Transfer of franchise means any transaction in which: 
(1)  Any ownership or other interest in a franchise or its cable system is transferred from one person or group of persons to another person or group of persons; or 
(2)  The rights and/or obligations held by the franchisee under a franchise agreement are transferred or assigned to another person or group of persons. 
(Ord. No. 2674, § I, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 32-3. - Grant of authority; franchise required. 
(a)  In order to make cable services available to the residents of the city, the city may grant one (1) or more franchises in accordance with this article and the execution of a franchise agreement. 
(b)  No person may construct or operate a cable system in the city without a franchise granted by the city and having entered into a franchise agreement with the city. 
(c)  The city recognizes that, as of the effective date of this article, a question exists under Oklahoma law as to whether an election is required in order to grant or renew a franchise for cable service, or whether under applicable provisions of state and federal law, a permit to use city public Ways to provide cable service may be issued by the city upon proper application, without the necessity of an election. Unless or until an amendment to the Oklahoma Constitution is adopted, a valid statute is adopted by the Oklahoma legislature, or a final judgment is rendered by the Oklahoma Supreme Court, a federal district court, or other court with proper jurisdiction, which judgment is not subject to further appeal, requiring that an election be held in order for the city to grant a franchise for cable service, the city may grant a franchise pursuant to a permit without requiring such election. Provided, the company, person, or entity making application for a franchise under this article, may, in accordance with applicable law, at its option, determine to have the city submit the question of such franchise to the qualified voters at a municipal election held for that purpose. 
(d)  At such time as a final judgment is rendered, which is not subject to further appeal, or a valid statute or constitutional amendment become effective, requiring the city to conduct an election as a condition to granting a franchise for cable service, then an election shall be held for that purpose. Provided, nothing herein shall act or be construed to impair any existing agreements with franchises which have become effective prior to such law change. 
(Ord. No. 2674, § I, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 32-04. - Franchise characteristics. 
(a)  A franchise shall be for a term or period of time not to exceed ten (10) years to serve all or specified areas of the city, and, in the event of a franchise being required, shall be in effect from and after approval thereof by a majority of the qualified electors at a special or general election, and upon the execution of a franchise agreement. A permit shall be effective upon the execution of an agreement as provided for herein. 
(b)  A franchise authorizes the franchisee to use the public ways within the city for installing cables, wires, lines, underground conduit and other facilities to operate a cable system within the city, but does not include any property of the city that is not dedicated to the city as public right-of-way, street, highway or alley, nor shall the right include any other city property in which the city has an interest. The franchise does not authorize such use on private property without the owners consent, nor does the franchise permit the use of privately owned easements without separate agreement of the owners. No reference to public right of way shall be deemed to be a representation that the city's interest or other rights in such property are sufficient to permit its use for the installation, maintenance, or operation of a cable system. In granting a franchise, the city grants to franchisee only those rights the city has an undisputed right and power to give or authorize. No rights shall pass to franchisee by implication. 
(c)  A franchise shall be nonexclusive, and will not preclude the issuance of another franchise, nor affect the city's right to authorize use of any public way by other persons as it deems appropriate. The granting of a franchise does not establish any priority for the use of the public way by any franchise holder. In the event of a dispute as to the use of the public way, the first priority shall be to the public generally, the second priority shall be to the city in the performance of its functions, and thereafter, between the authorized users of the public way as determined by the city. 
(d)  A franchise shall not relieve the franchisee of any requirement of any ordinance, rule, regulation or specification of the city now or hereinafter lawfully enacted by the city. The franchisee shall at all times be subject to the lawful exercise of the police power of the city to the full extent that such powers now or hereinafter may be vested in or granted to the city. However, any ordinance, rule, regulation or specification of the city enacted after a franchisee has entered into a franchise agreement shall not materially alter the rights or obligations of the franchisee under the existing ordinance and franchise agreement unless specifically authorized by state or federal law. 
(e)  A franchisee shall at all times be subject to and shall comply with all laws of general applicability. 
(f)  The provisions of this article shall apply to a franchise agreement as if fully set out in such agreement. The terms of this article shall prevail over conflicting provisions of the franchise agreement unless the franchise agreement contains an explicit intent of waiver. 
(g)  The franchisee shall make cable service available to all residents and businesses within the city, subject to the requirements of section 32-16. 
(h)  The granting of a franchise shall not prevent the city from imposing conditions, including additional compensation should the franchisee want to provide service other than cable service. 
(Ord. No. 2674, § I, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 32-5. - Applications for grant, renewal, modifications or transfer of franchise. 
(a)  A written application shall be filed with the city for the: 
(1)  Grant of new franchise; 
(2)  Renewal of a franchise; 
(3)  Modification of a franchise agreement; 
(4)  Transfer of a franchise or any other relief or request from the city pursuant to this article, the franchise agreement or the Cable Act. 
The applicant has the burden to demonstrate compliance with all applicable laws and entitlement to the relief sought.
